                  March 3, 2000, Friday, Late Edition - Final

FREED BY BRITAIN, PINOCHET IS FACING A BATTLE AT HOME

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1383 words

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 2


Britain abruptly dropped extradition proceedings today against Gen. Augusto
Pinochet, who then headed home to Chile where his political opponents were
waiting, intent on making him face months, if not years, of additional court
proceedings.

After 16 months of house arrest in distant London, where he waited out legal
twists and turns, General Pinochet was told by Britain's home secretary, Jack
Straw, early today that because of his failing health he did not have to stand
trial on charges of gross human rights violations.

Although Mr. Straw's ruling ended Mr. Pinochet's plight there, his case is
expected to have far-reaching implications in international law governing human
rights violations.  Page A6.

The 84-year-old former dictator was accused of abducting, torturing and
executing thousands of political prisoners during his 17-year authoritarian rule
in Chile. As the case now shifts to his homeland, it will undoubtedly have an
important political impact on the new civilian government and the still-powerful
armed forces.

President-elect Ricardo Lagos, a Socialist who takes office in nine days, has
pledged to let what promises to be a lengthy and complicated judicial process
run its course. But the departing government of President Eduardo Frei is
quietly pushing a constitutional reform that could erect another hurdle to
resolving the case, by allowing General Pinochet to retain his parliamentary
immunity from prosecution even if he gave up his current position in the Senate.

About 50 people who had family members disappear during General Pinochet's years
in power sat up most of the night holding hands and singing folk songs while
waiting for Mr. Straw's decision at the headquarters of a human rights group.
When news arrived that General Pinochet was free, they broke into sobs.

"Until the last minute we thought Jack Straw would allow the extradition," said
Viviana Diaz, president of Family Members of the Disappeared, "but we always had
to take into account the enormous political effort our government made toward
Britain, Spain, France and Belgium to free Pinochet." But despite her
disappointment, she added, "Pinochet left Chile as the king of the world, and he
returns a criminal condemned morally by the world."

By the afternoon, Ms. Diaz and other activists were in court filing a petition
to revoke General Pinochet's senatorial immunity, which was granted along with
his status as a senator for life under a Constitution written while he was still
in power.

Removing his immunity would be necessary before an indictment could proceed in a
case alleging his involvement with a military death squad known as the Caravan
of Death, which removed scores of political prisoners from police and army jails
for execution the month after the 1973 coup that overthrew President Salvador
Allende, a Socialist.

Across Santiago, a hundred supporters of General Pinochet celebrated at the
offices of the Pinochet Foundation with patriotic chants and songs. But while
expressing relief that the former dictator was returning home, they said Chile's
sovereignty had been sullied and their leader had been humiliated.

"No one won, everyone lost," said Luis Cortes Villa, a retired general who is
executive director of the foundation, a private group that promotes the former
dictator's image. "There is really nothing to celebrate when an ex-president is
arrested arbitrarily and unfairly."

The government and armed forces are going out of their way to ensure that
General Pinochet's arrival on Friday morning will be as uneventful as possible.
He is scheduled to land in a northern desert town before finally arriving in
Santiago, where family members, military commanders and leaders of the Pinochet
Foundation will give him a ceremonial welcome that will not be open to the
public.

The former dictator will then be taken to the Military Hospital for a medical
checkup that will last at least two days. Officials said he could remain there
under tight security for several weeks.

Judge Juan Guzman Tapia of the Santiago Appeals Court, who is investigating 60
criminal complaints against the former dictator, has requested a battery of
other medical tests be done by doctors chosen by the courts in preparation for a
possible trial. Under Chilean law, findings of dementia or mental impairment --
though not physical ill health -- would protect General Pinochet from legal
proceedings. Last month, two newspapers in Spain quoted British medical reports
as saying that he had suffered brain damage during two minor strokes in recent
months.

For more than a year Chilean officials argued that Spain's request to have
General Pinochet sent to Madrid to stand trial on torture charges was
unnecessary because the justice system here could try him. Now that claim will
be put to the test, with the armed forces and the first Socialist president
since Dr. Allende watching the case closely.

Judge Guzman has been engaged in an aggressive investigation into General
Pinochet's possible connection to more than 2,000 political deaths and tens of
thousands of tortures. And his ruling last year that an amnesty decree that
covered the years between 1973 and 1978 did not cover disappearances of people
who remain missing has opened the way for the arrests of about 50 retired
military and police officers.

But to prosecute General Pinochet, Judge Guzman must first request that the
Santiago Appeals Court lift the parliamentary immunity that accompanies his
position as a senator for life. That process could take months or years,
including appeals to the Supreme Court.

In a candlelight vigil tonight in front of La Moneda, the presidential palace,
500 protesters chanted "No to the amnesty, no to immunity, the blood of the dead
is not negotiable."

Apparently in an effort to nudge General Pinochet out of his Senate position,
President Frei and a coalition of moderate and conservative legislators have
proposed a new constitutional provision that would allow him to retire from the
Congress but retain his senatorial privileges, including salary and legal
immunity.

Human rights advocates say that the measure, which appears headed for passage at
the end of the month, would give General Pinochet extra protection because there
would be no provision in the law to strip immunity from a former president who
is no longer serving in the Congress.

President-elect Lagos has not spoken on the proposed constitutional measure
publicly. But while attending the presidential inauguration of Jorge Batlle in
Uruguay on Wednesday, he said: "The conditions exist to judge Senator-for-Life
Augusto Pinochet. If that were not the case, it would be as if to say we have a
castrated democracy."

For Socialists like Mr. Lagos who have served in the current Christian
Democratic-Socialist coalition government, working for General Pinochet's
release has been a bitter experience forced by their need to get along with the
powerful military and defend the country's sovereignty.

That explains why at the moment of a long-sought diplomatic victory, Foreign
Minister Juan Gabriel Valdes's reaction to the news from London was so
distraught. "This has been a disgraceful affair that has damaged the image of
Chile throughout the world," said Mr. Valdes, a Socialist. "And the principal
person responsible for that is General Pinochet himself."

The coming judicial deliberations in Chile are bound to be complex.

Human rights lawyers are likely to argue against any parliamentary immunity
defenses and against the 1973-1978 amnesty decree as contrary to new precedents
in international law that invalidate amnesties and statutes of limitations in
cases of crimes against humanity such as torture. The Supreme Court would most
likely have to rule on this point before lower courts could judge the former
dictator.

Meanwhile, General Pinochet's lawyers are expected to argue that Judge Guzman
does not have grounds to investigate alleged crimes committed on military
premises or during military service and that any case against the former
dictator should be decided before a military tribunal. In the past, civilian
courts have given military tribunals wide authority in cases involving military
personnel. Again, the Supreme Court would have to decide.

                   May 1, 2000, Monday, Late Edition - Final

A Gay Rights Rally Over Gains and Goals

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1039 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30


Waving banners of gay pride and identity, a crowd estimated in the hundreds of
thousands rallied in the nation's capital today, celebrating the gains of the
gay rights movement in recent years and vowing redoubled efforts on issues like
hate crime legislation.

One leader after another urged the crowd to demonstrate its influence at the
ballot box in November. For more than six hours, under a warm spring sun, a wide
range of speakers, including the parents of Matthew Shepard, the Wyoming gay
college student whose beating death galvanized the drive for laws against hate
crimes, addressed the unfinished agenda of the gay rights movement.

"Let people know you are a part of America, you are a solid God-fearing part of
America, and you deserve the same rights," said Dennis Shepard, Matthew's
father.

There was a strong political subtext to the day. Elizabeth Birch, executive
director of the Human Rights Campaign, the nation's largest gay and lesbian
organization, told the audience, "We must elect Al Gore as president of the
United States," arguing that "the very future of the U.S. Supreme Court for the
next generation hangs in the balance."

Ms. Birch said of Gov. George W. Bush's position on gay rights issues: "There is
absolutely nothing about these policies that is compassionate."

Vice President Gore, addressing the group by videotape beamed on a huge screen
above the Mall, declared, "I stand with you, and am with you every step of the
way" in the march for civil rights.

Mr. Gore said he would not rest in the fight against AIDS and in the struggle to
protect gay Americans from employment discrimination and to ensure that "crimes
of hate against all people, including gays and lesbians," are severely punished.

President Clinton, also speaking by videotape, said he had created the "most
inclusive" administration in history, with more than 150 openly gay men and
lesbians as appointees, and would "continue our fight for an employment
nondiscrimination act that would ban discrimination against gays and lesbians in
the workplace."

But there was more than electoral politics to the day; there was a broader, more
festive tone. The marchers, who began to wind from the Washington Monument to
the Capitol at 10:20 a.m., were a long, ebullient parade of cops and veterans,
drag queens and college students, gay parents with toddlers on their backs and
heterosexual parents marching in support of gay children.

Their signs and banners, some carefully designed and mass produced, some
homemade, reflected the diversity: "Proud Son of a Lesbian." "Protect Our
Families." "Stop Hate Crimes." "Ohio Gay Officers Action League." "Gay Veterans
of Chicago." "Proud to be from Vermont."

There were several variations on Vermont signs. The state, which recently passed
a bill creating civil unions that give gay couples the rights of marriage, was
praised and trumpeted throughout the day.

As the organizers hoped, there were many families here. Larry Leon was pushing
his 22-month-old twins in a double-stroller with his partner, Marc Salans, and
carrying a sign that demanded, "Keep Gay Adoption Legal." Mr. Leon, who lives in
Washington, said, "We want to celebrate our family, celebrate the joy of having
a family, celebrate the success of our adoption endeavor."

Susan from North Carolina, who declined to give her last name, said she, her
partner and their 17-month-old daughter were "just marching for our family."

Ms. Birch, of the Human Rights Campaign, described her and her partner's
adoption of twins and told the crowd, "Don't let anybody tell you that you're
not worthy of parenthood."

There were tiny clusters of protesters. As the march began, a man with a
bullhorn shouted, "Sick! Sick! Sick!" The marchers chanted back, "Shame! Shame!
Shame!" Another protester yelled: "You're despicable before God. You know
nothing about families." And a marcher shouted back, "Jesus loves me."

But by and large, the march had the air of a vast street festival, fed by the
array of entertainers and celebrities, from Melissa Etheridge to Martina
Navratilova, who took the stage at the foot of the Capitol. Anne Heche, the
actress, declared from the stage, "I gotta say I was straight for 27 years and I
never came to a party as big as this."

The march came under criticism from some gay activists, who argued that the
planning was not inclusive enough, that the organizers had allowed too much
commercialization with sponsors like United Airlines and Showtime Network and
that the purpose of the march was ill-defined.

One critic, Bill Dobbs, with the Ad Hoc Committee for an Open Process, said
today: "Rather than unite and galvanize the gay, lesbian, bisexual and
transgender community, the march's organizers and the Human Rights Campaign have
created divisions. That rift, about who speaks for the movement and how
decisions are made, must be addressed before we can move forward."

But Dianne Hardy-Garcia, executive director of the Millennium March on
Washington, as today's rally was called, said that taking such a strong, visible
stand for equality in an election year "is smart -- and a judicious use of
resources."

Ms. Hardy-Garcia said the march was intended to show the generational and
geographic range of the movement, its growing numbers of openly gay families and
its ability to build coalitions. "I think there was an image that we were only
an urban gay community," she said.

One of those coalitions was demonstrated on the stage today, when the family of
Matthew Shepard was joined by the family of James Byrd Jr., a black man who was
dragged to death behind a truck by three whites in Jasper, Tex.

Many of those here today said they hoped their presence would send a signal.
When asked why she was here, a New York City police sergeant replied: "Strength
in numbers. Pride. For some people, it's a life-altering event."

This was the first national gay rights march in Washington since 1993.
Organizers gave various estimates of the crowd size as the day progressed,
asserting that at its peak, it was 800,000; the United States Park Police no
longer issues crowd estimates, which had become an unending source of debate
with the organizers of various marches.

                 May 24, 2000, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

United States and Indonesia Quietly Resume Military Cooperation

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 567 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23


The Clinton administration has quietly resumed military cooperation with
Indonesia, senior defense officials said today, eight months after cutting off
those ties following massacres in East Timor.

The United States broke the freeze this month by inviting Indonesian military
observers to joint exercises in Thailand and by completing plans this week to
hold the first joint exercises between American and Indonesian armed forces in
July.

The exercises are a prelude to a much larger military-to-military program the
administration will present Congress this month to reward the new,
democratically elected Indonesian government for removing some of the senior
military officers under investigation for the East Timor massacres and for
imposing civilian control of the military, according to senior administration
officials.

Since taking office seven months ago, President Abdurrahman Wahid has appointed
a civilian minister of defense and removed General Wiranto, the powerful chief
of the armed forces, who is under investigation for allowing several army units
to orchestrate the rampage last year in East Timor, which left hundreds dead
after the province voted for independence.

But some members of Congress and human rights groups are critical of resuming
any relations with the military until the current investigations into the
massacres and other human rights abuses in East Timor lead to trials of senior
officers.

Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, will propose legislation as
early as this week to prolong the freeze on military relations until the
officers are all put on trial.

And a group of 29 human rights organizations has petitioned Secretary of State
Madeleine K. Albright to prevent any "resumption of military engagement at any
level."

"I really do think it is premature for the Pentagon to be resuming cooperation
when there has been a lack of accountability for the senior officers," said
Michael Jendrzejczyk of Human Rights Watch, which signed the letter to Dr.
Albright.

President Clinton suspended all military ties with Indonesia in September when
General Wiranto failed to reign in the local militia as it rampaged through East
Timor. And in its report issued earlier this year, the United Nations said its
investigation uncovered evidence that special forces of the Indonesian army did
"support the militias in intimidation and terror attacks" in East Timor.

To avoid working with those units, the Pentagon is renewing its ties first with
the Indonesia's air force and navy. The joint exercises this summer will be held
with Indonesian marines and will concentrate on humanitarian assistance and
disaster relief, according to a senior defense official.

"What better way than to take some first steps towards re-engagement with
humanitarian exercises and with the services that don't have a cloud over them,"
said a senior official who asked for anonymity.

After consultations with Congress, the administration hopes to begin what Dr.
Albright described in a letter to the human rights groups as a "carefully
calibrated" program to renew ties with the two militaries.

"Given where Indonesia was a year ago, this government has made tremendous
progress in asserting civilian control over the military," said Adam Schwarz,
the author of "A Nation in Waiting: Indonesia's Search for Stability," (Westview
Press, 1994).

                  June 6, 2000, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

O.A.S. to Send Panel to Peru To Check Vote

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

SECTION: Section A; Page 6; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 661 words

DATELINE: WINDSOR, Ontario, June 5


Responding to the unopposed election of Alberto Fujimori to a third term as
president of Peru, foreign ministers at the annual assembly of the Organization
of American States agreed tonight to send a mission to Lima to explore options
for strengthening democracy in Peru.

The team is to be led by Canada's foreign minister, Lloyd Axworthy, and Cesar
Gaviria, secretary general of the Organization of the American States.

"The presidential vote in Peru is a matter of deep concern to us all," Mr.
Axworthy said before the vote. "Left unexamined, it will certainly diminish the
credibility of this organization."

The resolution left it up to the mission to decide on a timetable and a forum
for its reporting. Many diplomats agreed that the mission would have the most
impact if it went to Lima well before Mr. Fujimori's planned inauguration date,
July 28.

Human rights and Peruvian opposition legislators who gathered here today called
for new elections, and, failing that, concerted pressure on Mr. Fujimori.

"It is important to tell Fujimori that we have you under the microscope here;
your case is not under a done deal," said Jose Miguel Vivanco, a Chilean lawyer
who is executive director of the Americas division of Human Rights Watch, a
Washington-based organization. "If the O.A.S. does not take these minimal steps,
the message is the O.A.S.will only react to confront bloody, unpopular coups."

The May 28 runoff in Peru set off a cascade of criticism. Mr. Fujimori ran
unopposed because his first-round opponent, Alejandro Toledo, had dropped out,
denouncing limits on media coverage and voting irregularities in the first round
of the election in April.

Rights advocates from Peru and North American converged here to pressfor strong
action.

"If this process is legitimized, in the end, other countries will be encourage
to follow the bad example of Peru," warned Sofia Macher, director of the
National Human Rights Coordinate, a coalition of about 60 Peruvian rights
groups. Calling President Fujimori's planned inauguration "a coup d'etat in slow
motion," she urged other countries to press Peru for "new elections under new
conditions."

Defending his government, Fernando de Trazegnies Granda, Peru's foreign
minister, cited its battles with hyperinflation and terrorism in the early
1990's, saying: "Don't judge us by where we fall short by utopian criteria, but
by what we have traveled through."

As the delegates debated Peru, another issue -- free trade -- brought 2,500
protesters to the steel fence protecting the meetings, though trade was not on
the agenda.  The protests here have been the largest in memory at an O.A.S.
gathering.

Canadian immigration officials at the border crossings from Detroit refused
admittance to 560 Americans in the four days before the O.A.S. meeting opened,
much higher than the normal rate of refusal of 1,000 a month. Ken Lawrence, a
spokesman for the immigration service, said many of "the individuals were coming
in to protest."

Danny Yen, a Canadian customs spokesman, said that during the same time at the
Detroit crossing, customs officials had confiscated from about 200 Americans
hundreds of items that could have been used in protests, including tear gas
canisters, gas masks, eye goggles, bleach, pepper spray, pipes, bats and flares.

On Sunday, 41 protesters were arrested outside the riverfront convention center
here, 35 for blocking a bus that carried delegates and several more for
attempting to scale the security fence. Sgt. David Rossell of the Windsor police
said that officers used pepper spray after protesters had thrown smoke bombs and
unknown liquids at them.

At the same time, about 400 people paraded in downtown Detroit carrying banners
and chanting "Clean up this mess, stop the O.A.S."

Today police officers removed scores of demonstrators who had linked arms and
sat in the rain to block delegates in three buses from arriving at an official
luncheon.

COUNTRY: PERU (98%); UNITED STATES (95%); CANADA (94%); NORTH AMERICA (79%);

                  June 30, 2000, Friday, Late Edition - Final

World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

SECTION: Section A; Page 9; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 943 words



EUROPE

UKRAINE: PRESIDENTIAL POWERS
A constitutional court ruled that President Leonid Kuchma's plan to strengthen
his powers over Parliament do not violate the Constitution. The ruling paves the
way for Mr. Kuchma to submit the changes to Parliament, which must pass them by
a two-thirds majority. Some opposition leaders want to water down the proposals,
fearing Mr. Kuchma's executive powers will too easily override the legislature.
Ever since Mr. Kuchma won re-election last November, he has been campaigning for
stronger powers to break the many deadlocks that have snarled economic reform
plans.  Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)


AUSTRIA: RIGHTS MONITORS
Austria said it was willing to cooperate with a panel asked to examine its human
rights records. The European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, France, will
appoint three monitors, who will send their findings to the other 14 European
Union governments. Analysts believe this could be a first step toward ending
Austria's political isolation within the Union, which froze political relations
with Vienna on Feb. 4 after Jorg Haider's far-right Freedom Party joined
Austria's coalition government.  Victor Homola (NYT)

TURKEY: ARMENIANS EXPELLED
Four Armenians invited to a meeting in the eastern city of Kars were expelled by
Turkish security agents. Local authorities had invited the four as part of an
effort to improve relations between the two countries, which would greatly help
the economy in Kars and other border areas. But the Foreign Ministry said that
since Armenia is occupying territory that belongs to Azerbaijan, Turkey's ally,
and is promoting hostility toward Turkey, the ministry is "not promoting such
contacts." Stephen Kinzer (NYT)

IRELAND: PREMIER TESTIFIES
Prime Minister Bertie Ahern told a tribunal investigating improper payments to
politicians that he had no knowledge of a donation of $91,000 that disappeared
in 1989. A Fianna Fail party supporter donated $121,000 to former Prime Minister
Charles Haughey, of which only $30,000 reached the party account. Mr. Ahern, who
handled party finances at the time, said he was aware of only the $30,000
donation, and he accepted blame for not sending a receipt for that amount.
Brian F. Lavery (NYT)

THE AMERICAS

ARGENTINA: SUING BRITAIN
Relatives of more than 300 sailors who were killed when the cruiser General
Belgrano was sunk by the Royal Navy during the Falklands war in 1982 announced
that they plan to sue Britain for damages next week in the European Court of
Human Rights in Strasbourg, France. Lawyers for the relatives, who have been
preparing the case for five years, will argue that since the ship's sinking was
outside the theater of operations, it violated international wartime
conventions.  Clifford Krauss (NYT)

COLOMBIA: REBEL TALKS
Delegations representing 21 nations, including European and United Nations
diplomats, began two days of meetings with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of
Colombia, the country's main left-wing guerrilla group, in a demilitarized area
controlled by the rebels. The topic of the conference is drug trafficking: the
guerrillas are heavily involved in the cocaine trade but say they would favor
alternative crop-substitution programs. The United States did not take part
because of a ban on official contacts with the group.  Larry Rohter (NYT)

CANADA: JAILED AGAIN
An upstate New York judge has jailed a Vancouver man who fled a penal work camp
29 years ago while serving up to 4 years for selling $20 worth of LSD to an
undercover agent. Allen Richardson told the Rochester judge he fled in 1971
because a guard told him he was about to be returned to Attica prison, where a
deadly riot had just occurred. The case was a cause celebre in Canada.  James
Brooke (NYT)

ASIA

KOREAS: TALKS PROGRESS
North and South Korea appeared close to a landmark agreement on the issues of
the repatriation of former prisoners and family reunions. The North Korean Red
Cross has agreed to hold reunions in August for families who were separated in
the Korean War, and South Korea would repatriate former North Korean prisoners
in September, reports from both sides said. Talks between the two, being held in
North Korea, are scheduled to wind up today.  (Reuters)

MIDDLE EAST

ISRAEL: PALESTINIANS COMPLAIN
Saeb Erekat, a senior peace negotiator, said the Palestinians had lodged
complaints with the Americans and the Europeans about increasing Israeli
reinforcements of settlements in Gaza and the West Bank. Palestinians report
seeing tanks moving into certain settlement areas, which they say is creating
panic among Palestinians.  Deborah Sontag (NYT)

IRAQ: SECURITY STEPPED UP
The United Nations is tightening security in Iraq after the shooting deaths of
two of its staff members at an office in Baghdad, a United Nations official in
Baghdad said. She said these procedures included checking again that all United
Nations employees had their identity cards and that a thorough verification of
visitors' identities should be made before they enter United Nations offices.
According to officials, Fowad Hussein Haydar, above, opened fire after entering
the building and demanding an end to sanctions against Iraq.  (Reuters)

AFRICA

SIERRA LEONE: PEACEKEEPERS FREED
Liberia said rebels in Sierra Leone had freed 21 Indian United Nations
peacekeepers and handed them over to the Liberian authorities. The statement did
not make clear whether the 21 were a group seized in Kuiva on June 5 or came
from a separate contingent surrounded in nearby Kailahun since early in May.
(Reuters)

               September 19, 2000, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

C.I.A Says Chilean General in '76 Bombing Was Informer

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS

SECTION: Section A; Page 6; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 870 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18


The former chief of Chile's secret police, convicted of masterminding a lethal
car bombing here in 1976, was an informer for the Central Intelligence Agency
when the bombing occurred, a year after he had received a one-time payment for
his cooperation, newly released documents show.

The official, Gen. Manuel Contreras Sepulveda, former head of DINA, the secret
police, under the 17-year military dictatorship in Chile, was enlisted by the
C.I.A. beginning in 1974, a year after Gen. Augusto Pinochet led a coup that
toppled the elected government of President Salvador Allende Gossens, the
documents show.

The American spy agency maintained its contacts with General Contreras until
1977, a year after General Contreras and his deputy, Brig. Gen. Pedro Espinoza
Bravo, organized the attack on Embassy Row in Washington, according to the
documents released today by the agency in a declassified report to Congress.

The bombing killed Orlando Letelier, Mr. Allende's former ambassador to the
United States, and a 25-year-old American associate, Ronni Moffitt.

The spy agency's relationship with General Contreras continued although "almost
immediately after the assassination, rumors began circulating that the Chilean
government was responsible," and "at that time, Contreras's possible role in the
Letelier assassination became an issue," the report says. It also says the
C.I.A. later received "specific detailed intelligence reporting concerning
Contreras's involvement in ordering the Letelier assassination" but does not
make clear when that information was obtained.

In 1993 in Chile, Generals Contreras and Espinoza were sentenced to seven and
six years, respectively, in prison for the crime, one of the worst cases of
foreign-sponsored terrorism on American soil.

"During a period between 1974 and 1977, C.I.A. maintained contact with Manuel
Contreras Sepulveda, who later became notorious for his involvement in human
rights abuses," said the intelligence agency report.

The relationship with General Contreras was viewed as "necessary to accomplish
the C.I.A.'s mission, in spite of concerns that this relationship might lay the
C.I.A. open to charges of aiding internal political repression," the report
said.

Although the C.I.A. said it had warned General Contreras that it would not
support any of his repressive activities, it ultimately issued a one-time
payment to him, even after it had found that "Contreras was the principal
obstacle to a reasonable human rights policy" in the military government.

The payment, an unspecified amount in 1975, was made in error, the report said,
after leaders of the C.I.A. had overruled their agents' recommendations to
establish a paid relationship with General Contreras, "citing the U.S.
government policy on clandestine relations with the head of an intelligence
service notorious for human rights abuses."

Peter Kornbluh, a senior analyst at the National Security Archive, a
nongovernmental clearinghouse for declassified documents, said the report sheds
light on the contacts with forces that toppled a democratic government and
killed thousands of people. "This is in fact the unraveling of a cover-up of
U.S. ties to repression during the Pinochet dictatorship," Mr. Kornbluh said.
"This is the first step toward a candid disclosure of the truth about that dark
era."

Central Intelligence Agency officials could not be reached for comment late this
evening.

The spy agency acknowledged in the report that its behavior in Chile would not
meet more rigorous standards in place today.

"As a result of lessons learned in Chile, Central America and elsewhere, the
C.I.A. now carefully reviews all contacts for potential involvement in human
rights abuses and makes a deliberate decision balancing the nature and severity
of the human rights abuse against the potential intelligence value of continuing
the relationship," the report said.

"These standards, established in the mid-1990's, would likely have altered the
amount of contact we had with perpetrators of human rights violators in Chile
had they been in effect at that time," it said.

In a similar case in Guatemala in 1996, the CIA acknowledged that it had
maintained a paid relationship with Col. Julio Roberto Alpirez, during a time in
which it concluded that the Guatemalan officer had been involved in covering up
the 1990 murder of an American citizen, Michael DeVine, and Efrain Bamaca, a
captured Guatemalan guerrilla.

The C.I.A. report on Chile, which was required by legislation written by
Representative Maurice D. Hinchey, a New York Democrat, said the spy agency was
"not involved in facilitating Pinochet's accession to president nor the
consolidation of his power as Supreme Leader."

But Mr. Hinchey, after studying the report, reached a different conclusion. "The
C.I.A. funneled millions of dollars to strengthen opposition political parties
working against the Allende government," he said. "That can cover a multitude of
sins."

Mr. Hinchey called the relationship with General Contreras a mistake. "It just
shows the zeal with which the C.I.A. operators at that time proceeded," he said.
"They made league with some very vicious people."

U.S. Says Asylum in Panama Helped Avert a Coup in Peru

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 756 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25


American officials today defended their role in pressing Panama to give refuge
to the ousted intelligence chief of Peru, asserting that his departure was
necessary to avoid a coup by officers loyal to him.

Administration officials confirmed that the intelligence chief, Valdimiro
Montesinos, has had a longstanding relationship with United States intelligence
agencies. But they said the contacts were informal and had no bearing on the
efforts to help him settle in Panama.

Even as administration officials insisted that Mr. Montesinos's departure was
important to helping Peru remain on a path toward democracy, human rights groups
voiced skepticism. They criticized the United States for seeking to arrange a
soft landing for Mr. Montesinos outside Peru, where it may be more difficult to
prosecute him for widespread abuses that were reportedly carried out under his
command.

Mr. Montesinos, who was a top adviser to President Alberto K. Fujimori, sought
political asylum in Panama on Sunday, 10 days after the release in Peru of a
videotape in which he apparently sought to bribe an opposition lawmaker. Mr.
Fujimori has announced that he will step down next year after holding new
elections and that he will abolish the National Intelligence Service. Mr.
Montesinos had headed agency, which was implicated in numerous cases of human
rights abuses.

Panamanian authorities have granted Mr. Montesinos a 30-day tourist visa and
have retained his passport, officials said. The decision to let him remain was
made after appeals from the Organization of American States and six Latin
American presidents, as well as telephone calls from Under Secretary of State
Thomas R. Pickering.

A senior American official said Peruvian officers loyal to Mr. Montesinos had
given numerous signs, beginning last week, that they would attempt a coup
against Mr. Fujimori unless they received an "ironclad guarantee" that Mr.
Montesinos would be given safe haven outside Peru. American officials were
specifically concerned about a military celebration, Armed Forces Day, that was
held as planned on Sunday.

Last week, as United States and Latin American diplomats struggled to defuse a
confrontation between supporters of Mr. Fujimori and Mr. Montesinos, army
leaders loyal to Mr. Montesinos sounded out the nation's two vice presidents to
gauge their support for a coup, but were rebuffed, the officials said.

Mr. Montesinos's loyalists in the army and the national police agreed to sign a
document in support of Mr. Fujimori's government only after they had seen United
States and Latin American leaders' efforts for Mr. Montesinos.

Some experts on Peru and human rights advocates voiced skepticism about the
rationale for granting him Montesinos safe haven. Cynthia McClintock, a
political scientist at George Washington University, said Mr. Montesinos's
military support in Peru was shallow, limited to several senior army officials.
She raised the prospect that the Central Intelligence Agency might have been
eager to remove Mr. Montesinos from Peru as he increasingly faced the prospect
of prosecution there.

A spokesman for the C.I.A., Mark Mansfield, declined to discuss Mr. Montesinos's
ties. An American official insisted, however, that the intelligence agency did
not play a role in arranging Mr. Montesinos's exit.

A regional specialist for Human Rights Watch/Americas, Jose Miguel Vivanco,
called the coup threat groundless and said the United States and other nations
of the region were promoting impunity for a major violator of human rights.
"This shows how powerful Montesinos is, how he managed to get full support of
the Peruvian government and the sympathy of key governments in the region,
including the U.S., to find a nice sweet deal for him," Mr. Vivanco said.

Mr. Vivanco's organization said Mr. Montesinos had ordered numerous crimes,
including the "disappearances," torture and executions of nine students and a
professor from La Cantuta University in 1992.

Despite such allegations, Mr. Montesinos drew praise from some American
officials for helping eradicate a threat posed by guerrilla organizations in
Peru and cooperating with American anti-drug efforts.

A spokesman for the State Department, Richard A. Boucher, acknowledged
Washington's role in persuading Panama to accept Mr. Montesinos. But he
challenged the idea that the administration was standing up for antidemocratic
forces in Peru. He also left open the possibility that Mr. Montesinos could
eventually be prosecuted.

                 October 29, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

Persecution Charged in Ex-Soviet Republic

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ

SECTION: Section 1; Page 6; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1560 words

DATELINE: TASHKENT, Uzbekistan


Beneath the silk head scarf, her eyes were filled with thought and prayer, grief
and anger. Her voice was soft and urgent, as if spilling out the story of her
husband might somehow bring him home.

"He was just the imam in the mosque," Munira Nazarov said, patting the youngest
of her six children, a boy of 7. "He used to talk to people about studying the
Koran and other good books. He didn't talk about politics."

Her husband, Obidhon Nazarov, the chief religious figure at one of Tashkent's
largest mosques, went into hiding in March 1998 after being followed for days by
the security police. Unable to find him, the authorities imprisoned his two
brothers, a brother-in-law and an uncle. They detained his wife for 10 days, and
men still pound on the door of his house with the butts of their Kalashnikov
rifles in the middle of the night.

A largely unnoticed war is being waged in this Central Asian nation of 24
million. According to foreign and Uzbek human rights advocates and religious
leaders, 4,000 to 5,000 Muslim men have been imprisoned in the last three years.
There is evidence of systematic torture, from beatings to extracted toenails.
Some prisoners have died.

Religious leaders and human rights advocates say the only crime of the thousands
detained is that they are pious Muslims. They contend that the government of
President Islam Karimov, which has already banned opposition parties and
silenced the independent press, is using a trumped-up threat of radical Islam to
stamp out the last vestige of dissent.

"The repression of religious people is worse than it ever was during the Soviet
era," said Mikhail Ardzinov, chairman of a banned human rights group who was
detained and beaten in 1999, when three members of his organization were
imprisoned.

Government officials deny using torture, but they justify other harsh steps by
saying they are battling religious extremists determined to turn the country
into a state like Iran or, worse, Afghanistan. President Karimov vowed in
September to press the crackdown, telling state television, "This plague and
sickness are capable of infecting the minds of young people."

Since the Soviet Union collapsed, there has been a slow resurgence of Islam in
traditionally Muslim Central Asia. The governments have tried to control its
growth, sanctioning mosques and overseeing religious schools. But officials
across the region, who tend to have an authoritarian bent, fear Islamic
extremism, though the nature and seriousness of the threat are not always clear.

Some dangers are concrete. Tajikistan fought a five-year civil war against
Islamic insurgents that ended in 1997, leaving at least 50,000 dead. This
summer, soldiers from Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan battled 100 to 200 rebels from
the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan. American officials say the group has ties to
the Taliban in Afghanistan and to Osama bin Laden, the Saudi financier suspected
of responsibility for terrorist attacks.

But in Tashkent, the targets of Mr. Karimov's campaign are members of
Hizb-ut-Tahrir, or the Party of Liberation, which says it promotes Islam as a
religious and a social force. Its leaders urge Muslims to pray five times a day
and to study the Koran to prepare for a future Islamic government.

The Hizb-ut-Tahrir criticizes the Uzbek government for corruption and repressing
Muslims, but has not, Western diplomats say, promoted violence.

Chaasime Minovarov, deputy director of Uzbekistan's State Committee on Religious
Affairs, which monitors religious groups, said thousands of men had been
arrested for advocating replacing the current government with an Islamic state.
He said that Hizb-ut-Tahrir has the same ideology as the gun-toting Islamic
Movement of Uzbekistan, but that the religious party may ultimately be more
dangerous because its members appear nonviolent.

"When the time comes, they will become warriors and they will start using
weapons," Mr. Minovarov said. "The government of Uzbekistan is trying its best
to bring the influence of this group to zero."

The Uzbek crackdown began in 1992, after the start of the Tajikistan civil war.
An Islamic-oriented political party and two human rights groups were outlawed,
and the government tightened control over mosques. Imams were required to
conclude their sermons by praising Mr. Karimov, the former Communist Party boss
who has solidified his authority since he became the country's first elected
president in 1991.

Women wearing head scarves and men with beards, signs of Muslim piety, were
banned from state universities in 1997. Mass roundups started the next year and
increased after five car bombings in February 1999 killed 16 people. The Islamic
Movement of Uzbekistan was blamed for the bombings, but any overtly observant
Muslim was in danger of arrest.

Some of the convictions of the thousands of detained people were based on
anti-state activities like distributing religious material and proselytizing.
Others were on narcotics offenses, which human rights advocates and family
members denounced as spurious. In some instances, older men have been imprisoned
in what Interior Minister Zokiron Almatov described as a policy of fathers
paying for the sins of their sons.

Often the suspects are tried in groups of 10 to 15, with guilty verdicts
virtually certain. A Western diplomat who monitors the issue said he did not
know of a single instance in which someone has been found innocent.

Sentences have been harsh, sometimes including death.

Azim Khodjaev, a father of two, died in prison last year. His body showed signs
of severe torture, including extracted fingernails, said people who saw it. The
family of Jurakhon Azimov said that half of his face was smashed and that his
body was covered with bruises and razor-blade cuts. The official cause of death
was heart failure.

Furkhat Usamanov, 42, was convicted of possessing a Hizb-ut-Tahir pamphlet and
died in prison. People who saw his body said he was bruised severely, but the
authorities said he, too, died of heart failure.

There are no reliable figures on how many prisoners have died in custody, or how
many are held. Acacia Shields, the Tashkent representative of Human Rights
Watch, which monitors abuses worldwide, estimated that at least 4,000 had been
arrested; others put the figure at 5,000 or higher.

Reviews of court cases and interviews with families of inmates produced evidence
of torture, and Western diplomats have raised the issue with the Uzbek
authorities. Still, it is difficult to know how widespread the torture may be or
whether, as the families claim, drugs and other evidence are routinely planted
by the police.

Mrs. Nazarov came to an apartment near the center of Tashkent the other night,
bringing her young son and another woman. Other groups trickled in as darkness
fell and finally there were about 20 people.

A dozen have husbands or sons in prison. Several knew one another from
worshiping at Mr. Nazarov's mosque, and some were strangers.  The details of the
arrests and torture were remarkably consistent.

Mukhabat Deminova said her son, Bakhtiyor, 31, had been taken away with his
friends, whom he had known since school days. "They played football and went on
picnics," she said. "The police said they were planning a jihad, a holy war.
They were in court Oct. 2, and all 10 showed bruises and broken bones and nails
torn out."

Umida Azimova said her husband, Toyir Abdusamatov, had eluded the police for
several months and gave himself up after being promised amnesty. Instead, he was
convicted on anti-state charges and sentenced to 16 years, though he said in
court that he was tortured into confessing.

"He was taken to prison, and I will be able to see him only once a year for two
hours," she said. "So many people die in these prisons, and I am scared that he
could be murdered."

The most notorious prison is in Zhaslyk in western Uzbekistan, a place where
international monitors are forbidden. Prisoners have told their families that
they are confined to their cells 23 hours a day and spend hours squatting, with
their hands behind their heads. Whenever they move a limb, they are required to
recite their thanks to President Karimov, their relatives say.

Suraye Ergashev's husband, Tulkan, was an imam arrested after the February 1999
bombings and sentenced to six years for distributing religious tracts. His uncle
was sentenced to eight years for the same crime.

"After he was arrested, the militia didn't allow my children to go to school for
a month, and they registered everyone who came to visit us," Mrs. Ergashev said.
"I have to take my four children and go to the police every 10 days now."

Few devout Muslim women in Uzbekistan work outside their homes. They said that
they had little money and that the government refused to pay the assistance owed
to their children. They are ostracized, and some have been forced to attend
neighborhood rallies where they are denounced as traitors.

Last month, Mr. Karimov signed an amnesty for political prisoners, but it
excluded people convicted of crimes against the state, which covers the
religious inmates. Sultan Isokhodjaev went to the prosecutor who had convicted
his son, Abdu Rashid, and pleaded for help.

"He told me, 'If he killed somebody, maybe I could help, but not for this
crime,' " Mr. Isokhodjaev said.


http://www.nytimes.com

East Timor Violence Requires an Accounting, U.N. Official Says

BYLINE: Agence France-Presse

SECTION: Section A; Page 29; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 537 words

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 23


The top human rights official for the United Nations voiced support today for
Indonesia's efforts to try the perpetrators of violence last year in East Timor,
but held open the possibility of convening an international tribunal if the
guilty were not brought to justice.

The official, Mary Robinson, high commissioner for human rights, said she
welcomed "the serious commitment of the attorney general and of the Parliament"
to bring to trial military and civilian suspects in the wave of violence that
swept East Timor after its people voted for independence.

But speaking after talks with Attorney General Marzuki Darusman on Jakarta's
progress in prosecuting, she said rights violators in East Timor could not
expect impunity.

"There has to be a real accountability once there has been a conviction for
serious offenses," Ms. Robinson said.

"There cannot be impunity for those who have been convicted for gross human
rights violations."

She added that it was important, first of all, that they be brought to trial,
and that the accountability be meaningful.

She also said she would not rule out convening an international tribunal to try
those behind the violence.

The Indonesian government has named 22 suspects -- several of them high-ranking
army officers -- in the violence that preceded and followed the United
Nations-supervised ballot in East Timor in August 1999.

On Nov. 6, the lower house of Indonesia's Parliament passed a human rights bill
that would enable the trial of past human rights abuses.

It provides for a maximum penalty of 25 years in jail for major rights
violations, including genocide and crimes against humanity.

Under the bill, any ad hoc rights tribunals set up to address rights cases would
first have to win both presidential and parliamentary approval.

Ms. Robinson also said her office would provide technical assistance in the form
of training for Attorney General Darusman's office.

That would enable Indonesian judges "to be fully trained to try cases involving
human rights violations," she said, adding that the assistance would also
include trips for Indonesian judges to the international tribunal at The Hague.

"I think it's very important, if a country is committed to establishing a human
rights court that meets international standards and is prepared to have the
training of judges to ensure that they fulfill their role," she said. "To me,
that is the best solution."

Mr. Darusman said the new court -- which would try cases involving four major
attacks and the murder of a Dutch journalist in East Timor -- would probably be
established in January.

Some 250,000 East Timorese fled or were forced from their homes during last
year's wave of terror and arson, blamed on militias raised and trained by the
Indonesian army, after the territory voted for independence from Jakarta.

Witnesses and rights activists have said the military either actively or tacitly
backed the pro-Indonesian militia in the deadly rampage in East Timor, a former
Portuguese colony that was invaded by Indonesia in 1975.

Hundreds of people were killed, and of the thousands who wereforced to flee to
neighboring West Timor, some 120,000 remain in squalid camps.

                November 24, 2000, Friday, Late Edition - Final

In Land Feud, Ruling Favors Greek Royalty

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 358 words

DATELINE: GENEVA, Nov. 23


The European Court of Human Rights ruled today that former King Constantine of
Greece and members of his family are entitled to compensation for palaces and
estates seized when he was dethroned three decades ago.

A panel of 17 judges at the court in Strasbourg, France, ruled 15-2 that the
confiscation of the royal family's property violated a portion of Europe's human
rights convention that guarantees property rights.

The court said it would examine the question of compensation for the former
monarch, his sister, Irene, and their aunt Catherine at a later date.
Constantine, 60, has lived in exile since he was deposed in 1967. The monarchy
was abolished in 1973, and Greece passed a law in 1994 confiscating the royal
properties.

Lawyers for the Greek government had told the court that the estates were never
the private property of Constantine and his relatives, and that they should
remain in government hands because they contain historical and archaelogical
sites.

The three properties at issue are the Mon Repos summer retreat on the island of
Corfu, an estate in Tatoi near Athens, the site of the royal cemetery, and real
estate in Polydendri in the foothills of Mount Olympus.

At a hearing in June, the deposed king's lawyers argued that he and his
relatives had indeed owned the disputed property as private individuals rather
than as royal family members. They asked for $1.4 billion in compensation if the
property was not returned. But Greece maintains that it wants to collect taxes
on the properties if the royal family wins a compensation award.

The Greek deputy foreign minister, Elisabet Papazoi, told Greek radio that the
former royal family owed $49.6 million in back taxes. She said that the
properties were worth about $464 million.

Constantine, who lives in London, lodged his complaint with the court (set up to
deal with allegations of violations of the 1950 European Convention on Human
Rights) in 1994, following passage of the law confiscating his property. A Greek
special supreme court upheld that law in 1997, which left the former king with
no avenue of appeal inside his former country.

The Palestinians And Right of Return

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 146 words



To the Editor:

Re "Mr. Clinton's Mideast Peace Plan" (editorial, Dec. 27):

Do not be too quick to dismiss the right of Palestinian refugees to return to
the vicinity of their former homes, whether this is in Israel or a new
Palestinian state.

Legitimate security concerns must be addressed in a manner consistent with
internationally recognized human rights, including the right to return.
Compensation and resettlement packages negotiated by governments can offer
additional choices but do not extinguish this right.

Palestinian refugees should have real options, whether they choose to return, to
be integrated in the countries where they now reside or to resettle in other
countries. Redress for past injustices should not create new ones.

HANNY MEGALLY
Exec. Dir., Middle East
and North Africa Division
Human Rights Watch
New York, Dec. 27, 2000

http://www.nytimes.com

Death Row Justice: View From Texas

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 163 words



To the Editor:

Texas not only leads the country in total executions (front page, Jan. 7), but
it is also the worldwide leader in putting juvenile offenders to death. In the
last decade the state carried out five death sentences against people who
committed crimes when they were below age 18, and it has scheduled three more
executions of juvenile offenders in the next two months.

The state has put itself at the forefront of a select group that includes Iran,
Nigeria, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia, the only countries other than the United
States that defy the international prohibition on executing juvenile offenders.

No one should be executed for crimes committed as a child. Governor Bush should
use his leadership to bring Texas in line with worldwide consensus and into
conformity with a basic principle of international justice.

MICHAEL BOCHENEK
Fletcher, Vt., Jan. 10, 2000

The writer is counsel, Children's Rights Division, Human Rights Watch.

http://www.nytimes.com

January 9-15;
Openly Gay in the Military

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

SECTION: Section 4; Page 2; Column 3; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 83 words


Britain unveiled a new code of conduct for its armed forces that ends its
practice of barring gay men and lesbians from the military. The government said
it had no choice after the European Court of Human Rights ruled last fall that
Britain's ban violated the basic human right to privacy. The code, which applies
to gays and heterosexuals, says "unacceptable social conduct," including sexual
harassment and overt displays of affection, will result in disciplinary action.
   SARAH LYALL

                January 20, 2000, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

DuPont Awards Focus on Foreign News

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

SECTION: Section E; Page 3; Column 1; The Arts/Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 533 words


With a strong emphasis this time on international reporting, the Alfred I.
duPont-Columbia University Awards for broadcast journalism were announced
yesterday, and many of the top honors went to prominent television journalists
for work ranging from South Africa to Eastern Europe to Rwanda.

Bill Moyers and his production company, Public Affairs Television, won the gold
baton, the duPont Awards highest honor, for a two-hour documentary on efforts by
South Africans to heal the wounds left by apartheid. The film was broadcast on
PBS.

Diane Sawyer and the ABC News program "20/20" won a silver baton for a report on
the neglect and abuse of handicapped children in Russian orphanages that are
little more than warehouses. The report was produced in cooperation with the
organization Human Rights Watch.

Bob Simon and the CBS News program "60 Minutes" also won a silver baton for
international reporting on what has been identified as the worst atrocity of the
war in Bosnia, the massacre of 8,000 Muslims by Serbs in 1995 in Srebrenica.

In another award for international coverage, the PBS series "Frontline" and its
PBS station sponsor, WGBH-TV, won a silver baton for a story of a far larger
massacre, the slaughter of 800,000 Tutsi by their Hutu enemies in Rwanda in
1994.

A small independent radio organization, Youth Radio in Berkeley, Calif.,
received honors for work with an international theme: broadcasting e-mail
exchanges between a schoolgirl in Kosovo and a California high school student
that documented the girl's struggles to stay alive in a deteriorating, dangerous
situation.

In the domestic area, Candy Crowley and CNN won a silver baton for their work
covering the impeachment of President Clinton, which was cited for intelligence
and fairness.

The television station KTVX in Salt Lake City won a silver baton for
investigative reports on the bribery scandal involving the Salt Lake City
Olympic Organizing Committee. The station's reporter, Chris Vanocur, did much of
the original reporting that created national interest in the scandal.

A regional cable news channel, New England Cable News, won a silver baton for
in-depth reporting on a range of regional issues.

Another television station, WTHR in Indianapolis, was honored for a series of
investigative reports revealing court-appointed guardians' abuses of an elderly
heiress to the Lilly pharmaceutical fortune.

The television station WMTW in Auburn, Me., and its reporter Christine Young won
a silver baton for investigative reports on a conservative lobbying group, the
Christian Civic League, which revealed violations of I.R.S. rules on funneling
its donations into campaigns against gay rights and abortion.

A radio production company, SoundVision of Berkeley, Calif., won an award for a
nine-hour series on National Public Radio covering a range of issues raised by
genetic research.

The PBS series "P.O.V." and its producer, Walter Brock, won a silver baton for a
portrait of Arthur Campbell, a disabled man fighting to live independently.

An independent producer, Stanley Nelson, won a silver baton for a 90-minute
documentary tracing the history and impact of black-owned newspapers.

http://www.nytimes.com

               February 9, 2000, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

Groups Reconsider Bookings at Hotels Accused of Racial Bias

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

SECTION: Section A; Page 19; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 842 words


The Adam's Mark hotel chain, facing a federal racial discrimination suit, has
lost the patronage of two national organizations, and two other groups that had
booked rooms for national conferences are considering cancellations.

Last month, the Episcopal Church of America, which had planned to use the Adam's
Mark in Denver as its headquarters for a convention in July, canceled its
contract with the company. The Human Rights Campaign, a national gay and lesbian
political organization, has canceled a fund-raising dinner it had planned at the
Denver hotel later this month.  Officials with the Evangelical Lutheran Church
in America are discussing whether to continue to rent rooms at the Adam's Mark
in St. Louis for two huge youth conventions this summer. And the Organization of
American Historians has found itself divided by an unusually intense internal
debate over whether to proceed with its annual gathering next month, also in St.
Louis.

As one executive board member of the historians group, Kenneth T. Jackson of
Columbia University, put it, "This issue is causing many of us to lose sleep."

The federal suit accuses the hotel chain of charging black customers higher
prices than white customers and segregating them in less desirable rooms as part
of a corporate pattern of discrimination.

It is not clear to what extent the chain, which is based in St. Louis and has 21
large hotels in 13 states, will suffer financial losses, because each
organization that reneges on its contract, company officials insist, will have
to pay cancellation fees.

The Episcopalians stand to lose a hefty $1.2 million, or 3 percent of their
annual operating budget. But a church spokesman said its leaders were
unequivocal. "Given the church's public posture on racism issues," the
spokesman, Jim Solheim, said, "it would be a contradiction to stay in a hotel
that's part of that chain."

The stakes are arguably highest for the historians. Canceling the contract,
organization officials say, will cost them at least $425,000, about a third of
the group's operating budget. Making matters particularly difficult is the
urgency of a decision: the conference starts on March 30. Also, the question of
doing business with the Adam's Mark has unearthed a delicate dilemma for the
9,000 members of the group, many of whose leaders specialize in the study of
race. If the historians cancel their contract, they risk bankrupting their
treasury, but if they go ahead, some members insist, they stand to lose
something greater -- a longstanding reputation as scholars with a record of
civil rights leadership.

"This kind of division has not occurred before," said William Chafe, an
executive board member and dean of the faculty of arts and sciences at Duke
University.

Some conference speakers have pledged not to attend a convention at the hotel, a
few panels have already been canceled, and there has been talk of demonstrations
by people inside and outside the group.

Now, in a departure from its initial position, which was to proceed with the
convention as planned, the board plans to urge hotel executives to reach a
settlement agreement with the Justice Department, in a telephone conversation
scheduled for tomorrow. If the hotel does not agree, board members say they will
consider other options.

"If we go ahead with the convention we will be doing it under protest," David
Montgomery, the group's president and a professor emeritus at Yale University,
said in an interview. "We will be using the convention not only to pursue the
academic work to which we are devoted and which is the purpose of our existence,
but also to use it as a moment for public methods of teaching about the past,
present and future of racial discrimination in the United States."

The suit is the first to charge a national hotel chain with a companywide
pattern of racial discrimination. It was filed in December after the Justice
Department failed to persuade hotel owners to settle, an agency spokeswoman
said.

The federal case was prompted by a lawsuit filed by five black college students
who rented rooms at the Daytona Beach hotel last spring for an annual social
gathering called Black College Reunion. The plaintiffs complained that the hotel
overcharged them for rooms, required extra deposits to have their room
telephones turned on and forced them to wear orange plastic wristbands to
indicate that they were guests. Justice officials also contend that the company
had a policy to limit the number of minority patrons in its bars and
restaurants.

Fred Kummer, chief executive of HBE Corporation, which owns the chain, has
maintained that race had nothing to do with its policies. "It's 100,000 young
people trying to have a lot of fun," he said, referring to the reunion. "The
fact that they're black is absolutely incidental."

Julian Bond, chairman of the N.A.A.C.P., which joined the students' suit, said
his group had not called for a boycott but was encouraged that the groups
voluntarily considered not patronizing the hotels.

IN BRIEF;
Commission Nominees

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 7; Column 2; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 134 words


From among a stack of more than 100 resumes, County Executive Andrew J. Spano
has nominated 14 residents to serve on the county's first Human Rights
Commission. The eight men and six women -- among them three African-Americans,
two Hispanics, an Irish-American and an Italian-American -- will review
complaints of bias and be empowered to fine violators of human rights laws as
much as $10,000.

Among those nominated -- and yet to be approved by the Board of Legislators --
are Chevon Fuller, a former civil rights prosecutor for the state Attorney
General's Office; Paul Redd, president and chief operating officer of the
Westchester-Putnam Affirmative Action Program; and Maria Gagliardo, an associate
professor of Spanish language and culture at Purchase College.   ELSA BRENNER

                  April 2, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

Rebel Ambush In Chechnya One of Worst For Russians

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

SECTION: Section 1; Page 13; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 769 words

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 1


As many as 32 Russian commandos were killed in Chechnya last Wednesday when
their convoy was attacked in a rebel ambush, the Defense Ministry said today.
Earlier reports had put the death toll at 7, with about 30 missing.

The deadly attack, one of the worst in a widening partisan war, took place as a
convoy of 41 elite Interior Ministry troops, on their way to the village of
Dargo, was attacked near Zhani-Vedeno, deep in the mountains of southern
Chechnya. Another group from Vedeno came to their aid, and many of them were
seriously wounded. Altogether, only five or six officers managed to break
through the ambush, according to various published reports.

The news agency Itar-Tass, quoting Viktor Medveditskov, a top Interior Ministry
official, said today that 32 bodies had been tentatively identified. According
to Interfax, quoting unidentified sources, only 19 bodies had been recovered in
the heavily mined terrain. One wounded man was found three days after the
attack.

The ambush was the second against an elite unit since an attack in the Chechen
capital, Grozny, against a unit from the Moscow region that left 20 dead. An
entire company of paratroopers, based in the city of Pskov, was wiped out early
last month in southern Chechnya, and 84 servicemen were killed.

At a news conference yesterday, Lt. Gen. Valery L. Manilov said the number of
servicemen killed in the north Caucasus had reached 2,036, with 6,076 wounded.
The figures include military and Interior Ministry troops killed last September
in the region of Dagestan after it came under attack by Chechen rebels, as well
as those who have died or been wounded in fighting in Chechnya.

"One shouldn't underestimate the enemy," said General Manilov, who not long ago
said the rebel forces were disorganized and hampered by a lack of communication.

The United Nations high commissioner for human rights, Mary Robinson, arrived
today in the region, on an inspection tour that will take her to detention
facilities where Russian troops have allegedly beaten and tortured Chechen
civilians. Mrs. Robinson has said she will investigate the evidence for alleged
human rights abuses committed by both sides in the six-month war.

Mrs. Robinson began today by touring refugee camps in neighboring Ingushetia,
where more than 200,000 Chechens have fled since the Russian military began its
campaign in their breakaway home region last fall.

Human rights groups and Western journalists have reported a series of atrocities
committed against civilians by Russian troops as they moved through Grozny and
other towns and villages in Chechnya to clear out rebel fighters. Human Rights
Watch, which last week documented 120 cases of civilians executed by Russian
troops, on Friday added another 7 to the list with a detailed report of
executions that it said took place in the village of Gekhi-Chu on Feb. 7.

Russia's conduct of the war in Chechnya is now being debated at the United
Nations Commission for Human Rights in Geneva, and will be taken up at the
parliamentary assembly of the Council of Europe on Monday.

President-elect Vladimir V. Putin, who has taken responsibility for the war,
which was started soon after he became prime minister last August, has said that
Moscow had to use military means to take back control of a region that had
become a haven for terrorists, bandits and kidnappers.

Today, Russian news agencies reported that experts were examining the body of a
hostage found in Chechnya which may be that of Maj. Gen. Gennadi Shpigun, the
Interior Ministry's representative in Chechnya who was kidnapped a year ago from
his car at Grozny airport.

The brazen kidnapping had a big impact in Moscow, where top officials --
including then Interior Minister Sergei V. Stepashin -- vowed publicly to use
any means necessary to get back their colleague.

In later interviews, Mr. Stepashin, who was briefly prime minister before Mr.
Putin, said the Shpigun kidnapping had led to preparations for a military
operation that was to occupy the northern half of Chechnya, and establish a
cordon sanitaire along the Terek River, which divides Chechnya roughly in two.

Sergei Yastrzhembsky, Russia's chief spokesman on Chechnya, said today that
forensic experts were examining the body retrieved in Chechnya, but that no
certain identification had been made. A German newspaper reported today that the
body believed to be that of General Shpigun had been found near the village of
Duba-Yurt, in the Argun gorge. According to Suddeutsche Zeitung, General Shpigun
had eluded his captors and frozen to death in the forest.

U.N. Aide, in Chechnya, Urges Study of Abuses

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 293 words

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 4


Despite unusual restrictions placed on her tour of the ruined Chechen capital of
Grozny on Monday, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, Mary
Robinson, said today that she had heard and seen "shocking" evidence of
extensive human rights atrocities by Russian military forces in Chechnya.

But she also reported a "constructive" ending to her trip, saying she had
received a pledge from Russian leaders to consider setting up an independent
national inquiry to investigate the accusations.

Asserting that "there must be a day of reckoning regarding the situation in
Chechnya," Mrs. Robinson indicated that Moscow was not likely to end its
isolation in the interntional community over its brutal campaign to subdue the
northern Caucasus without purging its own ranks of those troops and commanders
found to be guilty of atrocities.

Mrs. Robinson spoke at a news conference here after touring the parts of
Chechnya, Ingushetia and Dagestan affected by the war.

"I found it devastating to see Grozny and I was very affected by the depth of
misery and distress," she said.

In Nazran, the refugee center in Ingushetia, Mrs. Robinson said she met
witnesses who relayed "truly shocking accounts" of summary executions, rape,
looting and other attacks on civilians during the seven-month military campaign
by Russian forces.

Mrs. Robinson said that in a meeting with Foreign Minister Igor Ivanov, she had
urged the Russian leadership to consider "the importance of establishing an
independent, national commission of inquiry as a special measure that recognizes
the scale of human rights violations in Chechnya."

Mr. Ivanov, she said, indicated that Moscow was interested and that he pledged
to examine the proposal.
