                 April 25, 2000, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

Nike's Chief Cancels a Gift Over Monitor Of Sweatshops

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 709 words


The chairman of Nike, Phil Knight, will not make a planned $30 million
contribution to help his alma mater, the University of Oregon, renovate its
athletic stadium because the university joined a factory monitoring group other
than the one he supports, a senior Nike official said yesterday.

Mr. Knight, a billionaire who heads the world's largest footwear company, has
given about $30 million to the university over the last decade, but company
officials said he was disturbed that the university joined the Workers Rights
Consortium, a student-backed monitoring group.

Nike, which has faced criticism over working conditions in its overseas
factories, has often faulted the consortium for being unfriendly to apparel and
footwear manufacturers. Nike is an enthusiastic member of another monitoring
group, the Fair Labor Association, a White House-backed organization that,
unlike the Workers Rights Consortium, has apparel companies on its board.

In a statement, Nike said: "The University of Oregon, despite its unique
relationship with Nike and Phil, is free to align itself with the Workers Rights
Consortium. However, it does not mean that we are required to support those
efforts with which we have fundamental disagreements."

The University of Oregon, based in Eugene, has been developing plans to renovate
and expand Autzen Stadium, a project that is expected to cost $80 million.
University officials said they still hoped to talk with Mr. Knight to see
whether he might reconsider his decision.

Randy Newnham, a university senior and a coordinator of the Survival Center,
which supports social justice and human rights, criticized Mr. Knight's
decision.

"It's kind of amusing, considering that he's upset that we joined some
labor-monitoring body," Mr. Newnham said. "He keeps claiming that his company is
socially responsible and they don't use sweatshop labor. If that's the case, why
is he so upset that we joined this monitoring group? It kind of implies that
something isn't quite up to par."

Over the last six months, student groups at dozens of campuses have held sit-ins
and demonstrations to pressure their universities to join the Workers Rights
Consortium, instead of the Fair Labor Association. The consortium, set up by
students with the backing of several labor unions, now has 45 universities as
members. It monitors overseas factories that make hats, T-shirts and other
apparel that are made under license and carry a university's logo.

The students assert that the Fair Labor Association is dominated by corporations
and will not be vigorous in its monitoring. Its members include several consumer
groups, human rights groups and 130 colleges.

Nike officials criticize the consortium's makeup and its requirement for
surprise monitoring visits.

"We object to the Workers Rights Consortium because it does not provide a seat
on the table for companies," said Vada Manager, a Nike spokesman. "Another issue
is it has a 'gotcha' monitoring system, which in our minds is not a serious way
to achieve the common goal that we all want to achieve, which is to eradicate
sweatshop conditions."

To pressure Nike, United Students Against Sweatshops, the umbrella group backing
the consortium, the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees and
other groups issued a report yesterday that criticized Nike for using
sweatshops. The report faults Nike for doing much of its production in China,
where independent unions are prohibited and where, the report said, workers are
paid at most $1.50 for a pair of shoes that sells for $100.

Nike officials assert that the company has made great strides in improving its
factories, that they do more monitoring than most companies and that their
factories usually pay more than other factories in the regions where they are
situated.

Last month, Nike said it was ending its agreement to supply Brown University's
hockey teams after Brown joined the consortium. Brown officials said Nike's move
resulted from miscommunication.

Nicholas Reville, a Brown junior active in United Students Against Sweatshops,
said Nike and Mr. Knight moved against Brown and the University of Oregon, to
warn other universities against join the Workers Rights Consortium.


http://www.nytimes.com

When Peace Is Worse Than War

BYLINE: By William Reno;  William Reno, who teaches political science at
Northwestern, is the author of "Warlord Politics and African States."

SECTION: Section A; Page 31; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 573 words

DATELINE: EVANSTON, Ill.


Sometimes it is better to wage war than to agree to an unstable and unworkable
peace, a proposition that the current crisis in Sierra Leone bears out.

A peace agreement signed in July 1999 was supposed to help rebuild Sierra Leone
by installing a coalition government, composed of the current president, Ahmad
Tejan Kabbah, and Foday Sankoh, the ruthless leader of the main rebel group.

Under the accord, Mr. Sankoh became a vice president and commissioner of diamond
resources, the country's main source of income. Three of his lieutenants became
ministers of government. All were offered a blanket amnesty for past crimes. In
exchange, United Nations peacekeepers were to take the weapons of all
combatants. Instead, the rebels have captured and disarmed 500 peacekeepers, and
the country is in chaos once again.

This agreement failed for several related reasons. It mistakenly assumed that
the rebels were interested in peace, let alone had an interest in real
governing. It assumed that there was a civil war and treated Mr. Sankoh as a
legitimate champion of the rural poor, whose interests he claimed to represent.
In reality, Mr. Sankoh is not rebelling in any political sense. He has been
interested only in taking advantage of a corrupt state that had collapsed.

So, from the rebels' point of view, why have peace when it is the absence of law
and order that enables one to loot? Why let peacekeeping troops enter the
country's diamond mining area if one is profiting from the sale of these riches
on the black market?

In fact, the rebels never had any intention of honoring the peace accord; they
were only interested in waging war and looting the country.  The United Nations,
so reflexively attached to the mantra of peace at any price, sent peacekeeping
troops when there was no peace to keep. The United Nations and the State
Department, which helped negotiate the peace accord, should have known better.
As recently as March 1999, the United Nations Security Council had threatened to
prosecute Mr. Sankoh for war crimes. Earlier, a State Department report on
Sierra Leone had noted the discovery of civilian mass graves in areas where the
rebels had attacked.

Why would the United Nations and the United States agree to a power-sharing
agreement with Mr. Sankoh, whose forces have killed, raped and maimed tens of
thousands of men, women and even children?

The answer can be found in President Clinton's statement during his April 1999
visit to Rwanda, when he lamented the lack of United States action to stop the
genocide there. After this speech, the Clinton administration wanted to show
that it cared about human rights in Africa. Engineering a peace accord in Sierra
Leone, however slapdash, sent the desired message.

In the last few days, Nigeria has agreed to send its own forces back to Sierra
Leone, provided the West pays their costs. The West should jump at this, not
only because these soldiers are likely to be better equipped and trained than
the United Nations forces, but because they can fight back.

Unconstrained by the rules of peacekeeping, the Nigerians can wage war against
the rebels. And Nigeria, unlike the West, has national interests at stake.
Trouble anywhere in West Africa is a threat to its stability.

The peace agreement in Sierra Leone was quick and cheap, but doomed. Let us hope
that the West now recognizes this -- and doesn't opt for a second try at an
accord.

Does China Deserve Trade Status?

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 160 words



To the Editor:

William Safire (column, May 18) says President Nixon told him that "we may have
created a Frankenstein" in United States dealings with China. In "Beyond Peace,"
finished shortly before his death, Nixon wrote that "the giant is awake and is
beginning to move the world," making clear that he saw China's internal
dynamics, rather than United States policy, as the force behind the country's
emergence as a major power.

Nixon also argued that "economic freedom inevitably leads to political freedom.
. . . It will happen in China, but only if economic freedom is not suppressed by
frightened political dictators or sabotaged by shortsighted U.S. policies
cutting back on trade with China because of its human rights abuses."

JOHN H. TAYLOR
DIMITRI K. SIMES
Washington, May 19, 2000

The writers are, respectively, executive director of the Richard Nixon Library &
Birthplace Foundation and president of the Nixon Center.

                   May 21, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

ECONOMIC VIEW;
Lighting Up A Lesson In China Trade

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 795 words


WANDERING through a flea market in Shanghai earlier this year with Craig Smith,
The Times's new correspondent there, I stopped at a stall that was selling cheap
cigarette lighters with pictures of Mao Zedong pasted on them. Flick one open,
and it plays the tune of "The East Is Red." I don't smoke, but I couldn't resist
buying a handful.

Not far away, another merchant offered hundreds of hand-painted posters from the
days of the Cultural Revolution. I bought one dated 1976, showing a smiling Mao
leading a parade of workers and students into the promised land. We bargained a
bit before settling on a price of about $5.

Say what you will about capitalism, but you must admit it has a marvelous way of
turning even the most violent and earthshaking upheavals into safe, salable
kitsch.

And that, above all, is why it is worth continuing to encourage Beijing to move
along the path toward freer markets, private investment and open trade. Karl
Marx (remember him?) said it as well as anybody in, of all places, the Communist
Manifesto:

"The bourgeoisie, by the rapid improvement of all instruments of production, by
the immensely facilitated means of communication, draws all nations, even the
most barbarian, into civilization. The cheap prices of its commodities are the
heavy artillery with which it batters down all Chinese walls, with which it
forces the barbarians' intensely obstinate hatred of foreigners to capitulate."

What does this have to do with today's debate over China? Plenty.

The choice facing Congress this week over granting China what is called
"permanent normal trade relations" -- part of a deal to admit China to the World
Trade Organization -- turns on conflicting views of how to best induce change in
China's authoritarian regime.

On one side -- opposed to normalizing trade -- are those who argue that Congress
should vote every year on China's trade status, thus maintaining outside
pressure on Beijing to respond to complaints of human rights abuses. The annual
vote should not be given up, they say, because it is Washington's only stick for
persuading China to ease repression and to free dissidents. Treating China as a
normal trading partner, they say, will just entrench the current regime and
encourage its belligerence.

Opposing that view are those who believe that change inside China can exert
greater leverage for reform than any diplomatic pressure. Through broader trade
and contact with the outside world, the Chinese people will be exposed to the
full range of Western life, from the sublime to the ridiculous. In the end, the
temptation will prove irresistible. Treat China as a normal country, this side
argues, and it will eventually turn into one.

"Openness is a two-way street," Nicholas Lardy, a senior fellow at the Brookings
Institution, said last week in a telephone interview from Beijing. "Already
there are thousands of foreigners living in China and interacting on a daily
basis across a very broad spectrum. That will only grow as China joins the
W.T.O. At the same time, tens of thousands of the most promising Chinese have
gone to the West as students. They've come back -- often to very high positions
in government, banking and business -- changed for good."

I VISITED China for the first time this year. But even without an earlier point
of reference, it was clear that though the economy remains very basic, the
country has changed immensely in the last two decades.

As recently as the early 1980's, nearly everybody in Shanghai, the most
Westernized city in China, still wore the famous blue Mao suits. Only top
officials had cars; everyone else pedaled bicycles or rode buses. Lights were
dim. Public restaurants and private enterprises barely existed. Architecture
seemed frozen in a pre-World War II time warp. Today, everything is different:
jeans and khakis are ubiquitous; cars and taxis compete with bikes on crowded
streets; glass-sheathed skyscrapers abound; Shanghai throbs with activity day
and night.

"We tend to forget," Mr. Lardy said, "how much change has already occurred."

As private enterprise spreads and markets open to real competition from domestic
and foreign companies alike, tens of millions of Chinese are shedding their
dependence on the state. They are richer and freer. It's not democracy, but it
is the first step toward a genuinely pluralistic society.

And that is just the beginning.

"China now feels competitive heat across continents and oceans," Robert Wright
wrote in a recent issue of The New Republic. "It must face the same logic the
rest of the world faces. In the age of the Internet, even more than in the age
of industry and print, granting enough liberty for cutting-edge prosperity while
denying political liberty is a tall order."

China Trade Bill Passes By Wide Margin in House
Lawmakers voted, 237 to 197, to give China permanent normal trading privileges.
A Republican majority that was larger than expected made good on President
Clinton's top remaining legislative priority; three out of four Republicans
voted in favor of the measure, while two out of three Democrats voted against
it. The vote virtually assures the end of the annual review of China's trade
status, a ritual for 20 years that Beijing considers humiliating but opponents
say maintains leverage over improving human rights.   A1

Ruling on Immunity Puts Chile Closer to Trial of Pinochet

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 795 words

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, May 24


A Chilean appeals court has stripped the immunity of Gen. Augusto Pinochet,
removing an important obstacle in the way of his possible trial. He faces
charges that he was involved in the kidnapping, murder and torture of thousands
during his 17 years as Chile's dictator.

The decision of the Court of Appeals is subject to a possible reversal by the
Supreme Court, and even lawyers working to prosecute General Pinochet say it
could take years of legal wrangling before a trial could begin, and that is
assuming that the general, now 84, lives that long. He has circulatory problems
and has a history of strokes and diabetes.

Nevertheless, the 13-9 decision by the appellate judges, voted in private on
Tuesday but leaked to local reporters, demonstrates that Chile's courts are
willing to take independent stands after decades of subservience to the armed
forces.

It also demonstrates the commitment of President Ricardo Lagos, the recently
inaugurated Socialist, to let the mechanisms of justice go forward despite
friction with military commanders and threats by congressional conservatives to
bottle up much of his program if the prosecution of General Pinochet continues.

Carlos Salinas, acting legislative director of Amnesty International USA, said:
"Throughout Pinochet's captivity in Great Britain, the Chilean government
repeatedly insisted that he be returned for prosecution in Chile. This appears
to be the first step toward the Chilean government making good on its promise."

General Pinochet's legal troubles began in earnest in late 1998 when he was
arrested in London on a Spanish warrant charging him with human rights
violations. The general, who is a senator for life under a constitution written
while he ruled, and thus has immunity, was released by British authorities in
February after doctors said he was not physically and mentally fit to stand
trial.

While legislators have a cloak of immunity, judges may strip it away if they
have evidence that a crime may have been committed. General Pinochet has the
right to challenge the court's ruling on immunity.

Once the matter is settled, there are several legal issues that must be ruled
on, including whether General Pinochet is mentally fit to stand trial and
whether he would be tried by a civilian or military court.

General Pinochet now faces 108 criminal complaints, mostly filed by family
members of about 3,000 people who disappeared after his violent 1973 coup
against President Salvador Allende Gossens.

Through a spokesman, General Pinochet recently said, "I never ordered anybody to
be killed or tortured."

Judge Juan Guzman, who is prosecuting Mr. Pinochet, has anchored his case on 19
people who have been missing since they were dragged out of prisons by soldiers
led by some of General Pinochet's top aides in the weeks after the coup.

The 19 people -- who were among 75 prisoners believed to have been summarily
executed -- have never been found, but the Supreme Court has accepted Judge
Guzman's interpretation that they should be considered kidnap victims, rather
than dead. If the bodies were found, the slayings could possibly be covered by a
general amnesty involving most rights violations committed during the early
years of the dictatorship, though there is a court challenge arguing that mass
murder and torture are crimes against humanity superseding any amnesty. But
considering the prisoners to be kidnapped, and possibly still held, offers a
loophole for the prosecution.

Congressman Pablo Longueira of the Independent Democratic Union, who is opposed
to the general's prosecution, recently called the legal interpretation behind
Judge Guzman's prosecution "a ridiculous joke." He added, "We all know those
people are dead."

The Independent Democratic Union and another conservative party had been in
negotiations with President Lagos to rewrite sections of the Constitution that
limit the president's appointment powers over military commanders and that give
the military powers to appoint senators. But the talks have bogged down as Mr.
Lagos has refused to interfere in the judicial proceedings and as government
attorneys have joined in the prosecution.

President Lagos has been equally forceful in displaying his resolve as top
military commanders have showed displeasure with the prosecution of their former
commander in chief. After a high-level lunch of top military and police
commanders on May 15 was interpreted as a show of defiance, President Lagos
publicly scolded them in a diplomatic but pointed statement.

Since his return from Britain, Mr. Pinochet has been keeping as low a profile as
possible. He has not been attending Senate sessions, even for important votes,
and he has not spoken out on the issues of the day.

COUNTRY: CHILE (99%); UNITED KINGDOM (92%); PERU (79%); UNITED STATES (79%);

CITY: LONDON, ENGLAND (79%);   LIMA, PERU (71%);

COMPANY: INTERNATIONAL USA TELECOM (55%);   AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL  (55%);

                  May 27, 2000, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

Rebels Release More Hostages In Sierra Leone

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 448 words

DATELINE: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, May 26


The Liberian government said today that Sierra Leone's rebels had released 180
more United Nations peacekeepers, even as the country's president announced that
the rebels' leader, Foday Sankoh, would be prosecuted.

The peacekeepers were handed over to authorities in Foya, a border town in
neighboring Liberia, the statement released in Monrovia said. Liberia said the
latest release left fewer than 100 of the original 500 peacekeepers who were
taken hostage still in rebel hands.

In the government's first announcement on Mr. Sankoh's fate since his capture
earlier this month, President Ahmed Tejan Kabbah accused the rebel chief of
committing serious crimes. "This time around Sankoh will be prosecuted," he
said.

He did not say what charges the rebel chief would face or when a trial would be
held. The government has said that any prosecution would be for crimes that were
committed after the signing of a peace accord a year ago that ended Sierra
Leone's eight-year civil war.

The United Nations said today that it believed that several mutilated corpses
found on Monday were the bodies of peacekeepers. The bodies appear to be those
of four Zambians and one or two Nigerians, said a United Nations spokesman,
David Wimhurst.

The United Nations has been collecting information from the various forces who
had fighters in the area near Rogberi Junction, about 50 miles east of the
capital, Freetown, where there was a battle on May 6 between peacekeepers and
rebels.

Four Zambian and two Nigerian soldiers were reported missing after the battle,
Mr. Eckhard said.

Some of the bodies were dressed in Zambian military uniforms bearing the United
Nations insignia. However, in the past rebels have stripped United Nations
captives of their weapons and uniforms and used them in battle, so there could
be rebel bodies among them, Mr. Eckhard said. The bodies were discovered not far
from where two foreign journalists were killed on Wednesday.

The rebels killed tens of thousands of people and intentionally mutilated many
more during the country's eight-year civil war, which ended in July with a shaky
peace accord. The conflict re-ignited earlier this month when the Revolutionary
United Front took the United Nations peacekeepers hostage and began advancing
toward Freetown.

Since then, an alliance of pro-government forces has been pushing the rebels
away from the capital.

Human rights officials have also received reports that both rebels and
government forces abused civilians in recent weeks.

Human Rights Watch accused the rebels of imposing a "reign of terror" during its
weeklong occupation of the area around Masiaka, a town 45 miles east of
Freetown.

                 May 31, 2000, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

Indonesia Inquiry: Digging Up Agonies of the Past

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 914 words

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 30


Investigators who are struggling to break through the mental fog of former
President Suharto as they question him are searching for something that is
perhaps more valuable than the billions of dollars he is said to have stolen
from his country.

They are fighting to reclaim a piece of their nation's history.

The fitful interrogations of the ailing 78-year-old former president, who was
placed under house arrest on Monday, are one part of a broad campaign by
President Abdurrahman Wahid to dig into a past that is filled with hidden
abuses.

As with the national treasury, which Mr. Suharto used as his personal bank
account, he ravaged his country and then concealed the evidence. The abuses have
ranged from shady business deals to dirty political tricks to military
massacres.

Now Mr. Wahid is pushing to dig up the bones of the past in a series of
investigations and trials. In response, he is receiving mostly abuse, either
from people who shout that he is moving too slowly or from others who fear
instability or personal exposure.

"The main motivation is a hunger to explore this period of Suharto's
government," said Adam Schwarz, the author of "A Nation in Waiting" (Allen &
Unwin, 1999), the basic history of Indonesia's recent past. "I don't think it's
really about the money, and it's only partly about issues of justice. What is
really driving this is a strong desire for an accounting of what happened in the
past, whether in the case of human rights violations, judicial misconduct or
corruption.

"The positive thing is that Indonesians will to some extent be able to put the
past behind them. The negative is that a lot of bad things will be dragged back
up to the surface and confronted."

Some of Indonesia's most powerful people are resisting this process. Most of
those who prospered during the 32 years of Mr. Suharto's rule were complicit to
some degree in the abuses or corruption that were the order of the day.

"If they are really serious," said one victim of a violent raid on an opposition
party office in 1997, "then the police headquarters would be empty, because
everyone was involved."

As they push to uncover the truth about past abuses, the investigations also
have become a battleground of contemporary politics, enabling Mr. Wahid to keep
some of his opponents from the Suharto years on the defensive.

Some powerful people apparently are fighting back, instigating violent incidents
in an attempt to derail Mr. Wahid's government and the threat it poses to them.
Defense Minister Juwono Sudarsono, who was also a cabinet member in the previous
government, said he knew of several former civilian and military officials who
are paying to foment unrest.

Some analysts have noted that on several occasions when a new investigation is
opened or new charges are brought, a riot erupts or bombs go off somewhere in
this volatile nation.

The investigation of Mr. Suharto did not begin in earnest until Mr. Wahid took
office in October. During the previous 17 months, after Mr. Suharto's forced
resignation in May 1998, the interim government of President B. J. Habibie --
stocked with Suharto loyalists -- protected him.

The interrogations are moving slowly now because Mr. Suharto's mind has been
affected by three strokes. The disability is apparently being maximized by his
team of lawyers, and perhaps by Mr. Suharto himself, to hamper the questioning.

Mr. Wahid and his attorney general, Marzuki Darusman, are also meeting
resistance as they probe a number of other difficult areas of the past.

The most startlingly successful initiative so far, perhaps because it was
politically insulated, was the trial and conviction on May 18 of 24 soldiers and
a civilian for the massacre of an Islamic teacher and more than 50 students last
year in the province of Aceh. The defendants received jail terms of up to 10
years each, although human rights campaigners now ask why none of their
superiors have been charged in the killings.

It will be much more politically difficult to complete an investigation into a
campaign of violence last year in East Timor after that former Indonesian
province voted for independence. General Wiranto, the former military chief,
resigned his cabinet post this month as he continued to undergo questioning as
one of 21 high-ranking officers and civilians implicated by a government
commission.

Opening another highly sensitive investigation this month, the National
Commission on Human Rights began summoning former generals for questioning about
the killings of at least 50 Muslim protesters in the Tanjung Priok district of
Jakarta in 1984. Among those questioned were the former military chief, Benny
Murdani, and a former vice president, Try Sutrisno.

So far there has been no full-scale investigation into the riots in May 1998
that helped bring down Mr. Suharto. It was clear from many accounts by witnesses
that much of that violence was instigated and that a campaign of rapes of ethnic
Chinese women was orchestrated and involved members of the military.

And although Mr. Wahid has raised the issue, there has been no formal
investigation yet into the massacres that began it all: the killing of 500,000
people and the jailing without trial of hundreds of thousands more in an
anti-Communist purge that began in 1965.

The origins and responsibility for those atrocities have never been fully
explored, but their ultimate outcome was clear: Mr. Suharto became president of
Indonesia.


http://www.nytimes.com

                  June 13, 2000, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

Turkey and the Kurds

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 160 words



To the Editor:

Re "As War Wanes, Tourists Return to Turkey's East" (Kars Journal, June 7):
Tourism is indeed a positive sign of a newly stabilized region. But it should
not come at the cost of human and civil rights.

You state that in the 1990's, "violence was common and tourism all but
unthinkable" and that current conditions "are more relaxed than they have been
in years." Your reasoning is this: "Today the Kurdish rebel leader is in jail.
His guerrillas have stopped fighting." You ignore the oppression of 20 million
Kurds by the Turkish government.

Kurds have been arrested for speaking their own language and practicing the
traditions that have been part of their culture for thousands of years. Just
this month, two Kurdish mayors were denied the right to travel to the United
States to speak about human rights violations.

The Kurdish struggle is not over.

BOB FILNER
Member of Congress, 50th Dist.
San Diego, June 9, 2000

                  June 20, 2000, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

Foreign Affairs;
Knight Is Right

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

SECTION: Section A; Page 25; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 728 words


Some things are true even though Phil Knight, the chairman of Nike, believes
them.

Mr. Knight recently made news by suddenly withdrawing a contemplated $30 million
gift to the University of Oregon after the university balked at joining a
coalition -- the Fair Labor Association (F.L.A.) -- that was formed by human
rights groups, colleges, the U.S. government and companies such as Nike to
alleviate global sweatshop conditions. Oregon opted to join an alternative group
being pushed on college campuses, the Worker Rights Consortium (W.R.C.), which
also plans to combat sweatshops, but refuses to cooperate with any companies,
such as Nike.

The natural assumption is that Mr. Knight is wrong. The truth is, Nike has a
shameful past when it comes to tolerating sweatshops. But on the question of how
best to remedy those conditions in the future -- which Nike has now agreed to do
-- Mr. Knight is dead right and Oregon wrong: The best way to create global
governance -- over issues from sweatshops to the environment -- when there is no
global government is to build coalitions, in which enlightened companies,
consumers and social activists work together to forge their own rules and
enforcement mechanisms. That's what the F.L.A. represents and it's what the
W.R.C. doesn't.

We've heard plenty this year about the downsides of globalization. The question
is what to do about it. The more radical protesters, such as the W.R.C., want to
trash multinationals and get the World Trade Organization to set rules for
workers and the environment, not just for trade. And what practical effect have
the protesters had so far? Zero.

So what to do? Well, it comes down to this: Do you want a make a point or do you
want to make a difference? The F.L.A. was formed to make a difference. The
W.R.C. was formed to make a point.

The F.L.A. was founded four years ago, and it now includes the Lawyers Committee
for Human Rights, the National Council of Churches, the International Labor
Rights Fund, 135 universities and major apparel companies such as Liz Claiborne,
Levi Strauss, Nike, Reebok and Adidas. After long talks, this diverse group
agreed on a nine-point code for any apparel factory anywhere in the world --
including rules against forced labor and child labor, as well as freedom of
association, minimum wages, maximum working hours, lighting, bathrooms and
safety. They also agreed on a system of independent monitoring, surprise
inspections and follow-ups, which is now being tested in five developing
countries.

Companies whose factories comply will be able to sew an "F.L.A." label into
their clothing, and the 135 universities have agreed that their logos will go
only on F.L.A.-made products. Global brands can't afford any longer to be
associated with sweatshops, and the F.L.A. creates a credible system for
empowering consumers to punish dirty companies and reward improving ones.

The W.R.C., by contrast, is backed by protectionist U.S. unions, such as Unite,
that don't want any system that would give a stamp of approval to any production
outside the U.S. That's one reason the W.R.C. won't work with companies. But
that means the W.R.C. has no way of consistently monitoring factories or
following up remedies, and it is only focused on clothing sold on college
campuses.

It's good that there's a W.R.C. out there noisily protesting sweatshops and
embarrassing companies. But the W.R.C. is not a substitute for the F.L.A., which
has a comprehensive strategy for upgrading the whole apparel industry. It's a
pity that some cowardly college presidents -- intimidated by a few vocal and
often uninformed students -- have quit the F.L.A. in favor of the W.R.C.

"If you want to improve people's lives in the absence of a global government,
you need to align the economic interests of the better global companies with the
social interests of the least advantaged people," said Sam Brown, the 1960's
antiwar activist, former U.S. ambassador and now director of the F.L.A. "We need
to make these companies our allies, not our opponents. We won't change the world
overnight. But it is foolish to dismiss the F.L.A. because it does not go far
enough or fast enough. The issue is how to get from here to there, and the
F.L.A. has a real strategy for harnessing U.S. consumer power to change the
lives and working conditions of real people."

http://www.nytimes.com

                 June 21, 2000, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

Sierra Leone Asks U.N. For Role In War Court

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

SECTION: Section A; Page 7; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 776 words

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 20


Sierra Leone has asked the United Nations to set up a war crimes tribunal to try
rebel leaders whose troops maimed and killed Sierra Leoneans and abducted 500
international peacekeepers, plunging the country into a new round of violence in
May.

But the proposed court, as outlined in a letter to Secretary General Kofi Annan
from Sierra Leone's president, Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, would be a far cry from an
international tribunal of the sort established in the 1990's for the Balkans and
Rwanda. Instead, it would be closer to the one now being created for Cambodia's
Khmer Rouge, with considerable power in the hands of the national government.
Prosecutors and judges would be a mix of Sierra Leoneans and foreigners.

The hybrid court envisioned by Sierra Leone would be based there and limited to
hearing cases against only one faction, the Revolutionary United Front of Foday
Sankoh. This spring, Mr. Sankoh broke a year-old peace agreement that had given
him a role in government and turned his troops on both Mr. Kabbah's army and
United Nations peacekeepers. He is now in custody.

Britain, which sent troops to Sierra Leone last month, helped Sierra Leone draft
its proposal for a tribunal, diplomats said today. The court would be
established under one of possibly three Security Council resolutions on Sierra
Leone to be debated in coming weeks. The other two would impose an embargo on
arms sales and diamond exports and enlarge the United Nations peacekeeping force
and strengthen its powers.

Diplomats say the United States originally appeared to want a more international
tribunal, but now seemed to be closer to supporting the British-assisted plan
outlined by President Kabbah. An American official said that the United States
was still far from a decision on the shape of the court.

At a Security Council meeting today, the American Ambassador, Richard C.
Holbrooke, said that he was against creating a new tribunal for Sierra Leone but
that "some form of extension of the international war crime umbrella to cover
these odious people must be undertaken."

A copy of President Kabbah's letter and its detailed annex, sent a week ago, was
made available to The New York Times by experts outside the United Nations.
Officials in the organization would not discuss the plan, saying it is still
being studied.

The limitations on the proposed court's reach and the large role reserved for
the weak government and justice system of Sierra Leone raise fears among some
international human rights experts, who say numerous factions have been involved
in abuses in Sierra Leone, in a war marked by the hacking off of civilians'
limbs and the destruction of countless communities.

"There are two main concerns that we have," said Peter Bouckaert of Human Rights
Watch, who recently returned from Sierra Leone. "One is that it deals only with
the R.U.F. We think for a tribunal to have any kind of international
credibility, it would have to address the criminal responsibility of all sides
in the conflict."

In addition to the Revolutionary United Front, he said, there are the Armed
Forces Revolutionary Council; one of its most violent factions, known as the
West Side Boys; and bands of former government soldiers who joined the rebels to
attack Freetown, the country's capital, in January 1999 after Mr. Sankoh broke
an earlier peace agreement.

A second concern cited by Mr. Bouckaert was "the dominant role that Sierra Leone
would play in this proposed hybrid court, considering the politicization that
would take place and also the limited capacity that the Sierra Leone judiciary
has at this stage."

President Kabbah said in his letter and annex that a court created by the
Security Council would have "the advantage of strong enforcement powers that
will call for cooperation from states in investigations, arrest, extradition and
the enforcement of sentence." He also asked that it be paid for through an
international trust fund.

Turning to the working of the court, Mr. Kabbah called for a "narrow" list of
those to be charged from the Revolutionary United Front, possibly in the dozens.
He said this would allow the court to be "quick and efficient."

Mr. Kabbah asked for a blend of Sierra Leone and international law to be applied
in order to include crimes against humanity and crimes against peacekeepers,
which are not in the national code. He expected the court to sit in Sierra Leone
unless security made it necessary to move elsewhere. It would have West African
and possibly other judges. For appeals, the tribunal could make use of an
appeals panel in The Hague, which hears cases from the Balkans and Rwanda.

http://www.nytimes.com

Report Says U.S. and Others Allowed Rwanda Genocide

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1085 words

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 7


The United States and other nations that failed to prevent or stop the genocide
in Rwanda in 1994 should pay a "significant level of reparations," an
independent panel said today.

The seven-member international panel, assembled by the Organization of African
Unity, also singled out France and Belgium as well as the United Nations and the
Roman Catholic and Anglican Churches as those most guilty of not doing enough to
prevent or stop the atrocities that killed up to 800,000 people.

The group acknowledged that Rwanda's Hutu-led government was behind the
killings, in which Hutu militias rampaged through the country, massacring ethnic
Tutsi and moderate or antigovernment Hutu who defended them, but it added that
"external forces" had also had a responsibility for what has happened to Rwanda
in a century of crisis.

The panel asked Secretary General Kofi Annan to establish a commission to
formally identify the countries that owe Rwanda the money to rebuild the
devastated country, and to set an appropriate scale of compensation. It also
demanded that Rwanda's international debts be canceled.

In its report, "Rwanda: The Preventable Genocide," the panel said that the
events of 1994 cannot be forgotten, and that Rwanda should no more be assigned
to "ancient history" than the Holocaust.

It also noted that the long-term effects of those weeks of horrific violence and
brutality continue to be felt throughout the region, especially in Congo. "The
1994 genocide in one small country ultimately triggered a conflict in the heart
of Africa that has directly or indirectly touched at least one-third of all the
nations on the continent," the report said.

The report reviews the same issues and reaches many of the same conclusions as
another independent experts' study commissioned by the secretary general. But it
also takes a deeper look at the roots of the ethnic conflict in Rwanda,
beginning with 60 years of colonial rule, first by Germany and then Belgium,
when ethnic divisions were exacerbated if not manipulated.

It is also far harsher in its criticism of Security Council members, especially
France and the United States, saying France could have prevented the genocide
and the United States could have stopped it.

"Of course there would have been no genocide if certain Rwandans had not
organized and carried it out; there is no denying that fundamental truth," the
report said. "But it is equally true that throughout the past century external
forces have helped shape Rwanda's destiny and that of its neighbors." The report
does not absolve the current Tutsi-led government in Rwanda of sometimes failing
to meet challenges it inherited, despite the "resilience and vigor" shown by the
survivors now rebuilding the country and their lives.

Rwandans still confront human rights abuses under the Tutsi-led government
formed from the Rwanda Patriotic Front, which seized power in the summer of
1994. The country, struggling with refugee resettlement, is still at war in
Congo, where ethnic Hutu militias remain a menace, the Rwandan government says.

Those militias instigated the genocide in April 1994, after the president,
Juvenal Habyarimana, a Hutu, was killed in a plane crash in Kigali that was
possibly caused by a missile attack. The report characterizes the four-year
period leading up to the outbreak of violence as "the triumph of ethnic
radicalism" among the majority Hutu population that set the scene for the
nightmare that followed.

At this point, the report said, France had "unrivaled influence at the very
highest levels" of the Hutu-led government in Rwanda and chose not to exercise
it to derail well-laid plans for the genocide.

At a news conference today, Ambassador Stephen Lewis, a Canadian member of the
Organization of African Unity panel and a former deputy executive director of
Unicef, said that the new report chose to focus more heavily on the role of the
Security Council, especially France and the United States, than the report
prepared for Mr. Annan last year. Mr. Lewis said that French behavior was
particularly indefensible.

"We repudiate the position of the government of France, the position that
asserts they had no responsibility," he said. "They were closer in every way to
the Habyarimana regime than any other government. They could have stopped the
genocide before it began. They knew exactly what was happening."

Worse, he said, the French peacekeeping mission eventually sent to the region
allowed a huge number of Hutu attackers to flee the country to neighboring
Congo, then known as Zaire, "thereby ushering in the larger Great Lakes
catastrophe."

"There is almost no redemptive feature to the conduct of the government of
France," Mr. Lewis said.

As for the United States, which blocked the Security Council from sending
peacekeepers to Rwanda once the massacres had begun, Mr. Lewis said the American
role was "an almost incomprehensible scar of shame on American foreign policy."
Speaking personally, he said, "I don't know how Madeleine Albright lives with
it." Secretary of State Albright was then the United States representative at
the United Nations.

President Clinton, on a subsequent visit to Africa, apologized to Rwanda for the
lack of international response, as has Belgium, the former colonial power.
France has never expressed remorse or accepted blame.

The report was very critical of the Roman Catholic Church. "We were shocked by
the role of the church," Mr. Lewis said today. Although priests and lay
Catholics were among those who tried to save Tutsi, there were other church
officials who did not; some helped lure Tutsi to their deaths.

There were "leaders of the church who did not speak out strongly and take
stands," Mr. Lewis said. "Since Rwanda is a very Catholic country, we felt we
had to say something."

Anglican Church authorities have apologized for ignoring human rights abuses or
for acts that encouraged Hutu death squads. The Roman Catholic Church has not,
the report said.

In addition to Mr. Lewis, who introduced the report here today, the panel
consisted of Sir Ketumile Masire, a former president of Botswana and the panel
leader; Amadou Toumani Toure, former president of Mali; Lisbet Palme, a Swedish
child psychologist and expert on the United Nations Committee on the Rights of
the Child; Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, former finance minister of Liberia; P. N.
Bhagwati, former chief justice of India's Supreme Court; and Hocine Djoudi, an
Algerian judge and diplomat.

                 July 22, 2000, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

Scores Reported Dead as Rebels and Militias Clash in Colombia

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section A; Page 5; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 538 words

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 21


Clashes between Marxist rebels and Colombia's main right-wing paramilitary force
have killed up to 100 people this week in two remote areas of the Andes
mountains, authorities said today.

The fighting, confirmed by a paramilitary warlord, Carlos Castano, were among
the most violent this year and included a battle for control of a region in
northern Bolivar Province long known as a stronghold of the Cuban-inspired Army
of National Liberation, or E.L.N..

"The idea is to force them out of the only sanctuary they have left," Mr.
Castano told a local television station.

He was referring to what military sources have described as intense combat since
Wednesday around the San Lucas mountain range, where commanders of the E.L.N.,
Colombia's second-largest guerrilla army, are thought to have their main base.

Col. Jaime Martinez, a regional chief of the National Police, told reporters
that as many as 60 guerrillas and 15 members of Mr. Castano's outlawed United
Self-Defense Forces, an umbrella organization of ultra-right militias, were
thought to have been killed in the fighting.

But he said the death toll was unofficial and based only on accounts from
peasants fleeing the area.

Mr. Castano, who spoke in a brief phone interview with R.C.N. television, did
not comment on the number of dead in the San Lucas fighting. But he rejected
rebel assertions that the paramilitary offensive there was backed by government
security forces, long accused of tacitly supporting militias in their war
against leftists and suspected rebel sympathizers.

The offensive started as several E.L.N. commanders, two of whom were released on
parole from a maximum security prison today, prepared to meet Colombian
business, civic and labor leaders in Geneva on Monday to prepare for
full-fledged peace talks with the government.

No firm date has been set for formal negotiations, which would take place more
than a year and a half after the government opened talks with the larger
Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC.

Cuba has agreed to act as a "facilitator" and possible mediator in the talks,
together with the governments of France, Spain, Norway and Switzerland.

Colombia's internal conflict, which has intensified in recent years as rebels
built up their own sources of financing -- including widespread kidnapping and
involvement in the drug trade -- has killed more than 35,000 people since 1990.

The other battle this week also began on Wednesday, according to local
government officials, when FARC rebels raided one of Mr. Castano's strongholds
in a rugged mountain area of northwest Antioquia Province, killing at least 28
paramilitary gunmen.

The death toll was the highest reported this year involving gunmen from the
paramilitary group, which human rights groups blame for most of the peasant
massacres and other atrocities committed in Colombia's protracted civil
conflict.

"The information we have is that there are about 30 dead, including two
civilians," said Jaime Montoya, mayor of Ituango, where the fighting occurred.

Mr. Castano disputed the toll in his televised comments, however, saying no more
than 15 of his men had died, along with 6 guerrillas and 5 civilians.

                August 2, 2000, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

Pinochet Reportedly Stripped of Immunity in Secret Court Vote

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 800 words

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 1


The Chilean Supreme Court voted in secret today to strip Gen. Augusto Pinochet
of his senatorial immunity, according to local radio and web site accounts. The
decision would remove the last legal obstacle to a full-scale criminal
investigation of the former dictator and would permit his trial on charges of
kidnapping, murder and torture.

The president of the court, Hernan Alvarez, said the justices would release
their opinion formally sometime next week. "We are not going to make any
statements," said Mr. Alvarez, after the 20 justices consulted for four hours
today. "The Supreme Court has instructed me merely to say an agreement was
reached."

But neither he nor any other court or government official disputed the reports,
all attributed to anonymous sources close to the Supreme Court and the
presidential palace, and all widely disseminated among Chileans.

The vote, reported as 11 to 9, had been expected after the court's 11-to-9
rejection last week of a defense motion to proceed with medical tests of the
former dictator before ruling on his immunity.

"I am very content," said Juan Bustos, a lawyer for human rights victims
involved in the case against General Pinochet. "The report surging through the
courthouse is that we have won and General Pinochet no longer has immunity from
prosecution." There were no public reactions from General Pinochet's lawyers or
family.

With the decision, the Supreme Court has apparently upheld a ruling made in May
by the Chilean Court of Appeals, which was also disclosed to many of the same
news organizations more than a week before it became official. Observers have
theorized that the courts and government are using the technique to try to
soften reactions and control the size of demonstrations supporting and opposing
General Pinochet.

Lawyers arguing the case against General Pinochet maintained that there was
enough evidence linking him to disappearances and other crimes that he should be
stripped of his senatorial immunity. Never elected to the Senate, General
Pinochet took his life-time seat in 1998 under a constitutional provision
written during his 17-year dictatorship.

The case against General Pinochet gathered momentum here after he was arrested
in London in 1998 on a Spanish warrant for many serious rights violations. He
was freed for health reasons four months ago and allowed to return to Chile, but
his standing in society and even among the military leaders and right-wing
parties has suffered.

During the proceedings, no evidence ever linked the general definitively to any
single crime. But prosecutors are hoping that his deteriorating legal status
will encourage several retired officers who are already imprisoned to testify
that the former dictator was aware of their crimes or helped cover them up.

"This is just the beginning of the legal process and there will need to be a
long investigation to gather proof," said Ricardo Israel, a political scientist
at the University of Chile. "For a conviction, some eyewitness or document has
to come forward, otherwise the evidence is all circumstantial."

Mr. Israel and many other experts say General Pinochet, who is 84 and suffers a
variety of health problems, will probably die before he can be convicted. But
for many critics of his government, the fact that he could face justice in
Chilean courts at all is a giant step toward a full civilian-based democracy.

Sebastian Brett, the Human Rights Watch representative in Chile, said the
court's stripping of General Pinochet's immunity would signify "the most
important decision in Chilean judicial history." He added, "It would show that
dictators are not above the law in their country."

Judge Juan Guzman, who is prosecuting the Pinochet case, is now expected to
force the general to answer a long series of questions meant to link him to a
case involving 19 people who disappeared soon after the 1973 coup that brought
him to power. The 19 are believed to have been executed on the orders of top
Pinochet aides.

The general's lawyers say he is not guilty in the executions and disappearances
of more than 3,000 people. But during the Supreme Court hearings last month they
argued that he was not healthy enough to stand trial because he was unable to
direct his lawyers adequately.

However, they said any tests of the former ruler for mental illness would be
unacceptable. That claim will probably set up the next legal test, since under
Chilean law all criminal defendants over 70 must receive a medical examination
before trial, and mental illness may prevent legal proceedings to go forward.

General Pinochet's legal maneuverings appear intended to broaden defendants'
due-process protections to include physical illnesses as well as mental health
problems.

                 August 22, 2000, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

Editorial Observer;
In Chile, the Balance Tips Toward the Victims

BYLINE: By TINA ROSENBERG

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 851 words


Until the last few weeks, testimony about the horrors committed by the Chilean
military after Gen. Augusto Pinochet's coup in 1973 has virtually all come from
one side, the victims'. The military refused to cooperate with Chile's truth
commission, and provided very little information for the families of those who
disappeared.

The man who walked around Santiago's National Stadium with a television reporter
recently represented something new for Chileans. Roberto Saldias was a soldier
in 1973. He talked about the executions he witnessed in the stadium. He named
one perpetrator and promised to identify others in court.

The television appearance of Mr. Saldias is one more sign of Chile's
transformation. After nearly a year of discussion between military leaders and
human rights advocates, the armed forces pledged to help find the bodies of
victims if those with information could remain anonymous. And earlier this
month, the supreme court stripped General Pinochet of his legislative immunity,
providing the first real chance that he could stand trial.

The change in Chile is in part due to the passage of time, which has brought a
new generation of judges into office. But the catalyst for their new
assertiveness was the arrest of Mr. Pinochet in Britain on a Spanish warrant in
1998. That arrest caused reverberations elsewhere and led to the detention of
Chad's former dictator in Senegal, although the courts later released him. Other
arrests of tyrannical leaders could follow. But for now, Mr. Pinochet's capture
has left a deeper footprint in Chile, where it has changed the balance of power.

New democratic or reformist governments that lack power over the old guard can
do little to reckon with the past. This was true of Chile until recently, and of
most of Latin America's former military dictatorships. Typically, the generals
retain their guns and can at any moment point them at civilian heads. It is also
the case in most nations of the former Soviet Union, where top Communist
officials retain positions of influence and can block any moves to bring the old
regime's criminals to account.

Very few countries have given victims acknowledgment of their suffering or
families information about lost loved ones. Those that have done so possessed
the power to threaten the collaborators or murderers with exposure or trials if
they did not talk. Germany opened the files of the secret police, or Stasi, to
its victims. It had not anticipated that as a result, many ex-informers would
contact their victims to sit down and talk. Their motive is damage control --
they know they will be caught. But it has produced a healthy outpouring of
discussion about why people collaborated and allowed many Stasi victims to hear
personal confessions from their spies.

Another country that has given some psychological healing to victims is South
Africa. The unique feature of its truth commission -- those who confess to
crimes can get amnesty from prosecution -- has broadened South Africa's
reckoning with the past. Instead of trials in only a few high-profile cases,
which is all the country could very likely afford, dozens of victims got to hear
confessions and relatives of the murdered learned what happened to their loved
ones.

This could happen only because the government of Nelson Mandela could credibly
threaten the old apartheid killers with real jail time if they did not talk. If
Mr. Pinochet's successors in Chile had tried this, the military would simply
have laughed.

That changed with Mr. Pinochet's arrest. His detention tipped the balance of
power in Chile and unleashed desires for justice that people had buried for a
quarter-century. It also allowed Chile to press for testimony, offering the same
deal as South Africa's truth commission. The military men who signed agreements
in Chile to provide information on the 1,200 people still missing did so because
for the first time, they run a real risk of prosecution for the forced
disappearances. If Mr. Pinochet is tried in Chile, it will be under a new
interpretation of a general amnesty he decreed in 1978 -- mainly benefiting his
own forces. The courts now say that if the body in a case has not been found,
the case is ongoing and can be prosecuted. If a body is found, the case becomes
a murder -- and therefore covered by amnesty. So soldiers can escape trial for
disappearances by producing the bodies.

The world community could help achieve similar accountings in other countries if
the International Criminal Court were up and running. Established two years ago
in a treaty signed by 120 nations -- the United States not among them -- the
court will try those accused of genocide and other heinous crimes. It offers the
hope of international justice for those too powerful to be tried at home. But it
will also provide an outside threat of justice that could strengthen a nation's
own ability to try its criminals.  The International Criminal Court could help
solve a central problem of dealing with the past -- that nations most in need of
trials are least likely to be able to hold them.

Mexican Environmentalist Is Found Guilty

BYLINE: By The New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 3; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 218 words

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 28


In closing a case that has led to outrage among environmental groups around the
world, a district judge in the state of Guerrero sentenced Rudolfo Montiel
Flores today to almost seven years in prison for drugs and weapons crimes.

Environmental groups consider Mr. Montiel, 44, a political prisoner, saying his
only crime was to organize protests against loggers who were cutting forests
around his village north of Acapulco.

Last year, gunmen killed several members of rural ecological group led by Mr.
Montiel. In May 1999, Mr. Montiel said that he was detained and tortured by
soldiers who forced him to sign statements that confessed to marijuana
cultivation and possession of illegal arms.

This summer, the Mexican National Human Rights Commission said that his rights
had been violated, that evidence against him had been planted.

Mr. Montiel, a poor indigenous farmer, was arrested and convicted with a friend,
Teodoro Cabrera Garcia, who was sentenced today to 10 years in prison.

Lawyers for the men pledged to appeal the sentences and to help organize
protests to reignite interest in the case.

Leaders of Amnesty International in Mexico City said they would urge
President-elect Vicente Fox Quesada to dismiss the sentences against the two men
after he takes office in December.

Justice in East Timor

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 172 words



To the Editor:

Re "Indonesians Differ on Penalties for the Past" (news article, Aug. 27):
Forceful prosecutions of those who committed rights abuses in Indonesia and East
Timor are necessary if Indonesia is to build a democratic future. Elements of
the Indonesian military continue to create mischief -- for example, by backing
militias that harass East Timor and block the return of refugees.

An international tribunal should be set up to deal with crimes against the East
Timorese since 1975, when Indonesia illegally invaded its neighbor. Last
January, a United Nations investigation recommended a tribunal for military and
militia violence during last year's independence plebiscite. Creating a tribunal
is especially urgent now that Indonesia's consultative assembly has amended the
Constitution to let the abusers off the hook, crippling its own prosecutors'
ability to try past injustices.

JOHN M. MILLER
Brooklyn, Aug. 27, 2000

The writer is media coordinator for the East Timor Action Network.

Pinochet Appeal for Unity

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 96 words

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 4


Gen. Augusto Pinochet, 84, facing a possible trial for human rights abuses
during his 17-year dictatorship, urged Chileans today to put the past behind
them and focus on the future.

He released a letter to the Chilean people saying, "I hold in my heart the hope
that our divisions and yesterday's pain are overcome and that we will look to
the future in benefit of new generations."

It was read by his granddaughter, Maria Jose Martinez, at his residence in
Santiago. Gen. Pinochet did not speak. In August, the Supreme Court stripped him
of his immunity from prosecution.

Journalists Under Siege

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 482 words


The editors of two opposition newspapers in Congo are facing the death penalty.
Emile-Aime Kakekese Vinalu's crime was writing two articles that analyzed a tiff
between high-level officials, complained of disunity in the opposition and said
that those who speak their minds get arrested for crimes against state security.
The government of Laurent Kabila then proved him right. Then Jean-Pierre Ekanga
Mukuna was arrested, apparently for refusing to give authorities Mr. Vinalu's
home address. Both men are charged with high treason.

The beleaguered editors in Congo have plenty of company. A Serbian journalist,
Miroslav Filipovic, is now serving a seven-year sentence for espionage and
disseminating false information after he reported on the Yugoslav Army's war
crimes in Kosovo. As parliamentary elections approach in Azerbaijan, authorities
have arrested the editor of an opposition newspaper on trumped-up charges that
he participated in a hijacking attempt. In Paraguay a reporter was run over by a
car driven by the security chief of the nation's former comptroller, who is
accused of corruption.

The world is seeing an epidemic of government attempts to silence independent
journalists, less through murders than through legal harassment and physical
threats. Paradoxically, the new repression is in some ways a sign of progress.
Azerbaijan was not persecuting independent journalists 10 years ago, because it
had none. Most nations now attacking journalists are quasi-democracies and so
must put up with at least some independent media. But their leaders use libel
suits and threats to stop reporters from investigating corruption, and often
jail journalists and shut media down for tax offenses or other pretexts during
political campaigns.

Ultimately, respect for a free press comes with democratic development and
economic growth, in part because only a robust private sector can provide enough
advertising to give the media independence. But a free press is also an integral
part of both kinds of progress and needs more help from the outside today.
Several international groups provide lawyers for accused journalists, and
independent media in places such as Serbia get a big percentage of their budgets
from Western governments and nongovernmental groups. But these donors tend to
concentrate on high-profile nations.

Another strategy is to try to discourage attacks by exposing them. Turkey, whose
bid to join the European Union depends on its civil rights record, has responded
to visits from the Committee to Protect Journalists by releasing some jailed
writers and reporters. But exposure only works when governments take press
freedom seriously. Liberia recently arrested a British TV crew investigating
reports of diamond smuggling by President Charles Taylor. When African leaders,
including Nelson Mandela, complained, Mr. Taylor released the four men.

http://www.nytimes.com

Pursuit of Democracies

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 147 words



To the Editor:

The criticism of Australia by the United Nations Committee for the Elimination
of Racial Discrimination (news article, Aug. 31) should serve as a reminder.

There is a movement in the liberal democracies to yield sovereignty to agencies
that purport to monitor human rights abuses. Amnesty International, for one, has
trained its sights on the United States. Let us not deceive ourselves. Most of
the United Nations member countries despise Western democracies, with the United
States topping the list.

The targets of the United Nations' zeal will be the democracies, not the rogues
and despots of the world. The Western circles who are pressing for an
International Criminal Court, for instance, will not see Sierra Leone's
machete-wielding criminals in the docket, but American soldiers.

EDWARD J. PRENNER
Forest Hills, Queens, Aug. 31, 2000

http://www.nytimes.com
