                December 2, 2000, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

MEXICO PRESIDENT INSTALLED, VOWING TO SHARE POWER

BYLINE: By GINGER THOMPSON

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1200 words

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1


Vicente Fox Quesada, a son of ranchers who became a business executive, was
inaugurated as president of Mexico today, promising that in the dawn of Mexico's
first real democracy, he would share power long monopolized by one party.

After swearing before Congress to uphold the Constitution, Mr. Fox, 58, accepted
a satiny red, white and green presidential sash from the outgoing chief
executive, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, who by law could not seek re-election.
In that brief moment, Mr. Fox became the first opposition politician in 71 years
to take the presidency away from the Institutional Revolutionary Party. Before
the rise of the PRI, as that party is known, all of Mexico's rulers had come to
power by force or political imposition.

In an inaugural address before Congress, Mr. Fox spoke liltingly at times about
the occasion, which he described as a "triumph for all."

He invoked the names of Mexico's most beloved reformers, many of them
assassinated at the peak of their crusades, and promised that his government
would live up to their ideals. Then he laid out plans for a new kind of Mexican
government: one in which the voice of opponents would not be snuffed out or
ignored; one that would serve the interests of the poor before those of the
rich; and one that would fight discrimination, corruption and human rights
abuses.

Although he will lack a majority in Congress, Mr. Fox said he would press ahead
with his campaign promise to establish a kind of truth commission to investigate
unsolved corruption scandals and political assassinations. He received rapturous
applause from members of Congress when he pledged that his government would not
push to privatize electricity plants or sell the national oil company, Pemex,
considered a pillar of Mexican sovereignty.

Mr. Fox said he would try to be the president Mexico has never had, one who
accepts and even enjoys having his power balanced by a divided Congress, strong
state governors and grass-roots organizations that directly represent the
people.

"I differ radically from the old view that power is not to be shared," he said.
"I will share the power, and also the responsibilities. I am the guardian of
power, not its owner.

"I will not be a do-all president," he said. "Ending with us is the age in which
the president was omnipresent on the national stage. It is no longer one person,
or one government that is responsible for the destiny of the nation. All of us,
in the trenches of our daily lives, have a role to play in the great struggle
for a better Mexico."

Mr. Fox's most forceful overtures were aimed at Mexico's Indian people, who make
up about 10 percent of the population but who have almost no political and
economic influence.  In his inaugural address, Mr. Fox lamented that most
indigenous people continue to suffer "intolerable injustice, marginalization and
inequality." Their communities struggle against levels of illiteracy, hunger and
poverty that dwarf the national averages.

The new president said he would assume direct responsibility for creating more
opportunities for indigenous people to take part in government activities, and
for guaranteeing their political rights.

He also used the speech to send a message of peace to the conflict-ravaged state
of Chiapas, where rag-tag groups of indigenous guerrillas took up arms against
the government six years ago to protest against generations of injustice and
other abuses. Mr. Fox said he would immediately seek the legislature's approval
of reforms that had been proposed four years ago by a group of congressional
mediators. The reforms reflected many of the rebels' demands, but were blocked
by the Zedillo administration.

Mr. Fox has said many times since he was elected in July to a six-year term that
he was ready to meet with the Zapatista guerrillas and accept some of their most
important demands -- including removing a number of government troops from the
region. But the Zapatistas never replied.

Then, 48 hours before Mr. Fox's inauguration, the best-known Zapatista leader,
who calls himself Subcommander Marcos, ended the rebels' silence by issuing a
scathing farewell to President Zedillo, calling his six years in office "a
nightmare." And Subcommander Marcos also said he would hold a news conference on
Saturday, in the Chiapas jungle, to talk about the Fox administration. As if in
response, Mr. Fox today ordered troops to withdraw from some positions
encircling the Zapatista rebels, his national security adviser, Adolfo Aguilar
Zinser, told Reuters.

Having risen to power on the wave of a national desire for a shift to democracy,
Mr. Fox, the father of four adopted children, started his presidency with an
inauguration day filled with activities aimed at setting him apart from his
predecessors.

Just after sunrise, he went to pray at the Basilica de Guadalupe, the shrine to
Mexico's patron saint. A Catholic, he was the first modern president ever to
publicly receive a blessing by a priest before taking office.

It was an unusual religious display by a head of state in a country that has had
a bloody tradition of enforcing the separation of church and state. Later, in
the middle of his speech at the national auditorium, his youngest daughter,
Paulina, a teenager, ran up to the podium to give him a gift of a crucifix.

Mr. Fox also had breakfast with hundreds of homeless children, mental health
patients and street vendors in the outcast community of Tepito.

In another break with tradition, he gave two speeches during the day rather than
one. He started his formal inaugural address with a tender "hello" to each of
his children. And afterward, he delivered a funny and humble speech to an
auditorium filled with supporters.

Rather than bestowing power privately upon his new cabinet, he inaugurated them
on live television. He read aloud government ethics rules, which prohibit
members of the cabinet from taking money from any sources that would compromise
their integrity. And then he made them swear to uphold those rules.

At dusk, he stood out on the balcony of the National Palace and led tens of
thousands of Mexicans in a patriotic rally at the Zocalo, the plaza at the
center of the capital. But after delivering another speech, the president took
off his ceremonial sash, his suit jacket, tie and cuff links, and waded into the
crowded plaza, where he sat on a stage among the people. Later, he held an
elegant dinner for visiting dignitaries at the 18th century castle in
Chapultepec Park.

It was a whirlwind day, and as Mr. Fox rushed from one event to the next, it
became clear that even though he was now president, he would continue to keep
the pace of a candidate. His staff said he felt most comfortable among ordinary
people. And during his speeches, the new president, whose preferred style of
dress includes jeans, cowboy boots and wide-brimmed hats, reminded Mexico that
"I have my boots well set on the ground."

But because Mr. Fox's National Action Party will not have the majority in
Congress, the new president is expected to continue to campaign in order to
harness public support for the deep and contentious reforms he aims to carry
out.

Rebel's Death Laid To Guatemala Army

BYLINE: By The New York Times

SECTION: Section A;  Page 17;  Column 1;  Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 255 words

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 6


An international tribunal ruled today that the Guatemalan Army was guilty of
murder, torture and other crimes in the case of a left-wing guerrilla who
disappeared in 1992, a lawyer in the case said today.

The Inter-American Court of Human Rights, a branch of the Organization of
American States, found that the Guatemalan military had killed Efrain Bamaca
Velasquez, a captured Mayan rebel leader, and obstructed justice after the
killing, said Denise Gilman, a human rights lawyer in Washington. Ms. Gilman
represents Mr. Bamaca's widow, Jennifer K. Harbury, an American lawyer who went
on hunger strikes in Guatemala City and in Washington to press for classified
information on her husband's case. The court sits in San Jose, Costa Rica.

A White House panel found in 1996 that the Central Intelligence Agency knowingly
hired as paid informers a number of Guatemalan military officers suspected of
political assassinations, extrajudicial killings, kidnapping and torture. One
Guatemalan Army officer on the C.I.A. payroll, the panel said, "ordered and
planned assassinations of political opponents," a second took part in
"assassinations or assassination attempts," and a third "participated in
assassination, extrajudicial killing and kidnapping."

The White House panel said that one of those C.I.A. agents, a Guatemalan colonel
named Julio Roberto Alpirez, took part in the interrogation and torture of Mr.
Bamaca. The international tribunal's ruling today firmly fixed responsibility on
the Guatemalan military.

WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 926 words



ASIA

AFGHANISTAN: TALIBAN ACTS OVER SANCTIONS -- The ruling Taliban responded to
tough new United Nations sanctions by pulling out of United Nations-mediated
talks on ending Afghanistan's civil war and refusing any handover to the United
States of the terrorism suspect Osama bin Laden. The Taliban also ordered an
immediate boycott of products from the United States and Russia.  (AP)


INDIA: POLITICIAN FACES LEGAL ACTION -- The western state of Maharashtra said it
would pursue legal action against a hard-line Hindu politician, Bal Thackeray,
who advocated that India's 120 million Muslims be deprived of the right to vote.
Chief Minister Vilasrao Deshmukh said his remarks were contrary to the
Constitution and "hurt the feelings of Muslims."
 Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

EUROPE

TURKEY: PRISON SIEGE CONTINUES -- Soldiers smashed through the walls of two
prisons to battle inmates reportedly armed with guns and makeshift
flame-throwers as the fight for control of 20 prisons entered its second day. At
least 19 people were dead, and the European Commission warned that tactics used
by Turkey were again calling into question its human rights record. Prime
Minister Bulent Ecevit said raids on 18 other prisons had ended a two-month
hunger strike.
 (AP)

DENMARK: FOREIGN AIDE QUITS -- Foreign Minister Niels Helveg Petersen resigned,
saying he could no longer support Denmark's ambivalence in committing to the
European Union. Mr. Petersen, 61, an influential member of the Radical Left
Party, which shares power with the Social Democrats, said he was deeply
disappointed by a Sept. 28 referendum in which Danes rejected the euro. He said
his departure was not a protest directed at Prime Minister Poul Nyrup Rasmussen,
a leading euro advocate.
 (Agence France-Presse)

ITALY: CATHEDRAL BOMB THEORY -- The police investigating an unexploded bomb
found in Milan's cathedral suspect it may be linked to a Spanish anarchist
group, Italian news agencies reported. A group called International Solidarity
claimed responsibility in a message to the Roman daily Il Messaggero, saying it
opposed conditions at top security prisons in Italy and Spain. The message also
attacked the Roman Catholic Church and its Holy Year.  Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

GERMANY: EMBRYO RESEARCH CONDEMNED -- Officials criticized British plans to
permit research on human embryos, with Hubert Huppe, deputy chairman of
Parliament's ethics committee, calling the technology "cannibalism." He said the
move to allow stem cells to be used in developing new medical treatments
breached fundamental human rights. And Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, in an
article in Die Woche, said the case for using human embryos in research was not
proven.
 Victor Homola (NYT)

SPAIN: E.T.A. TIED TO POLICE SHOOTING -- A Barcelona policeman was shot dead by
two unidentified people believed to be members of the Basque separatist group
E.T.A. They fled the scene, leaving a car loaded with more than 28 pounds of
explosives, according to the police, who said the two may have planned an attack
in the city, site of two recent E.T.A. killings.
 Emma Daly (NYT)

SPAIN: EDITORS' PLEA ON GUSINSKY -- Senior editors from Vladimir Gusinsky's
Russian media empire have written to Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar asking that
Madrid deny Moscow's request to extradite the businessman on a fraud charge.
They accused Russian prosecutors of falsifying documents in order to "blackmail"
Mr. Gusinsky, in a Spanish prison pending the extradition hearing, into selling
his companies, which have long been critical of the Kremlin.
 Emma Daly (NYT)

AFRICA

RWANDA: COOPERATION ON DOWNED JET -- The government said for the first time that
it would cooperate with an inquiry into the downing of a presidential jet that
set off the killing of more than 500,000 minority Tutsi and moderate Hutu in
1994. President Juvenal Habyarimana died in the plane attack. The Tutsi-led
government said it would back an investigation by prosecutors for the
International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, who are considering whether to
include the April 6, 1994, plane crash in their genocide review.
 (AP)

THE AMERICAS

COLOMBIA: BRITONS FREED -- Two Britons kidnapped in the Darien Gap rain forest
on Colombia's Panamanian border were freed after nine months, the British
Embassy said. Paul Winder and Tom Hartdyke were abducted in the same region
where three American missionaries disappeared in 1993. The Darien Gap is a
roadless swatch of jungle and rivers where left-wing rebels and right-wing death
squads battle.  Juan Forero (NYT)

CANADA: CHINESE SUE OVER OLD TAX -- Three Chinese- Canadians have filed a class
action suit seeking $15 million in damages for a head tax that was levied on
80,000 Chinese entering Canada between 1885 and 1923. Levied solely on Chinese
immigrants, the tax reached $500 in 1923, when it was replaced by the Exclusion
Act, which barred Chinese immigration until abolished in 1947.  James Brooke
(NYT)

TRINIDAD: FINAL ELECTION RESULTS -- Final election results showing that Trinidad
and Tobago's governing party won a majority in Parliament were delivered to
President Arthur Robinson, a key step toward installing a new government. The
final results, nine days after the election, showed Prime Minister Basdeo
Panday, left, and his United National Congress winning 19 seats, to 16 for the
opposition People's National Movement and one for the National Alliance for
Reconstruction.  (Reuters)

Germany Shuts East German Crime Bureau

BYLINE: Agence France-Presse

SECTION: Section A; Page 5; Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 171 words

DATELINE: BERLIN, Dec. 28


Germany's top crime-fighting agency for offenses committed under the former East
Germany closed its doors today after nine years' work.

The Central Investigations Body for Government and Unification Crime said it had
wrapped up its operations, which since its founding on Sept. 1, 1991, included
more than 20,000 cases.

More than 16,000 of its cases involved charges against the East German
government, including what were later deemed human rights violations, like
orders to shoot to kill people crossing what was then the border with West
Germany and the state-run program of using barred drugs to increase athletic
performance.

The investigations body helped to bring accusations against dozens of former
East German border guards.

Most of them received light sentences in the German courts after they argued
that they had been following the orders of superiors.

The office looked into cases of drugging involving about 9,000 former East
German athletes -- many of whom suffered lasting health problems.

PUBLIC LIVES;
Making Her Case Against Foreign Leaders

BYLINE: By JOYCE WADLER

SECTION: Section B; Page 2; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 858 words


A JURY in Manhattan came down hard on Radovan Karadzic this week, ordering the
former Bosnian Serb wartime leader to pay $4.5 billion in damages to victims of
rape, torture and genocide.

The case is one of a series of suits brought against foreign leaders by the
Center for Constitutional Rights in recent years, all of which have had a
similar outcome: a huge money judgment that everyone agrees will be impossible
to collect.

Everyone, that is, except Jennifer Green, one of the lawyers who argued the
Karadzic case in federal court in Manhattan.

"It's going to be hard," Ms. Green says -- an understatement, with Dr. Karadzic
at large. And of the other cases, she says, "No money has been collected yet."

You never say never, do you?

"That's my attitude," Ms. Green, 38, says firmly. "Look at the Holocaust cases
that 50 years later are getting settled. The clients don't get involved because
they expect to see a judgment tomorrow, they do it to hold the person
accountable. And the judgment can have other effects besides the transfer of
money. The case we had against Gramajo" -- the former Guatemalan defense
minister Hector Gramajo, sued for damages regarding murder and torture -- "he
was being groomed for the presidency of Guatemala, and he's no longer a
candidate."

A pleasing memory, which makes the lawyer grin.

"He was sued on his graduation day from the Harvard School of Public Policy, in
'91. It was my graduation day, too -- I went to Harvard Law. There was a great
picture of him being served in The Boston Globe. I showed it to my mother and
said, 'This is what I'm going to do.' "

There are human rights types who are deadly serious. Then there is Jennifer
Green. She is serious about her work, all right: there are 12-hour days, an
office crowded with files, and of course the nightmare she had after the
Karadzic trial ended. An interesting look into the soul of the lawyer, that
nightmare.

But she also laughs a lot, particularly at herself, little self-deprecating
contrapuntals of, "Yeah, right, Jen," or remonstrations for her Midwestern
accent: "God, I sound like Fargo, and they were two states away."

Home was the college town of Madison, Wis., where her father was an electrical
engineer and her mother a teacher who was involved in social services. Ms.
Green's mother may have pointed her toward activism -- looking out for an elder
brother who was born with a heart defect and a learning disability made Ms.
Green protective -- but it was Marlon Brando who took her concerns global.

He blows into Wisconsin on behalf of the Menominee Indians, and before you know
it Ms. Green is on the Amnesty International mailing list.


AS for the Karadzic case, with which she has been involved since 1993, Ms. Green
can tell you the stories of the 13 plaintiffs who testified, all of whom were
Bosnian Muslims who suffered at the hands of Serb soldiers. Sometimes doing
this, she uses the tag "John" or "Jane," used in court to protect identities.
Sometimes she skips a name, for there were many Johns and Janes who could not
face the ordeal of testifying.

"John One," Ms. Green begins, looking down, her arms folded protectively.
"Soldiers pulled his teeth out with pliers. He was forced to perform sexual acts
with other male prisoners. He also testified about people being decapitated,
then the soldiers forced them to play soccer with the people's heads. Yeah, they
could be real creative. John Two, he was so badly beaten he has trouble now
turning his head. John Three, he's a man named Dr. Emil Kapetanovic: he was
forced to stand naked against the wall, also to play Russian roulette. They
tortured him with the door open so other people could hear."

She turns, when that accounting is over, to the women.

"Jane One, she was 16 years old at the Trnopolje concentration camp, taken out
of a line where she was waiting for water and gang-raped. Jane Two and Three
withdrew."

Moving on.

"Jane Seven was waiting for a bus in Sarajevo with her husband -- we showed
footage of the bombing in Sarajevo at the trial. The last thing she remembered
was looking at her watch, then looking at her husband, who had been blown in
half."

She talks about the pain involved in eliciting that testimony.

"In terms of our clients, we were constantly on the alert for whether we were
retraumatizing them in some way. Some questions you don't ask. There were issues
about people having trouble sleeping."

How was it for the lawyers?

"A couple of the others said they were having troubles with nightmares. I was
O.K. until the trial ended; then it hit me."

Ms. Green's nightmare, the telling of which requires prompting:

"Someone was being chased, I couldn't stop something from happening." A prompt.
"Someone was going to get killed, it was a kid, it was in the woods, which some
of our clients had been describing. I came up and saw this thing happening." A
prompt. "No, it wasn't a gun. It looked like a knife. Then I woke up."

The nightmare recurred later the same night. The second time, though, Ms. Green
was able to change the ending.

What happened the second time?

"I got the kid and ran."

SECTION: Section A; Page 2; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

INTERNATIONAL   A3-10

Britain Says Health Makes Pinochet Unfit for Trial
Britain said medical tests showed that Gen. Augusto Pinochet was unfit to stand
trial in Spain on charges of crimes against humanity and that it was inclined to
drop the extradition case against him and let him return to Chile.   A1


Seeking Women's Help in Chile
Ricardo Lagos, the Socialist presidential candidate, is making an 11th-hour
effort to gain the women's vote in hopes of winning a runoff election against
Joaquin Lavin, a former aide to Gen. Augusto Pinochet and once considered a long
shot.   A10

U.S. Pledges Aid to Colombia
The Clinton administration announced a $1.3 billion, two-year emergency aid
package to fight narcotics in Colombia, deepening American involvement in that
country's long war against narcotics traffickers and rebels.   A4

Barak Breaks Silence on Talks
Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel, speaking in a television interview, said
the peace talks with Syria had reached a decisive stage in which both sides
would have to make difficult decisions.   A3

A Trial Over the Holocaust
The revisionist historian David Irving delivered his opening statement in the
libel case he brought against an American author and her British publisher. Mr.
Irving, who has said that Hitler did not approve the mass killing of Jews, says
his reputation was irrevocably damaged by the book's assertions that he is a
Holocaust denier who manipulates history to serve his own ends.   A7

China Is Pressed on Rights
The Clinton administration said China's human rights record had continued to
deteriorate and that the United States would again sponsor a United Nations
resolution criticizing Beijing for crackdowns on political dissent and religious
freedom.   A10

Russia Reviews Battle Plan
Russian officers provided accounts of the fighting in Shali that has alarmed
Moscow and prompted a close review of Russia's military strategy in Chechnya.
The rebel offensive has raised questions of whether Chechnya can ever be made
fully secure for Russian forces.   A3

World Briefing   A6

NATIONAL   A12-21

Court Backs States' Rights In Age-Discrimination Case
The Supreme Court ruled, 5 to 4, that Congress lacked the authority to bind
state governments to a federal law that bars bias against older workers. It was
the first of five federalism rulings due this term.   A1

The justices heard arguments on the Violence Against Women Act.   A18

Expanding a National Monument
President Clinton declared more than 1,500 square miles along the Grand Canyon's
northern rim a national monument, doubling the size of federally protected land
there.   A12

Greater Tax Aid for the Poor
President Clinton plans to propose a $2 billion-a-year increase in the earned
income tax credit for 19 million families living below or just above the poverty
line.   A17

McCain's Plan for Taxes
Senator McCain proposed a tax cut half the size sought by Gov. George W. Bush
and pledged that as President he would seek a Congressional vote on a plan to
overhaul the Social Security system in his first year.   A20

Postage Rate Rise Proposed
The Postal Service's Board of Governors proposed raising the price of a
first-class stamp by 1 cent, to 34 cents, early next year.   A16

U.S. May Not Sell Its Nickel
The Energy Department is backing away from a plan to sell its stock of surplus
nickel, a metal used in stainless steel and other alloys, because of concern
that the material, left over from nuclear weapons manufacture, may be too
radioactive.   A17

Fatal Journey for Stowaways
Officials in Seattle said 3 of 18 stowaways died in cargo containers aboard a
ship from Hong Kong. Hong Kong authorities pledged a crackdown on such
trafficking in illegal immigrants, which is on the rise.   A1

I.N.S. Delays Repatriation
The I.N.S. said it would extend its Friday deadline for returning Elian Gonzalez
to Cuba. Although the decision came a day after a Florida judge granted
temporary custody to a relative of the boy's in Miami, the I.N.S. said it
retained jurisdiction.   A12

Students' Expulsions Stand
A federal judge upheld the expulsions of six students who brawled at a football
game in Decatur, Ill.   A12

NEW YORK/REGION   B1-10

Economic Boom Would Fuel Pataki's Spending Plans
Governor Pataki proposed a $76.8 billion budget that relies heavily on the
state's prosperity to finance higher spending for schools, environmental
projects and prison construction and an array of tax cuts.   B1

An Emphasis on Technology
Governor Whitman, in her sixth annual address to the New Jersey Legislature,
proposed $100 million in new spending to help researchers convert their
scientific advances into thriving businesses, and to help train "the high-tech
work force of tomorrow."   B5

New Hudson Bridge Urged
The Tappan Zee Bridge has become so dilapidated and is so congested that it
should be torn down and replaced with a new eight-lane bridge with commuter rail
tracks at a cost of $4 billion, a state panel said.   B1

Judges Hear Museum Case
Three federal appellate judges questioned City Hall's rationale for cutting
funds for the Brooklyn Museum of Art over an exhibition of art that many people
found sacrilegious.   B3

Try Pinochet Anyway

SECTION: Section A; Page 32; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 78 words



To the Editor:

Re "Pinochet Is Ruled Unfit for a Trial and May Be Freed" (front page, Jan. 12):

Under the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet in Chile, ill health did not
excuse a person from being tortured.

Why should it now excuse General Pinochet from being tried for those crimes
against humanity?

TRACY FITZSIMMONS
Redlands, Calif., Jan. 12, 2000

The writer is a professor of Latin American politics at the University of
Redlands.

                January 15, 2000, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

New Twist in the Pinochet Case

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 485 words


Britain's declaration that Gen. Augusto Pinochet is medically unfit to stand
trial should not be the final word on this matter. More information is needed,
and it can be provided under a reasonable plan proposed yesterday by the Spanish
judge who is seeking to prosecute the former Chilean dictator for human rights
abuses.

Under the plan, outlined by Judge Baltasar Garzon, two doctors appointed by his
Madrid court would take part in a new examination of Mr. Pinochet, who has
suffered a series of minor strokes. The result of that exam, and an earlier one
performed solely by British physicians, would be made available to Judge Garzon.
He would then determine whether Mr. Pinochet should be spared a trial because of
mental impairment and an inability to understand the charges.

This case is too important to set aside without a second medical opinion, and
without giving the Spanish court access to the doctors' reports. The British
government has not shared the results of the first examination with the Spanish
court.

If Mr. Pinochet is found by the Spanish court to be unfit, even some of the most
fervent advocates for prosecution would have to agree that justice would not be
served by proceeding against an enfeebled man.

The case has already made a profound contribution to international law. It
established that even former heads of state do not enjoy impunity for crimes
against humanity, and may be tried outside the country where the crimes were
committed. It has also had a liberating effect on Chile. When General Pinochet
was arrested in London in October 1998, many feared that the charges would
destabilize Chile's transition to democracy. As Chileans prepare to vote for a
new president this weekend, it appears the opposite has occurred.

Between 1973 and 1990 General Pinochet presided over the murder or disappearance
of more than 3,000 Chileans and the torture of thousands more.  His intimidation
was so complete that he and his associates escaped prosecution for a decade
after he stepped down. But since his arrest, emboldened Chilean courts have
issued rulings that have shaken the military's immunity. More than two dozen of
his former officers have been arrested for murder and kidnapping. Former
political prisoners are preparing to file the first criminal complaint accusing
General Pinochet and some of his former officers of torture.

None of this has disturbed Chile's fledgling democracy. On the contrary,
Chileans have experienced the first presidential campaign since his coup in 1973
that was not distorted by the polarizing legacies of General Pinochet. The
candidates -- Ricardo Lagos, a Socialist, and Joaquin Lavin, a former official
in General Pinochet's government -- have stressed everyday problems like health
care, crime and unemployment. It suggests that those who feared the
destabilizing power of justice underestimated its healing effect.

Doubting Pinochet Is Unfit, Spaniard Calls for 2d Opinion

BYLINE: By AL GOODMAN

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 580 words

DATELINE: MADRID, Jan. 14


The Spanish judge behind efforts to try Gen. Augusto Pinochet for human rights
abuses asked Britain today for a second medical examination of the former
Chilean dictator to determine if earlier tests erred in ruling him unfit to
stand trial.

The judge, Baltasar Garzon, in a written opinion, appealed to Home Secretary
Jack Straw, who announced on Tuesday that he was inclined to release General
Pinochet, 84, after nearly 15 months of house arrest in Britain, because four
British doctors recently deemed him unfit for trial.

The results of that examination, conducted on Jan. 5, were released only to the
British government and general's defense lawyers.

Judge Garzon said that two forensic doctors appointed by his Madrid court should
take part in the new examination and that his court should get the results of
both tests. Under Spanish law, General Pinochet could be excused from trial only
if he were mentally impaired and could not understand the charges.

"It constitutes a universal negative precedent," the judge warned the British
government, "to avoid a criminal proceeding for unknown medical reasons."

Mr. Straw has set a deadline of next Tuesday to receive comments from Spain and
other parties to the case. But in a fresh sign of the political overtones of the
proceedings, the Spanish government said it might not send Judge Garzon's
petition through diplomatic channels to London if it does not contain new
elements for the case.

Foreign Minister Abel Matutes said today that the judge's document had arrived
at his ministry, but he promised only that it would be studied over the weekend.

Spain's conservative government has publicly maintained neutrality in the case,
which has put relations with Chile under strain. But many advocates of putting
General Pinochet on trial for rights abuses during his 1973-90 military rule
charge that Madrid has been working behind the scenes to undercut Judge Garzon's
effort.

Joan Garces, a Spanish lawyer representing victims of repression in Chile,
expressed confidence that Judge Garzon's petition would reach London by next
week's deadline.

The Chilean government has readied a military jet to whisk General Pinochet home
to Chile if Mr. Straw sets him free.

Judge Garzon wrote that physical impairment and old age would not be sufficient
grounds for exclusion from trial. He cited the cases of Klaus Barbie, a Gestapo
official in occupied France, and the French Nazi collaborator Maurice Papon, who
were tried and convicted of war crimes despite their advanced ages and physical
ailments.

England's highest court, the Law Lords of the House of Lords, has ruled that
General Pinochet is not immune from prosecution for acts committed while he was
a head of state.

Judge Garzon indicted General Pinochet in December 1998, after his arrest on
Oct. 16, 1988, on charges of genocide, terrorism and torture in connection with
the killing or disappearance of more than 3,000 people. But Britain's highest
court later limited the charges to 35 counts of torture and conspiracy to
torture alleged to have occurred after 1988.

Judge Garzon's petition said it was "repugnant" to consider the release of
General Pinochet on humanitarian grounds without knowing his medical condition.

But the judge acknowledged the power of the Home Office to make what he termed a
"political decision" to end the extradition proceeding. "This seems to be the
last step of this troubled extradition process," he said.

                 January 23, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

Gentle Negotiations Said to Soften Taliban's Rules for Women

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

SECTION: Section 1; Page 6; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 842 words

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 21


Three years after the Taliban took control of most of Afghanistan and introduced
a harsh and unforgiving Islamic piety that all but obliterated women from public
life, relief and development experts say that months of quiet negotiation with
Taliban leaders are beginning to dent the prohibitions.

Erick de Mul, coordinator of United Nations relief programs in Afghanistan, said
in an interview this week that it might be time to begin adjusting the picture
of Afghanistan under the Taliban, which he said had brought peace to much of a
country battered by civil war -- but then had no program to rebuild it.

"It's not as black and white as it's often depicted," said Mr. de Mul, who was
in New York for consultations.

As Mr. de Mul, who is Dutch, talks about the small advances that the United
Nations and a host of relief agencies are making in Afghanistan, the new picture
that emerges is of a strongly absolutist movement hitting the wall of daily
reality.

"There is mounting pressure from the population itself," said Mr. de Mul, who
accepts that the Taliban were first welcomed by Afghans, who had had enough of
corrupt and violent rule by the mujahedeen, the Muslim warriors who drove out
Soviet troops in the 1980's. "People are expecting more than peace and security.
'We want to have a better future for our children,' they say. 'We want to have
possibilities to work.' "

Aid workers and the Taliban have together learned a valuable lesson in recent
years, Mr. de Mul said. When talks break down, he said, "we go to this point and
say, O.K., let's leave it for a while and discuss it later on."

"It's all very slow, and many, many times inconclusive, but the important thing
is that there is a dialogue, and increasingly it is possible to call a spade a
spade -- to go more directly to the issue," he said.

Schools for girls are opening, some officially and many others privately in
homes, Mr. de Mul said. In recent months, he added, Taliban authorities have not
enforced an edict prohibiting foreign Muslim women from going out in public
without a close male relative. Aid experts have tried to assign Muslims from
other countries to work with Afghans because of their sensitivity to the tenets
of Islam and because they offer an alternative model of Islamic womanhood, most
immediately to the Afghan co-workers. But foreigners know that pushing too hard
is counterproductive.

"Demanding changes in law is not working yet," he said. "So the other thing is
to create realities that become so strong that eventually the reality will
determine the legal framework." It is not a policy supported by most human
rights groups or the Clinton administration, which has imposed sanctions on
Afghanistan because of its support for terrorism and its violations of women's
rights. The United States does not allow Americans to be assigned there by the
United Nations.

The United Nations World Food Program -- headed by an American woman, Catherine
Bertini, who is based in Rome -- has made large strides in bringing women into
the work force in Afghanistan, Mr. de Mul said. "W.F.P. is pushing the right
agenda in an intelligent way -- with a lot of results," he said.

In Jalalabad, an eastern Afghan city near Pakistan, the closing of smugglers'
routes that brought in subsidized Pakistani wheat created a food crisis
recently. The World Food Program, with access to donated wheat, decided to open
bakeries.

"In order for us to do that, we said, O.K., we have to send people out to make a
survey of households," Mr. de Mul said. "We said we want to have 50 percent male
and 50 percent female surveyors, otherwise there is not going to be a bakery
project. This took about two weeks of them saying, 'No, it can be done by men;
there is no need for women.' In two weeks they came around and said, 'That's
fine.' "

Mr. de Mul said that even in Kandahar, a bastion of orthodoxy and the
headquarters of the Taliban's leader, Emir Muhammad Omar, changes are
noticeable, in part because of a good provincial governor, Mullah Hassan, who is
both a devout Muslim and an administrator in tune with popular opinion.

In Kandahar province, the United Nations and private agencies are training
health workers, opening schools for girls and boys and helping local councils
known as shuras.

"Six months ago, there was a meeting of a number of the shuras of the southern
region in Kandahar," Mr. de Mul said. "It was a three-day event where
representatives of all these community organizations came together. The Taliban
authorities were invited. The governor of Kandahar opened it." The meeting ended
with a statement of priorities.

"The first priority was education, and education for girls and boys," Mr. de Mul
said. "Second, they wanted to have more and better trained traditional birth
assistants, midwives. Third, they wanted to have increased possibilities for
women to be gainfully employed, especially widows.

"So you take the three priorities, and almost all refer to women. But all the
representatives at the meeting were men."

                 January 28, 2000, Friday, Late Edition - Final

Burmese Troops Overrun Base of Rebels Who Took Hostages

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 643 words

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 27


The small jungle base of God's Army, the Burmese rebel band that took hundreds
of people hostage at a Thai hospital this week, was overrun by the army of
Myanmar today, Thai officials said.

Dissidents living outside Myanmar, the former Burma, said the base was captured
early this morning. They said that 50 people had been captured but that the fate
of the twin 12-year-old boys said to lead the group, Johnny and Luther Htoo, was
not immediately known.

Ten gunmen from the group, which is made up of ethnic Karen separatist fighters,
were killed on Tuesday after taking hundreds of people hostage for 22 hours in a
hospital in the Thai border town of Ratchaburi.

Thai human rights groups are demanding an investigation into reports that the
gunmen were summarily executed by security forces who raided the hospital.

Thai newspapers quoted unidentified commandos as acknowledging that they had
shot some of the gunmen in the head even though they were not acting
aggressively. They said they had done this in the heat of the fast-moving
pre-dawn raid, to protect their own lives.

God's Army, a fundamentalist Christian band of no more than 200 fighters, had
been under intense attack at their hideout inside Myanmar for the last two
weeks.

The gunmen who took over the hospital had sought to stop Thailand's artillery
attacks on the rebels, which the Thais said were intended to prevent them from
fleeing across the border into Thailand.

A Thai intelligence officer told The Associated Press that about 100 fighters
fled their camp today, with the twins leading one of two groups.

God's Army is a splinter group from the main Karen separatist group, the Karen
National Union, which is one of several ethnic insurgencies that continue to
battle the government despite a series of peace agreements during the 1990's.

The Karen National Union issued a statement today saying its longtime leader, Bo
Mya, 73, had been removed from command. They said the decision had been made at
a scheduled leadership meeting and had nothing to do with the actions of the
God's Army group.

The larger insurgency claims to have 12,000 fighters along the 1,000-mile border
between Thailand and Myanmar. Independent estimates put the number closer to
3,000.

In the wake of the takeover, the police in Ratchaburi said unidentified callers
had made bomb threats against another local hospital, a school and a department
store. Residents said schoolchidren and shoppers had gone out into the streets
as the buildings were searched.

If the Htoo twins are still alive, it is not clear what their ragtag insurgency
might have the strength to do next. It has little support among other
insurgencies or Burmese dissidents, who depend on Thailand for sanctuary. The
Karen National Union joined a virtually unanimous condemnation by Burmese
dissident groups of the takeover.

Even the larger insurgencies have been on the defensive for several years. In
the early 1990's the Karen fighters lost all their main bases.

After the hospital takeover, Thai public sentiment has turned strongly against
the rebels and the 100,000 Burmese refugees taking shelter in camps just inside
Thailand.

U.S. Weighs Refugee Need

By The New York Times

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Thailand has yet to ask the United States to accept 1,500
new Burmese student refugees, but a State Department official said today that
the United States "would be willing to consider taking more refugees if there is
a need."

The United States has agreed to resettle 600 student refugees from Thailand this
year. The students fled Burma after the military coup in 1988 and have been
refugees in Thailand for more than a decade. The official said they had no
connection to the Burmese guerrilla group that stormed a Thai hospital this
week.

World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 889 words



EUROPE

BRITAIN: TORIES EXPEL ARCHER -- Jeffrey Archer, a flamboyant member of the House
of Lords and best-selling novelist, was expelled from the Conservative Party for
five years for having concealed damaging details of a 1986 scandal involving a
prostitute that forced him to give up his candidacy in November for the first
elected mayor of London. The party's ethics and integrity committee said his
behavior was "reprehensible." He called the punishment "grossly unfair."
Warren Hoge


BOSNIA: SREBRENICA COMPLAINT -- A group of survivors of the 1995 massacre of up
to 8,000 Bosnian Muslims in Srebrenica tried to file a complaint at the
international war crimes tribunal in The Hague, charging Secretary General Kofi
Annan and other officials with partial responsibility for failing to protect the
town. Fred Eckhard, Mr. Annan's spokesman, said the tribunal does not allow
individuals to bring cases, saying that right rests solely with its chief
prosecutor, Carla del Ponte.   Barbara Crossette

UKRAINE: PARLIAMENT PROTEST -- Left-wing legislators holed up in Parliament
resumed a protest session for a third day. The lawmakers have said they fear
that opponents may storm the building and turn it over to a pro-government
majority that walked out last month and has been holding rival sessions in an
exhibition hall. Parliament split on Jan. 20, when some 250 deputies left in
protest at the refusal of the leftist speaker, Olexander Tkachenko, to put to a
vote a motion calling for his dismissal.   (Reuters)

GREECE: APRIL 9 VOTE -- Prime Minister Costas Simitis called for early elections
in an attempt to win a fresh mandate to negotiate Greece's entry to the European
Monetary Union this year. The announcement of the April 9 vote, five months
earlier than scheduled, puts an end to speculation and nervous trading on the
Athens stock market.   Anthee Carassava

THE AMERICAS

MEXICO: DEATH THREATS -- The Miguel Agustin Pro Juarez Human Rights group, one
of whose lawyers was tied up and interrogated by masked men in October, has
received new death threats. After the Inter-American Rights Court ordered the
government to protect Miguel Pro workers last fall, the threats ceased. But a
recent message left at the group's offices said: "We let you rest, but what's
coming will be the fun part. Now let's see if your foreign accomplices help
you."   Sam Dillon

ASIA

JAPAN: ILLEGAL SHOES -- It is now illegal to wear platform shoes while driving
in Osaka, Japan's second largest city. The Osaka police said thick soled shoes,
which have become the latest fashion among young Japanese women, are a safety
hazard. The crackdown comes after a young woman wearing six-inch platform boots
crashed into a pole, killing a friend riding in the passenger seat last
November.   Calvin Sims

JAPAN: SECT'S OFFICES INSPECTED -- More than 200 security officials held their
first inspections of Aum Shinrikyo centers under a new law aimed at controlling
the activities of the religious sect, which recently changed its name to Aleph.
The inspections, which civil libertarians have said are unconstitutional, do not
require a search warrant.   Calvin Sims

PAKISTAN: KASHMIR HOLIDAY -- On the eve of "Kashmiri Solidarity Day" in
Pakistan, the military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, made another strident
statement, vowing never to "allow Indian threats to intimidate us." The
government has declared a public holiday to focus national attention on the
Kashmir dispute.   Barry Bearak

EAST TIMOR: MASSACRE EVIDENCE -- United Nations forensic experts have uncovered
evidence of an organized massacre of East Timorese in Oceussi, a seaside enclave
surrounded by Indonesian West Timor. Twenty-six bodies and other partial remains
have been found, one with execution-style gunshot wounds and others with
injuries that appeared to have been caused by machetes.   Barbara Crossette

AFGHANISTAN: MEASLES EPIDEMIC -- A spreading measles epidemic in a remote part
of Afghanistan has killed at least 100 people, the United Nations said. The
outbreak began in the northern Samangan Province, an area where fighting between
the ruling Taliban and an opposition alliance was fierce last year. Many people
are displaced across terrain that can be reached only by donkey convoys.
Barbara Crossette

MIDDLE EAST

IRAN: CARTOON ENRAGES CLERICS -- Thousands of clerics in the holy city of Qum
called for the execution of Culture Minister Ataollah Mohajerani, saying his
ministry's relaxed stance toward the news media allowed Ayatollah Mohammad Taqi
Mesbah Yazdi, a senior hard-line cleric, to be portrayed as a crocodile in a
newspaper cartoon. In Muslim cultures, crocodiles are associated with treachery.
"Death to Mohajerani!" some 4,000 clerics chanted during their protest.   (AP)

AFRICA

IVORY COAST: 'BLACK BOX' FOUND -- Divers brought up a "black box" of a Kenya
Airways jet that crashed into the Atlantic with 179 people aboard, leaving only
10 known survivors. The device was the flight data recorder, said a French
aviation official. The cockpit voice recorder remains submerged. Investigators
are hoping the black boxes will shed light on why the Airbus 310 plunged into
the Atlantic moments after takeoff on Sunday.   (AP)

General Rejects Liability for Timor Abuses

BYLINE: Agence France-Presse

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 173 words

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 8


The former Indonesian military chief, General Wiranto, said in an interview
today that he would not accept personal or legal responsibility for any crimes
committed by his troops in East Timor, despite having been implicated in the
atrocities by a national human rights panel.

He broke a weeklong silence in an interview with The Straits Times of Singapore,
hitting back at the panel that was set up to investigate the violence that
flared in the former Indonesian terrority in September 1999. General Wiranto has
been resisting pressure from President Abdurrahman Wahid -- who is on an
overseas tour -- to resign as senior security minister.

In his defense, General Wiranto cited as an example the My Lai massacre of
villagers in Vietnam by American troops. "When one of the U.S. officers in
Vietnam during the Vietnam War killed a number of innocent villagers, the My Lai
incident, I don't think the commander in chief of U.S. troops in Vietnam, or the
Joint Chiefs of Staff, was asked to be legally responsible," he said.

THE WORLD: INDONESIA'S PRESS;
The Victor Is a Victim In Liberty's Triumph

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1018 words

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia


IN the nearly two years since Indonesia's strongman, Suharto, stepped down in
May 1998, it is the press that has been the most free, and the most tumultuous,
of Indonesia's institutions. It has been the fundamental underpinning for the
continuing move toward a democratic society.

But in some ways today it is also a victim, not just a protagonist, in the
liberation -- and disorder -- it has helped unleash.

Its condition reveals a lot about the chaotic freedoms of the new Indonesia,
where the harsh hand of the dictator has often given way to the unpredictable
passions of the mob.

In many arenas the rules that governed, and often stifled, the nation have been
eased or removed or simply ignored. As a result -- as in many newly liberated
nations -- Indonesia's road from repression to democracy is wild and uncertain.

This week, the focus of change is on the military, with President Abdurrahman
Wahid returning Sunday from a foreign trip to confront his most prominent
general, Wiranto, who has so far refused the President's demand to resign.

The general, accused of human rights abuses, represents the old guard that,
under Mr. Suharto, saw itself as standard bearer and enforcer of a top-down
regime known for corruption, repression, and the silencing of dissent.

Since Suharto's fall, the military has been retreating under the pressure of a
popular demand for civilian rule. But its new weakness in the eyes of society
comes with a social cost: It has contributed to the uncertainties and
instabilities the nation faces.

"At the present moment," said Susanto Pudjosumatono, chief editor of the daily
Jakarta Post, "who cares about the law? Street justice is the order of the day.
Mobs deal with thieves and burglars. Police are caught red-handed as burglars.
Villagers loot estates. Communal conflicts are flaring. People resort to
violence to settle disputes."

This is the arena in which the press now operates.

Freed of the fear of arrest or the closure of their newspapers, editors no
longer censor themselves to please authorities. But self-censorship is alive
among editors of newspapers both big and small. It is the mob they fear.

When Christian churches were burned on the island of Lombok recently, one
newspaper, sidestepping the religious conflict, declined to identify them,
calling them blandly "houses of worship."

When mobs demonstrated in the eastern Indonesian city of Ujungpandang late last
year, local editors said they refrained from revealing the instigators for fear
that the mobs would turn on them as well.

In the central Javanese city of Solo, the most devastated city in the huge riots
of early 1998, armed thugs have threatened reporters in their newsroom. Even in
the capital, Jakarta, not long ago, a mob protested outside the offices of
Tempo, the nation's leading magazine, vandalizing vehicles.

Clear and professional reporting can be the most difficult in the places where
it is most needed, places like Ambon and Aceh where separatist or communal
conflicts threaten to touch off a nationwide backlash.

Bambang Harimukti, the editor of Tempo, said that to assure that his reports are
complete and unbiased he must consider sending in non-local staff members who
leave the area as soon as their reporting is done.

"It is not the authorities wielding their power who are the biggest threat
anymore," Mr. Susanto said. "Now the clear and present danger comes from the
people."

In this unstable arena, the press has played a crucial role in keeping the
country's political and social evolution more or less on course. As an
independent institution, its reforms came quickly, leading the way into a new
atmosphere of openness.

"With all the changes we've seen, the press is perhaps Indonesia's most
transformed institution," said Warief Djajanto, an executive at the Indonesian
news agency, Antara.

In the first 18 months after Mr. Suharto stepped down, 1,500 press licenses were
issued by the liberal-minded new minister of information, Yunus Yosfiah.

Then, under a new press law passed last fall, the requirement for licenses was
abolished. Nobody knows now how many newspapers and radio stations have joined
the babble around the nation, but they have contributed to a brand new sense
that anything goes.

The best of the newspapers offer serious political reporting and analysis,
investigations of corruption and military abuses, high-stakes policy debates and
fundamental explorations of new directions for Indonesia.

But with so many new outlets, the country suffers from a crippling shortage of
trained journalists and much of what is printed and aired lacks fundamental
elements of accuracy and fairness.

With so few resources, some small newspapers do not even pay their reporters.
They simply issue them press cards and leave them to seek whatever fees and
payoffs they can earn from their sources.

"When we organize training for young reporters, many lack professionalism both
in journalistic competence and in ethical competence," Mr. Susanto said.

Defense Minister Juwono Sudarsono, in a recent interview, complained of
widespread tabloid journalism.

"We have a vigorous press but it is often a vigorous and irresponsible press,"
he said. "A lot of hopes have been placed in the press but I don't think these
hopes have been fulfilled."

PERHAPS those hopes were too high at this early stage. Without the free press,
flawed as it is, Indonesia might have made far less progress than it has.

When Mr. Suharto was president, just about every institution in Indonesia had
one thing in common: from the courts to the bureaucracy to the military to the
press, they were tailored to serve his interests.

When he departed, he left intact a venal and self-serving legislature, a
power-hungry military and a thoroughgoing culture of corruption that, without
the pressure of an overwhelming popular will, might well have reverted to their
old ways.

They never had a chance. Suddenly, political talk shows filled the airwaves, an
unfiltered puree of wisdom and nonsense.

But at their heart was a powerful momentum for change.

Character Test

SECTION: Section 4; Page 12; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 151 words



To the Editor:

"The Next President's Duty to Intervene" (Op-Ed, Feb. 13), by Michael Ignatieff,
clearly conveys the tug-of-war between national interests and values. Americans
want a president with a strong moral character and a conviction to lead by our
values, not merely our national interests. But global stability has become both
a national interest and an American value, so a president must respond to the
threat of genocide or "ethnic cleansing" not only in Europe but also in Africa,
Asia and the Americas.

Human rights issues never win presidential campaigns, but character will surely
be important in this one. Let us keep prodding candidates to clarify their plan
of action or inaction in situations of genocide. Let them reveal their character
and convictions.

ANTHONY J. KOZLOWSKI
Minneapolis, Feb. 14, 2000

The writer is president of the American Refugee Committee.

Russian War Crimes?

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 136 words



To the Editor:

Re "Chechens Tell of Torture in Russian Camp" (news article, Feb. 18): The
heinous acts of rape, murder and torture described as being committed by Russian
troops are certainly human rights violations. But there are broader
implications. If the stories are true and substantiated, these acts are war
crimes under international law. Further, if these practices are widespread or
systematic, they may rise to the level of crimes against humanity.

We should not shy from calling these acts by their rightful names. During the
last decade we waited too long to apply the appropriate name to events in
Bosnia, Rwanda and elsewhere. Let us not repeat this error.

ALAN DORSEY
Washington, Feb. 18, 2000

The writer is deputy director of the Crimes of War Project at American
University.

                  March 13, 2000, Monday, Late Edition - Final

Pope Asks Forgiveness for Errors Of the Church Over 2,000 Years

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1349 words

DATELINE: ROME, March 12


Saying "we humbly ask forgiveness," John Paul II today delivered the most
sweeping papal apology ever, repenting for the errors of his church over the
last 2,000 years.

"We cannot not recognize the betrayal of the Gospel committed by some of our
brothers, especially in the second millennium," the pope, dressed in purple
robes for Lent, said in his homily. "Recognizing the deviations of the past
serves to reawaken our consciences to the compromises of the present."

The public act of repentance, solemnly woven into the liturgy of Sunday Mass
inside St. Peter's Basilica, was an unprecedented moment in the history of the
Roman Catholic Church, one that the ailing 79-year-old pope pushed forward over
the doubts of even many of his own cardinals and bishops. He has said repeatedly
that the new evangelization he is calling for in the third millennium can take
place only after what he has described as a church-wide "purification of
memory."

To underline the apology's religious significance, seven cardinals and bishops
stood before the pope and cited some of the key Catholic lapses, past and
present, including religious intolerance and injustice toward Jews, women,
indigenous peoples, immigrants, the poor and the unborn.

The pope also mentioned the persecution of Catholics by other faiths. "As we ask
forgiveness for our sins, we also forgive the sins committed by others against
us," he said.

At the beginning of his pontificate, John Paul's boldest gestures were on the
political front, confronting Communism in the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and
Latin America and also challenging human rights violations and the economic
injustices of capitalism. But the apology, issued in the twilight of his papacy,
is theologically more daring.

His effort to cleanse his church's conscience for the new millennium has already
drawn criticism, but it is almost certain to mark his legacy deeply.

"The apology does not just apply to individuals, but the church as a whole, and
that is very important," the Rev. Lorenzo Albacete, who teaches theology at St.
Joseph's Seminary in Yonkers. "Because it reflects this pope's desire to
reconcile with other Christians and other religions, people are tempted to view
it as a tactic, but its immense spiritual importance to this pope lies in the
fact that it did not come within a diplomatic or theological agreement, but in
the liturgy of the Mass during Lent and the Holy Year."

The pope, broadening a process of reconciliation that began in the 1960's during
the Second Vatican Council, has issued apologies before, notably regretting in a
1998 document the failure of many Catholics to help Jews during the Holocaust.
That document, "We Remember: A Reflection on the Shoah," disappointed many
leading Jewish groups, which complained that the pope did not go far enough in
apologizing for the silence of church leaders, including the wartime pope, Pius
XII.

Today, in the prayer dedicated to "confession of sins against the people of
Israel," John Paul did not mention the church's behavior during the Holocaust,
just as he did not elaborate on other sins of the church. He said, "We are
deeply saddened by the behavior of those who in the course of history have
caused these children of yours to suffer, and asking your forgiveness we commit
ourselves to genuine brotherhood with the people of the Covenant."

Rabbi Marvin Hier, dean of the Simon Wiesenthal Center, called today's apology a
"bold and important step forward," but added that he was disappointed that the
pope had not mentioned the Holocaust explicitly. "The church still wants to
steer clear of dealing with the role of the Vatican during World War II," he
said.

The pope also acknowledged that church followers had "violated the rights of
ethnic groups and peoples and shown contempt for their cultures and religious
traditions." He deplored divisions between Catholicism and other branches of
Christianity, and also discrimination against women. "Given the number of sins
committed in the course of 20 centuries," Bishop Piero Marini, who is in charge
of papal ceremonies, said before the Mass, "it must necessarily be rather
summary."

The need for Catholics to examine their collective conscience is something that
this pope has been thinking about for years, and he laid out his rationale for
it in a 1994 apostolic letter called "The Coming of the Third Millennium." He
also raised the subject privately in meetings with key cardinals, and his
proposal was sufficiently ground-breaking that they requested that the
theological and historical implications first be studied in depth.

The result was a dense 31-page treatise by the International Theological
Commission, which, with Vatican oversight, ground out the theological precedents
and also the limits to the apology.

Written by a committee and released earlier this month, the document addresses
concerns that the apology will be misunderstood or misused by those "hostile to
the church." It also reflects other worries of theologians, who had to grapple
with such complex issues as how a church that considers itself holy can admit
mistakes, and whether it is fair for today's church to condemn acts by previous
generations made in good if misguided faith.

The document explains that the church is holy, but is stained by the sins of its
children, and requires "constant purification." It implies but does not directly
address the delicate issue of whether past church leaders also erred.

"The document should have put it in bold print that 'children of the church'
includes popes, cardinals and clergy, and not just people in the pews," the Rev.
Thomas Reeves, editor of the Jesuit magazine America, commented. "The pope had a
great idea that some in the Vatican are obscuring with a fog machine."

The document also cautions against judging past generations by today's moral or
religious standards, and says today's believers cannot be held responsible for
sins committed by Catholics hundreds of years ago.

It nevertheless concedes that there is "an objective collective responsibility"
for past errors that modern Catholics should acknowledge and repent.

At a news conference last week, Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, who heads the
Vatican's Congregation of the Doctrine of the Faith, the modern successor to the
Inquisition, addressed the issue of why the church feels ready to concede error
now, and not in earlier times.

Protestantism and the Enlightenment "created a new historiography of the church,
claiming that it was not just stained by sin but completely corrupt, so the
church had to build up a Catholic historiography to combat it," he explained. He
said the collapse of atheist, totalitarian systems had left the church "in a new
situation of freedom to return to our sins."

But the difficulty for theologians and church historians to determine what
exactly constituted knowable error during the Crusades, the Inquisition, holy
wars, the burning of heretics and the forced conversions of Indians and
Africans, led to a more elliptical reference to "sins committed in the service
of truth." Cardinal Ratzinger prayed that Catholics would recognize "that even
men of the church in the name of faith and morals, have sometimes used methods
not in keeping with the Gospel."

The pope said, "Christians have at times given in to intolerance and have not
been faithful to the great commandment of love, sullying in their way the face
of the church." But he did not note specific episodes in the church's history
like the Crusades or the Inquisition.

John Paul, who rode up the basilica aisle on a rolling platform, a
strength-saving device he has been using since Christmas, read his homily in a
clear, firm voice that belied the palsied trembling of his hands, a symptom of
Parkinson's disease.

The pope's act of repentance was so unusual that some Catholics predict that it
will take time for its full importance to sink in.

"This is an entirely new thing," said the Vatican spokesman, Joaquin
Navarro-Valls. "I think it will take years for the church to absorb it."

WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 997 words



EUROPE

NETHERLANDS: 3 APOLOGIES -- The government apologized to Jews, Gypsies and
Indonesians for a "chilly" official response in the past to their claims to
property seized during and after World War II. Prime Minister Wim Kok said the
government had to face up to "mistakes and shortcomings" made in the 1940's and
offered $180 million, in addition to past restitutions, to the Central Jewish
Congress. Gypsies received an extra $13 million. Indonesians who sided with the
Dutch during Indonesia's fight for independence in 1949 were offered $110
million.   Marlise Simons (NYT)

GERMANY: BERTELSMANN JOINS FUND -- Bertelsmann, the German media company that
owns Random House, said it would contribute to a $5 billion fund to compensate
Nazi-era slave and forced laborers, but declined to say how much. The company is
in the process of revising its corporate history in the light of evidence that
it did not, as it previously contended, oppose Hitler's regime. Contentious
talks on how the fund should be divided will resume here today.   Roger Cohen
(NYT)


NETHERLANDS: CROAT HANDED OVER -- A Bosnian Croat accused of war crimes was
handed over to the United Nations tribunal in The Hague, where he arrived with a
psychiatrist and other medical personnel. Mladen Naletelic, 54, a former
military commander, was indicted for persecution, torture and murder of Muslims
in Bosnia in 1993 and 1994. The new Croatian leadership, in contrast to past
governments, accepted tribunal doctors' findings that he was well enough to
stand trial.   Marlise Simons (NYT)

IRELAND: ORANGEMEN IN DUBLIN -- Northern Ireland's Orange Order, whose summer
parades of men in bowler hats and orange sashes regularly plunge the province
into turmoil, has been invited by Dublin officials to march there in May. "We
have the right of free assembly here," Lord Mayor Mary Freehill said. A Sinn
Fein spokesman compared Ms. Freehill's action to "the state governor inviting
the Ku Klux Klan to march in Alabama."   Warren Hoge (NYT)

THE AMERICAS

CHILE: PINOCHET IN HOSPITAL -- Gen. Augusto Pinochet, 84, entered a clinic for
tests after fainting in his residence outside Santiago. The clinic would not
comment on the condition of the former dictator, who returned to Chile on March
3 after spending 16 months under house arrest outside London on a Spanish
warrant charging him with human rights violations.   Clifford Krauss (NYT)

COLOMBIA: REBELS BLACK OUT CITIES -- Power was cut to a huge swath of central
and northeast Colombia, including the capital, Bogota, and at least six other
cities, after a wave of sabotage attacks by Marxist rebels opposed to a selloff
of the state power industry. At least eight of the country's 32 provinces,
including oil-producing regions of the northeast, were hit by the cuts. The
privatizations were ordered by the International Monetary Fund as part of a $2.7
billion loan deal.   (Reuters)

MONTSERRAT: VOLCANO IS NEW THREAT -- The newly active Soufriere Hills volcano
hurled glowing rocks high into the sky, setting off fiery avalanches and shot a
thundering ash cloud as high as 30,000 feet, scientists said. The explosion sent
a new coat of ash over parts of the island's northern "safe zone," where
residents have been living since the volcano began erupting in 1995. Since then,
7,000 of the 11,000 residents have left for other Caribbean islands and Britain.

   (AP)

ASIA

JAPAN: EX-AIDE ADMITS HARASSMENT -- The former Governor of Osaka, Japan's
second-largest city, admitted for the first time in court that he had groped a
21-year-old campaign worker last year. Until now, Isamu Yamada, a former
comedian who still uses his stage name, Knock Yokoyama, had denied accusations
of sexual harassment while agreeing to pay a large civil settlement. Mr.
Yokoyama resigned after his indictment for sexual molestation.   Calvin Sims
(NYT)

PHILIPPINES: WAR ON REBELS -- President Joseph Estrada said he had ordered "all
out" military action against Muslim separatist guerrillas in the south. He also
announced on a visit to Kauswagan that the mayor would go on leave after
accusations by residents that he fled when guerrillas of the Moro Islamic
Liberation Front occupied the Kauswagan town hall last week in fighting that
left at least 21 people dead.   (Agence France-Presse)

MIDDLE EAST

IRAN: ALBRIGHT REBUKED -- In its latest response to Washington's decision to
ease economic sanctions, the foreign ministry rebuked Secretary of State
Madeleine K. Albright and other officials for a "lack of honesty" and "ignorance
of the geography of the region." The statement appeared aimed less at the moves
announced by Dr. Albright than at remarks she made later in India that made note
of divisions over policy toward the United States between Iran's democratic
reform movement and a hard-line faction associated with the ruling clerics.
John F. Burns (NYT)

AFRICA

COMORO ISLANDS: COUP ATTEMPT FOILED -- The army foiled a coup attempt and a son
of a former president was in custody, officials said. Shots rang out in Moroni,
the capital, but no casualties were reported. Officials said they believed that
the action, the 19th coup or attempted coup since independence from France in
1975, was led by two sons of the islands' first president, Ahmed Abdallah, who
was assassinated in 1989. They said one son, a former agriculture minister, had
been arrested.   (Reuters)

ZIMBABWE: SQUATTERS STAY PUT -- White farmers whose properties were illegally
occupied by war veterans in a demand for land reform said there was no
indication that the police had acted to evict the squatters within 24 hours, as
ordered by the High Court on Friday. The court said that if the squatters
refused to leave, the police were to forcibly remove them after 72 hours, a
deadline that expired late Monday.   (Agence France-Presse)

INTERNATIONAL   A3-13

Pope Deplores Plight Of Displaced Palestinians
John Paul II described the plight of Arab refugees as "degrading" and "barely
tolerable" during a stop at Yasir Arafat's residence in Bethlehem. Israeli
officials pointed out that the statements did not go beyond established Vatican
positions.   A1

The pope, during a visit to a refugee camp, articulated a more empathetic
understanding of the hardships of refugee life than many Palestinians would have
heard for quite some time, had the remarks been translated from English into
Arabic.   A8


Hopes for Syria-Israel Talks
President Clinton's coming meeting with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria could
lay the groundwork for renewed talks between Syria and Israel, but no deal is
imminent, diplomats in the Middle East said.   A9

New View of Iraq's Bombs
A former high-ranking official in Iraq's secret nuclear weapons program says
that before the 1991 Persian Gulf war, Iraqi students in the United States
combed university libraries for bomb-building information and Iraqi agents and
scientists collected valuable data at American scientific conferences.   A10

An Appeal to India
President Clinton, in a speech to Parliament, asked India to renounce its
nuclear weapons. He reminded India's leaders that the United States and Russia
planned to sharply reduce their stockpiles.   A6

Taiwan Leader to Quit Party
President Lee Teng-hui has yieldied to demands that he step down as chairman of
the governing Nationalist Party, party officials said.   A3

No Deal on Khmer Rouge Trials
A team of United Nations negotiators left Cambodia after failing again to reach
agreement with the government on the ground rules for a trial of the surviving
leaders of the Khmer Rouge.   A3

Turkey Split on E.U. Entry
Turks are fervently debating whether their nation should make the profound
political changes, improve its human rights record, repeal laws that limit free
expression and give more cultural rights to Kurds, steps that are necessary for
membership in the European Union.   A5

Lawyers Spend to Fight Bush
Trial lawyers are spending huge amounts of money from the nationwide tobacco

Still Making Moonshine
A state and federal task force has arrested three people on charges of illegally

 J.L. Chestnut, the lawyer for Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin, left, formerly known as

The economy of the New York region is not expected to suffer seriously if the

rise to as much as $2 a gallon by summer and then begin dropping by fall.   B1

The state health commissioner, Antonia Novello, announced that investigators had

from a case in which a urologist removed the wrong kidney of a 79-year-old

criminal investigation.   B1

Prosecuting Pinochet: Washington Should Help

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 152 words



To the Editor:

If the prosecution efforts in Chile and Argentina are to succeed, the United
States must take a more active role (Editorial Observer, March 21). The Chilean
military is starting to use against the newly elected government the same
tactics of intimidation that it used against the Salvador Allende government. It
has announced that if Gen. Augusto Pinochet is brought to trial, there is a risk
of a civil war.

The United States should publicly support the efforts of the embattled Chilean
judiciary to prosecute General Pinochet and other human rights violators. The
F.B.I. has acknowledged that it worked in liaison with the Pinochet government;
the United States should provide the Chilean judge in charge of the prosecution
with documents related to these events.

CARLOS MORENO
New York, March 21, 2000

The writer is a lawyer for Chilean exiles in the United States.

Understanding Kashmir

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 153 words



To the Editor:

Contrary to what Pankaj Mishra implies (Op-Ed, March 22), the Indian government
remains the best instrument for upholding human rights in the state of Kashmir.
The terrorists in Kashmir should be stopped, not appeased. Indian security
forces are repressing armed violence, not discontent.

Indian secularism views all of India, including Kashmir, as the common homeland
of all the Indian people. Many Kashmiri Muslims are dissatisfied with the
actions of Indian security forces, but that does not derogate the rights of
secular Muslims and non-Muslims in Kashmir to receive the protection of the
Indian Constitution.

Indian security forces have committed excesses in Kashmir, but the Indian
government has made persistent efforts to maintain their discipline while
conducting an extraordinarily difficult anti-terrorist operation.

SANJOY BANERJEE
Union City, Calif., March 22, 2000

http://www.nytimes.com
