INTERNATIONAL   A3-11

Israel-Syria Peace Talks Are Put on Indefinite Hold
The Clinton administration said the resumption of the Israeli-Syrian peace talks
had been postponed indefinitely, after Syria demanded that its major negotiating
point -- Israel's withdrawal from the Golan Heights -- be settled immediately.
Both sides will send experts to Washington to provide comments on the draft
treaty that has been written by the United States.   A1

Dispute Over Arms Inspector
Secretary General Kofi Annan called back the Swedish arms control expert Rolf
Ekeus, left, who uncovered and destroyed large quantities of Iraqi weapons after
the gulf war of 1991, to lead a new United Nations commission created to finish
the job more than a year after monitoring broke down. But Russia formally
objected, putting the appointment in doubt.   A1


Jailed Kurdish Rebel Seeks Role
Abdullah Ocalan, assured for the moment that he will not be hanged, wants to
take part in the incipient national dialogue in Turkey about how the country
should deal with its Kurdish minority. But Turkey's prime minister ruled out a
role for Mr. Ocalan.   A10

New Offensive in Chechnya
Russian warplanes and artillery bombarded Grozny in a new offensive that Russian
commanders hoped would bring their siege of the breakaway republic's capital to
a decisive end. Benefiting from clear skies, Russian aircraft carried out a
record number of attacks on Grozny, according to Russian press reports.   A1

Mayor to Miss Holocaust Event
Mayor Eberhard Diepgen of Berlin has decided not to attend a ceremony paving the
way for a large Holocaust memorial in the German capital, a project he has long
opposed. The ceremony, to be attended by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, President
Johannes Rau and Elie Wiesel, is intended to put to rest a decade of tumultuous
debate over the memorial.   A3

Pinochet Re-examination Asked
Spain sent Britain a petition seeking a second medical examination of Gen.
Augusto Pinochet to determine if earlier tests wrongly declared him unfit to
stand trial for human rights abuses.   A3

China Anoints 'Living Buddha'
Chinese authorities presided over the enthronement of a 2-year-old boy as an
important "living Buddha" in the Tibetan religion, the official New China News
Agency reported. The government-in-exile of the Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual
leader, said it would not approve the choice.   A4

Report on Hunger and Weight
A study of global trends said the number of overweight people in the world now
rivals the number of hungry, underfed people. The report says the two extremes
are increasingly found in all societies, poor as well as rich, although in
differing proportions.   A10

World Briefing   A6

NATIONAL   A14-21

Gore and Bradley Tangle on Racial Profiling
Bill Bradley challenged Vice President Al Gore to press President Clinton to
issue an executive order banning racial profiling. In the debate in Des Moines a
week before the Iowa caucuses, Mr. Gore fired back with a forceful defense of
the president.   A20

Mr. Gore appeared with Coretta Scott King at a Martin Luther King Day ceremony
in Atlanta.   A20

Rally Against Rebel Flag
Tens of thousands of people marched in Columbia, S.C., to demand that the
Confederate flag that flies over the Statehouse be removed from public life.
Officials said the racially diverse marchers numbered 46,000, far surpassing the
6,000 white supporters of the flag who gathered there a week ago to praise it as
a symbol of Southern heritage. The march against the flag took place on the day
that celebrates the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. -- though not
in South Carolina, which has no official commemoration.   A14

Effort to Enforce Gun Laws
The White House will ask Congress for $280 million in new spending to enforce
existing gun-control laws, a strategy intended to address one of the main
complaints of those who oppose gun restrictions, administration officials said.
   A18

Doubts About Security Study
The Transportation Department is rethinking a plan to study whether an airport
security measure discriminates against members of minorities. The Arab American
Institute had complained that the study -- which includes asking passengers
about their religion and ethnic background -- was worse than the problem it was
supposed to detect.   A14

EDUCATION

Revival of Western Classics
The classics, whose relevance has long been dismissed by critics who complain
that they celebrate the works of a cadre of writers who are almost exclusively
white, male and dead, seem to be making a comeback at a number of institutions.
   A1

ARTS   E1-12

Bertelsmann History Revised
A panel appointed by the German media conglomerate to review company history
during the Nazi era issued preliminary findings that the publisher was closed in
1944 because its books -- largely fiction for German troops -- were not
considered critically "important for the war" effort. The company had offered
the view that the closing was the result of political opposition to Hitler.   E1


A Large-Scale Art Donation
Peter and Eileen Norton said they were donating nearly 1,000 works by more than
450 artists to 29 institutions. Most of the works are from the 1990's, and Mr.
Norton, the software entrepreneur, estimated their value at $3 million. Still,
in sheer numbers, the gift is one of the largest of contemporary art by a
private donor.   E1

NEW YORK/REGION   B1-6

State G.O.P. Challenging McCain on Primary Ballot
The New York Republican State Committee, which is supporting Gov. George W. Bush
in the presidential race, said it would seek to disqualify Senator John McCain,
above, from the primary ballot today in about half the state. Party officials
said his campaign had not met arduous petition requirements. Mr. McCain, who has
sued in federal court to overturn the New York system, suggested that the state
party was trying to rig the March 7 primary.   A1

The Senate Race on King's Day
Hillary Rodham Clinton attended several holiday celebrations, tying the legacy
of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to her own ambitions and denouncing what
she said was the racial divide of Mayor Giuliani's tenure. She also held her
first meeting with the Rev. Al Sharpton. Mr. Giuliani attended smaller events
organized by black supporters.   B1

Fugitive Seized at Border
Jaquan Muhammad, who is believed to have eluded the police in Midtown last
Tuesday by leaping from one high-rise to another, was returned to the city after
being stopped at the Canadian border. He was charged with second-degree murder
in a Brooklyn killing and is a suspect in several knifepoint robberies.   B3

medicine to keep their practices lucrative.   A1

Hope for Preventing Cancer
Scientists at the National Cancer Institute say an aspirin-like drug, a
selective cox-2 inhibitor, may be able to block cancers from forming.   F1

On Competence and Confidence
Cornell researchers said they had found that most incompetent people do not know
they are incompetent -- and are more confident than people who do handle things
well.   F7

Camera Helps Blind Man 'See'
A tiny camera wired to the brain has given a blind man a limited ability to
perceive objects.   F3

WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

SECTION: Section A; Page 6; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 961 words



EUROPE

RUSSIA: MIR REPRIEVE
The space station Mir got a reprieve when the government came up with more money
to keep it in orbit for another seven months. Private investors, some from the
United States, are expected to provide $28 million for the station. A crew is
expected to arrive in April for a mission of 45 to 72 days, said Yuri Koptev,
head of the space agency. Mir, in its 14th year, has been empty since August,
and was due to crash into the Pacific.   Celestine Bohlen (NYT)

POLAND: 9 RUSSIANS OUSTED AS SPIES
Poland ordered nine Russian diplomats out of the country for spying, a blow to
the countries' already uneasy relations. Moscow called the expulsions an
"explicitly unfriendly and provocative action" and warned that "appropriate
response measures become inevitable."   (Reuters)


ITALY: POPE TO SINAI
The Vatican confirmed that John Paul II will visit a monastery at the foot of
the traditional Mt. Sinai on a trip to Egypt lasting from Feb. 24 to 26, a month
before a major pilgrimage to the Holy Land. The Pope, 79, who plans to visit
Israel, Jordan and Palestinian territories in March, had hoped to begin his tour
of biblical sites at the Iraqi city of Ur, but the Iraqis squelched the plan.
Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

SWEDEN: ADMITTING MISTAKES
Prime Minister Goran Persson has taken the first step toward rewriting Swedish
history by admitting his country acted wrongly in World War II, historians and
Swedish Jews said. Mr. Persson broke 60 years of tradition by ending a defense
of neutral Sweden, which, it has emerged, sold iron ore to Germany for munitions
and let German troops cross its territory into Finland and Norway. Mr. Persson
will open a Holocaust conference next week.   (Reuters)

GERMANY: PLEA ON NAZI KILLINGS
Germany asked the Greek Supreme Court to dismiss a lower court ruling that it
owes $30 million to survivors of 218 people who were killed by Nazis in the
village of Distomo on June 10, 1944. Germany says the issue of reparations was
closed with a 1960 compensation treaty with Greece. A ruling is expected in
mid-February.   Victor Homola (NYT)

BRITAIN: QUESTIONS ON DEPORTEE
Lord Janner, chairman of the Holocaust Educational Trust, challenged the
government to explain how Alexander Schweidler, 78, is living freely and drawing
a pension in Britain since being deported by the United States in 1994 after
admitting he had been a Nazi concentration camp guard. A naturalized Briton of
Slovak origin, he was at the Mauthausen camp in Austria.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

TURKEY: POLICE SENTENCES UPHELD
A court upheld the seven-and-a-half year jail terms imposed on five police
officers convicted of beating Metin Goktepe, a journalist, to death in 1996.
Human rights advocates say the case is a test of whether Turkish officers who
commit such crimes still receive their traditional immunity from prosecution.
Stephen Kinzer (NYT)

THE AMERICAS

MEXICO: BODY HUNT HALTED
A joint search with American forensic experts for the bodies of people executed
on the orders of drug traffickers has been called off. The excavations, in
Chihuahua state near El Paso, Texas, unearthed nine bodies. More than 100 have
disappeared. A top prosecutor said Mexico would continue to investigate without
American help.   Sam Dillon (NYT)

ASIA

SRI LANKA: PEACE PLAN
The main opposition party said it would support a plan by the government of
President Chandrika Kumaratunga to bring peace to the country by giving greater
constitutional autonomy to regions dominated by the Tamil minority. The
opposition had blocked legislative passage of the measure, but now offers its
votes if some of its own reform proposals are included.   Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

SOUTH KOREA: A MOVE TOWARD TALKS WITH NORTH
President Kim Dae Jung said he would formally propose a summit meeting with
North Korea if his newly inaugurated governing party wins parliamentary
elections on April 13. Since taking office nearly two years ago, Mr. Kim has
often expressed a willingness to meet the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, but
he has never before proposed a summit meeting.   (AP)

MIDDLE EAST

IRAQ: ANNAN ATTACKED
Stepping up a barrage of verbal attacks on Secretary General Kofi Annan for
nominating a new arms inspector that President Saddam Hussein does not like,
officials quoted in the controlled Iraqi press accused Mr. Annan of being in
league with Washington to impose a system "riddled with spies and false
experts." Mr. Annan named Rolf Ekeus, who dismantled many Iraqi arms from 1991
to 1997, as the head of a new commission, but he is being blocked by Russia,
France and China.   Barbara Crossette (NYT)

IRAN: GERMAN FREE TO LEAVE
A German businessman who was sentenced to death in January 1998 for having sex
with an Iranian woman has been ruled free to leave the country. Helmut Hofer,
56, said he would leave today. Under Iranian law, sex outside marriage with
non-Muslims is punishable by death. Germany is a big trading partner of Iran and
had warned that executing Mr. Hofer would severely harm relations.   Victor
Homola (NYT)

AFRICA

SUDAN: PIPELINE REPAIRED
Officials have repaired a new 1,000-mile oil pipeline that had been damaged in a
bomb attack. The Beja Congress, representing a minority ethnic group, claimed
responsibility for the attack, the third since Sudan, locked in a 16-year civil
war, began pumping oil this summer.   Ian Fisher (NYT)

GUINEA-BISSAU: CONCEDES IN VOTE
Malam Bacai Sanha, ruling party candidate in a presidential election, conceded
defeat to Kumba Yala, head of the Party for Social Renewal, after a second-round
runoff on Sunday.   (Agence France-Presse)

               January 26, 2000, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

Turkish Terror Victim Espoused a Tolerant Islam

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER

SECTION: Section A; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 770 words

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Jan. 25


With Turkey in shock over the discovery of dozens of savagely tortured bodies
beneath the hide-outs of a religious terror group, much of the outrage and grief
has been focused on the case of the only female victim.

The woman, Konca Kuris, was often described as a Muslim feminist. In books,
articles, lectures and television appearances, she had described Islam as a
religion that guarantees women's rights, and asserted that male commentators
over the centuries had twisted its essence in ways that led to the oppression of
women.

In July 1998, Ms. Kuris was kidnapped from the street in front of her home in
the Mediterranean city of Mersin. There were no clues to her fate until her
burned and disfigured body was exhumed on Saturday from a shallow grave in
Konya, 220 miles northwest of Mersin.

Her body was one of 33 that have been found so far at properties used by
Hizbullah, or the Party of God, a group dedicated to overthrowing the secular
Turkish state and establishing an Islamic republic in its place.  Police
investigators are searching for more bodies.

Hizbullah is not believed to be connected to the similarly named group that has
fought against the Israeli occupation of southern Lebanon.  Both groups,
however, proclaim loyalty to a fundamentalist interpretation of Islam.

According to press reports, the police team that uncovered Ms. Kuris's body also
found a videotape containing scenes of torture sessions she endured over a
period of weeks. During one of the sessions, her captors are said to have
accused her of seeking to become Turkey's version of Salman Rushdie or Taslima
Nasrin, writers whom some Muslims consider heretics deserving of death.

"She had a great influence on Turkish women," said Ayse Onal, who has written
several books on feminism in Turkey. "She showed that it's possible to be
completely modern and still be faithful to Islam.  That's why she was killed.
Hizbullah, which is a very sick and deeply violent group, could not tolerate her
point of view."

Ms. Kuris was the only intellectual among the Hizbullah victims found so far.
Most of the others are believed to have been Kurdish businessmen from war-torn
provinces in the southeast.

After the first bodies were found last week, several politicians, news
commentators and others charged that the Turkish military had collaborated with
Hizbullah in the early 1990's, encouraging its death squads to kill Kurds
considered favorable to the cause of Kurdish nationalism.

President Suleyman Demirel rejected that charge, but appeared to agree that some
government agents or agencies might have had connections to Hizbullah.

"The state does not commit murders or order murders to be carried out," Mr.
Demirel told reporters in Ankara on Sunday. "There may be forces belonging to
the state that act illegitimately, but they are committing a crime."

Military commanders issued a statement denying that they or their predecessors
had sponsored or aided Hizbullah.

"The general staff is closely following operations against the Hizbullah terror
organization and shares the public's justified outrage at the horrors that have
recently been uncovered," the commanders said.  "Directly linking this merciless
murder network to the Turkish armed forces is a senseless and illogical
slander."

Turkey is arguably the world's most secular Muslim country, and many people
here, especially women, considered Ms. Kuris an exemplar of their tolerant brand
of Islam.

Born in 1960, she was married at 17 and had five children. At a young age she
became interested in Islam, but quit the first religious sect she joined after
being asked to wash its leaders' clothes. Later she made a trip to Iran with a
Hizbullah delegation, but returned disillusioned with the organization because,
she said, it supported a brand of Islam that was hostile to women.

After reading the Koran and various works of commentary, she began challenging
religious orthodoxy, asserting that Islam does not require women to cover their
hair with scarves and does not require the separation of the sexes at funerals
or in schools.

She also urged that public prayers be offered in Turkish rather than the
traditional Arabic.

"Konca used her mind, her emotions and her conscience to interpret God's
message," said Gonul Tufekci, a lawyer who is prominent in Islamic feminist
circles here. "This approach challenges the ideology that tries to use Islam as
a tool to keep women down. It is based on the concept of an open mind. This
concept is repugnant not only to groups like Hizbullah, but to many institutions
in this part of the world."

                January 29, 2000, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

Turkish Military Accuses Religious Political Party

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER

SECTION: Section A; Page 5; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 595 words

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Jan. 28


Conflict between the secular Turkish military and the country's
religious-oriented political party, which led to the forced resignation of a
prime minister in 1997, has flared up again.

Military commanders have asserted that the party, Virtue, represents the
extremist mentality of a terrorist group that claims to be acting in the name of
Islam. In recent days, Turks have been stunned by disclosures that the group,
Hizbullah, apparently gruesomely tortured and killed dozens of people that it
considered heretical. Today clerics at mosques throughout the country condemned
Hizbullah.

Virtue is the country's main opposition party, holding 105 seats in the
550-member Parliament. A senior prosecutor, Vural Savas, had already asked the
Constitutional Court to ban the party on the grounds that it poses a "clear and
present danger" to secularism in Turkey.

Until last week, when Hizbullah's apparent savagery was first made public
following the discovery of disfigured bodies buried at its hideouts, there
seemed little chance that the court would agree to close Virtue. But in the wake
of disclosures about the bodies, the climate has changed palpably. With new
discoveries, some 39 bodies have been found.

Denying a link between Virtue and Hizbollah, Numan Kurtulmus, who heads the
Virtue organization in Istanbul, said: "It is nonsense, because we strongly
support the ideas of democracy and human rights. But emotions are running very
high. Our party could be a victim."

Several prominent politicians and news commentators have contended that
Hizbullah could not have emerged in war-torn southeastern Turkey without the
cooperation of security agencies there.

Among those who suggested this connection was the Virtue leader, Recai Kutan. He
said that at the time Hizbullah was apparently kidnapping and killing Kurdish
nationalists in the early 1990's, southeastern provinces were under emergency
rule because of a crackdown on a Kurdish insurgency and "even a bird could not
fly there without the security forces knowing about it."

"What is the secret behind all those unsolved murders that have been committed
in the southeast over the last 10 years?" Mr. Kutan asked. "Why did the
authorities not launch a campaign against the terror organizations?"

Those remarks evidently outraged military commanders. On Wednesday they issued a
statement recalling that the Constitutional Court has in the past closed three
religious parties and suggesting that Virtue was "harboring guilty feelings" in
the wake of the disclosures.

"It has been seen with great regret that in a speech about the Hizbullah terror
group delivered on January 25, the leader of a political party made unjust and
unseemly accusations against the Turkish armed forces," the commanders said in a
statement. "This mentality, whose ultimate aim is to set up an Islamic state,
views the Turkish armed forces as the biggest obstacle preventing it from
reaching its goals.  The Turkish armed forces, with the support of the great
Turkish nation, will never allow this mentality to achieve its goal."

Such statements have great resonance here, because the military's mistrust of
Islamic political parties led it to pressure Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan to
resign in 1997, and later helped persuade the Constitutional Court to ban his
political party, called Welfare.

Prosecutors have asserted that the Virtue party of today is nothing more than an
extension of Welfare, and that Mr. Erbakan is controlling it from behind the
scenes even though he has been banned from politics.

                February 1, 2000, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

Japan Puts Gas-Attack Sect Under Scrutiny

BYLINE: By The New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 200 words

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 31


A public commission ruled today that Aum Shinrikyo, the religious group that
killed 12 people in a nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway in 1995, continues to
pose a threat to society and it instructed security authorities to put the sect
under surveillance for up to three years.

The Public Security Examination Commission, which is technically an independent
panel but is heavily influenced by the government, invoked a law enacted last
year that will allow the police and Justice Ministry officials to enter the
sect's property for inspections without a search warrant.

Under the surveillance law -- specifically directed at the group, which recently
changed its name to Aleph from Aum Shinrikyo -- the sect must report the names
of its members and details of its assets and activities to the authorities.

Beginning on Tuesday, when the commission's decision will be published in a
government gazette, the group's every move will be monitored by the authorities,
a security official said.

Human rights advocates and civil libertarians denounced the decision as a
violation of the group's basic rights and warned that the action could have
broad implications for democracy in Japan.

U.S. Victims of Chile's Coup: The Uncensored File

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 2223 words


Twenty-six years ago, as the forces of Gen. Augusto Pinochet overthrew the
Socialist government of Salvador Allende, two American supporters of President
Allende were killed in Chile under circumstances that stirred suspicions of
C.I.A. involvement.

American officials categorically denied any role in the young men's deaths,
which were dramatized in the 1982 movie "Missing."

Compelled by the Freedom of Information Act, the government in 1980 released the
results of classified internal investigations, heavily censored in black ink,
that appeared to clear the American and Chilean governments of any
responsibility.

But now, those thick black lines have been stripped away. Spurred by the arrest
of General Pinochet in 1998, President Clinton has ordered the declassification
of "all documents that shed light on human rights abuses, terrorism and other
acts of political violence during and prior to the Pinochet era in Chile."

Some of those documents make clear for the first time that the State Department
concluded from almost the beginning that the Pinochet government had killed the
men, Charles Horman, 31, and Frank Teruggi, 24. The investigators speculated,
moreover, that the Chileans would not have done so without a green light from
American intelligence.

"U.S. intelligence may have played an unfortunate part in Horman's death," said
one newly declassified memo. "At best, it was limited to providing or confirming
information that helped motivate his murder by the government of Chile. At
worst, U.S. intelligence was aware the government of Chile saw Horman in a
rather serious light and U.S. officials did nothing to discourage the logical
outcome of government of Chile paranoia."

With most of the blacked-out portions now restored, the documents declassified
by the State Department illustrate how exemptions in the Freedom of Information
Act -- a law that was meant to reduce secrecy -- can be misused.

Two principal exceptions that the department used allow the government to
withhold information on the grounds of national security and executive
privilege. "They're not protecting national security information at all," said
Peter Kornbluh of the nonprofit National Security Archives, which promotes the
declassification of government documents. "Preventing embarrassment is not an
exemption clause."

Even after extensive Senate intelligence committee hearings in the 1970's, the
American role in the overthrow of Mr. Allende remains a matter of dispute and
conjecture. Mr. Kornbluh said that other government agencies responsible for
carrying out United States policy in Chile, including the C.I.A. and the
Pentagon, have so far failed to release key records on the era.

Regarding Mr. Horman's death, Mark Mansfield, a spokesman for the C.I.A.,
recently released a 22-year-old letter denying any role by the agency and said
it would show the public files on the case this spring.

The State Department refused to address questions about the two deaths, saying
few of the people involved in the case still work for the government. The former
officials, most of them retired and scattered around the country, largely
disavow any responsibility for what happened.

Mr. Horman's widow, Joyce, is hoping that enough has changed to finally learn
what really happened to her husband. She is asking for Washington's help in her
quest for an honest explanation of his murder from the new Socialist government
in Chile.

"I want to know who gave the order," said Mrs. Horman, who has never remarried.
"Nobody's held accountable."

Her husband and Mr. Teruggi were friends who belonged to a group of young
left-of-center Americans attracted by Mr. Allende's socialist experiment in the
early 1970's. In Santiago, they worked for a newsletter that reprinted articles
and clippings from American newspapers critical of United States policy.

When General Pinochet seized power on Sept. 11, 1973, Mr. Horman was at Vina del
Mar, a coastal resort, with Terry Simon, a family friend from New York who was
vacationing in Chile.

Ms. Simon said she and Mr. Horman saw American warships offshore and spoke to
American naval officers stationed in nearby Valparaiso, who appeared elated at
the coup's success. The two interpreted what they saw as proof of American
connivance in the military takeover.

Eager to return to Santiago, they rode back with Capt. Ray E. Davis, chief of
the United States Military Group at the American Embassy, who had been making
his weekly visit to the naval station.

Two days later, as General Pinochet's forces moved to arrest thousands of people
around the country, men in military uniforms abducted Mr. Horman, ransacking his
apartment. His wife, Joyce, was out at the time. She never saw him again. Ms.
Simon searched with Joyce for Mr. Horman and eventually flew home to New York.

Around the same time, security forces arrested Mr. Teruggi and his roommate,
David Hathaway, at their apartment. They were held at the national stadium with
thousands of other political prisoners. Mr. Teruggi never returned from his
second interrogation.

Mr. Hathaway was released alone and later flew home to the United States. A
friend identified Mr. Teruggi's body in the government morgue. His throat had
been slashed, and he had been shot twice in the head.

The search for Mr. Horman was more tortuous. His father, Edmund, flew in from
New York to help. He and Mr. Horman's wife followed whatever leads they could,
keeping in close touch with the embassy, which supplied escorts and pressed Mrs.
Horman for a list of her husband's friends. Doubting the diplomats' motives, she
says, she never supplied it.

Captain Davis, now 74 and retired, said in a recent interview that he had
nothing to do with the deaths and he appeared offended by the resurgence of
questions about the killings.

He talked of his close ties to the Chilean military during his time there and
said he had welcomed General Pinochet at his home, but was in no position to
demand that Chilean Army commanders answer for the killings, and had not been
ordered to do so. "We weren't down there to cause trouble," he said. "We sold
them weapons."

He called Mr. Teruggi and Mr. Horman "part of the problem" in Chile. "They were
down there handing out pamphlets against the government," he said.

The two men, actually, had been supporting the Allende government, not the one
Captain Davis hoped to see in power. He corrected himself: "against the people
who were trying to do something about it."

The Hormans have long contended that despite the embassy's avowal that it was
doing all it could to find Charles, its officials would merely confirm
information the family had obtained for itself. Taken together, the newly
released documents support their suspicions.

It was not until 1976 that the State Department took a critical look at the
killings. The move was prompted by a disaffected Chilean intelligence officer,
Rafael Gonzalez, who told reporters that he had witnessed Mr. Horman being held
prisoner by Chile's chief of intelligence.

Mr. Gonzalez quoted the intelligence chief as saying Mr. Horman "had to
disappear" because he "knew too much," and said a man he presumed was American
was in the room.

Mr. Gonzalez also described a "cozy relationship" between American and Chilean
intelligence services to destabilize the Allende government, and said that
American operatives had even given their Chilean counterparts lists of suspected
leftists to be rounded up in the first days of a military takeover.

(In its hearings, the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence found that the
C.I.A. had in fact compiled arrest lists but said it had no evidence that they
were passed to the Chileans. Those lists are among the documents the C.I.A. has
not released.)

Facing pressure from Congress, the State Department ordered two internal reviews
in 1976. The first, completed in August, was carried out by Rudy V. Fimbres,
regional director for Bolivia and Chile in the Bureau of Inter-American Affairs.
The second was conducted by Frederick Smith, a State Department lawyer, in
November and December.

The investigators were permitted to examine only documents either publicly
released or already available in the State Department. Their reviews appeared to
confirm doubts and inconsistencies that American newspapers had already reported
but that State Department officials had repeatedly discredited.

The documents showed that an embassy official had received a tip that Mr. Horman
had already been killed before his father arrived in Chile. That tip was not
followed up.

Instead, embassy officials told Edmund Horman that leftists may have kidnapped
his son, contradicting their own cables home, which quoted neighbors who said
they had witnessed Chilean security forces taking Mr. Horman away.

The internal reviews also questioned the time of Mr. Horman's death, saying
there was no reason to accept the Chilean government's assertion that he died
just before the American Embassy learned of his disappearance.

The Pinochet government had ignored numerous requests from the United States for
an autopsy report on Mr. Horman, the documents show.

One review asked why Captain Davis, who had driven Mr. Horman and Ms. Simon to
Santiago, had taken their registration card from the hotel where they were
staying.

Captain Davis at first denied that he had taken the card, but changed his mind
when read a passage from a letter he wrote to one of the investigators, now
among the declassified documents, mentioning the registration card. "I don't see
why it's important," he said.

The Horman family believes the card was given to the Chilean military, and
tipped them off to the new address of the Hormans, who had moved just a few days
before.

"Based on what we have," the first inquiry concluded, "we are persuaded that the
government of Chile sought Horman and felt threatened enough to order his
immediate execution. The government of Chile might have believed this American
could be killed without negative fall-out from the U.S. government."

The memo said that there was "circumstantial evidence" that the C.I.A. "may have
played an unfortunate part in Horman's death," as well as Mr. Teruggi's. It also
said the State Department had the "responsibility" to refute baseless
allegations and "to proceed against U.S. officials if this is warranted."

The second investigation, completed a month before Gerald Ford's presidency
ended, drew a similar conclusion. It blamed the Chilean government for both
deaths and said it was "difficult to believe" that the Pinochet government would
have carried out the killings without some signal, perhaps even an inadvertent
one, that the deaths would not cause "substantial adverse consequences" in
Washington.

The memo -- to Harry W. Shlaudeman, the assistant secretary of state for
inter-American affairs -- recommended interviewing Mr. Gonzalez, the disaffected
Chilean intelligence officer, again and going back to the C.I.A. for a full
accounting.

"If an explanation exists," a memo in the investigation said, "it does not
appear in the files and must be sought elsewhere."

But both inquiries appear to have ended there. Mr. Shlaudeman himself
recommended interrogating Mr. Gonzalez further, even submitting a detailed list
of questions for the purpose that the C.I.A. was allowed to review. But he
dismissed the call for investigating the actions of the C.I.A.

Interviewed recently, Mr. Shlaudeman said that he remembered little about the
issue. "A lot of things have happened since then," he said.

Until jarred loose by General Pinochet's arrest in London in October 1998, these
reports remained largely hidden from the public.

In 1978, State Department officials debated how much of the documents to show
the Horman family, which was then suing the United States government for
"wrongful death," a case that was dismissed "without prejudice," meaning that it
could be reopened.

One official, Frank McNeil, then deputy assistant secretary of state for
inter-American affairs, urged the department to err on the side of greater
disclosure.

"Classification should not be used to prevent embarrassment of government
agencies or officials, which would be the principal reason for withholding when
one gets down to the bone," he said.

Nonetheless, the documents released to the Hormans omitted large swaths of
material on the grounds of national security and executive privilege.

Experts note that executive privilege protects the president's deliberations
with his advisers, in this instance Henry A. Kissinger, who served Presidents
Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford as secretary of state.

Dr. Kissinger said he had never seen the documents or the recommendations and
had been out of the country much of the time. "It's very easy, 30 years after
the event, to be so heroic and to create the impression that one had nothing
else to do except follow one particular case," he said. "If it were brought to
my attention I would have done something."

Mr. Fimbres himself, who is now retired, said recently that he was not surprised
at the State Department's apparent failure to pursue the investigation further.

"Something like this easily goes into the black hole," he explained.  "And
everybody watches it go down."

CORRECTION:

An article last Sunday about newly declassified United States government
documents that shed light on the disappearance and death of two American
supporters of President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile in 1973 misstated the
name of a private group that promotes the declassification of of government
documents. It is the National Security Archive, not Archives.

A picture credit was omitted on Feb.13 with an article about the uncovering of
American files on the deaths of Charles Horman and Frank Teruggi, American
supporters of Salvador Allende in Chile. The picture, showing Charles and Joyce
Horman, was by Karen Tweedy-Holmes.

                February 14, 2000, Monday, Late Edition - Final

Half of Afghan Ex-Hostages Fly Back Home From Britain

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 440 words

DATELINE: LONDON, Monday, Feb. 14


A chartered aircraft took off from a British air base early this morning, flying
more than 70 former hostages from last week's airliner hijacking back home to
Afghanistan, witnesses said.

A Home Office spokeswoman said earlier that 72 of the 142 freed hostages had
agreed to go home voluntarily.

The rest were reported to be applying for political asylum in Britain.

Three buses carrying the former hostages were seen leaving a temporary
immigration site in Gloucestershire in western England on Sunday night to go to
nearby Brize Norton air base.

"Some of the former hostages were smiling and waving as they went past," a
witness said.

The Taliban authorities of Afghanistan, Islamic fundamentalists who have no
diplomatic relations with Britain, have asked for the return of all the
hostages.

The hijacking became a political issue in Britain after news reports during the
standoff suggested that the hijackers as well as many of those on board wanted
asylum and a chance for more comfortable life under Britain's welfare system.

When the four-day hijacking ended at Stansted airport here on Thursday, it
quickly emerged through official channels that dozens had applied for asylum.

The opposition Conservatives accused Home Secretary Jack Straw of turning
Britain into a "soft touch" for immigrants.

Mr. Straw struck back today, insisting that he had the powers to turn the former
hostages away if they were not granted asylum.

"We can," he told BBC television. "Once processes are concluded, we have every
right to remove people from this country who do not have right to remain. It
happens every day."

Mr. Straw said Britain faced a difficult choice between its obligation to
provide asylum to those with a well-founded fear of persecution at home, and its
duty to "prevent and deter the very serious international terrorist crime of
hijacking."

Human rights activists urged Mr. Straw not to deport those wanting to stay in
Britain so they could avoid returning to miserable living conditions under the
Taliban government.

The police said three of the 22 people arrested in connection with the hijack
had been released without charge and had joined the freed hostages.

The remaining 19 were still being questioned by the police and were expected to
appear in court soon to be charged under the country's Prevention of Terrorism
Act.

One of the plane's pilots said at a news conference on Saturday that the
hijackers, who seized the Ariana airliner on a domestic flight in Afghanistan
last Sunday, had threatened to kill their hostages and blow the plane up when it
landed in Britain.

Feminists' Gains

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 159 words



To the Editor:

Re your Feb. 10 news article about Susan Brownmiller's feminist poker games: I
invite those who feel that the feminist movement has "lost its steam" to note
that New York is home to one of the largest and most active chapters of the
National Organization for Women in the country.

In the last two years alone, we have organized more than 50 actions and have
helped win crucial gains for women like the clinic access-anti-stalking bill and
a court victory against the New York State Division for Human Rights for their
major delays in processing discrimination claims.

We have Ms. Brownmiller's generation to thank for bringing us where we are. But
we need veteran feminists to take part, advise and encourage us, not dismiss our
hard work in the battles we are still fighting.

GALEN SHERWIN
New York, Feb. 10, 2000

The writer is president of the New York City chapter of the National
Organization for Women.

               February 16, 2000, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

Hearing on Suit by Reporter Held Captive

BYLINE: By The New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 740 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15


A federal judge took the first step today in awarding damages in a lawsuit filed
by Terry Anderson seeking $100 million from the Iranian government for the pain
and suffering he experienced during nearly seven years as a hostage in Lebanon.

The hearing before Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson of Federal District Court
coincided with efforts to persuade Congress to enact laws allowing victims of
terrorism and the victims' families to collect on judgments against countries
that sponsor terrorist acts.

"Iran and other sponsors of terrorism must be held accountable for supporting
activities that kill, injure, torture and imprison innocent persons," said Mr.
Anderson, the former chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press.
"No government is above the law when it violates basic human rights."

Mr. Anderson was among 18 Americans taken hostage in Beirut in the 1980's. He
was held the longest, spending 2,454 days in captivity before he was freed on
Dec. 4, 1991.

Judge Jackson opened the two-day hearing by saying that the government of Iran
had not responded to the lawsuit and was in default. Iran did not send a
representative to the proceedings despite being notified through diplomatic
channels.

The suit, filed last March under a 1996 law that allows legal action against
countries that the United States government accuses of sponsoring terrorism,
asserts that Mr. Anderson's kidnappers were members of Hezbollah, or Party of
God, a "a politico-paramilitary terrorist organization" with ties to Iran. The
suit also says that Hezbollah received financing, training and direction from
Iran.

"This law was designed to make terrorism expensive," Mr. Anderson said in a
break in today's proceedings. "And we are going to make it expensive for Iran."

The Islamic Republic of Iran and its Ministry of Information and Security were
named as defendants. The law that allows victims of terrorism to sue foreign
countries in American courts requires the State Department to list the country
as a sponsor of terrorism. Iran has been on the list since 1984.

Mr. Anderson's case follows others with similar intentions. In March 1998, a
federal judge ordered Iran to pay $247.5 million to the family of Alisa M.
Flatow of West Orange, N.J., who was studying at a seminary in Jerusalem in 1995
when she was killed in a suicide bus attack for which Islamic Jihad, with ties
to Iran, claimed responsibility.

In August 1998, a federal court ordered Iran to pay $65 million in damages for
its role in the kidnappings of Joseph J. Cicippio, Frank H. Reed and David P.
Jacobsen, three Americans held with Mr. Anderson in Lebanon. They have been
unable to collect on the settlements.

Congress passed a measure in October 1998 that called for the State Department
and the Department of Treasury to help victims of terrorism locate money to
settle judgments. But the legislation included a provision allowing the
president to waive implementation in the interest of national security.

Administration officials have voiced concern that the sanctity of American
diplomatic property abroad, a right extended to all diplomatic missions under
international law, might be compromised if private citizens here seized foreign
government property under such court decisions.

At the State Department today, James P. Rubin, a department spokesman, said Iran
did not accept the jurisdiction or the awards in Mr. Anderson's case and that
the State Department opposed the attachment of diplomatic property to settle
claims awarded by a court.

Senators Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, and Connie Mack,
Republican of Florida, proposed legislation in 1999 to establish a system for
tapping a foreign government's frozen assets that could be used to settle these
claims and ease the administration's concern that diplomatic property, like
foreign embassies, would be among the assets involved.

"American citizens deserve the right to know that their government stands behind
them when acts of terrorism are committed against their families," Mr. Mack said
in October when he presented the Justice for Victims of Terrorism Act.

After his release, Mr. Anderson, 52, and his wife, Madeleine Bassil, wrote a
book about his ordeal, "Den of Lions." He now teaches journalism at Ohio
University and serves on the board of the Committee to Protect Journalists, a
nonprofit group that works for press freedom around the world.

               February 16, 2000, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

Two Rwandans Held in Europe In 1994 Deaths

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 337 words

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 15


Two high-ranking former Rwandan army officers were arrested in Europe today in
connection with the 1994 massacres in which a half million Rwandans died.

The suspects were arrested at their homes in small towns in France and Denmark
on warrants issued by the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda.

The French Interior Ministry said the police arrested Francois-Xavier
Nzuwonemeye in Montauban, in southwest France.

Mr. Nzuwonemeye was the second suspect arrested in France in less than three
months in connection with the massacres. A Paris court is to decide whether Mr.
Nzuwonemeye will be extradited to Arusha, Tanzania, where the Rwanda tribunal is
situated.

French authorities did not provide information on Mr. Nzuwonemeye's alleged role
in the massacres.

The Danish police arrested Innocent Sagahutu in Ringkobing, 200 miles west of
Copenhagen.

The statement described both suspects as "high-ranking military officers, both
former members of the Rwandan Armed Forces."

An estimated 500,000 minority ethnic Tutsi and Hutu opposition members died in
three months of killing led by members of the Hutu-dominated government. The
slaughter ended when Tutsi-led rebels came to power.

Mr. Sagahutu was identified as an army captain wanted in connection with the
killing in 1994 of Rwanda's Prime Minister, Agathe Uwilingiyimana, and 10 United
Nations peacekeepers from Belgium who had been assigned to protect her.

Last November, the former Rwandan Minister of Higher Education, Jean de Dieu
Kamuhanda, was arrested in France. He was extradited to Tanzania this month to
stand trial on charges of genocide.

On Feb. 5, the British police arrested Tharcisse Muvunyi, 46, of Rwanda, on
charges of genocide.

Since it was established by the United Nations in November 1994 to "prosecute
persons responsible for genocide and other serious violations of international
humanitarian law" committed in Rwanda that year, the tribunal has delivered
seven verdicts. It is holding 39 people in custody in Arusha.

THE WORLD: Beirut, Meet Tehran;
A Time of Testing for Islamic Zeal

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1342 words

DATELINE: NABATIYE, Lebanon


A GROUP of hard-eyed men from Hezbollah, the Party of God, were driving an
American correspondent down a narrow road outside this village in southern
Lebanon last week when the visitor pointed through the open car window toward an
Israeli fortification high on a rocky hill to the south.

Something on the hill was glinting in the blinding sunshine. It was probably an
Israeli soldier's binoculars, and the reaction of the Hezbollah fighters was
quick and angry. "In the name of Allah, don't point!" the driver said, turning
the car and racing back toward the village. "If you point, the Israelis will
think you're aiming at them, and they'll hit us with their 155-millimeters."

The reproach was a hard lesson, but it was nothing compared with the cold fury
of the Hezbollah men a little later while driving past billboards showing the
supreme icons of Hezbollah's brand of Shiite Muslim fundamentalism -- Ayatollah
Ruhollah Khomeini, who led Iran's Islamic revolution in 1979, and his successor
as the Islamic Republic's supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
Blundering again, the reporter asked where were the images of Iran's president,
Mohammed Khatami, an Islamic reformer whose calls for greater democracy and
human rights have electrified his country and crystallized the battle between
reformers and conservatives that culminated in the Iranian parliamentary
election held Friday.

This time the driver slowed, looked back at his questioner with something
approaching contempt, then fell silent.

Among militant Shiites in Lebanon, apparently, Mr. Khatami is a nonperson,
somebody who merits only scowls. Later, much the same reaction was evident in
Hezbollah's heavily guarded sanctuaries in the southern suburbs of Beirut, where
Hezbollah leaders are preparing to face up to their own day of reckoning. That
will be the moment in July when Israeli troops complete their promised
withdrawal from Lebanon and leave Hezbollah to make a historic choice between
the militant Islamic policies of its past and mounting pressure for more
pragmatism -- particularly if Lebanon's neighbor and protector Syria resumes
seeking peace with Israel.

AFTER 20 years of holding high the banner of Islamic fundamentalism, the
conservative mullahs of Iran and their counterparts in the leadership of
Lebanon's Hezbollah have arrived, more or less simultaneously, at their
respective political Rubicons, the point at which their cause will either adjust
or wither. Partly this is a matter of coincidence, of political timetables in
Iran and Lebanon that have their separate logics. But there are common factors,
too, as there have been since the first stirrings of Shiite clerical insurgency
in the two countries more than 40 years ago.

Reaching any broad conclusions about the tide of affairs in the Islamic world is
fraught with hazard, considering that there are more than 50 Muslim nations,
comprising more than a billion people, vastly different cultures in Africa, the
Middle East and Asia, and a deep theological and political schism between the
world's 800 million Sunni Muslims and 200 million Shiites. But some trends are
too compelling to ignore; the events now unfolding in Iran and Lebanon,
suggesting a broader movement toward political realism in the Shiite world, are
among them.

Because of the Sunni-Shiite schism, tracing back to the dynastic rupture that
followed the death of the Muslim Prophet Mohammed in 632 A.D., it would take an
intrepid chronicler to suggest that something still broader may be stirring
across all of Islam -- a slow, even crab-like move away from the militancy that
seemed like a rising tide at the onset of the 1990's. After all, Osama Bin
Laden, the heir to a Saudi Arabian fortune who is the world's most-wanted
terrorist leader, is still at large in Afghanistan, with cells of armed
supporters spread widely through the Middle East, North Africa and Europe.

Other forms of Islamic militancy continue to lurk, on the fringes of power or
underground, in dozens of countries -- Indonesia, Pakistan, Egypt, Sudan,
Algeria among them. Some experts think the world has yet to see the high tide of
Sunni fundamentalism, an equivalent of the Shiite revolution in Iran in 1979.

But for the moment, what seems inescapable is that the men who kick-started the
wave of Islamic militancy in the modern world, the Shiite clerics of Iran and
Lebanon, have their backs to the wall, even if few hard-line mullahs in either
country seem ready to fly the white flag just yet.

In Iran, where huge numbers of voters turned out for parliamentary elections
last week, the results will take days to compile and it is possible that
reformers, divided among themselves and deprived of some of their best
candidates by pre-election screeners loyal to Ayatollah Khamenei, may have to
settle for something less than outright victory. And in Lebanon, a surface
appraisal would suggest that Hezbollah, after 15 years of battling Israeli
troops, is on the verge of its brightest moment yet, the unilateral Israeli
pullout promised by Prime Minister Ehud Barak.

But in Lebanon, as in Iran, the longer-run trends seem to lie against the
militants. With Israel's troops gone, the Islamic group will be deprived of its
most powerful card, and Lebanon's 3.5 million people will be left to weigh
whether they want to give the group more political power than it already has
with its minority bloc in the Lebanese parliament. Every sign says that they do
not. In recent times, Hezbollah has even been rewriting history, pretending it
had nothing to do with the brutal terrorism it sponsored in the 1980's, and
playing down its commitment to an Islamic state.

Similarly, in Iran, the long run seems to strongly favor the pragmatists, if
only because of demographics. The young constitute a great bulge in Iran's
population -- people under 25 who are too young to remember the revolution or to
have fought against Iraq or to do anything today but chafe at the social
restrictions Ayatollah Khomeini imposed as the price of liberation from the rule
of Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi. Those young are a formidable, and growing, base
of support for the forces of reform.

If the pragmatic trends hold, it will be an ironic comeuppance for the Shiite
fundamentalists, who once viewed the Iran-Lebanon axis as the basis for building
an eventual Islamic superstate. Only in Lebanon, it seems, do many people
remember that it was here, in the 1960's, that Musa al-Sadr, an Iranian-born
Shiite cleric, pioneered the populist form of Shiite political awakening that
found its ultimate expression in the Islamic revolution in Iran. Revered by
Shiite moderates and revolutionaries alike, he disappeared on a trip to Libya in
1978, the apparent victim of a plot by the Libyan leader Muammer el-Qaddafi, a
Sunni Muslim who, most Lebanese Shiites suppose, did not favor the rise of
Shiite fundamentalist power in the heart of the Arab world.

LESS than six months after Mr. Sadr's luggage turned up off a Tripoli-Rome
flight without Mr. Sadr, Ayatollah Khomeini was on a flight from Paris to
Teheran, where he declared the Islamic state that turned Iran upside down.
Within a few years, the militant Lebanese Shiites who felt orphaned by Mr.
Sadr's disappearance were empowered again when Ayatollah Khomeini sent 5,000
Iranian revolutionary guards to Lebanon's Bekaa valley, where they armed,
trained and indoctrinated the Hezbollah force that went to war against Israel.

Now, in both countries, the hard-line clerics are faced with evanescent dreams.
About the only solace for them may be that their Shiite faith has rested from
the start on a cult of dispossession, betrayal and defeat. Just as Shiites
believe that Sunnis usurped the rightful inheritance of Ali, the Prophet
Mohammed's son-in-law and the Shiites' first imam, so now the hard-liners may
come to believe that their enemies on Earth have wrested from them the Islamic
state that, according to the militants, was the millennarian promise vouchsafed
them by the Prophet.

EUROPE

BRITAIN: MEDICAL REPORT CHALLENGED: Belgium, France, Switzerland and Spain
registered formal challenges to a British report suggesting that Gen. Augusto
Pinochet, 84, is medically unfit for extradition to Spain to stand trial on
torture charges. Jack Straw, the Home Secretary, promised a response "as soon as
possible."   Alan Cowell (NYT)

SPAIN: CAR BOMB KILLS 2: Fernando Buesa, a leader of the opposition Socialist
Party, and his bodyguard died when a car bomb exploded as they walked in the
Basque regional capital of Vitoria. The government blamed the Basque separatist
group E.T.A., and Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar vowed to resist the rebels.
Al Goodman (NYT)


BRITAIN: TRIAL ON TELEVISION: Several media companies, including the BBC, CNN,
ABC and CBS, asked a Scottish court to allow them to televise the trial of two
Libyan men accused of blowing up Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in
1988. Although English law bans cameras from the courtroom, Scottish law allows
trials to be broadcast after they are over.   Sarah Lyall (NYT)

GEORGIA: STALIN'S GRANDSON CAN'T RUN: The Central Election Commission rejected
an attempt by Yevgeny Dzhugashvili, a grandson of Stalin, to run for president,
ruling that he could not be a candidate in the April 9 election because he is a
Russian citizen. Mr. Dzhugashvili, a 64-year-old retired army colonel who has
called for restoration of the Soviet Union, was barred from running for
Parliament last fall. Stalin, whose original surname was Dzhugashvili, was born
in Georgia.   (AP)

TURKEY: CLASHES IN KURDISH REGION: Police forces battled demonstrators in the
Kurdish city of Diyarbakir who were protesting the arrest of three Kurdish
mayors charged with aiding Kurdish terrorists. The clash reflects the sudden
worsening of relations between Kurdish politicians and the government.   Stephen
Kinzer (NYT)

INDONESIA: GENERAL FACES QUESTIONING: Parliament plans to question General
Wiranto about the killings and destruction in East Timor last year. The general
was suspended from his cabinet post this month so that he could concentrate on
investigations into the atrocities and on a criminal investigation by the
attorney general.   Seth Mydans (NYT)

THE AMERICAS

CANADA: GUN LAW CHALLENGED: The Supreme Court heard a challenge to a law that
would require all Canadians to obtain licenses by the end of the year and
register all their guns by the end of 2001. The challenge, initiated by six
provinces, asserts that the federal government is invading their right to
regulate private property. Since the new law went into effect 15 months ago,
roughly 5 percent of Canada's estimated 3 million gun owners have applied for
licenses. A ruling is expected this spring.   James Brooke (NYT)

MEXICO: SUSPECTED KIDNAPPER HELD: Federal authorities arrested Nicolas Caletri
Lopez, 44, whom they described as one of Mexico's most prolific kidnappers, and
said they were seeking to identify government officials who may have protected
him. Authorities attributed the abduction of at least seven industrialists to
Mr. Caletri.   Sam Dillon (NYT)

MIDDLE EAST

ISRAEL: SECURITY SPENDING SLASHED: Israel cut its budget for security for the
170,000 Jewish settlers in the West Bank and Gaza, slashing such funding from
$34.5 million to $6.2 million in line with overall cuts in the Defense Ministry
budget, the government said.   Deborah Sontag (NYT)

ISRAEL: WITHDRAWAL FROM LEBANON: Maj. Gen. Giora Eiland, the Israeli Army's
chief of operations, told reporters that he expected Israeli troops to leave
Lebanon by year's end, but expressed doubt about Prime Minister Ehud Barak's
July 7 deadline for a withdrawal. The July date is based on the uncertain
prospects for a peace pact with Syria, he said, adding that without such an
agreement there could still be "some formula" for a withdrawal.   William A.
Orme, Jr. (NYT)

AFRICA

RWANDA: U.N. SEEKS REVERSAL: The United Nations war crimes prosecutor argued for
the reversal of a decision that could free a top suspect in the 1994 genocide
that took the lives of at least 500,000 ethnic Tutsi and moderate Hutu in
Rwanda. The prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, said new evidence proves that it was
not the fault of prosecutors that the suspect, Jean-Bosco Barayagwiza, a former
Hutu government official, was not charged for the crimes in a timely manner. But
Mr. Barayagwiza's lawyers said that the evidence was not new and that Mr.
Barayagwiza should be released, as ordered by an appeals court late last year.
   Ian Fisher (NYT)

BURUNDI: CLINTON URGES PEACE: President Clinton urged Burundi's leaders to
"accept the risks of peacemaking" and reach a settlement. In a speech beamed via
satellite to negotiators in Tanzania, Mr. Clinton said the United States
supported efforts to resolve the civil war in Burundi, which has killed more
than 200,000 people since 1993. Aides said it was the first time the White House
had engaged in video diplomacy.   (AP)

ZIMBABWE: MUGABE FACES SUIT: The Supreme Court ruled that human rights lawyers
may sue President Robert Mugabe to force him to release the findings of two
inquiries into alleged atrocities by troops trying to stop a rebellion in
Matabeleland in the 1980's. Mr. Mugabe commissioned the inquiries but the
results have never been made public.   Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

SOUTH AFRICA: SUBPOENAS WITHDRAWN: Bowing to pressure from the media, the Human
Rights Commission has agreed to invite -- not subpoena -- dozens of editors and
news directors to defend themselves against charges of racism. The panel agreed
to withdraw its subpoenas provided that the news organizations agreed to
participate in the hearings on racism in the media, which are scheduled for next
month.   Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

Utah Senate Approves Bill To Fight Polygamist Crimes

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 508 words


More than a century after Utah outlawed polygamy, state lawmakers are still
trying to fight polygamist clans.

The state Senate voted 28 to 1 yesterday in favor of a bill that would earmark
$500,000 for prosecution of abuse and fraud in polygamous societies and pay for
a hot line and emergency shelter for women and children who leave polygamous
enclaves. The bill now goes to the House, where a similar bill was defeated last
month.

"We want to make it clear that this is not about people with different religious
beliefs or consenting adults," said the bill's sponsor, Senator Ron Allen, a
Democrat. "This is about felonies in these communities."

Mr. Allen said that he believed there were about 50,000 polygamists in Utah and
that about 300 women and children left polygamous families in the last year.

Polygamists in the state trace their beliefs to Mormonism, but the Church of
Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints long ago disavowed the practice and Utah, as a
condition of statehood, outlawed polygamy in 1896. Polygamy, a third-degree
felony, is rarely prosecuted because many of the marriages, while performed in a
church, are not registered with the authorities.

"It's come to my attention in the past couple of years that there are a number
of human rights violations in our state in these closed societies," Mr. Allen
said. "Some are the same types of crimes that occur in non-polygamous society,
such as child abuse and incest, but also welfare and tax fraud. There is a
preponderance of empirical evidence that these crimes are quite common and may
even have the tacit approval of some community members."

Mr. Allen said the extra money and resources were needed because there should be
more aggressive investigations and prosecutions, which have to penetrate what he
called "secret communities."

"These people are taught to not talk to the outside world," he said.

He cited cases of women and children who left their families behind and had
nowhere to go.

"We believe it's a first major step," Mr. Allen said, "and we are giving women
and children an opportunity to set their own directions and have a sense of
freedom in their lives."

State Representative Matt Throckmorton, a Republican, called the proposed
legislation discriminatory prosecution.

"They have a religious belief about plural marriages; they do not have a
religious belief that these crimes are acceptable," said Mr. Throckmorton, who
voted against the bill in the House.  "We currently have laws to deal with these
crimes. We don't need a new prosecutor or new money."

The Utah attorney general's office has about $75,000 in its budget for
investigations of crimes in isolated communities.

The jailing of two prominent polygamists for child abuse last year put a
spotlight on the issue. A father pleaded no contest to beating his 16-year-old
daughter after she ran away from a marriage to her uncle, who was convicted of
incest.

Vicki Varela, a spokeswoman for Gov. Michael O. Leavitt, a Republican, said the
governor supported the bill.

Battling in Colombia but Touring Together in Europe

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1191 words

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 27


Officially, peace talks between the Colombian government and the largest rebel
group are stalled, with no date set for them to resume. Yet just the other day,
the government's chief negotiator boasted that "we have advanced further this
month than in 40 years of conflict."

That apparent paradox is a result of an unusual new twist to efforts to
negotiate an end to a civil conflict that has killed 35,000 Colombians just in
the last decade. Army troops continue their confrontation on the battlefield
with the leftist Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known by its Spanish
acronym as Farc. But at the same time, a delegation with representatives from
each side has spent most of February touring Europe together.

The unconventional arrangement has been described by Victor G. Ricardo, the
government's chief peace negotiator, as an effort to build confidence and trust
between the adversaries while "coming to know the models of friendly countries."
At each stop along the way, the joint government-guerrilla delegation has met
with officials, intellectuals, aid donors, religious leaders and journalists,
often issuing a joint statement afterward.

Last summer, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange visited leaders of the
rebel group at their jungle stronghold in San Vicente del Caguan. The Colombian
government explained the move as part of an effort to "educate" the guerrillas,
whose main leader has been fighting in the bush for more than 50 years, about
the modern world and its ways.

The European trip, which included stops in Norway, Sweden, Italy, the Vatican,
Switzerland, Spain and France, seemed motivated in part by the same desire.

At the very least, the guerrillas have been exposed not only to European social
democracy but also to a barrage of criticism of their involvement in drug
trafficking, kidnapping for ransom and human rights violations. The implication
is that if Europe is ever to view the group as an insurgency with legitimate
political goals, as it did Central American guerrillas in the 1980's, it must
change its behavior.

Perhaps as a result, some experts here say they have detected a slight shift of
position by the group on the question of a cease-fire. Though the guerrillas
have always said fighting would continue until at least 80 percent of the
negotiating agenda had been resolved, Raul Reyes, the leader of the rebel
delegation, has suggested that the group might be willing to call a halt to
hostilities at an earlier stage.

The rebels have also softened the tone of their criticism of links between
government security forces and right-wing death squads, which they previously
had contended were one and the same. "We know that the president has not created
the paramilitary groups and that he wants to combat them," Mr. Reyes said in
Paris last Thursday. A day later, he added, "Fortunately, it is not the entire
army but only a part of the military that participates in this."

A few optimists like Leon Valencia, a columnist for El Tiempo, the main daily
here, have even suggested that the ties being developed between the two sets of
negotiators have created an opening to international mediation of the conflict.
The rebel group has a reputation here for xenophobia, and just last summer
rejected a government request that international monitors be sent to the zone
where the government ceded them control in the hope that it would speed peace
talks.

Indeed, such a mediator already appears to be in place. The United Nations
Secretary General, Kofi Annan, recently appointed Jan Egeland, a former deputy
foreign minister of Norway, as his special adviser on the conflict here.
Colombians welcomed the move because of the crucial role Norway played in peace
agreements between Israel and the Palestinians and, more recently, the
government of Guatemala and guerrillas there.

But since taking office 18 months ago promising to bring peace, President Andres
Pastrana has often been criticized for conceding too much to the rebel group,
including control of a chunk of territory the size of Switzerland, without
receiving anything in return. For those and other critics, the European tour,
which ended over the weekend, has provided plenty of new ammunition.

"This has been like the formal presentation of an unruly debutante to polite
society," said Alfredo Rangel Suarez, a former national security adviser to the
Colombian government. "It reinforces the Farc's legitimacy as a counterweight to
the government, strengthens their image in the eye of Colombian public opinion,
and lifts the morale of their combatants in the field."

The government has repeatedly refused to grant the rebel group formal
recognition as a belligerent. But with the government and rebel negotiating
teams traveling and meeting European governments together, Mr. Ricardo, the
peace negotiator, is in practical terms both conceding the rebels that status
and saying he recognizes them as his partners in peace efforts.

But even as the European tour was taking place, the United States Congress has
been considering a Clinton administration request for $1.6 billion in emergency
assistance to Colombia. The largest single component of that proposed package,
which the rebel group has condemned, consists of 63 helicopters for the
Colombian armed forces and police, intended to allow them to operate in
coca-growing areas that the rebels dominate.

Criticizing the Clinton administration package, the director of the United
Nations counterdrug program here, Klaus Nyholm, described it last week as "a lot
of stick and very little carrot." Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont,
has expressed similar concerns at recent hearings in Washington, estimating that
79 percent of the aid package is destined for the Colombian military.

But from the Colombian government's point of view, that would beprecisely the
utility of the American aid. It would be only one part of a much more ambitious
$7.5 billion program that the Pastrana administration calls Plan Colombia, which
contains proposals both to curb the narcotics trade and to bring about economic
and social development.

So while Mr. Ricardo escorted the rebels around Europe, another Colombian
government delegation met with European governments seeking nearly $1 billion in
aid for the "carrot" part of Plan Colombia. One benefit of the rebel tour, then,
was that it permitted the Colombian government to remind potential European
donors that it is up against dogmatic guerrillas with a blinkered view of the
world and little sense of politics other than from the barrel of a gun.

In dealing with Washington, a senior government official said here on Friday,
the Pastrana administration constantly needs to remind the United States that
while "we are going to fight drugs," the peace efforts are also vital.

But because "Europe thought it strange we have a peace process and a counterdrug
strategy in the same package," he added, there is also a need to "tell Europe
the opposite": that while negotiations are essential, "you cannot address the
causes of violence without addressing drug trafficking."

War Crimes Tribunal Sentences Croatian General to 45 Years

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS

SECTION: Section A; Page 7; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 697 words

DATELINE: PARIS, March 3


An international tribunal in The Hague today sentenced a Croatian general, the
highest-ranking military commander yet brought to trial, to 45 years in prison
for war crimes committed during the Bosnian conflict.

The tribunal for the former Yugoslavia sentenced Gen. Tihomir Blaskic for
ordering a series of attacks on Muslim villagers in Bosnia between 1992 and 1994
while his forces were trying to secure the area for Croatia. It was the harshest
sentence handed down by the tribunal since the United Nations created it in
1993.

Unexpectedly, the court also indirectly indicted the government of former
President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia, openly stating that Zagreb had overall
control of the Bosnian Croat authorities and over General Blaskic's militia.

"The Republic of Croatia did not content itself with merely remaining a
spectator on the sidelines or even seek simply to protect its borders," the
ruling read. "It intervened in the conflict, pitting Muslims and Croats of
central Bosnia against each other."

General Blaskic, 39, was convicted for crimes against humanity, war crimes and
grave breaches of the Geneva Convention, which deals with the protection of
civilians during war. Although he was not charged with "killing a Muslim by his
own hand," the judges said that as commander of the militia, the so-called
Croatian Defense Council, he was responsible for personally ordering attacks and
for failing to prevent or punish crimes committed by his subordinates.

In Zagreb, officials of the new government immediately criticized the verdict,
saying that General Blaskic had been far more moderate than many Croatian
nationalists. "There is no doubt that the sentence is very harsh and I believe
it will have to be re-examined in the appeals process," Prime Minister Ivica
Racan said on Croatian radio.

Announcing the ruling of the three-judge panel, Judge Claude Jorda cited a long
list of atrocities by the Croatian militia against terror-stricken Muslims in
the villages of Bosnia's Lasva Valley, in which hundreds were killed and many
were beaten, raped or burned alive in their homes. One of the worst examples was
the rampage in village of Ahmici, which led to the death of more than 100 men,
women and children.

"The crimes you committed, General Blaskic, are extremely serious," Judge Jorda
said. "The acts of war carried out with disregard for international humanitarian
law and in hatred of another people, the villages reduced to rubble, the houses
and stables set on fire and destroyed, the people forced to abandon their homes,
the lost and broken lives, are unacceptable."

Witnesses said that as the sentence was read out in the courtroom, Ratka
Blaskic, the defendant's wife, broke down, sobbing, while he remained calm.

During the trial, Croatian nationalist extremists had threatened Ante Nobilo,
one of General Blaskic's lawyers, who then moved his family temporarily to The
Netherlands from Croatia.

The general's defense lawyers had argued that the commander was powerless to
stop the Croatian militiamen because they were "poorly trained recruits" in a
new and ill-organized command. But the judges ruled that the court had more
"evidence than it needs to note that the chain of command was operating
satisfactorily."

Prosecutors expressed satisfaction with the verdict and said the sentence had
helped achieve their goal of judging the most senior commanders of the war in
the former Yugoslavia.

"Today is a turning point," said Paul Risley, spokesman for the prosecutor's
office. "In previous sentences, we've been forced to deal with the foot soldiers
and camp guards and the like who carried out crimes. Now we are moving to the
more senior commanders."

Although the leaders of the war are still at large, three senior Bosnian Serb
commanders are now also in custody in The Hague, and their trials are expected
to start soon.

General Blaskic's trial took 25 months and involved testimony from 158 witnesses
and some 30,000 pages of evidence. It has been held up, both inside and outside
the tribunal, as an example of how the court should not function, paving the way
for reforms meant to speed up the proceedings.
