Silent Minority

BYLINE: By Ira M. Lapidus;  Ira M. Lapidus's most recent book is "A History of
Islamic Societies."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 19; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 708 words



THE ARAB SHI'A
 The Forgotten Muslims.
 By Graham E. Fuller
 and Rend Rahim Francke.
 290 pp. New York:
 St. Martin's Press. $45.

This book deals with a subject that receives scarcely any attention from
American policy makers and even less from the general public. The Shiite Muslims
of Iran are relatively well known to us. The Shiite minorities throughout the
Arab world are virtually unknown.

The numbers are small. Adherents of the Shia branch of Islam represent about 12
million Iraqis, or between 55 to 60 percent of the population; about 400,000
Bahrainis, or 70 percent of the population; some 500,000 Kuwaitis, or 25 to 30
percent of the population; some 300,000 to 500,000 Saudis, or 2 to 3 percent of
the population; and about 1.3 million Lebanese, or 30 to 40 percent of the
population. But they are strategically situated in the oil-producing and transit
regions of the Persian Gulf or on the sensitive Israeli frontier.

"The Arab Shi'a" calls our attention to their plight. In general, the Shiites
are impoverished, discriminated against and sometimes brutally repressed. The
regime of Saddam Hussein has curtailed their religious activities, executed the
principal religious leaders and crushed any organized Shiite opposition. After
the gulf war countless numbers of Shiites were killed for rising up against the
government. In Saudi Arabia they are not even considered Muslims. No public
expression of religious faith is allowed; religious books are banned; rights to
build mosques are restricted.

The Shiites in the Arab states ask for an end to discrimination and for freedom
to worship. But in Bahrain, Saudi Arabia and Iraq they have no leverage. No
dialogue is possible with these governments. If resistance is expressed for the
sake of a just Islamic state, both moderate Shiites and Sunni Muslims will
reject the call as religious radicalism. If Shiites present their claims in
secular democratic language, the Sunnis will reject them as a cover for
sectarian interests. Violence is not inherent in Shiism, but in these countries
there is practically no other recourse.

Graham E. Fuller, a senior policy analyst at RAND Corporation, and Rend Rahim
Francke, the executive director of the Iraq Foundation, an organization
dedicated to democratization in Iraq, urge us to recognize that the condition of
the Shiites is a serious problem in terms of human rights, the safety of oil
supplies and long-term regional stability. They are gently critical of American
policy for its support of dictatorial regimes, and they argue that Washington
should pressure Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Kuwait to further integrate their
Shiite populations. The reader can tell that they have little hope that this
will be done. United States policy in the Persian Gulf region is based on the
support of these friendly governments.

The situation of the Shiites in Lebanon is entirely different from that in other
Arab countries. There, civil war destroyed the state and gave the Shiites, once
the poorest, most despised part of the population, a chance to become the most
powerful political force in the country. In post-civil war Lebanon, Amal, one of
the largest political parties, and the more radical Hezbollah have accepted the
idea of a multireligious society. This pluralism is Fuller and Francke's best
model for a solution to the Shia question.

The book is especially valuable for policy considerations, but it lacks the
human dimension that might engage our deeper sympathies. More important, the
central concept of "The Arab Shi'a" seems flawed. Despite shared religious
beliefs, Arab Shiites are not a single people. They do not have a central
religious authority or any common institutions. Some Shiites are religious
militants calling for a just Islamic state; others are secularists working for
integration into the existing states. While Iran is now the most important
center of Shia religious scholarship, Arab Shiites keep their distance,
understanding that Tehran has its own nationalist agenda. The truth is that the
Shiites are not unified anywhere except in this book, and there cannot be a
single American policy toward them, only a variety of responses depending upon
the conditions in each country.

C.I.A. Gives Fired Official a Career Award

SECTION: Section A; Page 11; Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 183 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9


The C.I.A. has awarded a career achievement medal to a former senior official
who was fired in 1995 for failing to notify Congress about human rights abuses
in Guatemala, intelligence officials said.

The official, Terry Ward, had been the chief of operations for Latin America. He
was fired for his role in managing the C.I.A.'s relationship with the Guatemalan
military and for having failed to tell Congress about the agency's ties to a
Guatemalan colonel, Julio Roberto Alpirez, a paid American agent, who was
accused of involvement in the murder of an American innkeeper, Michael DeVine.

The Distinguished Career Intelligence Medal is routinely given to retiring
senior C.I.A. officials. The decision to issue it to Mr. Ward at a closed
ceremony later this month was first reported by The Washington Post. Mr. Ward
could not be reached for comment.

The award is being given to Mr. Ward at a time when the man who fired him, John
Deutch, the agency's former director, is himself under investigation by the
Justice Department for serious security lapses involving his home computers.

Editorial Observer;
Searching for Justice in Chile and Argentina

BYLINE: By TINA ROSENBERG

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 770 words


Until 16 months ago, it appeared that Chile had come to terms with the crimes of
the Pinochet years. The murders, torture and forced disappearances, most of
which took place in the mid-1970's, had faded from public attention. Not much
was happening in the courts. But on Oct. 16, 1998, Gen. Augusto Pinochet was
arrested in London on charges issued in Spain, and the illusion of Chile's
reconciliation abruptly ended.

Although General Pinochet will not face trial in Spain, today dozens of his
high-ranking military officers have been arrested in Chile on charges of murder,
kidnapping or torture. A judge is investigating 60 accusations of Mr. Pinochet's
involvement in these crimes. Questions of justice, healing and the fate of the
disappeared are once again gripping society. It is now apparent that Chile's
silence about the past was due to fear, pressure from a civilian government
anxious to keep the generals happy, and the sense that no justice was possible.
The emotion uncorked by Mr. Pinochet's arrest in connection with events that
took place a quarter-century ago shows the necessity of a reckoning with these
crimes. Time alone, it seems, will not free a society from the grip of the past.

Chile's treatment of Pinochet-era crimes has been limited by the government's
reluctance to provoke any insubordination from a still-powerful military. The
civilian government set up a truth commission, but the armed forces did not
cooperate, and to this day refuse to acknowledge that there was a policy of
killings or provide information about the fate of the disappeared. Except for a
handful of cases there were no trials, and courts respected an amnesty that
General Pinochet issued for crimes committed before 1978.

Even today, anti-Pinochet politicians are eager to grant him a peaceful
retirement. Although Chile argued to Britain that Mr. Pinochet should face
justice at home, the government and Congress supported a constitutional
amendment allowing him to keep senatorial immunity even if he gives up his
Senate seat. The amendment goes to a final vote on Saturday. The new president,
Ricardo Lagos, should start his term by vetoing this cynical proposal. Most
Chileans, according to polls, would like to see Mr. Pinochet tried. So many
torture victims have sought treatment since his arrest that organizations that
offer counseling are inundated.

To a lesser extent, judicial investigations abroad are also finding their echo
in Argentina. Baltasar Garzon, the Spanish judge who indicted Mr.  Pinochet, is
investigating several Argentine military leaders for crimes during the "Dirty
War" era, in the mid-1970's. That has helped inspire an Argentine judge to order
the arrest of several members of the Dirty War juntas, including two former
heads of state, for the kidnapping and illegal adoption of babies born to
prisoners who were later murdered.

After the dictatorships fell in 1983, Argentina convicted five junta leaders of
murder, torture and other crimes. But a series of military rebellions frightened
the civilian governments into issuing amnesties and, in 1990, pardoning the
junta members still in prison. Even today, however, the outraged families of
victims pursue justice and information about the missing. Mothers of the
disappeared still march, and an organization of the children of the missing is
active nationwide. Another group, Grandmothers of the Plaza de Mayo, has located
76 of the babies taken from prisoners. The grandmothers' efforts led to numerous
trials of low-level baby-snatchers -- a crime not covered by amnesties or
pardons -- and made possible the trials of junta members today.

The soldiers who killed and tortured, and the civilian governments who later
chose silence over justice, little imagined that decades later the crimes would
still roil their nations. One reason Chileans and Argentines are seeing justice
today is the presence of a new generation of judges who owe nothing to the
generals. In addition, most of the victims were urban, middle-class political
activists. Those who survived torture, and families of the dead and disappeared,
have the time and political skills to pursue their crusade.

The other reason that time has not brought silence is that many of those who
were killed simply disappeared. Their bodies were never found, and every family
still lives, even after 25 years, with a flicker of hope that the missing son
will someday walk through the front door. They cannot move on. As the past year
has shown, nor can a society truly bury the past while the bones are missing,
the killers free and the dead unmourned.

http://www.nytimes.com

                 March 23, 2000, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

Terms of Khmer Rouge Trials Still Elude U.N. and Cambodia

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

SECTION: Section A; Page 3; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 575 words

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 22


A team of United Nations negotiators left Cambodia today after failing again to
reach agreement with the government on the ground rules for a trial of the
surviving leaders of the Khmer Rouge.

The head of the delegation, Hans Corell, said, "We are very close." The
Cambodian government spokesman, Om Yentieng, said: "Mr. Corell has our phone
number. The door remains open."

But on at least one key point, the Cambodians appeared to be intractable as the
United Nations insisted on a tribunal that would not compromise on international
standards of justice.

Though neither side would discuss details of the talks today, diplomats said the
main sticking point involved the demand by the United Nations for a foreign
prosecutor with the authority to issue indictments.

The Cambodians insist on having co-prosecutors -- one foreign and one Cambodian.
This would effectively give the Cambodian side veto power over any indictment.

Discussions between the United Nations and Cambodia have made little progress
over the last year since the surrenders of the last fugitive leaders of the
radical Communist movement responsible for the deaths of more than a million
Cambodians from 1975 to 1979.

United Nations legal experts, who have pioneered in setting up international
tribunals for Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia, have determined that the
Cambodian justice system does not have the competence or political independence
to conduct a trial on its own.

The discussions over the past week, like previous talks, sought to find an
acceptable formula for international participation in the process.

Prime Minister Hun Sen, whose first impulse after the surrenders was to propose
to "dig a hole and bury the past," has resisted international control of a
trial, arguing that this would compromise Cambodia's national sovereignty.

Diplomats here say the chief concern of Mr. Hun Sen, who defected from the Khmer
Rouge in 1977, appears to be a loss of personal control over the process in a
country where he has proclaimed himself the "only captain of the boat," with
final say over all walks of life.

After the the Khmer Rouge killed most of Cambodia's educated people, and after a
decade of civil war that further devastated the country, there are few people
here who even understand the workings of an independent judiciary or the
shortcomings of their own system.

For example, in what was apparently intended as a demonstration that he was
cleaning up the judiciary, where acquittals are routinely purchased by those who
can afford to, Mr. Hun Sen this month simply ordered the re-arrest of several
dozen recently released defendants.

After a final meeting today with the prime minister, Mr. Corell, who is under
secretary general for legal affairs, said: "A few issues still divide us. But we
have made great progress and I am pleased to confirm that we are much further
along the road to success than we were a week ago." He said that his
seven-member team had been willing to continue talking but that the Cambodians
had asked for an adjournment.

Mr. Om Yentieng said Mr. Hun Sen might meet Secretary General Kofi Annan for
further discussions when they both attend a meeting of developing nations in
Cuba in mid-April.

Though Mr. Corell said he would be willing to return for more talks, he said he
had made clear to the Cambodians "the limits in which the United Nations has to
act in this unprecedented endeavor."

METRO NEWS BRIEFS: CONNECTICUT;
Fire Chief Resigns Amid Bias Accusations

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section B; Page 4; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 128 words

DATELINE: HARTFORD


After a troubled tenure that included accusations of racism and a three-week
suspension for the misuse of city time, Hartford's fire chief has resigned.
Deputy Chief Charles Teale will take over until a replacement is found, a city
official said yesterday.

Chief Robert Dobson has overseen the 400-member department -- the state's
largest -- since April 1995. He was suspended for three weeks in April for
working on city time at a Bloomfield art gallery and gift shop he and his wife
own and for using a city vehicle to get there.

Chief Dobson, who is black, also faces two federal lawsuits and a state human
rights complaint charging that he discriminated against white firefighters in
promotions and duty assignments. He has denied the bias allegations.

THE POPE IN THE HOLY LAND: A STRIDENT VOICE;
Mufti Says That Israel Uses Holocaust 'to Win Sympathy'

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG

SECTION: Section 1; Page 20; Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 649 words

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 25


The mufti of Jerusalem, who is scheduled to meet with Pope John Paul II on
Sunday, said today that he was fed up with "the way Israel uses the Holocaust to
win sympathy" and to avoid international censure for its behavior toward the
Palestinians.

Sheik Ikrima Sabri, the chief Islamic cleric of the city, who was appointed in
1994 by Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, minced no words in an interview.
All week, with the international media in town, he has availed himself quite
stridently of the public stage that he has been granted by being on the pope's
interfaith itinerary. He has made no attempt to temper his strong views.

Sheik Sabri said today that he believed that the number of 6 million Holocaust
victims is exaggerated. He said Israel demonstrated this week, when it "took
even the pope" to the Yad Vashem Holocaust memorial, that "it considers its pain
more important than anyone else's."

"There have been many massacres in the world," Sheik Sabri, 56, said. "Why is
this Holocaust in particular more important?" he asked. "When it comes to our
cause, nobody pays attention -- whether it is the Crusader massacres against
Muslims or the massacres against Palestinians committed by Israelis. And we
don't keep using and using these massacres to remind the world what we are
owed."

"I never deny that the Holocaust happened, but we believe the number of 6
million is exaggerated," he continued. "The Jews are using this issue, in many
ways, also to blackmail the Germans financially. The Holocaust is the reason
that there isn't a bigger noise against Israel as an occupying force. The
Holocaust is protecting Israel."

The words clashed starkly with the pope's message of reconciliation, and
particularly his conclusive embrace this week of the enormity of the Holocaust.
This embrace included an emphatic rejection of denial or minimization of the
Holocaust.

But the mufti, unlike the Palestinian political leaders, has not acceded to the
pope's agenda here, which includes interfaith healing. He refused to attend the
pope's interfaith gathering on Thursday, where there were verbal clashes over
the status of Jerusalem between Israel's chief rabbis and the lower-level Muslim
cleric who was assigned by Mr. Arafat to go in the sheik's place.

This puts the pope in a very awkward situation. While he has successfully
remained above the fray so far, it might be difficult if the mufti makes such
remarks in his presence on Sunday.

Vatican spokesmen said today, after similar comments were published in La
Repubblica in Italy, that the pope's schedule would not change, but that they
might add a briefing after the morning meeting. "It's certainly not our fault if
Hitler hated the Jews," the mufti was quoted as saying in the Italian newspaper.
"Weren't they hated pretty much everywhere?"

Sheik Sabri also said he believed that Israel was creating a tense atmosphere in
the Old City in advance of Sunday's meeting with the pope.

With stringent security measures, including ordering Palestinian shops in the
area closed, the Israeli police could be provoking violence, he said. He said he
would not be surprised if youths resorted to stone-throwing "because they are
being provoked."

He said his message to the pope would be, "You are a man of peace, and in order
for this city to enjoy peace, the occupation should end and you should stand
with us."

He added: "The visit of the pope opens the door for the whole world to pay
attention to what's going on in the Holy Land, the reality on the ground. This
week the Israeli media cannot monopolize the flow of information. The whole
world is here to see."

Rabbi David Rosen, director of the Anti-Defamation League here, said Israel
would look to Mr. Arafat to distance himself from the mufti's remarks. "It's
very sad that the highest Muslim official in Jerusalem sullies the name of
Islam," he said.

Policing the World

BYLINE: By Jack F. Matlock Jr.;   Jack F. Matlock Jr., a former United States
ambassador to the Soviet Union and the author of "Autopsy on an Empire," is
George F. Kennan professor at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton,
N.J.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 26; Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1465 words



DELIVER US FROM EVIL
 Peacekeepers, Warlords and a World
 of Endless Conflict.
 By William Shawcross.
 447 pp. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $27.50.

William Shawcross's "Sideshow: Kissinger, Nixon and the Destruction of
Cambodia," published in 1979, set off a passionate debate over responsibility
for the massacres inflicted on the Cambodian people in the 1970's by Khmer Rouge
fanatics. Shawcross contended that President Richard Nixon and Henry Kissinger,
his assistant for national security at the time, were the principal culprits.
Referring to American policy during the Vietnam War, Shawcross concluded,
"Cambodia was not a mistake; it was a crime."

To many observers, this reviewer included, Shawcross's accusation seemed not
merely excessive but perversely misdirected. Whatever mistakes the Nixon
administration might have made in Southeast Asia, the charge that the United
States government was responsible, even indirectly, for the murderous behavior
of the Khmer Rouge seemed patently unreasonable. In blaming the United States,
Shawcross implicitly lifted much of the guilt from those who were directly
responsible for one of the most gruesome atrocities in human history: the Khmer
Rouge leaders and their mentors and supporters in Mao Zedong's China.

In "Deliver Us From Evil," Shawcross is still looking for culprits other than
the local demagogues and warlords who have initiated and perpetuated conflict in
the 1990's. His current target is broader than a single government; he
identifies it at various times as the members of the United Nations Security
Council, the "international community" or even the entire "post-cold-war world."
In an early chapter he sets forth the proposition that "the post-cold-war world
has exaggerated ethnic hatreds, encouraged the failure of states, exacerbated
internal conflicts (or at least prolonged them) and led to more global
disorder." Such a statement could make one nostalgic for the cold war until one
remembers what it actually was like.

Readers, however, should not allow questionable judgments of culpability to
detract from the value of this book. When Shawcross describes what he has
witnessed, he is persuasive. His fast-paced account shifts abruptly from one
conflict to another -- Cambodia to Bosnia, Somalia to Sierra Leone, Rwanda to
Kosovo, Iraq to East Timor. Along with vivid descriptions, he gives us a feel
for the context in which these conflicts have arisen and unforgettable glimpses
of the catastrophic impact they have had on human lives.

Shawcross finds few heroes among the political leaders of the past decade. He
repeatedly characterizes the policies of the major powers as either cowardly and
inept or self-serving and destructive, usually giving scant attention to the
domestic political context in which policies were made. He is, however,
sympathetic to the United Nations officials in trouble spots. They were rarely
given the means to achieve the goals set by member governments, yet were held
responsible for failures not of their making.

If the book has a central positive character, it is Kofi Annan, the current
United Nations secretary general. Shawcross traveled with Annan in Africa, the
Balkans and elsewhere. Invariably picturing Annan's role in a favorable light,
Shawcross fuses descriptions of his trips with explanations of the way the
conflicts developed and character portraits of the local protagonists.

Whenever Shawcross focuses on a particular problem, his judgments are more
reliable than the statements he makes regarding post-cold-war conflict in
general. He notes accurately that the thousands of deaths that preceded the
Dayton agreement on Bosnia in 1995 might have been avoided if the United States
had supported the settlement proposed in 1993 by former Secretary of State Cyrus
Vance and the former British foreign secretary David Owen. The Clinton
administration undermined the Vance-Owen proposal for reasons that were more
theoretical than practical: it did not wish to "legitimatize" the consolidation
of ethnic groups into cantonal areas. Forced movement of people is indeed a
deplorable practice that should be discouraged when possible. However, given the
passions that were raging in Bosnia in 1993, relocation was surely preferable to
the mass murder, mayhem and rapine that followed the breakdown of negotiations.

The Dayton accords stopped most of the plundering and killing in Bosnia, but
ethnic cleansing has not been reversed. There is still no effective central
authority or sense of nationhood in Bosnia. Even the fragile peace that prevails
will depend, for the foreseeable future, on the willingness of foreign
governments to provide military force sufficient to deter the various factions
from going after one another once again.

Shawcross also criticizes American policy in several other troubled areas.
President Clinton precipitately withdrew American forces from Somalia once they
experienced casualties, he says, making a bad situation even worse. In addition,
Shawcross argues, though less plausibly, the United States prevented other
nations from responding promptly to the genocidal massacres that suddenly
erupted in Rwanda. And the refusal by the United States to consider intervention
on the ground in Kosovo resulted in an aerial war against Serbia that has had
many unintended negative effects: Slobodan Milosevic is still in power in
Serbia; Kosovo is under international occupation with no end in sight; and
ethnic cleansing has continued, though now against Serbs rather than Albanians.

Over all, the message implicit in "Deliver Us From Evil" is gloomy: Shawcross
describes only qualified and partial successes for peacemaking (in Cambodia and
Bosnia) and failure virtually everywhere else. Nevertheless, he makes an effort
to end the book on an optimistic note with the suggestion that the idea of
"humanitarian intervention" is gaining international support. This is a
questionable judgment, and Shawcross's prescriptions tend to be muddled and
contradictory. "Intervention can assist people when they are desperate," he
argues, but he demands that it be "consistent" and that it be "followed
through." At the same time, he considers "humility" to be "important" and warns
that "we cannot suddenly rebuild failed states . . . in our own image."

So what should be the object of intervention? Troops on the ground may prevent
atrocities (at least for a time), but do strikes from the air directed at a
country's infrastructure help? And what does "follow through" mean? Policing an
area forever? Creating a civil society? Apparently not the latter, since that
would be seeking what Shawcross considers impossible, a society "in our own
image."

The glib cliches Shawcross offers do not resolve these questions. His story,
vivid as it is, is selective and partial. He passes over with slight, if any,
mention several examples of local war and ethnic cleansing that have begun or
persisted in the past decade. More important for informed judgments, he fails to
examine situations where serious violence might well have arisen but did not.
How did apartheid end in South Africa without the violence many predicted? How
did the Baltic nations secure their independence from the Soviet Union with no
more than sympathy from the outside world? Why has there been no war (or ethnic
cleansing) between Russia and Ukraine? How did the Czechs and Slovaks manage an
amicable divorce?

Each instance of peaceful change has special aspects, but all share one feature:
the change was brought about, or peace preserved, when the leaders of the
countries and the major factions in them sought to resolve their differences
without violence. By contrast, the tragic conflicts Shawcross describes spun out
of control when force was used, either by governments or opposition movements
(usually by both), to achieve political ends. Their guilt should not be
transferred to the United States, the international community or the
"post-cold-war world." It rests with identifiable individuals and specific
groups that have chosen destructive means to achieve what are rarely if ever
laudable ends.

It is obvious that the world community has not yet created effective
international instruments to protect human rights. But the problem may be that
human rights can be protected effectively only by the societies in which people
live. How the international community can best support the development of civil
societies and encourage responsible political leadership is one of the most
daunting tasks facing humanity as it enters the new millennium. Pace Shawcross,
the answer is likely to involve less military intervention from the outside and
greater use of nonviolent political, economic and, especially, moral
instruments.

                  March 27, 2000, Monday, Late Edition - Final

Wartime Workers in the Philippines to Sue Japanese Companies

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 6; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 372 words

DATELINE: MANILA, March 26


Thousands of Filipinos will join a class-action suit against Japanese companies
to seek compensation for forced labor during World War II, a Filipino lawyer who
is heading the suit said today.

Most of the Filipinos conscripted into the wartime labor force by the Japanese
Army were made to work in mines and plantations operated by Japanese companies,
said the lawyer, Rod Domingo. Among the companies that may be sued are members
of the Mitsui, Mitsubishi, Matsushita and Hitachi groups, as well as Toyota and
Nissan, he said.

Last week, after a long and often bitter negotiations, German companies and the
German government agreed on how to pay out $5 billion to surviving forced
laborers and others from the Nazi era. Those receiving the money include mainly
non-Jews from central European countries, and a much smaller number of mainly
Jewish slave laborers.

Mr. Domingo said the lawsuit in the Philippines would be consolidated with
similar class-action suits filed in California by former World War II prisoners
and civilians from Australia, Canada, China, England, Scotland and the
Netherlands. He encouraged living victims or their heirs to file claims.

He said the suit would "ask for an accounting and restitution from Japanese
corporations that reaped profits during the war from the misery, which they have
prolonged for the sake of profitability."

A research paper on Japanese companies that used slave labor in the Philippines
showed that more than a dozen had operated cotton plantations in more than 10
provinces in the northern, central and southern Philippines covering tens of
thousands of acres.

One company, Mitsui Kozan, reportedly used 1.5 million Filipino workers under
life-threatening conditions to reconstruct a copper mine in Mankayan in northern
Benguet province that resistance fighters had blown up.

Another company, Ishihara Sangyo, also operated an iron and copper mine in
central Antique province using 5,000 to 6,000 workers.

The lawsuit will be based on a California law that prohibits slave or forced
labor, said Mr. Domingo, who helped win a $150 million settlement for 9,539
Filipinos against the estate of the late dictator, Ferdinand Marcos, for human
rights violations.

Justice for the Khmer Rouge

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 416 words


More than two decades after the mass slaughter in Cambodia, a critical moment is
at hand in a long-overdue attempt to bring the killers to justice. United
Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan will soon decide whether the U.N. should
participate in a criminal court that will try surviving leaders of the Khmer
Rouge, whose members killed more than a million Cambodians between 1975 and
1979. The court will be in Cambodia and needs the approval of Cambodia's
strongman, Hun Sen, who is doing all he can to impose conditions that would
enable him to manipulate the trials. Mr. Annan must make clear that the U.N.
will not abide by those conditions.

A team of U.N. negotiators left Cambodia last month after failing to reach
agreement with the government on ground rules for the tribunal. But progress was
made and the negotiations are not over. Mr. Annan is expected to take up the
matter directly with Mr. Hun Sen at a meeting of developing nations in Cuba
later this month.

Some form of international participation will be essential to real justice. The
Cambodian judicial system has neither the competence nor the political
independence to conduct credible trials on its own. The best approach would be
an international tribunal like those the U.N. established for Rwanda and the
former Yugoslavia, but Mr. Hun Sen rejected the idea. Until last month
discussions on U.N. support for Cambodian trials had made little progress since
the surrender in 1999 of the last fugitive Khmer Rouge leaders.

The main sticking point involves a legitimate demand by the U.N. that the
tribunal include a foreign prosecutor with independent authority to issue
indictments. The Cambodians have insisted on having co-prosecutors, one foreign
and one Cambodian, in a collaborative arrangement that would effectively give
Mr. Hun Sen veto power over any indictment. This would be unacceptable. The U.N.
must not participate in a process that fails to grant an independent prosecutor
sufficient authority to issue indictments.

The Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot died in 1998, but many of his top lieutenants are
alive and free in Cambodia. Mr. Hun Sen cut deals that effectively gave some of
the top surviving Khmer Rouge leaders -- Ieng Sary, Nuon Chea and Khieu Samphan
-- immunity from prosecution in exchange for their loyalty. But their immunity
should not apply to an internationally backed tribunal, and the U.N. must insist
that these men be tried. Without them the process would be a mockery.

http://www.nytimes.com

AFRICA

ZIMBABWE: PROTESTING MUGABE
An opposition group vowed to begin 100 days of prayer meetings and peaceful
demonstrations to protest the policies of President Robert Mugabe and his
governing party. The decision by the National Constitutional Assembly came after
thugs attacked its peaceful march over the weekend, injuring several people. The
group, which blamed the police for failing to prevent the violence, has
criticized official corruption, the unraveling economy and Mr. Mugabe's support
of black squatters on white-owned farms.  Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

AFRICANS AND EUROPEANS MEET
African leaders pleaded in Cairo for sweeping relief of their continent's
crippling debt at the start of the first Africa-Europe summit meeting. President
Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, left, opened the talks between the 15-nation European
Union and the 52-nation Organization of African Unity with a call for a radical
solution to the debt problem. Despite economic reform and efforts to spread
democracy and human rights, he said, Western aid had slumped in the last two
decades and Africa's share of trade had shrunk.  (Reuters)

SOUTH AFRICA: UNIONS' GLOBAL VIEW
The world labor union movement said it would muster all its strength to fight
the social and economic fallout of globalization, which it said was widening the
gap between rich and poor nations. Labor leaders addressing the start in Durban
of the 17th World Congress of the International Confederation of Free Trade
Unions said globalization needed to pay attention to social rights for it to be
a sustainable economic system.  (Reuters)

MIDDLE EAST

IRAQ: TURKS STRIKE AT KURDS
Turkish F-16 jets struck Kurdish rebel bases in northern Iraq, as more than
1,000 troops penetrated some six miles into the region in a new campaign to hunt
down the guerrillas, a military official said. Cobra helicopter gunships were
reported reinforcing the troops and armored units. No serious clashes with the
guerrillas were reported.  (AP)

INDONESIA: SUHARTO QUIZZED
A five-member team from the attorney general's office questioned former
President Suharto at his home about corruption during his 32-year rule. The
session ended after 90 minutes when Mr. Suharto said he was tired. He has defied
summonses to appear at the attorney general's office for questioning, saying he
is too ill. Seth Mydans (NYT)

LAOS: BLAST TIED TO TERRORISTS
Authorities blamed unspecified terrorists for an explosion at the Thank You Very
Much Restaurant in the capital, Vientiane, that it said wounded six Western
tourists and two Laotians. Such acts are rare in the capital but bandits and the
remnants of anti-Communist Hmong insurgents do operate in the countryside.  Seth
Mydans (NYT)

AFGHANISTAN: CURRENCY WEAKENED
Reported drought damage to opium crops has further battered Afghanistan's weak
currency and driven money changers in Kabul to try to dump the local currency in
favor of hard currencies. A bumper harvest last year established Afghanistan as
the world's leading source of opium, the United Nations estimates. Afghanistan
relies on opium, the raw ingredient for heroin, as its primary export.
Christopher S. Wren (NYT)

THE AMERICAS

MEXICO: VOTE SPLITS PARTY
A primary in the race for governor of Tabasco State has revived bitter divisions
in the governing party, known as the PRI, with complaints that the departing
governor, Roberto Madrazo, rigged the vote to favor a longtime aide, Manuel
Andrade, over Congressman Arturo Nunez, who has spent years as a senior official
in the government and the PRI. Partial results showed Mr. Andrade with 57
percent of the vote and Mr. Nunez with 38 percent. In the presidential primary
last year Mr. Madrazo challenged the PRI establishment, losing to Francisco
Labastida.  (AP)

EUROPE

SWITZERLAND: HOLOCAUST TRIAL
A Swiss man who denies that Hitler's gas chambers existed has gone on trial on
charges that he violated Switzerland's anti-racism law. Gaston-Armand Amaudruz,
79, is being tried in Lausanne for writing that there is no evidence of the
Holocaust's gas chambers. A 1995 Swiss law makes it illegal to deny or justify
genocide. Mr. Amaudruz, a spokesman for a far-right group, faces up to three
years in jail and a $25,000 fine.  Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

IRELAND: EX-PREMIER PAYING BACK TAXES
Former Prime Minister Charlie Haughey, 74, will sell off family properties to
pay more than $1.2 million in back taxes, including interest, on gifts received
while in office from a supermarket executive. Mr. Haughey's fall from grace
reached a low last year when he was booed by spectators at the funeral of a
previous Fianna Fail party leader. He is also facing charges of obstructing a
1997 tribunal looking into payments to politicians.  Brian Lavery (NYT)

GERMANY: RIGHTIST DATA
The number of neo-Nazi and right-wing extremists declined from about 54,000 in
1998 to around 51,000 in 1999, the Federal Agency for the Protection of the
Constitution said in an official report. The number of rightists deemed likely
to commit acts of violence, however, grew by about 10 percent to 9,000, the
agency said, adding that recorded violent attacks by far rightists reached 746,
up from 708 in 1998. Germany's seven million foreigners are considered
particular targets of those attacks.  Victor Homola (NYT)

GERMANY: SPYING ON KOHL
The former head of East Germany's foreign espionage service, Markus Wolf, said
in an interview with Reuters that his agents had known for a long time about the
illegal slush fund set up by the Christian Democrats under former Chancellor
Helmut Kohl. But he said he made little use of the information because he
considered all capitalists to be corrupt.  Victor Homola (NYT)

Cambodia's Latest Plague: Lynch Law

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1299 words

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia


What most unnerved Olivier de Bernon as he faced a violent mob not long ago was
the sight of a group of Buddhist monks in their bright orange robes, laughing
and pointing at him.

Mr. de Bernon, a French historian, had come across the crowd as it was kicking
and punching a young man accused of stealing a motorbike. Without stopping to
think, Mr. de Bernon stepped into the crowd, he recalled.

"He was already down and they were still beating him," Mr. de Bernon said. "At
the beginning I had one leg shaking, a mixture of fear and anger. I was so
upset. I was so upset. I knew at once that it was a lynching. They wanted to
kill him."

Without a word being spoken, the crowd fell back at the sight of the determined
foreigner. And then, for the next two hours until an ambulance arrived, Mr. de
Bernon stood over the unconscious young man, face to face with the crowd and a
dozen passive police officers and the group of giggling monks, who had not taken
part in the attack but found Mr. de Bernon's behavior so unusual as to be
amusing.

This kind of mob justice, often abetted by police officers who say they find the
lynchings and beatings a short-cut around the vagaries of the courts, has become
an epidemic in Cambodia.

The spread of mob killings in the past year is one of many signs of the failure
of a justice system that the United Nations tried to put in place here nearly a
decade ago.

All of this has led most experts to agree that Cambodian courts are unfit to
conduct a fair and professional tribunal for the men who led the Khmer Rouge
from 1975 to 1979, when more than a million people lost their lives.

When their guerrilla movement collapsed in the past two years, most of the Khmer
Rouge leaders retired, unchallenged, to quiet lives in Phnom Penh and elsewhere.
These include five former members of the Khmer Rouge standing committee, prime
defendants in any trial.

The United Nations, which has proposed to create an international court, has
reached an impasse with Prime Minister Hun Sen, who insists that Cambodian
prosecutors and judges dominate any tribunal.

As this dispute continues, the spread of mob killings -- and the number of
ordinary Cambodians who support them -- offers its own verdict on the quality of
the judicial system: the lynchings have become known as "people's courts."

"It's 'instant justice,' " said a foreign diplomat with long experience here.
"'Since there is no justice, I'll do it myself.' And the police are often
present and encourage people to do it."

"It shows the fragility or even the nonexistence of any form of a just system at
any level," he said. "I think it also shows the frustration of the people and
the brutality of this culture, still. This is a way to kill people very similar
to the way the Khmer Rouge did it. You don't need a gun; you can do it more
cheaply."

Most discouraging to those who want to reform the justice system is that many
Cambodians seem not to see the difference between the workings of a court system
and the rule of the mob.

When Mr. de Bernon returned to his office in Phnom Penh, where he is based, he
said, his Cambodian staff -- like the monks who had watched him -- found his
behavior peculiar. They tried to educate him: "But he was a thief," they said.
"People were upset."

The most prominent example of this blind spot in Cambodia's development is a new
campaign by Mr. Hun Sen -- at least partly aimed at impressing foreign critics
-- to whip the judiciary into line by executive fiat.

In what he called an anticorruption campaign, he ordered the police to rearrest
scores of suspects who were released without trial or freed before their
sentences were complete.

"The government respects the independence of the courts," the prime minister
said, "But we cannot allow bad people inside the court system to act
improperly."

This kind of attitude is the at the nub of the dispute over a trial of Khmer
Rouge leaders, said Demelza Stubbings, a representative of the London-based
rights group Amnesty International.

"Who is going to be in charge of a tribunal of the Khmer Rouge?" she asked. "Is
the government going to tell the court to try them again if it doesn't like the
results?"

More likely, experts here say, the outcome of any Cambodian-run trials would be
decided before they start. In what some people see as a test case, one Khmer
Rouge commander was tried last year for killings committed after the group was
driven from power. He was found guilty; the trial took one day.

The flip side of these convictions by fiat is the debilitating fact of life in
Cambodia that people with power, influence or money almost always go free.

"The phrase 'culture of impunity' has become almost a cliche," said the New
York-based group Human Rights Watch in a recent report on the justice system.
"The problem ranges from the failure to prosecute Khmer Rouge leaders to
hundreds of more recent unpunished crimes committed by current government
authorities."

Government officials, their bodyguards, members of the military, village leaders
and their goons, well-connected brothel owners and anybody with the money to pay
for freedom -- rarely are any of these punished.

No one has been arrested in a grenade attack at an opposition rally three years
ago in which at least 17 people were killed and more than 100 injured. No one
has been arrested in more than 100 political killings that followed Mr. Hun
Sen's coup in July 1997.

When soldiers shot dead nine fishermen suspected of stealing cows, the
investigating judge told Human Rights Watch she had not taken any action on the
case.

"I worry about my safety because the case is connected to the police, local
authorities and the military," the investigator explained. "The police and the
commune chief are O.K., but the military might be difficult."

Even if any of these cases were to reach a courtroom, the administration of
justice remains primitive.

Most educated people -- including judges and lawyers -- were executed during the
Khmer Rouge time. Many of the survivors fled as refugees in the 1980's when
Cambodia was occupied by Vietnam. Real legal education has only begun here since
the United Nations tied to restore a civil society in the early 1990's.

As a result, many judges have little or no legal education and many have not
been taught basic principles of justice.

It is a paradox that Mr. Hun Sen has formally acknowledged the inability of the
courts to try the Khmer Rouge, while insisting that they conduct the trials.

"The reason people kill robbers in the streets is that they have no trust in the
courts," he said recently.

It was into this world of topsy-turvy "justice" that Mr. de Bernon stepped the
other day. The representative in Cambodia of the French school of Asian affairs,
l'Ecole francaise d'Extreme-Orient, he has lived in Cambodia for 10 years.

"In less than two minutes it was clear that nothing would happen to me," he
recalled. "I understood rapidly that none of them was upset, enraged, angry.
They were just giving way to their bad instinct. Just because I was there I
spoiled something, a self-allowance beyond normal behavior. Physically I was
nothing, but I think I broke a game."

From time to time, he said, someone from the crowd would approach the man on the
ground and give a little kick or lift his eyelids with a key to see whether he
was still alive.

"I stood next to him, two hours, and when they came sometimes to play with the
body I interfered, gently, saying nothing," Mr. de Bernon said.

He said he spoke to a member of the crowd only once.

"The only thing I said was to a boy who kicked his head with his heel," he said.
"I had a very bad glance at him and I called him in Khmer, 'You are a chicken
with white ears.' A coward."

McCain Regrets Silence on Flag Issue

BYLINE: By The New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 324 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18


Senator John McCain of Arizona is expected to tell South Carolinians on
Wednesday that the state should remove the Confederate battle flag from over its
Statehouse and that he should have said so during the primary campaign there,
Republicans who have been briefed on the event said.

The Republicans said that in an address in the South Carolina capital, Columbia,
Mr. McCain would concede that he made a mistake in January when, in courting the
state's conservative voters, he said at one point that the flag was a "symbol of
heritage."

Civil rights groups have fought for removal of the flag, which was first erected
by segregationists at the height of the civil rights movement. The flag's
supporters call it a symbol of heritage, not racism, arguing that the Civil War
was over states' rights, not slavery.

The flag became a volatile issue during the primary. Mr. McCain's new position
could put pressure on Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, to alter his position that
it was a matter for South Carolina to decide.

When Mr. Bush was asked today about Mr. McCain's expected statement, he said: "I
believed the people of South Carolina should best solve this issue. I still
believe that. And I believe they will."

During the campaign, Mr. McCain made conflicting comments about the flag.

In January, Mr. McCain said he considered it "offensive" and a "symbol of racism
and slavery." The next day, in a statement distributed to South Carolina
reporters, he reversed himself and called the flag "a symbol of heritage." Aides
said he had misspoken in the television interview.

Then the next day, in an interview in New Hampshire, which was about to hold its
primary, Mr. McCain reversed himself again, saying that if he said he saw the
flag as a symbol of heritage, he had misspoken.

"My forefathers fought under the Confederate flag," Mr. McCain said. "I believe
that they believed their service was honorable."

                 April 20, 2000, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

After Campaigning on Candor, McCain Admits He Lacked It on Confederate Flag
Issue

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

SECTION: Section A;  Page 22;  Column 1;  National Desk

LENGTH: 952 words

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C. April 19


Senator John McCain apologized today for not having called for the removal of
the Confederate battle flag from the South Carolina Statehouse when he
campaigned in the state's Republican presidential primary, saying he had
compromised his principles out of political self-interest.

Mr. McCain, who built his presidential quest on a reputation for candor and
patriotism, said he had equivocated on the flag issue because he feared that if
his true feelings had been known it would have undermined his effort to wrest
the nomination from Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. Mr. McCain said in the
campaign that the divisive issues should be left to the state, as had Mr. Bush,
who stood by the position today.

In a subdued speech at a luncheon a stone's throw from the Capitol where the
Confederate battle flag flies, Mr. McCain, a former Navy war hero whose
ancestors fought for the South, indicted himself for a lapse in honor.

"I feared that if I answered honestly, I could not win the South Carolina
primary," Mr. McCain said. "So I chose to compromise my principles. I broke my
promise to always tell the truth."

Mr. McCain lost the Feb. 19 primary, a defeat that severely hurt his chance to
derail Mr. Bush's drive to the Republican nomination.

In the pivotal primary campaign, Mr. McCain repeatedly was asked his opinion of
whether the flag should be removed from atop the Capitol dome. Many liberal and
civil rights organizations, led by the National Association for the Advancement
of Colored People, have been pressing to have the flag known as the "star and
bars" taken down, declaring that it is a symbol of slavery and oppression of
African-Americans.

In January, Mr. McCain said he considered the flag a "symbol of racism and
slavery." The next day he called it a "symbol of heritage," a phrase used by
supporters of the flag. At all times he declared that the issue should be left
up to the people of South Carolina to decide without interference from
outsiders.

Today Mr. McCain said that both of his characterizations of the flag had been
accurate and that he still believed the matter should be handled by state
officials. But, Mr. McCain went on to say that his Confederate forefathers
"fought on the wrong side of American history."

"I don't believe their service, however distinguished, needs to be commemorated
in a way that offends, that deeply hurts, people whose ancestors were once
denied their freedom by my ancestors," he said.

Mr. McCain's statement today may place pressure on Mr. Bush to clearly state
where he stands. But Mr. McCain refused to be drawn in to a discussion of what
his action might mean for his one-time rival.

"This was an issue that affected my campaign," he told reporters after his
speech. "I don't believe it will affect anyone else's."

In response to questions, Mr. McCain also repeated his insistence that he would
"categorically state to Governor Bush that I do not want to be asked" to be the
presumptive Republican nominee's running mate in the fall. The Texas governor
has said he wanted to discuss this directly with Mr. McCain at a meeting
scheduled for early May.

As for flying the battle flag, "Governor Bush believes on principle that this is
a state issue for the people of South Carolina to decide, and, as he predicted,
they are working to address," said Scott McClellan, a spokesman for Mr. Bush.

Reading from a prepared text at the luncheon, Mr. McCain acknowledged that his
belated confession would not shield him from criticism.

"I do not intend for this apology to help me evade criticism for my failure," he
said.

"I will be criticized by all sides for my late act of contrition," Mr. McCain
added. "I accept it, all of it. I deserve it. Honesty is easy after the fact
when my own interests are no longer involved. I don't seek absolution."

Mr. McCain's appearance today before the South Carolina Policy Council, a
conservative, business-oriented research group, was on his first time back in
the state since his defeat in the primary. In his absence the issue of the flag
has continued to simmer. Last week, the South Carolina Senate passed a
compromise measure that would remove the battle flag from atop the dome and
place a smaller version in a monument to Confederate soldiers on the Capitol
grounds. That measure is now before the South Carolina House of Representatives.
The outcome there is uncertain.

How Mr. McCain's comments will affect the debate here is an open question. After
his speech he was given a standing ovation by most of the about 60 people at the
luncheon. Later, several pressed forward to shake his hand and say they admired
his candor.

"I think it took a lot of courage to come back down here and do this, to admit a
mistake and to admit he may be criticized for the mistake," said Cordell Maddox,
a Democratic representative from Anderson, S.C., who supports the Senate
measure. "What I'm hoping is that it's going to give some courage to people who
are on the fence about the Senate compromise."

One person who did not join in the acclaim for Mr. McCain was Jake Knotts, a
state Republican representative from Lexington County outside Columbia who sat
in stony silence while others applauded. Mr. Knotts was one of the few
Republican legislators who supported Mr. McCain in the primary. He is also a
flag supporter who said he had pressed Mr. McCain in the campaign on his true
feelings about the Confederate icon.

"Yes, I'm disappointed in him, very disappointed in him," Mr. Knotts said to
reporters after the speech. "I'm not only disappointed, I'm ashamed of him. I'm
ashamed that he lied to the people of South Carolina in order to further his
political career."

For Iran, Dark Pages of History

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 134 words



To the Editor:

Your recognition of the lingering Iranian bitterness toward the United States as
a result of the 1953 coup is laudable (editorial, April 18). However, it is
disingenuous to link the coup to the hostage-taking in 1979 as if the two were
somehow equivalent.

The Central Intelligence Agency's actions reinstituted a government that
oppressed millions and that required 25 years and thousands of lost lives to
overthrow. And anger at the meddlesome United States was at the heart of the
hostage-taking, from which all the hostages emerged alive after less than 15
months.

Neither the hostage-taking nor the coup is excusable, but if moral equivalence
is a condition for improved relations, then the cause is hopeless.

MAZDAK ATIGHI
Palo Alto, Calif., April 18, 2000

Sri Lanka, Limiting Reports, Says It Pushed Back Rebels

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 501 words

DATELINE: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, May 5


A day after tightening press censorship in the interests of national security,
the government said in an official press release today that troops had pushed
back Tamil rebels who were trying to capture the northern city of Jaffna, the
cultural capital of the minority Tamils.

But as they issued the release, officials also deleted portions of reports by
international news agencies that described an opposition rally organized by the
United National Party to protest the authorities' sweeping new powers.

"I consider this an issue of national security," said the chief censor, Ariya
Rubasinghe, director of information. "We can't afford to have commotions or
civil disturbances."

The regulations announced on Thursday let the government censor articles by
foreign reporters and close Sri Lankan newspapers that defy censorship rules.
Before, local journalists who ignored the censor received written warnings. The
government can also seize private property and prohibit strikes, political
rallies and criticism of President Chandrika Kumaratunga if it believes that is
necessary for security.

Mr. Rubasinghe said that although the regulations allowed censoring criticism of
Ms. Kumaratunga, "we won't enforce it seriously."

Since last month, the government has been in a pitched battle with the
Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, a group that has been fighting for a separate
homeland for the Hindu Tamil minority since 1983 and that the United States has
included on its list of terrorist organizations.

Since April 22, the rebels have taken control of two military bases in the
Tamil-dominated north in a push to regain Jaffna, which the government
recaptured five years ago. The majority of this island nation of 18 million is
Sinhalese and Buddhist.

The press release issued by Mr. Rubasinghe today said the government had
strengthened its position since April 22, when it pulled out of its sprawling
military base at Elephant Pass, which the Tigers now occupy.

"Continuous attacks by the troops caused the terrorists to flee southward with
their casualties," the release said. "All troops in Jaffna Peninsula are
determined to push back the terrorists. Due to confrontations on 3rd and 4th of
May, terrorists are in a state of disarray. However, the terrorists continued to
fire mortars at the troops."

The government said two soldiers were killed today and one was wounded. It added
that life continued normally in Jaffna, with government offices and schools
functioning. The government said it was providing "ample food" to residents who
needed the help.

It was not possible to assess the contents of the release, because no reporters
have been allowed to go to the battle front or to Jaffna, and telephone
communications to the peninsula have been disrupted.

Members of the United National Party held a rally here today in Independence
Square to protest the new regulations, including those that censor foreign press
accounts, saying they infringed on civil liberties.

                   May 21, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

As Political Crisis Mounts, Peru's Leader Relishes Fight

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

SECTION: Section 1; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1186 words

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, May 20


Taking a moment's break from a boisterous campaign rally the other day in the
colonial city of Cajamarca, President Alberto K. Fujimori pointed to a dark
cloud gliding over his head and cried, "Let there be rain for the farmers!"

Within moments, the sky poured open, and thousands cheered.

"Don't worry," Mr. Fujimori laughed into his microphone. "Everything is
coordinated."

It has often seemed that way over the last 10 years, as Mr. Fujimori effectively
confronted an array of plagues -- from hyperinflation to terrorism to an
invasion of narcotics traffickers, from war with Ecuador to massive flooding
caused by El Nino.

But only a day after Mr. Fujimori played with the clouds over Cajamarca, he
faced a mounting political crisis that will surely challenge his considerable
pluck and power. Alejandro Toledo, his opponent in the May 28 runoff
presidential election, dropped out of the race on Thursday. Mr. Fujimori was
left with an open field for victory and the prospect of a third five-year term,
but one in which his legitimacy and credibility would be questioned both here
and abroad.

Mr. Fujimori now faces the possibility of unending protest marches, criticism
from Washington and other foreign capitals, and even, perhaps, economic
sanctions from the United States Congress and the Organization of American
States that could impede his fight against drug trafficking and unemployment.

The 61-year-old president, who is the son of Japanese immigrants, was able to
face down international pressures after he suspended the operations of his own
Congress and Supreme Court in 1992 because he had overwhelming popular support.
But now Peru is badly split, with university students and labor unions preparing
to mount the biggest street protests in more than a generation.

Mr. Fujimori, in effect, has become a victim of his own success. Now that he has
virtually defeated the terrorists of the Maoist Shining Path, a growing number
of Peruvians are seeking an easing of his authoritarianism. In the last three
years, even as the terrorism waned, Mr. Fujimori did not ease his hold on power.
He tightened it.

Mr. Fujimori decided he could run for re-election this year even though the
Constitution prohibits three consecutive terms. He had three judges dismissed by
Congress when they disagreed with his legal interpretation that the
constitutional term limit did not cover his first term because it was completed
before the Constitution itself. He then established control over several
television networks through legal maneuvers, and withdrew Peru from the
jurisdiction of a regional human rights court.

Mr. Fujimori's powers were amply on display in the first round of the
presidential race when all television networks, save for one cable channel,
virtually boycotted his opposition.

"He has been manipulating so much that even if he won fairly, people wouldn't
believe it was a fair process," said Enrique Zileri, editor of the political
magazine Caretas. "Whatever happens, Fujimori becomes a much weaker president
who will be discredited internationally."

Hernan Chaparro Melo, a pollster, said, "With 57 percent of the people
continuing to believe the election process is unjust, we are entering difficult
times."

But Mr. Fujimori has had his back to the wall before, and he has always shown
himself to be a leader of great resourcefulness and impeccable timing.

Over the last few weeks, Mr. Fujimori suddenly emerged from his early campaign
slumber and appeared eager for a fight. He told enthusiastic campaign rallies
with growing crowds that he would not accept a postponement of the election even
before Mr. Toledo demanded that the vote be put off several weeks to give
foreign election observers time to test new computer software installed to count
the vote.

Mr. Fujimori sharpened his message on television and on the stump, arguing more
forcefully that he is the one candidate strong enough to lead this desperately
poor and often chaotic country. Taking on his greatest weaknesses, he pledged an
all-out attack on unemployment and confronted his foreign critics with diatribes
designed to inspire Peruvian nationalism.

"We don't need foreigners to tell us how to hold elections," Mr. Fujimori told a
crowd in the city of Trujillo shortly after Mr. Toledo's announcement that he
was dropping out of the race if the election was not postponed. "We're sovereign
Peruvians and we have the right to hold our democracy."

And after underestimating Mr. Toledo, an American-educated business school
professor who rose meteorically in the weeks before the first round vote, Mr.
Fujimori finally began taking him on -- calling him a rudderless, indecisive
leader who only knows how to turn to Washington, Buenos Aires and European
capitals for political direction.

Mr. Fujimori's old magic was amply on display this week as he toured the north
of the country. He laughed, danced and gleefully tossed cassettes of his
campaign songs to passersby who thrilled at seeing their president.

As his campaign caravan twisted through the streets of Chiclayo, a local
witchdoctor livened the proceedings by cavorting before the president's campaign
truck, waving a giant pumpkin and spritzing some alcoholic brew through his
teeth and onto the swelling crowds.

And as a brass band played his campaign theme song, Mr. Fujimori went into a
fevered jig on the stump as a throng of more than 10,000 went wild. "My advisers
tell me I shouldn't dance," President Fujimori laughed, "but I can't help
myself!" It was the kind of populist touch that led him to landslide victories
in 1990 and 1995.

Speaking in his heavily accented English for effect, he told the crowd, "They
ask: 'What is happening in Peru?' " Then answering the question firmly in
Spanish, he said, "We've had a government the last 10 years that has been
decisive and has never ducked the tough issues."

To crowds that filled the central plaza of Cajamarca, a highland city of
magnificent baroque churches, luscious cheeses and lyrical poets where the Incas
made their first stand against the Spanish invaders in the 16th century, Mr.
Fujimori called on the crowd to cheer loud enough so the Argentine government
could hear.

Donning a tall straw hat popular with the Indian peasants here, he snickered at
Mr. Toledo for traveling earlier in the week to Buenos Aires to consult with
President Fernando de la Rua and former President Raul Alfonsin.

Speaking of his opponents, he said: "If they were really democrats and really
trusted the people, they wouldn't complain all the time in Washington and Buenos
Aires. They show by going abroad that they don't care about the votes of the
Peruvian people."

Sharpening the nationalistic argument is Francisco Tudela, a former foreign
minister and Mr. Fujimori's vice presidential candidate. "I think there is a
fear, an ideological fear, of a very independent government in Latin America
that is outside the establishment," Mr. Tudela said in an interview. He added,
"The fact that President Fujimori did not negotiate with terrorist groups
irritates some abroad."


http://www.nytimes.com

                   May 22, 2000, Monday, Late Edition - Final

Mr. Putin's Missteps

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 494 words


As President Clinton prepares to visit Moscow next month, there are disquieting
signs that Russia's new president, Vladimir Putin, is steering the Kremlin
toward anti-democratic policies. A government raid on a private media company
earlier this month and Moscow's recent welcome for Yugoslavia's defense
minister, who has been indicted for war crimes, suggest a contempt for
democratic values that Mr. Clinton and his aides must consider as they plan for
the Moscow summit meeting.

It is possible that the police raid on the offices of Media-MOST and the defense
minister's visit were tactical maneuvers designed to placate some of Mr. Putin's
conservative political allies rather than a signal of new policies. Even so, Mr.
Putin must have understood that the steps would send a chilling message in the
first days of his presidency.

The government defended the crude search of Media-MOST headquarters as necessary
to gather information for a criminal investigation of suspected financial
irregularities at the company. Mr. Putin himself echoed that view when he
endorsed the police action, while affirming his support for a free press. But it
is difficult to believe that the arrival of masked agents with automatic weapons
was not an effort to intimidate an enterprise whose publications and broadcast
outlets have been critical of Mr. Putin and his prosecution of the war in
Chechnya.

By hosting Dragoljub Ojdanic, Belgrade's defense minister and a loyal ally of
Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav president, Moscow defied the war crimes
tribunal in The Hague, which was established by the United Nations Security
Council to deal with atrocities in the recent Balkan ethnic conflicts. Mr.
Ojdanic was army chief of staff during the war in Kosovo. The tribunal last May
charged him and other Yugoslav leaders with responsibility for the deportation
of hundreds of thousands of ethnic Albanians and the murder of hundreds of
others.

As a member state of the U.N., Russia had an obligation to detain Mr. Ojdanic so
he could be brought to trial. Instead, he met with Russian defense officials and
moved freely through Moscow during a five-day visit that coincided with Mr.
Putin's inauguration. Last week, after a visit by Belgrade's foreign minister,
Moscow granted Yugoslavia a $102 million loan. Mr. Putin may be playing to
nationalist and Slavic sentiment in Russia with his embrace of Belgrade, but
these steps are a direct slap at Washington.

Mr. Clinton's advisers talk about the coming summit meeting as an opportunity to
take the measure of Mr. Putin, and a chance to explore a broad agenda of common
interests. The Russian leader may turn out to be a pragmatic negotiator.
Certainly he is more energetic and more familiar with policy details than his
predecessor, Boris Yeltsin. On economic issues, he seems inclined to spur
reform. But on such critical issues as respect for democratic principles, Mr.
Putin has not made a promising start.

http://www.nytimes.com

Turkey Reviews the Darkest Hours in Its Painful Past

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER

SECTION: Section 1; Page 8; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 629 words

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, May 27


When a Turkish prosecutor announced recently that he wanted to indict Gen. Kenan
Evren, who led the 1980 military coup, officials in Ankara were not amused.

They quickly announced that the prosecutor had been placed in semiretirement,
and then said he would be investigated for abusing his office.

"For years I waited for someone to open this case, but too much time was passing
so I decided to do it myself," said the prosecutor, Sacit Kayasu. "This army is
my army, and it should protect me, not repress me."

It remains highly unlikely that General Evren, now an 83-year-old retiree, will
ever be called to account for his three unsuccessful coup attempts, for the one
that succeeded in September 1980, or for the excesses committed during three
years of military rule that followed. But the fact that a prosecutor could even
consider indicting him reflects a new climate in which the coup, along with
other painful episodes in modern Turkish history, can be discussed more openly
than ever before.

Before leaving power in 1983, the military imposed a law giving itself immunity
from prosecution for crimes committed during the period when it ran the country.
A move to repeal that law is gathering strength, though there is no prospect of
a repeal anytime soon.

According to the official version of the events of 1980, Turkey had fallen into
such chaos -- with people cowering in their homes as cities were besieged by
terror -- that the military was forced to intervene. The arrest of thousands of
people after the coup is said to have been a regrettable necessity.

Attempts to prosecute General Evren are not the only signs that a revisionist
view is emerging. Two new films portray the torture that was widespread in
military prisons.

One of the films, called "Where the Rose Wilted," tells the story of an innocent
man who is arrested following the coup and, in intensely graphic scenes,
savagely tortured by sadistic police officers.

"How can they do this?" one character wonders. "Even beasts wouldn't do such a
thing."

The other film, "After the Fall," tells the story of the coup through the eyes
of a 5-year-old boy whose family is shattered by its effects. His parents are
arrested and tortured, his grandmother collapses and dies during an army raid on
her house, and his grandfather begins losing his mind as he wonders who is
responsible for the tragedy unfolding around him.

"If one family in a small village suffered so much from the coup, imagine what
happened to the whole country," said the film's director, Atif Yilmaz. "The
effects of the coup are still with us. A lot of people are still carrying scars
after 20 years."

Some of those who were tortured after the coup have gone on to become successful
in business, journalism and academia. A handful have even been elected to
Parliament, including one man whose glistening teeth are all false, replacements
for the ones smashed out during torture sessions.

"It's finally becoming possible to acknowledge and discuss these things," Mr.
Yilmaz said. "There's more openness and more desire for honesty. Part of it
comes from our moving closer to the European Union, but a lot of it just has to
do with Turkey starting to grow up. What people like me are doing is trying to
give this country back its memory."

The 1980 coup is not the only sensitive subject filmmakers are beginning to
confront. One much-praised new film deals with the "wealth tax" that was imposed
on Christian and Jewish Turks during the 1940's with the intention of
bankrupting them or forcing them to emigrate. Another portrays Kurds as victims
of discrimination and military repression.

"I wouldn't say the military likes this," said a foreign ambassador posted in
Ankara, "but they're letting it happen."

Fiji Military Takes Control And Declares Martial Law

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 342 words

DATELINE: PACIFIC HARBOR, Fiji, May 29


Fiji's military said today that it was taking control of the country and
declared martial law, stepping into a crisis in which the prime minister has
been held hostage by gunmen since May 19.

The head of the armed forces, Commodore Frank Bainimarama, announced tonight
that the military was taking power.

The commodore said the Fiji Military Forces reserved the right to use force if
necessary to maintain and enforce the curfew. "I have, with much reluctance,
assumed executive authority of the country and henceforth declared martial law,"
he said at a news conference. Troops on leave and reservists were recalled to
barracks.

Local news media reported that a group of military officers had met with Fiji's
president, Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara, presented him with a whale's tooth in a
traditional ceremony and asked him to step down.

Mr. Mara's private secretary, Joe Brown, said military officials had informed
him that the president had resigned to enable the enforcement of martial law.

In Suva, the capital, witnesses said military personnel armed with automatic
weapons had taken over checkpoints that were previously manned by unarmed
police.

The coup leader, George Speight, led a band of gunmen into the parliament
complex on May 19 and took Prime Minister Mahendra Chaudhry, an ethnic Indian,
and some 30 other people hostage, including Mr. Mara's daughter.

Mr. Speight said he was acting on behalf of indigenous Fijians in deposing the
Chaudhry government, dominated by ethnic Indians. He has since then been locked
in negotiations with President Mara about the future of the Pacific island
nation.

Mr. Speight proclaimed himself the new leader of Fiji, but President Mara had
declared a state of emergency and claimed executive powers for himself. The two
sides negotiated through the indigenous Fijian Great Council of Chiefs.

On the first day of the coup, mobs looted Suva and, as negotiations dragged on,
violence returned when two soldiers and a journalist were injured by gunfire
last Saturday.

To Right the Wrongs of Slavery

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 116 words



To the Editor:

I agree with Glenn C. Loury (Op-Ed, May 29) that all Americans "should be
challenged to understand the contemporary consequences" of slavery. But I
disagree that this "historic" crime deserves special treatment in the form of a
truth and reconciliation process. Can we say that the abusive treatment of
Native Americans, women and gays is of lesser evil than that perpetrated against
slaves?

Each of these groups was treated by our leaders as well as by most citizens in
ways that deprived them of their human rights, dignity and often their lives by
massacres, legal indifference to sexual abuse and gay bashing.

DAVID H. BERNARD
San Francisco, May 29, 2000
