               January 12, 2000, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

CAMPAIGN 2000: THE CONFEDERATE FLAG;
McCain Effort to Straddle Sensitive Southern Issue Leaves Position Unclear

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1377 words


Over the last three days, Senator John McCain has made three conflicting
statements on the Confederate battle flag issue raging in the key primary state
of South Carolina, and with each statement, his position has become less clear.

On Sunday, speaking on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," Mr. McCain said
he considered the battle flag "offensive" and a "symbol of racism and slavery."

The next day, in a statement distributed to South Carolina reporters, Mr. McCain
reversed himself and called the flag "a symbol of heritage," using the precise
language that white Republicans have used in the state to justify keeping the
flag flying over the statehouse. Aides said he had misspoken in the television
interview.

Then last night, in an interview in New Hampshire, Mr. McCain reversed himself
again, saying that if he said he sees the flag a symbol of heritage, he
misspoke.

"My forfathers fought under the Confederate flag," Mr. McCain said. "I believe
that they believed their service was honorable."

But the statement calling the flag a symbol of heritage has been on his campaign
Web site for two days, and was distributed as a news release by his staff. His
top South Carolina strategist, Richard M. Quinn, said earlier in the day that
Mr. McCain had called the flag a symbol of heritage "at least 150 times in the
past."

But while the phrase "symbol of heritage" may sound innocuous outside the South,
its meaning is unmistakable in a region where conflicting interpretations of the
Civil War are often as important as any contemporary political issue. Saying the
flag is a symbol of heritage rather than a reminder of racism, is an argument
made by those who say the war was not fought over slavery, but over state's
rights.

Although Mr. McCain, like the other major Republican candidates, has declined to
take a position on the specific issue of whether the flag should fly over the
South Carolina statehouse, his characterization of the flag's symbolism makes
him the only major presidential contender to empathize with the flag's
supporters.

"When whites say heritage in the South, they are generally referring to a
heritage in which black people are excluded," said Bernard Powers, a professor
of history at the College of Charleston. "In the best possible light, the
senator is just trying to be political, but I fear that he is uninformed about a
critically important element of American history and its legacy for contemporary
times."

The flag issue is enormously volatile in South Carolina, which is holding a
Republican presidential primary on Feb. 19 that is crucial to Mr. McCain's hopes
for the nomination. The N.A.A.C.P. has declared an economic boycott against the
state as long as the flag flies over the capitol, but Republicans in the state
House of Representatives have blocked any attempt to move it.

In declaring the flag a symbol of heritage, Mr. McCain, an Arizonan, has taken a
more conservative position than his chief rival for the Republican nomination,
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas or any other major candidate. When he is asked
about the flag issue in South Carolina, Mr. Bush has repeatedly said the matter
was for South Carolinians to decide. On Monday night, he told MSNBC in an
interview that he would not fly the Confederate flag over the Texas statehouse
"because of the symbolism."

But Mr. McCain has much closer ties to the leaders of the pro-flag movement. One
of the most prominent members of the so-called Heritage Movement in the state,
who has helped organize the campaign to keep the flag flying, is Mr. Quinn.

Mr. Quinn, the editor in chief of the neo-Confederate magazine Southern
Partisan, is the father of state Representative Rick Quinn, the majority leader,
who has said the flag will not be lowered as long as the N.A.A.C.P. boycott is
in effect.

The elder Mr. Quinn said yesterday that he had not pushed Mr. McCain to support
the flag. But the emotions sweeping the state are intense and may explain why
Mr. McCain felt the need to issue a formal statement.

Although the business community is lobbying hard to remove the flag, most of the
Republicans in the legislature -- who represent white disnecessary to win the
primary -- are fervently in favor of the flag.

Mr. McCain's written statement, which also appeared on his Web site, was his
first on the subject, and was issued quickly after he seemed to suggest on
Sunday that he found the flag offensive.

"The Confederate flag is offensive in many, many ways, as we all know," he said
on the CBS program "Face the Nation" on Sunday. "It's a symbol of racism and
slavery. But I also understand how others do not view it in that fashion. My
forbears from Mississippi fought under the Confederate flag. They were not slave
owners, and I'm sure they considered their service -- one I believe died in
Shiloh -- was honorable. So, I obviously understand why many Americans find it
offensive."

A day later, he issued a statement apparently intended to correct the impression
that he finds the flag offensive, and it was that most recent statement that
appears to align him with the flag supporters.

"As to how I view the flag, I understand both sides," he said in the statement.
"Some view it as a symbol of slavery; others view it as a symbol of heritage.
Personally, I see the battle flag as a symbol of heritage."

But when asked last night why he said he saw the flag as a symbol of heritage,
Mr. McCain said, "If I said it, I misspoke."

He added, "My forefathers fought under that flag. I know that they thought their
service was honorable."

John Weaver, Mr. McCain's political director, said last night that Mr. McCain
had used the phrase many times but was referring to his relatives' service in
the Confederate army. "He's talking about the heritage of his family," Mr.
Weaver said. "That's different from heritage that some may see it as -- a sign
of segregation or political issues."

Mr. Quinn said in an interview yesterday that Mr. McCain had misspoken on Sunday
by not saying the flag was offensive "to some people." He added that Mr. McCain
has often said in the past that he considers the flag a symbol of heritage, but
had never issued a formal, written statement of his position before. Several
political reporters in South Carolina confirmed that they had heard Mr. McCain
describe the flag as a symbol of heritage over the past year.

Mr. Bush has several pro-flag supporters in his camp, as well, including Charlie
Condon, the state attorney general, co-chairman of Mr. Bush's South Carolina
campaign. But none are as well known for their ideology as is Mr. Quinn, whose
quarterly magazine has become a leading journal of the notion that the Civil War
was not fought over slavery.

A recent issue, the cover of which shows a man reading an Uncle Remus book to
his grandchildren, contains a list of the 15 best Southern books of all time.
Though the list includes Faulkner, Robert Penn Warren and Margaret Mitchell,
most are apologias for the Southern cause, and none is by a black writer.

"The magazine takes the view that the flag should be regarded as a symbol of
heritage, rather than slavery," said Mr. Quinn, who was the Rev. Pat Robertson's
media adviser in 1988. "Many Southerners believe that there are positive aspects
to Southern history, without having to link everything to slavery. Taking down
the flag or hiding it or treating it in a dishonorable way turns the banner over
to the racists on both sides. It helps define the flag as something ugly and
evil rather than something that memorializes the heroism of these young men who
fell for the South, most of whom were not slaveowners."

But the word "heritage" means something different to South Carolina's blacks,
most of whom do not vote in the Republican primary.

"It's a word kind of like 'choice' or 'life' in abortion, a code word to mean
certain things that people don't want to come right out and say," said Dr.
Lonnie Randolph Jr., president of the Columbia branch of the N.A.A.C.P., who
oversees the group's economic sanctions against the state. "Of course the flag
has to do with heritage, but it's a heritage of white supremacy and racism. Too
many people are in denial about what the heritage really is."

               January 12, 2000, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

Supreme Court Shields States From Lawsuits on Age Bias

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1305 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11


Continuing its march in the direction of states' rights, the Supreme Court ruled
today that Congress lacked the authority to bind state governments to the
federal law that bars discrimination against older workers.

The national policy against age discrimination in employment could not overcome
the states' sovereign immunity from suit in federal court, the 5-to-4 majority
said in the first of five federalism rulings the court is due to hand down
during its current term.

The vote was the same as in a series of rebuffs the court has dealt Congress
over the past five years on issues ranging from the regulation of gun possession
near schools to the right of state employees to sue for overtime and of
patent-holders to sue states for patent infringement.

The difference this time was a notable hardening of tone, with both the majority
and dissenting opinions conveying the impression that the two sides, wedded to
sharply opposing views of the authentic nature of the federal system, had little
left to say to one another across one of the great divides in the court's recent
history.

The dissenters, led by Justice John Paul Stevens, accused the majority of
substituting its own will for that of Congress and of displaying "the kind of
judicial activism" that "represents such a radical departure from the proper
role of this court that it should be opposed whenever the opportunity arises."

Justice Sandra Day O'Connor responded for the majority that the dissenters'
refusal to accept the court's recent rulings "makes it difficult to engage in
additional meaningful debate on the place of state sovereign immunity in the
Constitution."

The others in the majority were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices
Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy and Clarence Thomas. Justices David H.
Souter, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen G. Breyer joined the dissent.

Justice O'Connor announced the decision this morning just before the court
turned to hearing arguments in another of the term's federalism cases, the
government's effort to defend a central provision of the Violence Against Women
Act as a proper exercise of Congressional authority. The provision at issue,
authorizing victims of violence motivated by gender to sue their attackers for
damages in federal court, met with considerable skepticism from the justices who
formed the majority in today's ruling.

Congress passed the Age Discrimination in Employment Act in 1967 and extended it
to state governments in 1974. The law protects employees against discrimination
on the basis of age beginning at age 40 and authorizes suits for damages in
federal court.

While all states offer their employees some form of state-court redress for age
discrimination, the remedies vary and in many cases are not as useful as the
federal law, which provides for reimbursement of attorneys' fees and for double
damages in cases of willful violations.

In New York, employees may sue the state, but only in the Court of Claims, which
does not have jury trials; attorneys' fees are not reimbursed, and there are no
double damages. New Jersey state employees can take their complaints to the
state Department of Labor, which may order reimbursement for lost pay.
Connecticut employees have redress in the state's Commission on Human Rights and
Opportunities.

The decision today, affirming a 1998 ruling by the federal appeals court in
Atlanta, came in a consolidated appeal on behalf of a group of faculty members
and librarians employed by state universities in Alabama and Florida. The
Clinton administration joined the appeal to defend the constitutionality of the
law as applied to the state employers.

The decision, Kimel v. Florida Board of Regents, No. 98-791, came against a
background of several recent rulings interpreting the 11th Amendment, which
provides states with immunity from suit in federal court, and circumscribing the
ability of Congress to overcome the states' immunity. In a 1996 ruling, Seminole
Tribe v. Florida, the court held that Congress could not breach state immunity
in the exercise of its authority to regulate interstate commerce.

That left only one route for Congress: section 5 of the 14th Amendment, under
which Congress may act through "appropriate legislation" to carry out the
amendment's guarantees of due process and equal protection. On this basis, the
administration defended the application of the Age Discrimination in Employment
Act to the states, and on this basis the court's majority rejected it.

The law "is not 'appropriate legislation' under Section 5 of the 14th
Amendment," Justice O'Connor said, because age discrimination itself was not
inherently unconstitutional and because the law imposed requirements that "are
disproportional to any unconstitutional conduct that conceivably could be
targeted by the Act." The extension of the law to the states "was an unwarranted
response to a perhaps inconsequential problem," she said.

Justice O'Connor noted that over the last 25 years the court has rejected
constitutional challenges to mandatory retirement ages for various groups of
public employees. The lesson of these cases was that states were free to make
distinctions on the basis of age as long as the policy was rational, she said,
adding that there was no constitutional requirement that states "match age
distinctions and the legitimate interests they serve with razor-like precision."

"Under the 14th Amendment, a state may rely on age as a proxy for other
qualities, abilities, or characteristics that are relevant to the state's
legitimate interests," Justice O'Connor continued. Drawing a distinction between
age discrimination and discrimination on the basis of race or sex, she said that
old age "does not define a discrete and insular minority because all persons, if
they live out their normal life spans, will experience it."

This distinction raised the question of the fate of provisions in other federal
laws that bar states from other forms of discrimination against their employees,
such as the Americans with Disabilities Act or the Equal Pay Act's prohibition
against sex discrimination in the workplace.

Cases questioning whether these laws can be applied to the states as employers
have been appealed to the Supreme Court, and the justices may announce within a
week whether they will hear any of them. Justice O'Connor's opinion today left
open the possibility that other federal antidiscrimination laws might still
apply to the states as employers.

However, the majority opinion also made clear that to sustain such an
application, the court would have to be persuaded that Congress had acted not
only in response to discrimination in general, but to proof of a widespread
pattern of discrimination by the states themselves. There was no such evidence
of age discrimination by the states, Justice O'Connor said.

It was this part of the opinion, as much as anything else, that appeared to
provoke the dissenters' anger. Justice Stevens accused the majority of relying
on its own legislative judgments and of ignoring "the importance of respecting
the framers' decision to assign the business of lawmaking to the Congress."
Justice Stevens said the court should recognize that the Constitution itself
adequately protects state interests against federal intrusion by giving each
state equal representation in the Senate and by apportioning the House of
Representatives along state lines.

The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees issued a
statement denouncing today's decision. "We emphatically disagree that Congress
has overstepped its powers in extending to public employees the same legal
protections as private employees," said Gerald W. McEntee, the federation's
president. "Public employees are not second-class citizens."

                 January 14, 2000, Friday, Late Edition - Final

Republicans and the Confederate Flag

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 421 words


Both leading Republican candidates for president, Senator John McCain and Gov.
George W. Bush, are being too clever by half in the perennially inflammatory
debate over the Confederate battle flag in South Carolina. By declining to take
a principled stand in this key primary state, the candidates are pandering to
bias and perpetuating an outdated and ignoble practice from past Republican
campaigns.

For years, South Carolina has been the only state to fly the Confederate battle
flag over its Capitol. Black South Carolinians and many whites rightly view the
flag as a reactionary symbol of slavery and segregation, but they have sought in
vain to have it removed. The N.A.A.C.P. has declared an economic boycott against
the state for as long as the flag flies, but Republicans in the state
legislature have blocked all attempts to lower it.

Senator McCain, for whom the state's primary on Feb. 19 will be a crucial test,
has made conflicting statements on the flag. On Sunday, facing a national
television audience, he properly called it "offensive" and a "symbol of racism
and slavery." A day later, addressing South Carolina reporters, he reversed
himself and called the flag "a symbol of heritage." This was unmistakable code
language that conservative white Republicans -- Mr. McCain's base in the state
-- have long used to justify keeping the flag flying over the Statehouse.

Governor Bush has been no more principled.  While he has said he would not fly
the Confederate flag over the Texas Statehouse "because of the symbolism," he
has also repeatedly said that the matter was for South Carolinians to decide.
This won't do. It fails to take into account the concerns of a minority that
lacks the political strength to expunge this affront to its dignity as an equal.

Other states across the South have long since moved beyond this ugly debate.
Alabama, the last to do so, removed its flag from the Capitol dome in Montgomery
in 1993 after black legislators won a lawsuit. Business leaders throughout the
region, eager to compete in a cosmopolitan global market, have been at the
forefront of efforts to remove the alienating emblems of a bygone era.

The campaign in South Carolina recalls earlier efforts by the Republican Party
to tap into residual segregationist impulses, from Richard Nixon's Southern
Strategy to Ronald Reagan's appeal for states' rights at a county fair in
Philadelphia, Miss., in 1980. Today's Republicans are playing a cynical and, one
might have hoped, obsolete game.

                January 15, 2000, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

War Crimes Court Convicts 5 Bosnian Croats in '93 Massacre

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 465 words

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 14


The international war crimes tribunal in The Hague, in its largest case to date,
convicted and sentenced five Bosnian Croat militiamen today for taking part in
the massacre of more than 100 Muslims in a Bosnian village in April 1993.

In its ruling, the court rejected arguments that the massacre -- in Ahmici, a
village in central Bosnia where Muslims, including children, were burned alive
in their homes -- was a random act. Instead the court found that the killings
and burnings were part of an organized effort to terrorize Muslims and force
them to leave the region.

The presiding judge, Antonio Cassese, noted that the killing of unarmed Muslim
civilians had served no military purpose.

"Indisputably, what happened on April 16, 1993, has gone down in history as
comprising one of the most vicious illustrations of man's inhumanity to man,"
the judge said.

"Today, the name of that small village must be added to the long list of
previously unknown hamlets and towns that recall abhorrent misdeeds and make us
shudder with horror and shame," he added, going on to mention Dachau and My Lai.
A total of 116 were killed in the attack, including 33 women and children.

The court ordered the five men -- Zoran and Mirjan Kupreskic; their cousin
Vlatko Kupreskic; Drago Josipovic; and Vladimir Santic -- to serve sentences
from 6 to 25 years.

The prosecution praised the sentences, saying they set a benchmark for future
cases of "ethnic cleansing." Several higher-ranking defendants still await
verdicts.

The court also acquitted one defendant, Dragan Papic, saying his role in the
local militia was unclear and there was insufficient evidence to show he had
played an active role in the attack.

Since the trial began more than 15 months ago, the three trial judges had heard
testimony from 158 witnesses, some of whom described in detail the horrors of
the day when Ahmici was overrun by fighters who machine gunned entire families,
killed their livestock and set houses on fire. One witness in the case told how
she stood on a balcony, her dead son below, as jeering Bosnian Croat soldiers
told her to jump.

Four of the five men were convicted of persecution for helping to organize or
taking part in the violence, first shelling, then attacking house to house, as
soldiers of the Croatia Defense Force swept through the Lasva Valley from
January to May 1993.

The court described how the five had taken part in a rampage that resulted in
the killing of Muslims and the burning of 169 houses and two mosques. The
"tragic episode" was aimed at expelling the Muslims from the village, stopping
short of the most serious war crimes charge, genocide, the court said.

Lawyers for the five convicted men said they were shocked by the ruling and
planned to appeal.

WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 983 words



THE AMERICAS

MEXICO: CONVICTIONS OVERTURNED
Citing procedural errors by the prosecution, an appeals court overturned the
murder convictions of 24 pro-government Indians from the state of Chiapas, in a
case stemming from a 1997 incident in which 45 unarmed people, mainly women and
children, were killed. The victims were sympathizers of the Zapatista rebels.
Prosecutors can present their case again, and the accused will remain in jail.
   Julia Preston (NYT)

PERU: U.S. WOMAN ON HUNGER STRIKE
A New York woman convicted as a terrorist has begun a hunger strike, stepping up
pressure for a new trial at the start of the fifth year of her life sentence.
Jailed as a Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement leader, Lori Berenson, 30, began
refusing food Tuesday and is being monitored by doctors, prison authorities
said.   (Reuters)


COLOMBIA: ALBRIGHT IN TALKS
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright has arrived in Cartagena for two days
of talks with President Andres Pastrana on a trip that will also take her to
Panama and Mexico. The talks follow a two-year plan announced by Washington to
funnel $1.3 billion in emergency help to Colombia, much of it for military
equipment and training to fight leftist guerrilla groups.   Larry Rohter (NYT)

VENEZUELA: U.S. AID SPURNED
The Pentagon has delayed the arrival of two United States ships, on their way to
Venezuela with 450 marine and navy engineers to help the country rebuild from
floods and landslides. The action came after President Hugo Chavez was quoted as
saying he did not want American troops on Venezuelan soil. "Clearly, if they
don't want the help, we won't provide it," the Defense Department spokesman,
Kenneth H. Bacon, said.   Larry Rohter (NYT)

ARGENTINA: EMERGENCY PACKAGE
President Fernando de la Rua introduced to Congress an emergency economic
package that would allow him to fire thousands of government workers and
refinance the public debt. The legislation also requests authority to create
special judges to prosecute tax evasion.   Clifford Krauss (NYT)

MIDDLE EAST

ISRAEL: BARAK AND ARAFAT TO MEET
Prime Minister Ehud Barak will take a break from negotiations with Syria to meet
with the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, in Washington next Thursday, Foreign
Minister David Levy announced. Thursday is also the day that Israeli is expected
to undertake another large withdrawal from the West Bank.   Deborah Sontag (NYT)


ISRAEL: WAVE OF ARRESTS
Israeli troops carried out a series of "preventive" arrests in the West Bank
based on information that the Islamic Holy War group was planning attacks, the
army said. According to its statement, which did not say how many were being
held, the arrests were made near Jenin, Hebron and Ramallah.   (Reuters)

PALESTINIANS: ARREST LINKED TO ABU NIDAL
A key associate of the Abu Nidal guerrilla group, Nimer Halima, has been
arrested in Vienna, the police said. The group carried out deadly attacks in
Vienna in 1981, 1982 and 1985. Format magazine said Ms. Halima was detained as
she tried to withdraw $7.4 million from a bank.
   (Agence France-Presse)

KUWAIT: IRAQ-BACKED LEADER HELD
The leader installed in Kuwait after Iraq's August 1990 invasion is being held
in Kuwait after flying in from Norway in defiance of a death sentence against
him, the airport police said. Col. Alaa Hussein Ali headed the government set up
by Baghdad after its invasion of Kuwait in the 1991 gulf war.   (Agence
France-Presse)

AFRICA

NIGERIA: ISLAMIC LAW EXTENDED
A fifth province, Niger, has announced plans to extend Islamic law, or sharia,
after its declaration in Zamfara state last October, officials said. In December
the states of Kano, Sokoto and Yobe also announced steps to extend the law to
criminal and civil areas, claiming that right under the May 1999 Constitution.
   (Agence France-Presse)

EUROPE

GERMANY: KOHL TO TESTIFY
Former Chancellor Helmut Kohl was summoned as the first witness by a
parliamentary committee investigating his use of secret funds channeled to his
Christian Democratic Party. The panel, which will press Mr. Kohl to identify the
donors of more than $1 million during his tenure, begins work next Wednesday,
and he is likely to appear soon after that.   Roger Cohen (NYT)

FINLAND: CLOSE VOTE PREDICTED
Opinion polls for Sunday's first round of balloting for the successor to
President Martti Ahtisaari shows former Prime Minister Esko Aho, the Center
Party candidate, running even with the Social Democrat, Foreign Minister Tarja
Halonen, above. No one is expected to win more than 50 percent of the vote, and
a runoff is scheduled for Feb. 6.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

SPAIN: BASQUE LEADER FREED
Jose Antonio Urrutikoetxea, 48, a former top commander of the Basque separatist
group E.T.A., left prison after the high court freed him on the ground that he
had been convicted in France in 1990 on the same terrorism charges he faced in
Spain, where he was sent in 1996.   Al Goodman (NYT)

CROATIA: LEADER EMERGES
Stipe Mesic, 66, Croatia's last representative to the Yugoslavia that broke
apart in 1991, has emerged as a narrow leader in the presidential race to
succeed the late Franjo Tudjman, according to a poll to be published by the
newspaper Jutarnji List today, Reuters reported. The first round of elections
will be held Jan. 24.   Steven Erlanger (NYT)

ASIA

CHINA: FALUN GONG SENTENCE
A court has sentenced a retired senior air force official, 74, to 17 years in
prison on charges he was an organizer of the Falun Gong spiritual group,
according to the Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in
China, based in Hong Kong. Yu Changxin was formerly a pilot and Air Force
Command Institute professor. The Ministry of Defense would not confirm the
report.   Erik Eckholm (NYT)

Suspect in Serbian War Crimes Murdered by Masked Gunmen

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 948 words

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Jan. 15


Zeljko Raznatovic, a notorious Serbian paramilitary leader known as Arkan who
was wanted on war crimes charges in the Bosnian and Croatian wars, was shot and
killed today in the lobby of the Intercontinental Hotel here.

Mr. Raznatovic was shot in the left eye by gunmen about 5:15 p.m. and was
immediately taken to Belgrade's main emergency hospital where he was pronounced
dead at about 6:40, reported Studio B, the Belgrade television station.

A witness at the Intercontinental, where blood still spattered the entrance an
hour after the shooting, said that a bodyguard and an associate, known as Manda,
had also been killed. Other reports said that an unidentified woman was wounded.
She was believed to be Lidija Velickovic, the sister of Mr. Raznatovic's wife,
Svetlana, a famous Serbian folk singer known as Ceca.

The gunmen, described by the state news agency Tanjug as masked assailants who
used automatic weapons, apparently escaped, though police arrived quickly.

Mr. Raznatovic, 47, was said to be accompanied by his wife and their two
children, who were not reported hurt. The attack bore the hallmarks of political
assassinations here: gangland style, with shootings in a public place and no
arrests.

Mr. Raznatovic's paramilitary group, the Tigers, took part in the brutal
three-month siege of the Croatian city of Vukovar in 1991 and a year later
helped the Bosnian Serbs overrun northern and eastern Bosnia, where he was one
of the pioneers of the killing and violent expulsion of rival ethnic groups that
came to be known as "ethnic cleansing."

He was secretly indicted in 1997 by the international war crimes tribunal for
the former Yugoslavia for crimes against humanity in both Bosnia and Croatia.
But his indictment was made public by the tribunal in the Hague only during
NATO's bombing war against Serbia over Kosovo that began last March.

Mr. Raznatovic was thought to be dangerous to President Slobodan Milosevic of
Yugoslavia and other government figures because of what he knew about the
killings and atrocities of the war in Bosnia. The tribunal was said to be
negotiating at different points with Mr. Raznatovic to get him to turn himself
in and testify against others, but Mr. Raznatovic regularly denied those
reports. The immediate speculation here is that Mr. Milosevic, who has already
been indicted by the tribunal for war crimes during the Kosovo war, and his
regime would benefit most from the killing.

One of the very few occasions at which Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Raznatovic were
ever seen together was the 1997 funeral of Radovan Stojicic, a former deputy
chief of Serbian police whose name was linked to atrocities during the Croatian
war and who was gunned down in a Belgrade restaurant. His killers have never
been found.

Mr. Raznatovic was said by friends to have been worried about his safety in the
last few months, said Zoran Djindjic, the leader of the opposition Democratic
Party, who had various contacts with him. Mr. Milosevic was particularly irked
by Mr. Raznatovic's support of the Montenegrin President, Milo Djukanovic, after
the Montenegrin turned against Mr. Milosevic in 1997, Mr. Djindjic said in an
interview this evening.

At the same time, Mr. Djindjic said, Mr. Raznatovic kept strong contacts with
the Yugoslav and Serbian security services on whose orders he is said in the
past to have carried out assassinations of exiles in western Europe viewed as
enemies of the Belgrade government.

Mr. Raznatovic was also wanted by the international police group Interpol in
connection with bank robberies across western Europe.

He did not play a major role in the Kosovo war, though some of his Tigers were
engaged in the forced expulsion and murder of ethnic Albanians there. But Mr.
Raznatovic did not go to Kosovo himself, though Mr. Djindjic said that the
regime had urged Mr. Raznatovic to go. In fact, he spent much of the war in the
Hyatt Hotel in Belgrade, where many foreign journalists stayed, and which was
perceived as a place NATO would not bomb. An English-speaker, he was sometimes
interviewed about the war by CNN and the BBC.

Mr. Djindjic said that Mr. Raznatovic told him that in late 1996, Mr.
Milosevic's wife, Mirjana Markovic, wanted Mr. Raznatovic and his men to break
up the large pro-democracy demonstrations in Belgrade and offered him money to
do so. When Mr. Djindjic met with him then, Mr. Raznatovic told him he had
rejected the proposal.

During the Kosovo war, Mr. Djindjic said, Mr. Raznatovic kept Mr. Djindjic
informed about threats to his life, one of the reasons Mr. Djindjic left
Belgrade during the war to travel to Montenegro and abroad.

Mr. Raznatovic was one of the last of the criminal and paramilitary leaders
closely involved with both state security and the wars in Bosnia and Croatia.
Last month, Zoran Sijan, a mafia leader and a man with experiences similar to
Mr. Raznatovic, was killed, Mr. Djindjic said.

The last such figure still alive is Ljubisa Buha, known as Cume, who is based in
Belgrade, Mr. Djindjic said.

Mr. Raznatovic dabbled in politics in 1992-93, and was also involved in
business, both open and criminal, reaping what was thought to have been a
considerable fortune through his control of gasoline smuggling and illegal sales
during the international sanctions imposed on Yugoslavia during the war. He was
a well-known soccer fan, leading the club of the fans of the famous Red Star
soccer team. Later, he bought his own soccer club, Belgrade Obilic.

Mr. Raznatovic was shrewd, intelligent and had a criminal personality, Mr.
Djindjic said, adding: "He was baby-faced but very dangerous, without moral
scruples and a kind of beast."

                 January 16, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

COPING;
Q.& A. Day for Parents: 'Where Do I Fit In?'

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 3; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 811 words


TOMORROW is the holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. For some,
it's a day to sleep late and catch the sales at Macy's. But others, in
particular those of us with darker skins, will use the day to talk to our
children about a battle against prejudice we believe they will fight well into
this new century.

Many black parents do not have any special rituals associated with the King
holiday. If their children are old enough, they learn about and celebrate Dr.
King in school. If they're younger, they have little conception of this thing
called civil rights. But the raft of images associated with Dr. King and his
times -- attacking police dogs, dignified marchers, the civil disobedience
following his 1968 assassination -- are a powerful tool in presenting our
versions of history.

"It's the hardest thing black people have to teach their children," said Pamela
Newkirk, a college professor who lives with her husband and daughters, Marjani,
9, and Mykel, 5, in Greenwich Village.

Ms. Newkirk recalled the time about four years ago when Marjani came home from
school and said in horror, "Did you know, Mommy, that black people had to sit in
the back of buses!"

"It's so painful," Ms. Newkirk said. "It cuts so deep. You have this innocent
child who has no context for understanding this, it's so absurd."

Her solution is not only to talk to her children about the realities of a
society that sanctioned slavery for so long but also to inoculate them against
bias by building their self-esteem.

She went to her daughters' school, for instance, to talk about Kwanzaa. She
fills their home with nourishing black images, from the art on the walls to
beautiful brown-skinned dolls. She exposes them to black cultural events and she
monitors the books they read and the TV shows they watch. So when Dr. King's
birthday rolls around, and the speeches and the images play on, there is an
emotional as well as social context for the wellspring of pain.

The line between frightening children with stories of slavery and oppression and
making them aware of bias is delicate, parents say. A recurrent conversation
among African-American parents is what to tell children about race, when to tell
them, and whether to use words like "racism."

My son turns 2 this year. One day, I will tell him that Dr. King is a hero who
became famous, but that there are many unknown men and women, of all colors, who
stood up and still stand up against the wrongs done to black people.

"You have to be careful how you feed it to them," said Rosemary L. Bray, author
of "Martin Luther King" (1995, Greenwillow Books), a biography of Dr. King for
children 7 to 10. "I want my children to hate racism. I don't want them to hate
white people."

When Ms. Bray's 6-year-old son, Allen, learned that some white people once
enslaved black people, she said, "he was just dumbfounded, he was just amazed."
The other day, when he was listening to Dr. King's famous last speech, she said,
he turned to her and asked, "Mama, what is the promised land?"

"I really think it's important for kids to know that Martin Luther King was a
little boy like them and people were mean to him and he had to overcome his
rage," she said. "I tell Allen that people and societies can change, they can
overcome bad feelings and bad behaviors."

Luvon Roberson, a health communications specialist who lives on the Upper West
Side, said her discussions with her 12-year-old son, Ade, focus more on family
history and the concept of heroes. She has talked to him about respecting
differences -- without using the word race at all -- since he was about a year
old. She tells him stories about his maternal great-grandfather, Luther, who
took on the white establishment in Mississippi by sleeping with a gun by his
side and insisting that whites address his wife with a courtesy title.

Howard Gordon is a social worker and psychotherapist who lives in Williamsburg,
Brooklyn, and has two daughters, Carolyn, 16, and Elizabeth, 12. He lets them
know he wrote to politicians in the 1980's urging Dr. King's birthday be made a
holiday.

"We talk about Dr. King in a different way every year, because they're growing
up and there are always different things in their lives," he said. "Elizabeth,
for instance, had an experience in school where they wanted to move her into
another class and it seemed the majority of kids they were moving were black. My
older daughter said she felt people disrespected her because of the way she
speaks.

"I told them you're going to get it from white people who feel you're less
deserving, who are ignorant about your history," said Mr. Gordon, who is a
single father. "It's my responsibility to help them in a sensitive way to see
reality."

He took a deep breath. "I don't know if it's hard," he said of the lessons
learned and taught. "It just is."

                 January 17, 2000, Monday, Late Edition - Final

Political Motive Suspected in Killing of Serbian Warlord

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

SECTION: Section A; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1182 words

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Jan. 16


The Serbian authorities today provided few details of the assassination on
Saturday of Zeljko Raznatovic, a notorious Serbian paramilitary leader known as
Arkan, who was wanted on war crimes charges in the Bosnian and Croatian wars.

But officials of political parties here said Mr. Raznatovic, worried about his
security, had made overtures to the Serbian political opposition in the last few
months.

They said he had traveled to Montenegro, Serbia's sister republic, which is led
by President Milo Djukanovic. Mr. Raznatovic supported Mr. Djukanovic's election
in 1997 against the wishes of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia. But
Mr. Djukanovic, who is supported by the West, made clear to Mr. Raznatovic that
as an indicted war criminal he could not remain in Montenegro, these officials
said.

Mr. Raznatovic was killed in the lobby of the Intercontinental Hotel here, shot
three times in the face by gunmen about 5:15 p.m. as he emerged with friends
from the hotel restaurant.

He was taken to Belgrade's main emergency hospital, where he was pronounced
dead.

The immediate assumption here was that the Milosevic government had ordered and
carried out the killing, because Mr. Raznatovic knew too much about the
activities of Mr. Milosevic and his associates during the Bosnian and Croatian
wars that raged from 1991 to 1995.

"The main question was not whether Arkan would be killed, but when," said
Slavoljub Kacarevic, editor in chief of the independent daily Glas Javnosti.

Late last night, Mr. Raznatovic's followers, some of whom are members of
paramilitary groups who live in a sort of plush barracks in Belgrade, went to
his huge, modern house in the rich suburb of Dedinje, where Mr. Milosevic also
lives, and fired their guns in the air in mourning.

Officials say at least 500 families in Belgrade owe their livelihoods directly
to Mr. Raznatovic, who had businesses both open and shady, ranging from bakeries
to currency exchanges, oil smuggling and a casino.

His Serbian National Guard, known as the Tigers, was active in the Bosnian and
Croatian wars and was responsible for murder, looting and so-called ethnic
cleansing.

Mr. Raznatovic was secretly indicted by the war crimes tribunal in The Hague in
1997, apparently for events in Bosnia and in Vukovar, Croatia, where 250 Croats
were taken from a hospital and murdered. The tribunal did not disclose that he
was under indictment until NATO's bombing campaign against Serbia was under way
last spring, and the document detailing the charges has not been unsealed.

A tribunal spokesman, Paul Risley, said in a telephone interview today that
lawyers asserting that they represented Mr. Raznatovic had contacted the
tribunal, exploring the idea of Mr. Raznatovic turning himself in and agreeing
to testify.

Mr. Risley suggested that Mr. Raznatovic's fate might encourage other wanted
men, including the Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and former Gen. Ratko
Mladic, to consider turning themselves in to the relative safety of a Dutch
prison cell.

Mr. Raznatovic had close ties to the Serbian and Yugoslav intelligence services
and secret police, carrying a membership card in the Federal State Security
police.

In the shooting, two other men were also killed, a former business associate
named Milovan Mandic, known as Manda, and Dragan Garic, a high-level police
official who worked in the Interior Ministry, the political officials said,
confirming a report in Glas Javosti.

Mr. Kacarevic, the editor, said today that his newspaper believed that there had
been two gunmen with automatic Heckler and Koch machine pistols, and that one of
them had been wounded but crawled out of the hotel. Both managed to escape. A
woman who was passing by was also hurt, apparently trying to flee the carnage.
There were at least 38 shells on the floor of the hotel lobby, the police said.

Mr. Raznatovic, 47, was said to have been accompanied by his wife, the popular
singer Svetlana Raznatovic, known as Ceca, and their two children, as well as
his sister-in-law, Lidija Velickovic. The sister and sister-in-law are said to
own a boutique for luxury goods in the hotel.

Some news reports said Ms. Velickovic had been wounded, but Mr. Kacarevic said
she had not been, and had in fact organized the transport of Mr. Raznatovic to
the hospital.

The attack had all the characteristics of previous gangland style killings here
of public figures -- a police chief, other senior police officials, a top
journalist and shady business figures with ties to the Milosevic family or the
government.

Among those who have been gunned down in public in recent years are the former
chief of Serbia's uniformed police and the editor of an independent daily who
was once close to Mr. Milosevic's wife, Mirjana Markovic, but then turned away
from her. No arrests have been made.

Another indicted war crime suspect who was said to have led paramilitary forces
in Bosnia, Slobodan Miljkovic, died in a hail of bullets in 1998 in the Serbian
town of Kragujevac.

There will be a memorial service for Mr. Raznatovic on Tuesday and a funeral on
Wednesday. In the meantime, his body will be at the headquarters of his party,
the Party of Serbian Unity.

Serbian opposition parties called Mr. Raznatovic's killing emblematic of
Serbia's condition under Mr. Milosevic's rule. The Serbian Renewal Movement of
Vuk Draskovic, who says the secret police tried to murder him in a car crash
last October, said the killing was "confirmation that we live in a country of
state terrorism."

In a statement on the Belgrade television channel it controls, Studio B, Mr.
Draskovic's party said, "Such brutal executions aim to spread fear and general
insecurity among citizens."

Later today, Studio B said one of its main transmitters had been sabotaged,
cutting off up to two million viewers -- half of its possible audience -- in
central Serbia. Studio B's signal is often jammed in Belgrade and elsewhere,
with the government blaming NATO. The station said the sabotage had occurred
after it had managed to bypass the jamming.

Vladan Batic, coordinator of the Alliance for Change, an opposition coalition,
said the murder bore the hallmarks of hundreds of other political killings and
would never be solved.

"Violent death has become an everyday thing, and such a murder would be solved
quickly only if the police and judiciary functioned normally," he said. "Someone
is pulling the strings and deciding every morning who will be next."

In Sarajevo, a Bosnian Muslim official said Mr. Raznatovic's death was no
surprise. Mirza Hajric, an adviser to Muslim political leader Alija Izetbegovic,
told Reuters he was only sorry that Mr. Raznatovic would not go to The Hague to
testify against Mr. Milosevic.

"I think he could have provided crucial evidence on Milosevic's involvement in
war crimes in Bosnia," Mr. Hajric said.

Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said in a statement that the United
States took "no satisfaction in Arkan's murder and would have wanted him to
stand trial in The Hague for his crimes."

                 January 23, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

Mass Graves In Turkey Put Attention On Terror Cell

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER

SECTION: Section 1; Page 9; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 787 words

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Jan. 22


Police officers searching for victims of a religious-oriented terrorist group
found four bodies buried beneath a villa in the central Turkish town of Konya on
Friday night, bringing the total exhumed so far to 17.

The gruesome search has riveted the nation's attention since Monday, when a
heavily armed police squad surrounded a building that authorities called the
group's Istanbul headquarters and seized it after a spectacular gunbattle that
was broadcast live on television.

One man inside the building in Istanbul was killed. The police identified him as
Huseyin Velioglu, leader of a militant Islamic group known as Hezbollah, which
is believed to be unrelated to the anti-Israeli group Hezbollah based in
Lebanon.

Ten bodies, all nude and bearing signs of torture, were found beneath the
Istanbul hide-out. According to news reports, some of the bodies were missing
limbs, and others had nails driven into their skulls. The killers had planted
onions above the mass grave to cover up the odor.

The police captured two men who were inside the house. They also found
documents, computer disks and videotapes said to contain scenes of torture and
executions.

All 17 victims whose remains have been found so far are believed to have been
Kurds from southeastern Turkey, which has been torn by war and terror for years.
The lone woman among them was reportedly Konca Kuris, a writer who had often
portrayed Islam as a permissive religion that demands freedom for women.

An estimated 200 residents of southeastern Turkey, most of them businessmen
unsympathetic to the cause of militant Islam, have disappeared since August.
Hezbollah, which means Party of God, is now considered the prime suspect in many
of those cases.

The group is also suspected of involvement in a 1993 arson attack in the city of
Sivas. That fire killed 37 secularist intellectuals who had gathered for a
conference.

Although Turkey's Hezbollah is not believed to be connected to the group based
in Lebanon, the two evidently share a fervent commitment to radical Islam.
Turkish and Israeli officials believe that both groups receive support from
Iran, but the Iranian foreign minister, Kamal Kharrazi, who was in Turkey during
the Istanbul raid, denied that his government had any connection to Hezbollah in
Turkey.

Hezbollah emerged as a force in southeastern Turkey in the late 1980's, when a
Kurdish uprising was reaching its peak. For the next several years, the ranks of
Kurdish nationalists, intellectuals and businessmen were decimated by thousands
of unsolved "mystery killings."

In recent days, news commentators and academic researchers have asserted that
many of those killings may have been carried out by Hezbollah in cooperation
with the army and the police. Many of the victims were perceived as supporters
of the rebel Kurdistan Workers Party, or P.K.K., which the government was
determined to wipe out.

Now that the Kurdish group's top leader, Abdullah Ocalan, has been captured and
sentenced to death, fighting in the southeastern provinces has subsided. If
Hezbollah was once an ally of the government, it is now considered a threat
because of its support for radical Islam.

"Hezbollah's anti-P.K.K. stance and the sympathy it has received for killing
P.K.K. members has put the state in the position of being the target of the
Frankenstein monster it created," the columnist Gungor Mengi wrote in an
Istanbul newspaper. "We hope this incident has taught our leaders not to use
religious terror groups under any circumstances."

The two recent raids may lead to new investigations into some of the most highly
publicized mystery killings. The victims included not only Kurds, but also
prominent secularists like a newspaper columnist, Ugur Mumcu, who was killed by
a car bomb in 1993, and a former minister of culture, Ahmet Taner Kislali, who
was killed by a bomb last year.

Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit said operations against Hezbollah "will continue
until we have completely wiped out this murderous organization."

One leading expert on Turkish terror groups, Emin Gurses, a professor of
international relations at the University of Sakarya in western Turkey, said
Hezbollah and the Kurdistan Workers Party fought not only over ideology, but
also for control of smuggling routes.

"The P.K.K. was at the peak of its power in the early 1990's," Mr. Gurses said.
"Army commanders knew that it was dangerous to give free rein to Hezbollah, but
the P.K.K. was their main concern. Central authorities in countries around the
world close their eyes temporarily to these kinds of organizations in similar
circumstances. But now that the P.K.K. is defeated, a decision has been made to
crush Hezbollah."

                 January 28, 2000, Friday, Late Edition - Final

Rwanda Tribunal Convicts Private Citizen

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 9; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 169 words

DATELINE: ARUSHA, Tanzania, Jan. 27


A United Nations tribunal found a former Rwandan tea factory manager guilty
today of three genocide-related charges and sentenced him to life in prison.

The defendant, Alfred Musema, 50, the former director of the state-owned tea
factor, was the first private citizen tried and convicted by the tribunal, which
is prosecuting chief architects and perpetrators of the mass killings in 1994 of
more than 500,000 minority Tutsi and politically moderate Hutu. It was the
maximum sentence allowed.

"Musema personally led attackers to attack large numbers of Tutsi refugees and
raped a young Tutsi woman," said the presiding judge, Lennart Aspegren of
Sweden. "He knowingly and consciously participated in the commission of crimes,
and never showed remorse for his personal role in the commission of the
atrocities."

The three-judge panel found Mr. Musema guilty of rape, genocide and crimes
against humanity. It acquitted him on six other genocide-related counts. Mr.
Musema's lawyer said he would appeal.

                February 5, 2000, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

I.R.A. and the Arms Principle

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1003 words

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 4


The Irish Republican Army, now in the third year of a cease-fire, is trying to
convince people of its peaceful intent by not using its guns. But it has cast
doubt on that objective by insisting on keeping them.

The power-sharing Northern Ireland government, only two months old, faces being
suspended next week because the guerrilla group refuses to start disarming.  The
British and Irish Governments announced on Thursday that the I.R.A. must start
scrapping its arsenal now.

The I.R.A. shows no signs of yielding, and Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president,
said today that he did not expect them to do so in time to avert a shutdown of
the Belfast government. "No undefeated army ever acted on the back of a series
of demands to do certain things," he said.

In those words lay a telling reference to the thinking of the I.R.A., which
could start disarming immediately and still have an enormous arsenal left. The
force also has bomb-making equipment to enable it to speedily replace whatever
arms it sacrifices.

"When people ask why can't they just give in a gun or a bullet or a wheelbarrow
of weapons or whatever, that's the wrong question," said Dominic Murray, the
director of the Center of Peace and Development Studies at the University of
Limerick in the Irish Republic. "It's an understandable question, particularly
from outsiders, but it misses the point."

"It's not whether you decommission a ton or a ha'penny's worth," he said. "It's
not the amount; it's the principle."

The I.R.A. equates disarmament with surrender. The group stresses, as Mr.
Adams's words point up, that it is not an army that lost a war. It is taking
part in the peace settlement out of choice, not force, and disarming must be
voluntary, it insists.

"People say, 'Why don't they hand over a small amount, make a gesture,' " said
Brian Feeney, author of "Lost Lives," a book detailing the lives and deaths of
3,637 people who have been killed in sectarian violence since 1966. "The gesture
as they see it would be symbolic of their being the bad guys, their struggle the
one that was illicit and wrong."

Add to this sense elements of tradition, suspicion, fear and national
myth-making, and no amount of logic can overcome it.

Republicans, the largely Catholic movement that wants closer links to the Irish
Republic, generally recognize that the arrangements that the I.R.A. is now
defying have brought them significant benefits. Their politicians sit in the
power-sharing legislature and command primary ministries; a human rights panel
has been set up; hundreds of prisoners have been freed; the British troop
presence has been reduced. And the Royal Ulster Constabulary, which many
Catholics believe embodied harsh Protestant domination of their people, is being
demilitarized, down-sized and made more representative of the province's
population mix.

"There's nothing about the I.R.A.'s decision that is strategic," Mr. Feeney
said. "It's atavistic and sentimental."

Paul Arthur, a politics professor at the University of Ulster, put it this way:
"Never underestimate the impact of folk memory on the psychology of
republicanism."

When it comes to arms, the I.R.A. has no qualms about dashing the incipient
political careers of the Sinn Fein leaders who appeared to be relishing their
new roles as government ministers. In a warning last week, Mr. Adams betrayed
his own inability to sway the I.R.A., saying: "It is not easy to get the I.R.A.
to do this speedily. This is the reality."

Northern Ireland remains the most heavily armed area in Europe, with police
officers operating out of bunkers, riding the streets of the province in armored
personnel carriers and setting out on sidewalk patrols in bulletproof vests.

The issue of guns has continually arisen, and in peace talks politicians have
shied away from demanding iron-clad commitments. At the beginning of the current
talks, they came up with a neutral-sounding word -- decommissioning -- to try to
get around the onus of surrender attached to the word disarmament.

In the language of the 1998 peace accord, all that Sinn Fein and other parties
with links to paramilitary groups were committing themselves to was to use "any
influence they may have to achieve the decommissioning of all paramilitary arms
within two years." That period extends to May 22.

The clandestine nature of the I.R.A. makes it difficult to estimate the amount
of its weaponry with accuracy. Britain's domestic news agency, The Press
Association, has reported that the arsenal includes thousands of handguns and
rifles, Russian heavy-caliber armor-piercing machine guns, AK-47 semiautomatic
rifles, flame throwers, rocket-propelled grenades, mortars and grenade
launchers, surface-to-air missiles and from one to four tons of Semtex
explosive.

The bulk is said to have come in shipments from Libya in the early 1980's. The
Libyan leader, Muammar el-Qaddafi, said publicly that he wanted to arm the
I.R.A. in retaliation for the decision by Margaret Thatcher, then the British
prime minister, to assist American bombing raids on his country.

The Irish police also say illicit shipments from the United States have included
handguns, submachine guns, pistols and ammunition for sniper rifles.

I.R.A. arms are hidden on both sides of the border in holes and caves in farm
country. The police are sometimes alerted to caches by hikers and picnickers.

Various methods of taking the I.R.A. weapons out of circulation have been
suggested. They include allowing the I.R.A. to destroy its own weapons, with
verification coming from a monitoring panel, and what is called a "rust
solution," of alerting the authorities to the location of munitions and sealing
them off to prevent use.

Weapons are seldom out of sight in Northern Ireland. The walls of housing
projects there are scarred by murals showing ski-masked terrorists brandishing
machine guns. These days the ones in Catholic neighborhoods are displaying
chilling slogans that read, "Not one bullet."

                February 8, 2000, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

A Vallone Bill Bars Purchases In Sweatshops

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 319 words


City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone proposed legislation yesterday that would
bar New York City from buying uniforms or other apparel from companies unless
they paid at least what he called "nonpoverty wages."

Mr. Vallone said the bill could help ensure fair working conditions. The city
spends more than $70 million a year on uniforms for police officers,
firefighters and other public employees.

The bill is modeled on similar laws adopted by more than two dozen
municipalities and is intended to discourage the abusive labor practices often
found in the garment industry in New York City, around the nation and overseas.

"The City of New York should not be lending its taxpayer support to
sweatshop-like conditions which profit from subhuman business practices," Mr.
Vallone said at a news conference at City Hall.

The legislation, developed in conjunction with officials from the Union of
Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, would bar the city from
contracting with any apparel company that failed to pay what Mr. Vallone said
were "nonpoverty wages," as defined by federal guidelines. Under the bill, the
city comptroller would develop wage standards for overseas apparel
manufacturers.

Called the Anti-Sweatshop Procurement Law, it would require potential city
apparel contractors to provide information about their wages and demonstrate
that they comply with international and American regulations concerning labor,
the environment and human rights.

Patrick Lynch, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said he had
evidence that clothing produced for the Police Department was made in China,
where many factories suppress unions and require employees to work 70-hour
weeks.

Kathryn E. Freed, chairwoman of the City Council's Committee on Contracts and
the cosponsor of the bill, said, "It's time for New York to slam the door shut
on the sweatshop industry."

               February 10, 2000, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

Chancellor Proposes to Compensate Austria's Wartime Slaves

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

SECTION: Section A; Page 7; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 572 words

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 9


Austria's new chancellor, trying to calm foreign fears about his coalition with
the rightist Freedom Party, presented his government's platform to Parliament
today and said he wanted to compensate people forced into slavery in Austrian
factories during World War II.

The possibility of wartime compensation was included in a package otherwise
fairly typical for a conservative European government: tax cuts, plans to
balance the budget, faster sales of state assets, strong anti-crime measures and
curbs on immigration. The chancellor, Wolfgang Schussel, named a former
president of the Austrian National Bank as coordinator in charge of Nazi-era
compensation claims.

Mr. Schussel spent much of his speech addressing fears about the Freedom Party
and its leader, Jorg Haider, who is best known abroad for his anti-immigrant
stance and remarks interpreted as defending the Third Reich.

Noting that Austria is a stable democracy, Mr. Schussel pointed out that it has
very few anti-foreigner incidents, labor strikes or violent demonstrations.

"This Austria has not changed in the last few days," he said. He appealed to the
international community to "reconsider its prejudices and pre-formed opinions."

The government will press for former Nazi slave laborers, "who are after all at
an age where they need help quickly," to get payments, Mr.  Schuessel said.
Austrian companies that used slave laborers would be expected to pay, he said.

Today's announcement is "potentially significant, but there are many issues
still to be dealt with," said Gideon Taylor, executive vice president of the
Claims Conference, an umbrella body of 23 Jewish organizations that coordinates
and negotiates claims of Holocaust victims and their survivors.

After decades of portraying itself as Hitler's first victim, Austria has only in
the last few years acknowledged its own debt to Holocaust victims and begun to
restore property seized by the Nazis. Payments to survivors of up to $7,000 were
treated as compassionate aid, rather than as reparations owed. Also, Mr. Taylor
noted, most of the slave laborers in Austria were Poles, Czechs and other
eastern Europeans rather than Jews.

As Mr. Schussel spoke, about 1,500 officers surrounded the Parliament building
and blocked off traffic on the Ringstrasse, Vienna's most famous boulevard, in
anticipation of up to 20,000 protesters. But few showed up, and the cordoned-off
area was cleared earlier in the afternoon than expected.

Two weeks ago, the other 14 nations of the European Union threatened to isolate
Austria diplomatically if Mr. Haider was invited into a coalition government.
Since that government took office on Friday, Mr. Schussel has been at pains to
reassure Europe that it wishes to remain part of the union and does not plan to
oppose its expansion to include eastern Europe. Mr. Haider had opposed European
expansion, but he also opposed Austria's own entry into the union and has a
history of changing his political positions to suit changing circumstances.

Today a spokesman for the French government said France still "wants to go
further" in isolating Austria, but recognized that it had few allies, and
proposed no specific measures.

In Washington, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said she felt reassured
by promises from Mr. Schussel and said the recently summoned American ambassador
to Austria would return to Vienna this weekend.

                February 15, 2000, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

Which Path for America Abroad?

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 159 words



To the Editor:

Michael Ignatieff (Op-Ed, Feb. 13) is right in arguing that American values
require us to intervene to stop crimes against humanity even where our national
interests are not directly affected. But no one wants the United States to
become the world's policeman. What to do?

We need an international military force to be effective when peaceful measures
fail. We need an international criminal court to deter future offenders. We need
clear rules stipulating when the world community may lawfully intervene to stop
large-scale atrocities.

The international force called for by the United Nations Charter was never
created. A new criminal court is being formed, but the president has failed to
sign the treaty, which remains nonbinding without Senate ratification. Law is
always better than war.

BENJAMIN B. FERENCZ
Delray Beach, Fla., Feb. 13, 2000

The writer was a prosecutor at the Nuremberg war crimes trials.

                February 15, 2000, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

EDITORIAL OBSERVER;
Shifting Politics of the Confederate Battle Flag

BYLINE: By BRENT STAPLES

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 799 words


The Republicans began this election cycle with a conciliatory tone on race,
hoping to attract support from members of the black middle class, many of whom
fit the G.O.P. profile but were put off by the race-baiting and Willie
Hortonizing that dominated Republican politics during the 1980's. George W. Bush
seemed to be reaching out to black voters early on, when he took his message of
inclusion and "compassionate conservatism" into African-American communities
that had rarely seen Republican candidates in the flesh.

But the Republicans have reverted to old tactics in South Carolina, where the
two leading presidential candidates have hedged their bets for the Feb. 19
primary by supporting the right of South Carolinians to fly the Confederate
battle flag over the State Capitol, despite the flag's association with
segregation and the Ku Klux Klan.

This compromise with bigotry has proved convenient for the candidates at this
moment. But it could also stimulate the black vote across the Deep South in the
general election, threatening the Republican grip on Congress and aiding the
Democratic attempt to keep control of the White House.

Mr. Bush took the traditional states'-rights approach in South Carolina, arguing
from the start that the issue of whether to keep the flag rested with South
Carolinians themselves. But Senator John McCain took one side and then the
other, saying at first that the flag was "offensive" and a "symbol of racism and
slavery," then reversing himself, saying that it was defensible to fly the flag
over the capitol because it symbolized Southern honor in battle. In truth, the
Confederate battle flag as we know it today has little to do with the glories of
the Civil War and everything to do with the backlash against civil rights that
eventually made the flag a symbol of choice among neo-Nazis, skinheads and other
bigots.

In the years immediately following the Civil War, the Confederate battle flag
was not an omnipresent symbol in the South. But around the time of Jefferson
Davis's death in 1889 there was a blossoming of "lost cause" nostalgia, and the
flag emerged as an icon of defiance and racism.

The flag returned to popularity in the 1890's just as the former Confederacy was
stripping blacks of the rights to vote and hold political office, which they had
briefly enjoyed just after the Civil War. The flag had begun its transformation
from an emblem of a dead cause to a symbol of resistance to Reconstruction and
civil rights and, later, to an emblem associated with night riders and vigilante
terrorists. By the mid-20th century the battle flag had been fully appropriated
by the Klan and other extremists, who displayed it at cross-burnings and
lynchings and to show resistance to black demands for civil rights and equal
treatment under the law.

Apologists in South Carolina say that the flag was hoisted over the capitol for
the centennial of the Civil War, then mistakenly left flying. In truth, the flag
went up in 1962, a full year after the centennial. State officials were in a a
dispute with the Kennedy administration, which had urged the integration of the
Charleston, S.C., hotel where a centennial convention was being held. When South
Carolina refused to admit black delegates to the hotel, the convention was moved
to a nearby military base.

The flag's appearance a year later was an implicit endorsement of segregation --
and the premise that black citizens were unworthy of sharing public
accommodations with whites. South Carolina's present governor, Jim Hodges,
tacitly acknowledged this negative symbolism in this year's State of the State
Message, when he implored the legislature to remove the flag, reminding it that
"the entire nation is watching and listening to us."

In previous presidential campaigns, the flag issue in South Carolina came and
went quickly with little fanfare or lasting impact. This year's dust-up brought
a demonstration by civil rights activists that included nearly 50,000 people,
followed by the threat of an economic boycott against the state. In a
development that should shame both Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain, a group of former
state legislators who were serving while the flag went up recanted the decision
and urged the current legislature to bring it down.

The flag will eventually come down, making South Carolina the final state to put
it away. By failing to take a strong position now, the G.O.P. has missed an easy
opportunity to distance itself from offensive racial politics and to build the
beginnings of a bridge to the black electorate. In the quest to wring every
possible white vote out of South Carolina, Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain have
identified their party yet again with forces that have poisoned our national
politics for more than 100 years.

http://www.nytimes.com

Lithuania Holocaust Trial

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 2; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 75 words

DATELINE: VILNIUS, Lithuania, Feb. 15


Lithuania's Parliament amended the country's criminal code today to permit the
resumption of the first Holocaust trials in a former member of the Soviet Union.

Two trials stalled last year because of the failing health of the aged
defendants. The amendment -- which applies in cases of war crimes and crimes
against humanity -- allows defendants to follow the proceedings on a video link,
eliminating the need for their physical presence.
