U.N. War Crimes Prosecutor Declines to Investigate NATO

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 503 words

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 2


The United Nations' chief war crimes prosecutor said today that there was no
basis for a formal investigation into whether NATO committed war crimes during
the bombing of Yugoslavia a year ago.

"Although some mistakes were made by NATO, I am very satisfied that there was no
deliberate targeting of civilians or unlawful military targets by NATO during
the bombing campaign," the prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte of Switzerland, told the
Security Council. She said a detailed statement on her decision would be
released as early as next week.

A parliamentary commission from Russia, Yugoslavia's strongest international
supporter, and Western lawyers working for the Yugoslav government had brought
allegations of NATO war crimes to the tribunal last year. Several rights groups
have also raised questions about NATO attacks on civilian targets.

The 11-week NATO bombing campaign was intended to stop Yugoslav repression of
Albanians in Kosovo, the Serbian province now under the administration of NATO
and the United Nations.

Among the NATO actions taken to the Balkans tribunal by critics alleging war
crimes were an airstrike on a passenger train crossing a targeted bridge; the
bombing of a Serbian television center; killing of refugees in a convoy mistaken
for soldiers; the use of cluster bombs that can fragment over a wide area, in
one case hitting grounds of a hospital; and the use of depleted uranium in
weapons. There were also more general allegations of genocide and deliberate
environmental destruction.

"I am now able to announce my conclusion, following a full consideration of my
team's assessment of all complaints and allegations, that there is no basis for
opening an investigation into any of those allegations or into other incidents
related to the NATO bombing," Ms. Del Ponte, a former Swiss attorney general,
told the council. She did not discuss the allegations themselves.

The Balkans war crimes tribunal, based in The Hague, has played down the
importance of these charges since they were first made public late last year.
Officials have said that the tribunal was formed to charge individuals, not
institutions or organizations, with war crimes. NATO officials have answered or
dismissed the charges, but have said errors were committed.

Among these they include the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade.
American officials subsequently said that the bombing was an accident resulting
from the use of outdated maps and incorrect intelligence information, but China
has rejected this explanation.

Ms. Del Ponte, also chief prosecutor of a war crimes tribunal for Rwanda,
conducted only an informal study of the allegations against NATO, officials
said. She has been more deeply involved in formal charges against Yugoslavia's
president, Slobodan Milosevic, who was indicted by the tribunal last year.

But she told the council that she felt she had to examine the allegations
against NATO because it was her "obligation and responsibility" to look into all
complaints.

                 June 14, 2000, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

Russian Prosecutor Detains TV Tycoon, a Kremlin Critic

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES and MICHAEL R. GORDON

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1203 words

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 13


The Kremlin's chief prosecutor today arrested and jailed Vladimir A. Gusinsky,
head of a media empire that has sharply criticized the government.

The arrest roused fears of suppression of the press. But President Vladimir V.
Putin, traveling abroad, insisted that the arrest was an unwelcome surprise to
him.

The prosecutor said Mr. Gusinsky had been arrested on suspicion of embezzling at
least $10 million in federal property, apparently related to the purchase of a
government-owned television station in St. Petersburg in the mid-1990's.

His detention capped weeks of government-orchestrated pressure on his Media-Most
news organization, which includes Russia's lone independent television network
and numerous newspapers. The pressure included attempts to call in loans and a
spectacular police raid last month on the company headquarters here.

The arrest loosed a torrent of protest from Mr. Gusinsky's supporters and
enemies, many of whom worried aloud that the move signaled a new era of
repression under Mr. Putin. But Mr. Putin suggested that he was as shocked by
the detention as almost anyone else. Mr. Gusinsky was seized hours after Mr.
Putin had left Moscow on a weeklong diplomatic tour. After landing in Madrid,
his first stop, Mr. Putin called the arrest "a dubious present for me" and
insisted that he had no advance knowledge of it.

"I hope the prosecutor has sufficient reasons for this step," he said. "I will
find out all the circumstances tonight, and I will have my own viewpoint."

Mr. Putin's comments left open various explanations for the arrest and its
timing. One was that the president was trying to insulate himself from what was
certain to be a sharp reaction from Western leaders whom he is to meet this
week. Another explanation was that Kremlin officials had ordered the arrest
behind Mr. Putin's back, either to punish Mr. Gusinsky or to embarrass the
president.

Last month, after the raids on the Media-Most office, Mr. Putin insisted that
the actions had to do with possible crimes, not press freedoms, and he
criticized the company for contending otherwise. "No attempt at blackmail in
relation to law enforcement is permissible," Mr. Putin said at that time. "Just
as limits on freedoms of speech and of the mass media are not permissible."

Mr. Putin has attacked journalists as unhelpful and, in the context of the
Chechnya war, even traitorous. In recent weeks, Kremlin officials have closed a
television station in St. Petersburg and announced plans to require the
licensing of all newspapers.

A spokesman for Media-Most, Dmitri Ostalsky, called the arrest a pretext for
further curbs on press freedoms. "It is obvious that this has been drummed up,"
Mr. Ostalsky said. "And we can make no other evaluation than to say that the
authority has launched an outright repression against the owners of the
independent media."

Mr. Gusinsky's jousting with Kremlin critics has made Media-Most something of a
cause celebre among Western advocates of press freedom.

President Clinton indirectly expressed support for Mr. Gusinsky during his visit
here last week by giving his sole interview to a radio station owned by
Media-Most.

In Washington, reacting to the arrest, a spokesman for the White House, Joe
Lockhart, said: "We do have a concern about press freedom in Russia, and that
concern was expressed directly to President Putin in his meeting with President
Clinton. We're going to want to take a look at this and understand the details.
But we are quite concerned about some of the steps that have been taken against
the free media."

A former theatrical producer, Mr. Gusinsky built his empire after the Soviet
Union collapsed. Besides the NTV television network, the only one outside state
control that has a national reach, his holdings include a Moscow newspaper,
Sevodnya; a newsmagazine, Itogi, a joint venture with Newsweek; and Ekho Moskvy,
the popular Moscow newsradio station that Mr. Clinton visited.

The empire includes a publishing house and a film production company. Plans for
a multiplex movie theater in downtown Moscow are in the works, although they had
been suspended after the financial crisis in 1998.

Mr. Gusinsky is also a leader of the Jewish minority who has often been a target
of anti-Semitic attacks. He has taken his business to Israel, where he also
holds citizenship, and to the United States. Media-Most bought a 42 percent
stake in the Internet business of Israel's state telephone company together with
its Israeli partner, Maariv Holdings. NTV International began broadcasting last
year to viewers in the United States.

Mr. Gusinsky has clashed with the government before. In the early 90's,
President Boris N. Yeltsin's officials raided Media-Most. But the conflict has
seldom been as sharp as now.

Why is a matter of speculation. One school suggests that Mr. Putin's seemingly
sure purchase on the reins of government is nowhere near as strong as it is made
to seem and that he is actually beholden to insiders, holdovers from the clan
that ran the Kremlin under Mr. Yeltsin and that is linked to tycoons and vested
interests. In that view, the arrest today was muscle flexing by a group that has
run Russia through Mr. Putin for some time.

Either way, it shows "incredible stupidity" on Mr. Putin's part, said Michael
McFaul, a Russian political expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International
Peace. "It shows either that he is not in control -- and that's a bad sign -- or
that he is in control. And that is a bad sign."

Some, including Mr. Gusinsky, tie the actions against Media-MOST to the Kremlin
chief of staff under both Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Putin, Aleksandr Voloshin. Mr.
Voloshin is considered an ally of tycoons opposed to Mr. Gusinsky, including a
major financier and legislator, Boris Berezovsky.

Mr. Gusinsky supported Mr. Yeltsin's re-election campaign in 1996 against
Communist opposition -- and benefited handsomely. After Mr. Yeltsin had won a
second term, NTV received a license for daytime broadcasting.

But Mr. Gusinsky's support soured as Mr. Yeltsin's second term degenerated into
intrigue and economic collapse. In the last two elections, for Parliament and
the presidency, Media-Most outlets have been consistently skeptical of, if not
outright opposed to, Mr. Putin and his allies.

Mr. Gusinsky recently contended that Mr. Voloshin had sought to bribe him to
support the Kremlin in the campaigns, and failed. Mr. Gusinsky recounted:
"Voloshin said, as if he was joking: 'Let's pay you $100 million so that you
won't be in our way while the election is on. You could go on a vacation.' "

Tonight, Boris Nemtsov, a market reformer and a former Kremlin aide, faulted Mr.
Voloshin for the arrest. "There is complete chaos in the Kremlin
administration," Mr. Nemtsov said. "This was done by Voloshin. And if Putin is
not a hypocrite, he has to fire him."

Tonight, NTV broadcast a stream of accusations and complaints about the arrest,
many by top political and business figures. A senior official under Mr. Yeltsin,
Oleg Sysuyev, said the move was politically motivated. "In the eyes of the
public," Mr. Sysuyev said, "this will look like a political execution."

                 June 17, 2000, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

Africa's Swelling Refugee Crisis

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 688 words


The recent fighting between Ethiopia and Eritrea and the war in Sierra Leone are
adding to Africa's outcast multitudes. Refugees and the internally displaced --
those who flee their homes without crossing borders -- are among the saddest
byproducts of the continent's wars. Africa has more than 3 million refugees and
some 15 million internally displaced, a much higher number than 10 years ago.
These outcasts are straining the resources of their host communities and the
good will of donors, and yet there is no end to the stream of people fleeing for
their lives.

The average refugee from Kosovo received more than $1 a day from the
international community. In Africa, the average refugee gets 11 cents. The
internally displaced, who are only now starting to receive assistance from the
outside world, most often get nothing. In many refugee camps, the only
nourishment provided by the World Food Program and the United Nations High
Commissioner for Refugees is flour and oil. Powdered milk is sometimes
available, and nutritional biscuits are given to malnourished children. Because
donor nations are giving less, the refugee agency has had to cut back on health
care and education, which only goes through age 10 or 12. Some refugees from
Somalia and Sudan have lived in these conditions for 20 years, unable to return
until their homelands are at peace.

Yet some of these refugees are not much worse off than their hosts. Guinea, a
very poor country, now has more refugees per capita than any other nation. Some
countries, such as Sudan, produce refugees in one region and shelter them in
another.  Host nations get some reimbursement from the U.N. and sometimes get
food aid, but they must provide land and some social services and keep order in
the camps. African countries, historically generous to refugees -- especially
when they were fleeing colonial oppression -- are now balking at the burden.
Many politicians are finding it profitable to restrict refugees' rights and
blame them, rightly or wrongly, for problems like crime.

The exodus from the Rwandan genocide in 1994 illustrated a new, debilitating
obstacle to protecting refugees. Perpetrators of the genocide fled to the camps
across the border, turning them into internationally funded military bases.
Rwanda was an extreme example, but many camps -- which host countries tend to
build on the border to emphasize their temporary nature -- become recruiting
zones or rest stops for combatants. It is common for camps to be controlled by
one side in the conflict. Some camps of refugees from Sudan in Ethiopia, for
example, are essentially run by the Sudan People's Liberation Army, and relief
workers must carefully negotiate their access.

The U.N.'s refugee relief agency is weakly managed and needs more oversight --
in part because member nations use it as a patronage pit -- and its dependence
on host countries to provide services is another breeding ground for corruption.
But the agency is struggling with a difficult and dangerous mission: 24 members
of its staff, and 23 workers for the World Food Program, have been killed since
1992. The reluctance of donors has also crippled the agency, which finds it
easier to raise money for emergency appeals than to alleviate the chronic
miseries of most African refugees.

Although current refugee aid is meager, its most important shortcoming is that
it does not go to the vast majority who have not crossed a border. The
internally displaced should get aid when countries request it, or when a state
has collapsed to the point where no one can give permission.

Improving the lives of refugees also requires new attitudes within Africa. Host
governments should not build camps close to borders. Countries such as Tanzania,
Kenya and South Africa have joined many European nations and the United States
in passing or considering laws that would turn away refugees or restrict their
rights. These laws are pernicious everywhere. But what refugees need most is
what all Africans need most -- an end to the wars that have diverted the
continent's resources and created so much suffering.

A.C.L.U. Sues Michigan, Citing Bias in Giving College Aid

BYLINE: By NICHOLE M. CHRISTIAN

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 863 words

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 27


The American Civil Liberties Union today accused the State of Michigan of
discriminating against minority students by awarding thousands of merit
scholarships solely on the basis of standardized state test scores.

In the lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Detroit, A.C.L.U. lawyers
asked that the state be prevented from using scores from the Michigan
Educational Assessment Program to award onetime scholarships of up to $2,500 to
college-bound high school seniors. The lawsuit said the practice violated Title
VI of the 1964 Civil Rights Act.

The group also wants a judge to order the Michigan Merit Award Scholarship
Program to re-evaluate students who were denied awards this year and to include
other gauges like grade point averages and extracurricular activities in its
selection process. The A.C.L.U. filed its suit today on behalf of five high
school graduates, all members of minorities, who did not earn passing scores on
the reading, writing, science and math exams that make up the voluntary Michigan
test.

The A.C.L.U. maintains that the Michigan test is flawed because students in poor
schools rarely receive the same amount of preparation for the tests as students
from wealthier districts and private schools.

"This is not an attack on the MEAP test," the executive director of the Michigan
A.C.L.U., Kary Moss, said in a news conference. "What it is an attack on is the
misuse of the MEAP. By using the MEAP test alone, the state is essentially
punishing students for the schools they attend."

The state plans to give more than $100 million this fall to colleges and
universities that have accepted the roughly 40,000 Michigan high school students
who won scholarships. While states are increasingly tying grade promotion and
graduation to student test scores, Michigan is considered the only one to base
college tuition scholarships solely on test scores. Experts say most states use
a combination of measures in awarding tuition.

The A.C.L.U.'s lawsuit, which comes at a time of intense national debate over
standards in education and the use of test scores, could set a precedent, much
like a 1989 case in New York State. In that case, a federal judge forbade
officials to use SAT scores to award the prestigious Regents and Empire
scholarships, and the A.C.L.U.'s Women's Rights Project said girls were
disproportionately discriminated against.

"A defeat in Michigan should stop other potential test-score abusers in their
tracks," said Robert Schaeffer, public education director for the National
Center for Fair and Open Testing, a nonprofit advocacy group.

State officials here insisted that the test scores offered a clear picture of
academic achievement.

"A 2-point grade average is not the same in every school," said State Treasurer
Mark Murray, whose office administers the program. "We have a uniform, unbiased
assessment instrument that is the same in every school. No student has an
advantage or disadvantage."

The program is paid for with money from the state's settlement with tobacco
manufacturers. Students who attend Michigan colleges are eligible for $2,500 in
aid, while those who go out of state receive $1,000.

To further ensure equal access to a scholarship, Mr. Murray said students who
failed the test have two chances to retake it, and can qualify by passing two of
the four sections of the MEAP and receiving at least a 24 on the ACT or 1170 on
the SAT. The program was created by the Legislature in 1999.

Donald Heller, an assistant professor of education at the University of Michigan
who spent a year researching the legislation's impact, said such allowances did
little to close the gap. Based on his research, Mr. Heller said 1 in 3 white
students who took all 4 of the tests in spring of 1999 received a scholarship,
whereas only 1 in 14 blacks, and 1 in 5 Hispanics and Indians received awards.

"Michigan is the only state that uses a test like the MEAP test as the sole
criterion for awarding these scholarships," he said. "In all other state
measures such as high school rank, grade point average or those in combination
with a test like the SAT or ACT are used to determine who is awarded these
scholarships."

The A.C.L.U. lawsuit was based in part on Mr. Heller's research, which was
conducted independently months before the lawsuit.

"The vast majority of these awards are likely to go to students who would have
attended college anyway," Mr. Heller said.

After maintaining a 3.45 grade point average through high school and graduating
sixth in her class at Beecher High School in Flint, Bianca Kelly was certain
that she would be selected as a Michigan Merit Scholar. Even after learning she
had scored a 19 on the ACT and passed all but one of the MEAP tests -- science
-- she thought her record and extracurricular activities would help snare an
award. After all, Howard University had found reason enough to accept her.

But Michigan's scholarship program did not.

Bianca is applying for loans and depending on help from her family to pay
tuition, room and board at Howard. "It's just that I worked so hard and it's
like it still wasn't good enough," she said.

http://www.nytimes.com

                  June 30, 2000, Friday, Late Edition - Final

U.S. Gains a Compromise On War Crimes Tribunal

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

SECTION: Section A; Page 6; Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 914 words

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 29


The United States won an agreement today to keep the door open to further talks
on its demand that no American official or soldier be surrendered to the world's
first permanent court for war crimes as long as Washington has not signed the
treaty creating the court.

European and other nations are determined to keep the United States from being
frozen out of the biggest change in international law in decades. With their
help, the Clinton administration's ambassador at large for war crimes, David
Scheffer, won an agreement letting his delegation return to the final round of
negotiations on the form and functions of the court, in November. Without the
deal today, the United States' participation would have ended.

The deal was immediately criticized by many independent legal experts and
official delegates here, who say that no exceptions should be made for the
United States. Exempting Americans, they argue, only opens the way for officials
of other nations -- some of them ruled by dictators -- to avoid prosecution.

The United States voted against the creation of the tribunal, the International
Criminal Court, two years ago because the Pentagon and a Republican-controlled
Congress opposed it.

The court will deal with war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide. In
principle, the court will have universal jurisdiction, regardless of which
individual countries voted for the treaty to form it. That power makes
Washington nervous, feeling it would be vulnerable to unfair or frivolous
prosecution.

Mr. Scheffer said the United States would take the criticism into account and
would try to devise safeguards as it prepares for further negotiations. In the
meantime, he said, it is important for the United States to stay involved with
the court as it comes into operation over the next few years.

"The world needs a permanent international criminal court," he said in an
interview with several reporters today. "We need it because the perpetrators of
these heinous crimes must be brought to justice, and we need it as a deterrent
over the generations that follow. The international system simply cannot
continue to deal with these problems in an ad hoc manner indefinitely.

"This court has tremendous potential for being a vehicle for international
justice, and we want to be able to see that potential," he said. "We should be
able to assist the court and cooperate with it when it's in our national
interest to do so."

But Mr. Scheffer, who helped create war crimes tribunals for the Balkans and
Rwanda, is in danger of being hamstrung over the next few months by a bill
recently introduced in the Senate by Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina,
and John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, that seeks to block any American
cooperation with the International Criminal Court as long as the United States
does not sign and ratify the treaty. Mr. Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign
Relations Committee, has vowed never to allow ratification.

"It is clearly a locomotive coming down on us," Mr. Scheffer said of the bill
today. "But I would hope that the locomotive stops, because it's recognized that
we are making progress in these negotiations to achieve the very objective that
is behind this legislation. It is a counterintuitive piece of legislation
because it is undermining the very negotiating efforts that we are undertaking
to achieve the objective that we all agree must be achieved."

On Friday, delegates from more than 100 nations who have been meeting here for
three weeks are expected to approve two main components of the court's business,
the rules of procedure and a document called "the elements of crimes." These
elements are a compendium of legal definitions that Mr. Scheffer called a
checklist for prosecutors considering indictments.

The Clinton administration, which once spoke more forcefully for membership in
the court, was instrumental in calling for more specific criteria for war
crimes, genocide and crimes against humanity.

"Never before have war crimes and crimes against humanity and genocide been
defined with such precision as we now have in the elements of crimes," Mr.
Scheffer said. "This will be the document that guides prosecutors not only in
the I.C.C. but also in national and military courts for decades to come."

He added: "And defense counsel will look at this document to determine where
exactly their rights are in the defense of their clients with respect to any
particular crime. It's a truly historic document. We invested a tremendous
amount of our talent in it."

In a November-December session, the last at which countries that do not sign the
treaty establishing the court will have the right to participate in its affairs,
the United States will argue for a provision that allows specifically for an
exemption from prosecution. The accord today generally paved the way for that
debate by raising the general question of international agreements outside the
court's treaty.

In Washington, another American official was more cautious than Mr. Scheffer in
welcoming the move today. "Proponents of the court are certainly not speaking
for the American people," the official said. "It is inconceivable that the
American people would support the hauling of an American official before a court
that is not accountable to the American government when we are not party to the
underlying treaty. Ultimately we're going to have to address this more
fundamental question."

A Case the Scouts Had to Win

BYLINE: By Steffen N. Johnson;  Steffen N. Johnson is a lawyer.

SECTION: Section A; Page 25; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 625 words

DATELINE: CHICAGO


To the dismay of gay rights groups and some civil libertarians, the Supreme
Court ruled on Wednesday that it is unconstitutional for the state to require a
Boy Scout troop to admit a gay scoutmaster. The court's decision, however, goes
to the heart of the First Amendment's guarantee of free association. It may be a
civil right to have access to employment, or to transportation, or to hotels and
restaurants. But it is not a civil right to assist in raising other people's
children.

In the past, the court had understandably ruled that society's interest in
ensuring access to certain opportunities like jobs, school and other basic
necessities must sometimes override the right to associate with whomever one
pleases. Everyone needs to make a living. Everyone needs an education. Thus, the
court ruled that businesses or commercial gatherings like the Rotary Club cannot
exclude women from their ranks.

But serving as a role model for young children whose parents share common values
is not the same sort of privilege as a job or an education. It is a service, and
one entrusted to few people.

To extend the reach of anti-discrimination laws to private groups whose purpose
is not to make a profit, but to bring together people with similar values, would
destroy the nation's diverse tradition of voluntary collaboration for common
causes. And a world in which the government could declare which causes and which
moral positions benefit society, and which do not, could only be described as
Orwellian.

The case arose when the Scouts informed James Dale that he could not serve as a
leader of a troop in Monmouth County, N.J. Mr. Dale sued, claiming that the
Scouts had unlawfully discriminated against him because he was gay, and the New
Jersey courts agreed. But the Supreme Court, in a 5-4 ruling, said that forcing
a group to accept certain members may impair its ability to "express those
views, and only those views, that it intends to express."

Exercising the right to exclude others may seem intolerant, but such a right is
indispensable to private groups seeking to define themselves, to chart their own
moral course, and to work together for common ends. If the Boy Scouts were
required to admit leaders who advocated a position contrary to its own, then men
could assert the right to lead the Girl Scouts, gentiles could assert the right
to head Jewish groups and heterosexuals could assert the right to lead gay
groups.

Mr. Dale's supporters said that the case was about status-based discrimination
and that enforcing anti-discrimination laws against voluntary groups like the
Scouts was valid because anti-gay beliefs are not what brought the Scouts
together. But a group should not need to have an anti-gay agenda to hold the
view that homosexual behavior is wrong. Many churches, for example, teach that
homosexual activity is immoral while affirming that gay people should be treated
with equal dignity and respect. That does not mean that they have given up their
right not to appoint homosexuals to leadership.

Like many Americans, the Boy Scouts attempt to walk the line between tolerance
of everyone and disapproval of certain types of conduct. That they wish to
express their view by example or by quiet persuasion, rather than an outspoken
campaign, does not diminish their right to take a position on moral issues.

As the court's majority understood, people's rights to hold moral positions, to
associate with others who share the same views, and to instill those views in
their children without threat of outside interference are liberties that belong
as much to gay men and lesbians as to the Boy Scouts, as much to those who
advocate alternative lifestyles as to those who advocate traditional morality.

Word for Word/Pop Quiz;
History 101: Snoop Doggy Roosevelt

BYLINE: By SCOTT VEALE

SECTION: Section 4; Page 7; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1358 words


LISTEN up, class. We hate to spoil your holiday weekend, but an alarming new
survey of American history knowledge 2/3-- released just days before
Independence Day, no less 2/3 -- suggests that the nation is in desperate need
of summer school. The report, sponsored by the American Council of Trustees and
Alumni, a Washington-based nonprofit group that promotes liberal-arts study,
posed 34 high-school level questions randomly to 556 seniors at 55 leading
colleges and universities, including Harvard, Princeton and Brown.

Only one student answered all the questions correctly, and the average score was
a sobering 53 percent -- even with a couple of gimmes about cartoon characters
and rap stars tossed in. But maybe it's not too surprising: according to the
survey, none of the schools examined require American history courses for
graduation.


So put down those tube steaks and sharpen your pencils. It's time to match wits
with tomorrow's leaders.   SCOTT VEALE

Israeli Incursions Add to Friction Over Border

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER

SECTION: Section 1; Page 4; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 859 words

DATELINE: BORDER POST 34, Lebanon, June 29


The quick deployment of United Nations peacekeepers and Lebanese forces into the
stretch of southern Lebanon that Israel abandoned in May after 22 years of
occupation has been thrown into doubt with the controversy over a series of
apparent Israeli incursions across a border line drawn in 1923.

When the United Nations Security Council voted two weeks ago to endorse
Secretary General Kofi Annan's certification that Israel had indeed pulled out
its troops, opening the way for an additional force of peacekeepers to fill the
security vacuum along the border, Lebanon protested the findings. But Mr. Annan
brushed aside Lebanese objections, saying there were only a couple of border
violations by Israel and they would be cleared up swiftly.

But then there were more transgressions, and United Nations relations with both
Lebanon and Israel became strained. Newspapers in the region have reported an
angry exchange, including curses, between Mr. Annan and Prime Minister Ehud
Barak of Israel, as well as as a lengthy, middle-of-the-night telephone call in
which Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright reportedly shouted at President
Emile Lahoud of Lebanon to send his army into the south to replace the Hezbollah
guerrillas who are now the only force of local order.

The United Nations has sent officers from the peacekeeping force that has
patrolled the south for more than 20 years to survey and map the border, with
orders to report back to New York headquarters daily.

This week, the surveyors found nine violations by Israel, United Nations
officials said at their headquarters in Naqura.

Most of the violations, they said, were minor. One, for instance, involved a
lone Israeli soldier at an observation post on a hill a few dozen yards over the
nominal line, although the next day he was joined by two armored personnel
carriers.

But the violations have become a political issue, and have drawn a threat from
the leader of the Hezbollah militia to take unspecified action if the United
Nations does not resolve the dispute.

Here along a lonely stretch of road through the stony hills where the border
marches sharply north to swing around the Israeli settlement of Metulla are
several problems that have evolved during the two decades Israel maintained what
it called a "security zone" in southern Lebanon with the help of Lebanese
militias.

Border Post 33 -- a cement stake marking a point along the line -- is atop Sheik
Abad Hill, a little way south. It had been a South Lebanon Army and Israeli gun
position. B.P. 34 is in a creek bed below a cliff where a Lebanese family serves
thick coffee in a makeshift cafe of a truck and awning. B.P. 35 is on another
hill running north.

Across the creek bed is the Israeli hilltop settlement of Misgavan. Over the
course of the occupation, the Israelis moved their security fences forward, and
the settlement spread over the old border. Thus, if the original border were
followed, the settlement would be cut in half.

To the north in Addaiseh, the border line drawn in 1923 -- which runs down a
hill and then turns alongside the main road -- would, if strictly followed, put
about 10 Lebanese houses in Israel. Just to the south, the border runs so close
to a road alongside the Israeli settlement of Manara that it would be impossible
to build a security fence.

Like many of the problems of the modern Middle East, this one dates back to the
way the Western powers divided up the defeated Ottoman Empire after World War I.
Two lieutenant colonels, one French, one British, trudged up and down the hills
from the coast to below Mount Hermon, marking what was to be the border of Syria
and Palestine with piles of whitewashed rocks. Over the years, it shifted here
and there.

"This is a border on wheels," a United Nations official said.

But the Lebanese government, which takes its cues from Syria, has declared every
inch sacred. Israel, for its part, wants to retain high ground, which in much of
the area provides a commanding position overlooking its north.

Beirut newspapers quoted President Lahoud as saying that Mr. Annan had promised
him by telephone on Tuesday that the Israeli encroachments would be cleared up.
"Annan promised me to end the violations in three days and to send radar systems
and helicopters to monitor any future Israeli violations," Mr. Lahoud was quoted
as saying.

                             --------------------


Military Sentences 30

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 1 (Agence France-Presse) -- Amid rising concern over the
conduct of the trials, a military court today sentenced 30 Lebanese convicted of
collaborating with Israel to prison terms ranging up to 120 years.

The 120-year term was handed to Emile Yussef Nasr, who led a brigade of the
Israeli-allied South Lebanon Army. The court sentenced 42 others Friday night,
to terms ranging from several months to 15 years. The court has sentenced 605
people since it began work June 5 and intends to try about 2,200 Lebanese.

Amnesty International, the London-based human rights group, has called the
trials "a parody of justice" that "can in no way help national reconciliation."

World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Jeanne Moore

SECTION: Section A; Page 5; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 928 words



ASIA

MONGOLIA: FORMER COMMUNISTS WIN
The country's former Communist rulers won a landslide victory in elections on
Sunday and vowed to push ahead with economic reforms while doing more to combat
the social costs of the painful 10-year transition from Soviet satellite to a
free market. Unofficial results showed the Mongolian People's Revolutionary
Party won 72 out of the 76 open parliamentary seats. The party had ruled
Mongolia from the 1920's until 1996, when it was ousted by a democratic
coalition.   (Agence France-Presse)


INDIA: SRI LANKA PEACE PLAN
India said it had devised a package to end fighting in Sri Lanka and was ready
to take part in talks between the Sri Lankan government and Tamil rebels. Junior
Foreign Minister Ajit Panja said India favored a united Sri Lanka but did not
disclose details of the proposed package. Officials said Sri Lanka's president,
Chandrika Kumaratunga, would send a special envoy to India this week.
(Reuters)

JAPAN: U.S. MARINE ARRESTED IN OKINAWA
The police arrested a United States marine for allegedly molesting a 14-year-old
girl, threatening to stir up already tense relations between local residents and
American forces weeks before a meeting of the world's leading industrialized
economies. The 19-year-old marine, accused of breaking into a home and molesting
the girl in her room, denied the charge.   (Agence France-Presse)

THE AMERICAS

COLOMBIA: TRUCE TALKS
Government officials and leaders of the country's main guerrilla movement, the
Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, met in Los Pozos, 435 miles south of the
capital, to exchange proposals aimed at bringing an end to decades of fighting.
Their plans for an eventual cease-fire, however, were expected to contrast
sharply.   (Agence France-Presse)

SWITZERLAND: MOSSAD AGENT ADMITS SPYING
An Israeli secret service agent testified that he took part in a bungled
wiretapping two years ago in the Swiss capital, Bern. The agent, using an alias
for the trial, is accused of having tried to bug the apartment of a suspected
Hezbollah sympathizer.   Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

Prime Minister Mikulas Dzurinda and the Parliament speaker, Jozef Migas, have

LITHUANIA: NAZI CRIMES TRIAL HALTED
A court called an indefinite halt to the country's first Nazi-era war crimes
trial, citing the poor health of 93-year-old defendant, Aleksandras Lileikis.
Mr. Lileikis, a former American citizen stripped of his passport, has denied
charges that he turned over Jews to Nazi executioners during the German
occupation of Lithuania.  (Reuters)

NORTHERN IRELAND: VIOLENCE OVER MARCH
Dozens of Protestant militants attacked police in Drumcree, Northern Ireland,
with bricks and bottles after the province's Parades Commission barred members
of the Protestant Orange Order from parading after services this Sunday. The
commission said they could march at a future date if they agreed to speak with
Catholic residents who object to the march coming through their neighborhood.
Warren Hoge (NYT)

AFRICA

ZIMBABWE: WHITE FARMERS' BID
Zimbabwe's white farmers union said more than 200 white-owned farms would be
offered for immediate sale to President Robert Mugabe's government for black
resettlement. The offer came on the last day for commercial farmers to object to
Mr. Mugabe's plan to seize 804 white-owned farms for redistribution to landless
peasants.   (Reuters)

SOUTH AFRICA: DISPUTE ON CAUSE OF AIDS SWIRLS
President Thabo Mbeki's administration fired back at 5,000 scientists who signed
a letter affirming H.I.V. as the cause of AIDS, saying their declaration was a
"waste of time" and a distraction days before the International AIDS Conference
opens in the South African city of Durban. Mr. Mbeki, whose country has more
H.I.V.-positive people than any other, has angered many AIDS researchers and
activists by his position.   Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

MIDDLE EAST

EGYPT: PROTESTS OVER ARRESTS
Human rights groups called for the release of Saad Eddin Ibrahim, an
American-Egyptian sociologist who was arrested Friday night. Mr. Ibrahim, a
professor at the American University in Cairo and head of an Egyptian think
tank, said he was charged with preparing a documentary about elections that
harms Egypt's image and receiving foreign funds without government permission.
   (AP)

ISRAEL: MILITARY EXEMPTION BILL
After long debate, Parliament passed a preliminary bill that would legalize a
practice of granting draft exemptions for ultra-Orthodox seminary students. The
bill, sponsored by Prime Minister Ehud Barak, would change the present system,
which keeps some religious men in school and out of the workforce well into
middle age to keep their exemptions. It would allow religious students who left
school to serve four months in a special unit in place of three years of
mandatory service.   Deborah Sontag (NYT)

FIJI: CIVILIAN GOVERNMENT
Defying the gunmen holding the deposed government hostage, the military leader
appointed a temporary civilian government but said he would retain power until
the captives are freed. Commodore Frank Bainimarama, who took power 10 days
after rebels stormed Parliament on May 19 and seized top officials, appointed
the new government without consulting the gunmen, who demanded a role.   (AP)

BRITAIN: CURBING HOOLIGANS
The government proposed emergency laws to give the courts and the police power
to restrict suspected soccer hooligans from attending domestic matches and
prevent them from traveling to games outside England. With expected Conservative
support, the bill should become law before the end of the month. More than 950
English fans were arrested in Belgium during the just-ended Euro 2000
tournament, and organizers threatened to evict England from the competition.
Warren Hoge (NYT)


BRITAIN: ROYAL FREEZE
Queen Elizabeth II's taxpayer-supported income will be frozen at $12 million a
year for the next decade thanks to cost-cutting by her family and low inflation,
Prime Minister Tony Blair told Parliament. The payout, called the Civil List, is
reviewed every 10 years.  Warren Hoge (NYT)

GREECE: WITNESS PROTECTION
Witnesses to the June 8 terrorist attack against Britain's top military envoy to
Athens, Brig. Stephen Saunders, left, will be given special protection,
including third-country relocation, according to a government spokesman.
Dimitris Reppas said the move "will pave the way for a string of ad-hoc
counterterrorism measures" that Washington and the European Union have been
urging Greece to adopt in its fight against terrorism.  Anthee Carassava (NYT)

AUSTRIA: SANCTIONS REFERENDUM
Austria will hold a referendum in the fall on citizens' opinions of European
Union sanctions. The curbs, more symbolic than financial, were imposed to punish
Austria for letting the rightist Freedom Party into government. Citizens will be
asked whether the government should push for an end to sanctions, which amount
to a refusal by European ministers to meet their Austrian counterparts formally.
Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

LITHUANIA: UNFIT, BUT ON TRIAL
Judges and prosecutors said the trial of a 93-year-old man indicted for aiding
the Nazi killing of Jews could proceed despite a ruling that he was mentally
unfit. A court said a medical commission had ruled that Kazys Gimzauskas,
charged with aiding the NazI genocide during World War II, was unable to stand
trial. The court said it would meet on Sept. 11 to rule on how to proceed.
(Reuters)

The Catholic church in Brasilia threatened to punish a priest for passing out
condoms to prevent the spread of AIDS, highlighting an internal split among
clergy in the world's most populous Catholic country over the Vatican ban.
Warning of unspecified punishment, Archbishop Claudio Hummus condemned the
priest's "incompatible" practice of passing out condoms to the poor in Sao
Paulo.  (Reuters)

SRI LANKA: CENSORSHIP BACK
President Chandrika Kumaratunga, invoking an emergency decree, has reintroduced
censorship on local and foreign news media three days after a landmark Supreme
Court ruling that censorship was illegal. The decree will cover whatever the
government considers to be against national interests or detrimental to the
preservation of public order, officials said. Censorship of war-related news was
imposed under emergency regulations in May, but removed from foreign reporters a
month later.  P. J. Anthony (NYT)

KASHMIR: AUTONOMY REJECTED
The Indian Cabinet rejected a greater autonomy resolution passed by
Jammu-Kashmir state lawmakers last week. The resolution would have restored the
state's pre-1953 status, under which it had its own president, prime minister
and courts. The federal government would have had control of defense, foreign
affairs and communications. Similar autonomy demands were made by Assam in 1940,
Punjab in 1973 and Tamil Nadu in 1974.  P. J. Anthony (NYT)

JAPAN: CABINET SHUFFLE
Yoshiro Mori was reconfirmed as prime minister, a week after his Liberal
Democratic Party won a much narrower than predicted victory in legislative
elections. In what many analysts saw as a confirmation of his weak position, he
immediately picked a new cabinet in which the most powerful economic and foreign
policy positions were holdovers from his previous administration.  Howard W.
French (NYT)

MIDDLE EAST

IRAQ: MISSILE REPORT RIDICULED
Iraq ridiculed a report in The New York Times that Baghdad had restarted its
missile program and flight-tested a short-range ballistic missile, but did not
say whether or not it possessed the missile mentioned in the report. The Times,
which attributed the report to administration and Pentagon officials, said Iraq
had carried out eight tests of a missile, including one last Tuesday, involving
a ballistic missile that could carry conventional explosives or chemical and
biological weapons. The missile does not violate United Nations restrictions.
(Reuters)

A court in Senegal dismissed charges of torture against Hissene Habre, left, the
former President of Chad who has lived in exile in Senegal since being ousted in
1990. Senegal's judiciary, which has been going through changes since a new

court.  Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

Soldiers angry over pay took to the streets of Abidjan, firing in the air and
leaving the commercial capital deserted. The military government led by Gen.
Robert Guei, who seized power in a coup last December after an earlier protest
by disgruntled soldiers, said the disturbances were started by soldiers who had
been demanding $8,700 each for having supported the general.  Norimitsu Onishi
(NYT)

A War Crimes Court

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 152 words



To the Editor:

Re "U.S. Gains a Compromise on War Crimes Tribunal" (news article, June 30):

The worsening isolationist streak in American politics poses a threat to world
security. First, the United States opposed an international criminal court,
preferring underfinanced ad hoc tribunals, a move that, as we have seen, results
in only spotty prosecution.

Now the United States is trying to establish a precedent for granting all people
from a country (Americans, in this case) blanket immunity from prosecution by
the court.

If this precedent goes through, countries ruled by people who do commit grave
crimes against humanity will seek similar loopholes, destroying the
effectiveness of the court as a prosecutor of crime and a deterrent against it.

It's time for the United States to take responsibility as a member of the world
community.

BRIAN O'MEARA
Medford, Mass., June 30, 2000

A Newspaper Apologizes for Slave-Era Ads

BYLINE: By PAUL ZIELBAUER

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1140 words

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 5


In March, a front-page article in The Hartford Courant reported that Aetna Inc.,
one of Connecticut's largest companies, had apologized for profiting from
slavery by issuing insurance policies on slaves in the 1850's. The next day, The
Courant, the state's largest newspaper, ran a second front-page article
speculating that Aetna's contrition might prompt many other American companies
to apologize "for having reaped profits at the cost of human freedom."

That prediction turned out to be accurate. On Tuesday, after a four-month
investigation into its own archives, The Courant ran yet another front-page
article, in which it apologized for having published advertisements in its pages
for the sale of slaves in the 18th and 19th centuries.

In that article, below a banner headline, "A Courant Complicity, an Old Wrong,"
a spokesman for the newspaper said it was sorry "for any involvement by our
predecessors at The Courant in the terrible practice of buying and selling human
beings that took place in previous centuries."

Such ads were common in newspapers of the 1700's and early 1800's, when slavery
was legal in many states, including Connecticut. But even at a time when many
companies are acknowledging past wrongs, The Courant's apology is unusual -- in
part because so few of those newspapers still exist. The Courant, founded in
1764, is the nation's oldest continuously published newspaper.

Though the article about the ads appeared on Independence Day, when many readers
may have been preoccupied with holiday plans, many blacks interviewed in
Hartford today reacted positively to news of The Courant's apology.

"I think it makes a big difference," said Aristede Hill, a youth program
director at Hartford's Y.M.C.A. "I appreciate it. It should be brought to the
forefront."

He said he would find the article, which he had not yet read, and show it to the
youths he works with. "I'll definitely bring it up," said Mr. Hill, 30, of
Bloomfield, a Hartford suburb. "It's something to talk about, debate about."

The existence of the slave ads was known by some Courant executives, but no one
discussed it, said Lou Golden, the newspaper's vice president and deputy
publisher. But after the Aetna article, editors in the news department began an
inquiry into The Courant's history. And when they presented their findings,
everyone agreed an apology was appropriate, Mr. Golden said.

"We hadn't really focused on it, but when it came up, we decided to act on it,"
he said. "If we had focused on it sooner, we would have apologized sooner."

The Courant is not the first American newspaper to confront its involvement with
slavery. The paper, which said it published ads for the sale of slaves and the
return of runaways from 1765 until at least 1823, is one of many across the
nation believed to have printed them.

"It would just have been a natural thing that newspapers would advertise slaves
the way they would advertise any other commodity," said David Brion Davis, a
Yale University history professor and author of "The Problem of Slavery in
Western Culture," noting how deeply rooted slavery was, even in Northern states
like Connecticut, which abolished slavery in 1848.

"That tradition in American journalism goes back very early," said Tom Leonard,
a professor of journalism at the University of California at Berkeley. "I've
seen it in Benjamin Franklin's Pennsylvania Gazette, even though he was an
opponent of slavery."

The New York Times was founded in 1851, after slavery was outlawed in New York
State. A spokeswoman for The Times, Catherine Mathis, said the paper did not
believe that it had run ads for the sale or capture of slaves.

Other newspapers have published, or are preparing to publish, articles on their
complicity in the slave trade. The forerunner of The Times-Picayune in New
Orleans, a newspaper called The Daily Picayune, also ran advertisements seeking
to sell slaves or to find runaways, a fact the paper noted in a long article in
1993, said Jim Amoss, the newspaper's editor.

An editorial at the end of that series of articles included a reference to the
newspaper's past practices that read in part: "The newspaper has had a long
history of racial intolerance and insensitivity. Like all histories, we carry it
with us. We have tried to acknowledge our own failings and, in so doing, to
speak more clearly to our readers about the complex subject of race."

The Web site www.Afrigeneas.com lists runaway-slave ads from newspapers that
regularly published them, including The Baltimore Sun. On Sept. 17, 1852, for
instance, The Sun ran an ad offering a $100 reward for "A Negro Boy named George
Stewart, a slave for life."

Asked about the newspaper's 19th-century practices, William K. Marimow, The
Sun's current editor, said: "I think we've shown in the work we do our
commitment to human rights and civil rights. What the newspaper did then in my
mind was one symptom of an atrocity in America."

He also pointed out that The Sun was a finalist for a Pulitzer Prize three years
ago for a series on modern slavery in Sudan.

The Courant's idea to look into its connection to slavery originated within the
news department, said Jeni Frank, an assistant managing editor. But she and Mr.
Golden offered slightly different explanations of how the article came about.

Mr. Golden said a reporter working on the Aetna article was reporting on the
follow-up article about other companies, "and one of the sources asked, 'Is The
Courant going to apologize,' and the reporter came to us and said, 'Is The
Courant going to apologize?' And we said, 'Yes.' "

But Ms. Frank said she thought of investigating The Courant's possible
involvement in the slave trade during a news meeting on the day the Aetna story
was published.

Publishing the article on a holiday was not meant to lessen its impact, Ms.
Frank said. "We were not trying to avoid publicity," she said, "nor were we
trying to get publicity."

But the article appears to have made an impression far beyond Connecticut's
borders. Mr. Golden spent most of today on the telephone, fielding calls from
reporters around the country. Ms. Frank said the newspaper had received about a
dozen calls, mostly from television and radio stations. "I've gotten calls from
Seattle, from MSNBC," she said.

Ms. Frank said her reporters had noticed many people in Hartford discussing the
article today.

Roger Vann, the president of the Connecticut chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., did not
return calls seeking comment.

Mr. Golden and Ms. Frank said they would be encouraged if other newspapers
decided to explore their own involvement in publishing slave ads. "I think it
would be a good thing," Mr. Golden said. "I think that corporations and
organizations all bear responsibility for what their ancestors and forefathers
did."


http://www.nytimes.com

For Lebanese Linked to Israel, a Quick March Through Court

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER

SECTION: Section A; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 922 words

DATELINE: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 7


At the Military Tribunal, around the corner from the grand statue of a helmeted
and booted soldier clutching a book and the scales of justice, is a series of
bulletin boards with a list of 2,135 names.

These are the former members of Israel's proxy militia, the South Lebanon Army,
who turned themselves in after the Israeli Army abruptly pulled out of its
"security zone" in South Lebanon last month, or were caught by Hezbollah
guerrillas, and are now accused of collaborating with the enemy.

On Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, the military court sits in marathon session,
a half dozen senior officers on the bench led by Brig. Gen. Maher Safieddine,
plowing through the cases against the militiamen, issuing sentences overnight.

So far the court has handed down 667 verdicts in 13 batches of former
militiamen, largely Christians from an area that is predominantly Shiite Muslim.
About 1 percent of the defendants are acquitted, according to local news
reports.

Nearly all the men coming to trial appear to be minor players, rank-and-file
soldiers who say they were conscripted or joined because it was the only job
available. By their accounts, they mostly just moped about and never hurt
anyone.

With few exceptions, the sentences run about a year; some are as short as eight
weeks. And the militiamen are told they cannot go back to their home villages
for a time.

Gen. Antoine Lahd, the commander of the South Lebanon Army, escaped into Israel
along with other senior officers. They are expected to live abroad in
comfortable exile.

One of the few senior officers who was tried here, Maj. Emile Nasr, who was in
charge of operations in Jezzine, was sentenced to 13 jail terms of 10 years each
on multiple charges of collaborating with the enemy and disclosing army secrets.

He shelled Sidon in 1997 in revenge for the death of his niece and nephew in a
roadside bombing, killing 7 civilians and wounding 42. After several attempts on
his life, he reportedly cut a deal with Hezbollah to supply information, then
turned himself over to the Lebanese Army a month before the end of the
occupation.

Another officer, Etienne Saqr, who is believed to be in Israel, was given a
15-year sentence in absentia. Known as Abu Arz, he was the head of a notorious
far-right Christian militia, the Guardians of the Cedars.

For the most part, the trials seem perfunctory. On a recent day, when the court
was trying to get through 68 cases, most were adjourned because defendants had
no lawyers. The bar association has sent batches of lawyers, in their black
robes with white fur tassels, as public defenders, but they are unfamiliar with
the cases and ask for time to read the records. For the most part, they plead
for mercy, saying times were hard under the Israeli occupation.

One defense lawyer, Fadi Kanaan, asked for mercy and a general amnesty for all
the defendants, saying: "It was so dramatic for the inhabitants of the south to
live under occupation, isolated from their country and government. They did not
collaborate with the enemy out of principle, but were forced to do so as a
result of the occupation."

One defendant was convicted of being a double agent who turned his sister over
to the Israelis. Another, charged with giving false information to army
intelligence, said that he first had good information, but that as he was
pressed for more, he ran dry and started making it up. One man said he had risen
to the rank of sergeant in charge of transporting fuel, but was discharged for
stealing gasoline.

The lawyer for George Kawas, who was accused of being a longtime militiaman,
pleaded for mercy, saying, "You know what poverty is like, when money is put in
somebody's face like a carrot."

The trials have not been without criticism. Amnesty International has called
them a "parody of justice" that "can in no way help national reconciliation."

Hezbollah officials have criticized the court as too lenient, calling the trials
"ceremonial" and the sentences "scandalous." The leading newspaper, An Nahar,
has reported incidents in which villagers have beaten up returning militiamen
who received what they saw as light sentences. United Nations officials said
most of those attacked were Shiite Muslims who has worked with the mostly
Christian S.L.A.

On the Christian side, Cardinal Nasrallah Pierre Sfeir, the Maronite patriarch,
said he was forming a committee "to ensure that the trials are fair and unbiased
and that treatment of all prisoners is respectful of human rights."

U.N. Poised to Move In

 BEIRUT, July 7 (Reuters) -- The United Nations expects to send troops to South
Lebanon as soon as it is assured that Israeli troops are no longer making forays
into Lebanon, the United Nations envoy to the Middle East said today.

The envoy, Terje Roed-Larsen, said at a news conference after a day's talks with
President Emile Lahoud and senior Lebanese officials that Israel was willing to
stop encroaching on Lebanon, a key condition set by the government before it
approves deployment of Unifil, the United Nations force.

"Unifil will only deploy with the full cooperation of the government of Lebanon,
and the decision of Lebanon is that there will be no deployment before the
violations are resolved," said Mr. Larsen, who held extensive talks in Israel on
Thursday. "There appears to be a will within the government of Israel to rectify
the violations, but it remains to be seen whether deeds follow words."

                  July 16, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

COVER STORY;
Assessing Responsibility For Evil Beyond Imagining

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH

SECTION: Section 13; Page 4; Column 1; Television

LENGTH: 1090 words


It was to be the triumph of justice over vengeance. The Nuremberg trials, which
began in NOVEMBER(??) 1945, at the end of World War II, would establish the
principle that government leaders were accountable for crimes against humanity
and that no individual was exempt from guilt for committing atrocities in
wartime simply by claiming he was following orders.

Four justices, from the United States, England, France and Russia, presided over
the trial of 21 senior Nazi officials. Among those facing the court were the
wily, fat Luftwaffe chief Hermann Goering; Julius Streicher, publisher of the
anti-Semitic newspaper Der Sturmer, whose vile antics had brought him the
disfavor even of Hitler; the contrite Albert Speer, Hitler's favorite architect;
and the Nazi foreign minister Joachim von Ribbentrop, known as the Mad Hatter,
who babbled insanely.

In setting up the tribunal, the Allies had no body of law upon which to rely.
They had to invent a new system of legal procedures -- one that would form the
basis for future trials of those who commit crimes against humanity in the name
of war.

Tonight and tomorrow night, TNT presents "Nuremberg," the story of that
groundbreaking trial and of the powerful personalities who took part in it. The
film, written by David W. Rintels and directed by Yves Simoneau, is based on the
book "Nuremberg: Infamy on Trial," by Joseph E. Persico. Unlike the 1961 film
"Judgment at Nuremberg," the TNT drama uses testimony and other material from
the court transcripts. The producers also went to great lengths to reproduce the
actual courtroom in which the trials were held. The cast includes Brian Cox as
Goering; Christopher Plummer as the British prosecutor, Sir David Maxwell-Fyfe;
Max von Sydow as Sam Rosenman, who recruited Robert Jackson on behalf of Truman
to prosecute the trial; and Jill Hennessy as Jackson's secretary and love
interest.

The drama centers on Jackson, played by Alec Baldwin, who took the part, he
said, in order to introduce the Nuremberg trials to a new generation of young
people largely unfamiliar with them. "Most kids today born after 1980, their
awareness is all about popular culture," said Mr. Baldwin, also one of the
show's executive producers. "They don't know the things that you and I grew up
with."

The real Jackson was a small-town lawyer from Jamestown, N.Y., who had begun
practicing law when it was still possible to do so by apprenticing to another
lawyer instead of getting a law degree. A political liberal and a champion of
the Constitution, he was appointed solicitor general in 1938 by President
Franklin D. Roosevelt and chief justice in 1941.

"As a U.S. Supreme Court Justice, he had a nice, cushy job," said Mr. Baldwin,
who discussed the historical background of the trials in a recent interview in
New York. Jackson, he said, agreed to go to Nuremberg "when he was told it was a
chance to make history -- 'You're going to be the David Merrick of the trial and
produce the whole thing from straw.' "

Jackson was a great legal orator, and the role gave Mr. Baldwin (who is 42, some
10 years younger than Jackson was at the trial) a chance to utter some of the
grandest lines ever delivered in a courtroom. In his opening speech, Mr.
Baldwin, as Jackson, sets the premise for the proceedings: "That four great
nations, flushed with victory and stung with injury, stay the hand of vengeance
and voluntarily submit their captive enemies to the judgment of the law is one
of the most significant tributes that power has ever paid to reason."

Behind the scenes, though, there was squabbling between Jackson and the American
judge, Francis Biddle, who wanted to be president of the court. In the film, the
two men clash disceetly but repeatedly, until Jackson accuses Biddle of
sabotaging his prosecution of Goering.

But Jackson's chief antagonist in "Nuremberg" is Goering himself. In one scene,
Goering, who weighed 264 pounds when he surrendered, debates the question of
Nazi medical experiments with the prisoners' psychologist, Captain Gustav
Gilbert, played by Matt Craven.

"Let me ask you this: What was Hiroshima?" Mr. Cox's Goering asks. "Was it not
your medical experiment? And would America have dropped atom bombs on Germany as
easily as it did on Japan, making sure to kill as many civilians as possible? I
say not. Because to an American, a Japanese child seems less human than a
Caucasian child."

Goering was a cunning adversary in the courtroom as well. "He was speaking over
the head of the tribunal to the German people" about the glories of National
Socialism, Mr. Baldwin said. He attempted to stonewall the prosecutor's
cross-examination of him, and Jackson, who had not tried a case in years, was
accused of being unprepared.

The film follows the trajectory of Jackson's dawning awareness of the true
magnitude of the trial. "At the beginning, Jackson thought, 'Let's nail them on
this paper trail of broken treaties,' " Mr. Baldwin said.

At first Jackson, he added, thought that "putting people on trial for war crimes
was like handing out speeding tickets."

Then films of prisoners at death camps were screened for the court. At that
point in history, few had seen the photographic evidence of the crimes.
"Nuremberg" uses some of the same footage that was shown during the actual
proceedings. As the film flickers on the screen, there is no sound except the
projector's whirr, and the camera moves in on Mr. Baldwin's face as Jackson
himself realizes the full horror of the crimes.

By the trial's end, "Jackson's grasp of the significance of the war crimes has
overtaken Goering's rhetoric," said Mr. Baldwin. "Their crimes were not
committed by some rogue operation. This was administered by a government."
Jackson went on to deliver a Shakespearean summation: "They stand before the
record of this trial as bloodstained Gloucester stood by the body of his slain
king. He begged the widow, as they beg of you, 'Say I slew them not.' And the
queen replied: 'Then say they are not slain. But dead they are.' "

In 1946 Jackson resigned as prosecutor to return to the Supreme Court, and his
place was taken by Telford Taylor, who conducted the ensuing trials. During his
11 months at Nuremberg, he had helped forge a new principle of international
law: "No longer may the head of a state consider himself outside the law and
impose inhuman acts on the peoples of the world," the real Jackson said after
the trials. "It was a legacy infinitely more important than my work on the
Supreme Court."

Top Balkan Tribunal Upholds Ruling on Rape as War Crime

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 329 words

DATELINE: THE HAGUE, July 21


The Yugoslav war crimes tribunal today upheld a landmark ruling that established
rape as a war crime, rejecting an appeal by a Bosnian Croat commander convicted
of watching as a knife-wielding subordinate tortured and raped a female
prisoner.

The five-judge appellate chamber rejected every ground upon which the defense
contested the Dec. 10, 1998, judgment against the former commander, Anto
Furundzija, 31.

"The appeals chamber has not been persuaded as to the existence of any legal
errors which require it to intervene," the Guyanan presiding judge, Mohamed
Shahabuddeen, said for the tribunal's court of last resort.

Prosecutors hailed the decision.

"It demonstrates that people who are in a position of authority have a
responsibility to govern the behavior of people under their authority," said
Deputy Prosecutor Graham Blewitt.

Mr. Furundzija, head of the special military police unit called the Jokers,
stood by as one of his soldiers threatened a woman being detained, then raped
her during interrogation.

Mr. Furundzija received a 10-year sentence as a result of the attack, which
happened a year into the 1992-95 Bosnian war during a campaign to expel Muslims
from the Lasva River Valley. The soldier has been indicted but not captured.

Two international legal precedents were set. The tribunal admitted the victim's
testimony, even though she suffered from post-traumatic stress. It also expanded
the definition of sexual assault to be more easily punishable as an act of
torture.

A defense lawyer, Luka Misetic, had challenged the conviction on the grounds
that the presiding judge, Florence Mumba of Zambia, had not disclosed her
membership in a United Nations women's rights commission that advocated the
inclusion of rape as a war crime. The panel ruled that Ms. Mumba had not shown
bias in conducting the trial.

It also dismissed Mr. Misetic's claim that the sentence was excessive because
the crime did not result in loss of life.

U.S. Resists War-Crimes Court as Canada Conforms

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 758 words

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 21


When a majority of the world's nations decided two years ago to establish a
permanent court to try those charged with the most serious war crimes, political
opposition emerged in both the United States and Canada.

President Clinton and Prime Minister Jean Chretien were early supporters of the
permanent tribunal, now taking formal shape as the International Criminal Court.
But both faced problems in their respective legislatures, where members had to
approve the countries' participation.

In early July, Canada ratified the treaty creating the court, and announced that
it was the first nation to have brought its national laws in line with the new
tribunal.

The United States, on the other hand, is fighting a last-ditch battle to prevent
Americans from falling under the court's jurisdiction. Clinton administration
officials say America will not join the court in the foreseeable future because
the Senate Foreign Relations Committee -- especially its chairman, Senator Jesse
Helms, Republican of North Carolina -- has warned that its members will never
approve the treaty.

But the Canadian and American situations are different. Most important, Mr.
Chretien has a majority in the Canadian Parliament, while President Clinton must
deal with a Congress controlled by Republicans. Although Canada is active in
peacekeeping around the world, the United States, as the world's most powerful
nation, would be a bigger target for frivolous or politically motivated
lawsuits.

In a recent interview here, Canada's foreign minister, Lloyd Axworthy, said that
the Canadian government, unlike the United States, decided nevertheless to take
no chances with public opinion. It opened a national debate about the court and
began a campaign of "public diplomacy" to build support.

"It was a good debate," he said. "One party raised a number of objections to it,
about national sovereignty and individual rights, but it got approved
overwhelmingly."

"Our view," he said of the government's position, "was that if you have a
functioning national court system, then the international court is simply a
court of last resort."

Mr. Axworthy said that government leaders made acceptance of the court --
designed to bring trials on charges of genocide, war crimes or crimes against
humanity -- a top political priority.

"We sponsored a national forum across the country," he said. "Plus we have a
major Web site on the issue. Most important -- and I underline this -- is that
we enlisted the support of a number of key parliamentarians to do our work
internationally."

These members of the Canadian Parliament not only support the court in their
districts but also go to international meetings to build up wide backing in
organizations like the Inter-Parliamentary Union or NATO. Canadian diplomats
also promote the court, he said.

Canada also recently appointed a member of Parliament who is considered an
expert on the international court, Erwin Cotler of Montreal, as a special envoy
for this issue. "He's there to do the speeches, do the schmoozing," Mr. Axworthy
said. "He's a very popular spokesperson."

For Canada, the campaign is over domestically, and officials can turn to the
vexing questions of how to build more support in the United States for a court
that could be functioning within a year or two.

"It is no longer something that's going away; in fact it's probably something
that's coming quicker than most people would anticipate," Mr. Axworthy said.
"It's now taking form, shape and movement, plus some energy. That in itself
should be a message.

"Our strategy is to keep the U.S. engaged," said Mr. Axworthy, who meets
regularly with a dozen of his counterparts from around the world to discuss
issues of "human security," an area where the court ranks high, he said.

"Let's continue to work and massage and accommodate," he said of Washington's
fears. "But there has to be flexibility on the U.S. side. They have to adjust
their sights now too and recognize that they are not going to get an exemption
from this court. That's pretty clear. They've been told that."

Mr. Axworthy said that Canada and others would like to see a shift in American
thinking, but he added that they are aware that the American public is not high
on this issue. "It is so important, so crucial that the debate here shift its
focus from how you thwart it, frustrate it or stop it to how do we make sure
that your interests are looked after and that you can support probably what will
be the most significant new institution of this century."

U.N. Urges New Rules to Help Children in War

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 7; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 473 words

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 21


The United Nations outlined recommendations today to better protect children
caught in war, saying they have increasingly become the "innocent victims of the
persistent gap between law and practice."

The 55 proposals cover a range of issues confronting children in war zones,
including their recruitment into armies, their risk of harm from land mines and
their vulnerability to sanctions applied in times of conflict.

The United Nations estimates that some 300,000 children have been recruited,
mostly by rebel groups, to fight wars from Sierra Leone to Sri Lanka. Data from
Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund, indicate that between 1986 and 1996,
wars killed two million children, injured six million and orphaned one million.

Secretary General Kofi Annan said in a report to the Security Council that an
important starting point to reduce those numbers would be if all governments
ratified the core treaties and protocols on protecting children and for rebel
groups to also respect those standards.

He asked countries that support rebel factions -- with military, political,
financial or other aid -- to condition their assistance on compliance with those
norms. And he suggested that corporations be asked to develop voluntary codes of
conduct concerning trade with countries or other parties responsible for gross
violations of children's rights.

Mr. Annan stressed that people who commit genocide, war crimes and crimes
against humanity on children should not be offered amnesty as part of peace
negotiations.

His core recommendations are expected to be negotiated by the Security Council
and then translated into a resolution. In the report, Mr. Annan also urged the
council to take into consideration the "unintended consequences" of sanctions on
children when it debates whether to place embargoes on countries.

He suggested the council send assessment teams to targeted countries to
determine how embargoes might affect the civilian population.

"The potential long-term benefits of sanctions should be weighed against the
immediate and long-term costs to children," Mr. Annan said, citing the collapse
of education and health infrastructures and increase in infant mortality rates
associated with some sanctions regimes.

"The suffering of Iraqi children, as reported by Unicef, and of children in the
Balkans are troubling cases in point," he wrote.

The report also addressed ways the Security Council could help children recover
from wars. Mr. Annan urged that they be taken into account when designing peace
agreements.

Girls should be given particular attention to ensure that they receive equal
access to education and job training, Mr. Annan wrote.

He said children are disproportionately at risk from being maimed or killed by
land mines and urged more money for mine clearance and education.
