Where Suing for Libel Is a National Specialty;
Britain's Plaintiff-Friendly Laws Have Become a Magnet for Litigators

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 1; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 1280 words


When she first heard about it, Deborah Lipstadt believed that David Irving's
threatened libel suit would be little more than a fleeting inconvenience.

"I thought, 'This is a classic nuisance suit,' " said Ms. Lipstadt, the author
of "Denying the Holocaust," which portrays Mr. Irving as a Holocaust denier who
manipulates history to further his own agenda. "I thought there would be a few
lawyers' letters, and then it would go away."

But it didn't go away. Five years later, Ms. Lipstadt, a professor of Modern
Jewish and Holocaust Studies at Emory University in Atlanta, won a drawn-out
court case along with her publisher, Penguin Books, but only after spending more
than $3 million and enlisting a formidable army of experts who had to prove that
what she had said about Mr. Irving was true. The victory left Ms. Lipstadt with
an unusually personal understanding of the vagaries of English libel law.

In the United States, with its ironclad belief in the First Amendment right to
free speech, libel plaintiffs like Mr. Irving need to prove not only that the
speech in question is false, but also that it was published with a reckless
disregard for the truth. In England, the burden is in exactly the other
direction: the offending speech is presumed to be false, and it is up to
defendants like Ms. Lipstadt to prove that it is in fact true.

That may sound reasonable, but it can be prohibitively difficult, said Helena
Peacock, the legal director of Penguin Books in Britain. "Quite often, things
are true, but it's very hard to provide evidence in court that shows they're
true," she said.

As a result, the British system tends to have a dampening effect on what
newspapers print and what publishers include in books, especially when the
material is likely to offend someone who is powerful, rich or particularly
litigious. "A lot of journalists feel very strongly that the libel laws support
the very people they are traditionally supposed to call to account -- those in
authority," said Bob Jones, an emeritus fellow in journalism at City University
in London. "In a profit-oriented, highly competitive media industry, managements
are not too keen on taking risks when it comes to powerful people, because they
know how expensive it is."

Part of the reason for the difference in laws is that England has never held
free speech in as high esteem as the United States has; English courts have
tended to regard it as subordinate to things like reputation, for instance.
"It's all connected with the English culture of deference," said Eric Barendt, a
professor of media law at University College London.

Meanwhile, because of its plaintiff-friendly libel laws, London is
not-so-affectionately known among lawyers as "a town called Sue." "We're
becoming the libel capital of the world," said Mark Stephens, a lawyer
specializing in free speech cases here. "The U.K. is probably the best plaintiff
jurisdiction anywhere, and as a consequence we get increasingly sophisticated
plaintiffs looking at which country is best to sue in and being increasingly
attracted to the U.K."

A recent ruling by the House of Lords, which serves as England's court of last
resort, has not helped. The case concerned the effort of a high-profile Russian
politician and businessman, Boris Berezovsky, to bring a libel suit against
Forbes, the American magazine, in England. A 1996 Forbes article said that Mr.
Berezovsky was followed by "a trail of corpses, uncollectible debts and
competitors terrified for their lives."

Lawyers for Forbes argued that since the case involved a Russian citizen and an
American publication with a circulation in England of less than 2,000, it had
nothing to do with England. When a lower-court judge agreed, Mr. Berezovosky
appealed to the House of Lords and won.

Forbes plans to bring up the matter with the European Court of Human Rights in
Strasbourg, whose decisions can overrule even those of the House of Lords. But
if the case ends up going to trial, Forbes will be put in a highly awkward
position.

"One will have to ship a sizable number of members of the Russian underworld
here to testify," said David Hooper, a lawyer on Forbes's English legal team.
"The whole thing is ridiculous."

When they do find themselves sued in English courts, American publications tend
not to fare well. In a recent case, The New York Times and The International
Herald Tribune lost a libel suit brought by Marco Pierre White, a celebrity chef
in London, who said that a generally favorable Times article from 1998,
reprinted in The Tribune, libeled him when it said he had had a "well-publicized
bout with drugs and alcohol."

The Times drew this inference from Mr. White's autobiography, in which he
referred to having embarked on a "big bender," only reforming his "decadent"
ways because "eventually I couldn't stand watching another person getting drunk
or someone else injecting smack into his veins." Had the case been heard in
America, The Times would have argued that its characterization was an honest
interpretation of what Mr. White himself had said and did not show a reckless
disregard for the truth. But in England, the jury took a dim view of the
American free-speech tradition. It found for Mr. White and ordered the papers to
pay him some $125,000 in damages, as well as his legal costs, which are likely
to be several hundred thousand dollars.

By the same token, when American courts have occasion to consider England's
libel laws, they are hard-pressed to contain their dislike for a system so
antithetical to their own. This was made abundantly clear in 1996, when -- asked
to enforce an English libel judgment because the defendant had moved to Maryland
-- the Maryland Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, refused. "The
signing of the Declaration of Independence, the adoption of state constitutions
and the later ratification of the First Amendment signaled a major departure
from English law and policy concerning free speech and freedom of the press,"
the court said.

The concern for American newspapers and magazines, lawyers say, is that the
recent Berezovsky ruling, as well as the growing availability of American
publications on the Internet, will make them increasingly vulnerable to
plaintiffs seeking to take their grievances to English courts. "In the Internet
age," said Patrick J. Carome, a specialist in defamation law in Washington,
"there is a worry that we're going to see more and more situations where foreign
defendants are being hauled into court in countries like England."

Why does England persist in holding on to its libel laws?

They certainly have few champions among newspapers in Britain. But because of
the news media's almost universal unpopularity among lawmakers (who know only
too well what it feels like to be on the wrong side of a tabloid article),
Parliamentary efforts to amend the system have generally failed.

There are some good aspects to the laws, argues David Price, a defamation lawyer
in England: "I would defend them on the basis that whether something is true or
false is a useful piece of information. A trial on whether a public figure has
or has not been guilty of wrongdoing is a much more useful exercise than one on
whether a newspaper believed he was guilty of wrongdoing."

Even Ms. Lipstadt believes that fighting Mr. Irving in court, as unpleasant as
it was, had an unforseen benefit: "In the U.S., this would have been thrown out
of court, but if it had been thrown out, Irving would have been able to say that
he never got his day in court. I thought, 'This British law is making me jump
through hoops.' But he was the one who was stripped naked."

Editorial Observer;
How Slavery Fueled Business in the North

BYLINE: By BRENT STAPLES

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 899 words


The German Parliament hoped to discourage a wave of lawsuits -- and close the
door on an ugly past -- when it voted to support a fund through which
corporations will compensate people who worked as slave laborers in Germany
during World War II. But by agreeing to pay reparations, corporations like
DaimlerChrysler, Deutsche Bank, Siemens and Volkswagen are tacitly admitting
that German corporate wealth rests at least partly on slave labor extracted from
Jews during the commission of crimes against humanity.

This has been a big year for institutional contrition, with the Vatican
apologizing for misdeeds of the past -- extending back to the Inquisition -- and
Swiss banks seeking atonement for appropriating the accounts of Holocaust
victims. But in the United States Congress, a bill that would bring about a
similar reckoning with regard to two and a half centuries of slavery may never
see the light of day. Legislation sponsored by Representative John Conyers Jr.
of Michigan calling for a study of reparations has failed to reach the House
floor, even after being submitted to Congress every year for more than a decade.

The failure of Congress to take this bill seriously reflects the sense among
Americans as a whole that slavery has no economic bearing on the nation as it
exists today. But if a 34-year-old lawyer named Deadria Farmer-Paellmann has her
way, a broader debate about reparations and the links between modern
corporations and the slave economy may be on the way.

A part-time musician and amateur historian, Ms. Farmer-Paellmann attended law
school solely to develop a legal argument for reparations. After scouring
corporate archives, she has turned up connections between modern corporations
and predecessor companies that seem clearly to have profited from the slave
trade, in some cases obliquely but often quite directly.

Inspired by the German case, Ms. Farmer-Paellmann is planning to sue a dozen
corporations for "unjustly enriching" themselves and has already begun
distributing archival records that provide provocative examples of corporate
involvement in the trade. The planned lawsuits are novel. But the news articles
about her first few discoveries have already broadened public awareness of the
extent to which the United States depended on slaves to build the national as
well as the Southern economy.

Charles Ogletree, a Harvard Law School professor, is among those paying
attention. He says he is considering both litigation and legislation and is
helping to plan a conference scheduled this fall on the reparations issue.

Modern-day Northerners tend to view slavery as confined to the Confederacy,
thinking of the Northeast as made up of "free states." Americans are for the
most part unaware that slavery covered all of the original colonies and their
successor states and began to loosen its grip in the North only in the early
1800's, when personal liberty laws went into effect. New York City was a capital
of human bondage, with more slaves than any other city with the possible
exception of Charleston, S.C.

New England survives in the history books as the hotbed of abolitionism and the
home of the crusading anti-slavery novelist Harriet Beecher Stowe. But Ms.
Farmer-Paellmann has turned up documents revealing a different New England, one
in which corporate founders and respected businessmen trafficked in slaves, even
after aspects of the slave trade were made illegal.

One of the most serious offenders was the Rhode Island businessman John Brown,
who founded Providence Bank, an early predecessor of the modern FleetBoston
Financial Corporation. The Fleet corporate history portrays Brown as a
"respected merchant." But Ms. Farmer-Paellmann has unearthed records showing
that Brown owned ships that embarked on several slaving voyages and that he was
prosecuted in federal court for participating in the international slave trade
after it had become illegal under federal law. Records show that Providence Bank
lent substantial sums to Brown, and Ms. Farmer-Paellmann suspects that the bank
both financed and profited from the founder's illegal slave trading. For its
part, FleetBoston contends that incomplete records make a conclusion impossible.

The most disturbing document to emerge so far reveals that the Aetna Insurance
Company of Hartford actually insured slave owners against the loss of their
human chattel. That Aetna knew the horrors of slave life is evident in a rider
through which the company declined to pay the premium for slaves who were
lynched, worked to death or who committed suicide. Aetna says that incomplete
records forbid its knowing how many such policies were written. After the policy
came to light, the company apologized for having been involved in the slave
trade.

Ms. Farmer-Paellmann claims to have found similar documents concerning more than
a dozen corporations still doing business in this country and has promised to
file several lawsuits charging these companies with unjustly enriching
themselves at the expense of slaves. Whether or not the lawsuits succeed is
almost beside the point. This exercise will have done its job if it reveals to
the public the role of slavery in shaping American life. More than a few modern
fortunes rest on the suffering of human beings who once accounted for a large
portion of American wealth and lived in chains here for 250 years.

Syria Is Sued by Family of Man Killed by '96 Bomb in Jerusalem

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER

SECTION: Section A; Page 6; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 731 words


The family of an Israeli-American man killed in a 1996 terrorist attack in
Jerusalem filed suit in New York yesterday against Syria, contending that it
provided critical support to Hamas, the militant Palestinian group whose members
carried out the suicide bombing attack.

The suit seeks to hold the government of Syria, the Syrian Defense Ministry and
two Syrian officials legally responsible for the attack in which 24 people were
killed, including Ira Weinstein, a 53-year-old butcher who lived in Israel for
the last decade of his life, and whose family is bringing the suit.

The two Syrians are Mustafa Tlass, the defense minister, and Ghazi Kanaan, the
commander of Syrian forces in Lebanon.

In the suit, the Weinstein family says that Syria is liable for Mr. Weinstein's
death and the suffering that he and his family endured because Syria provided
Hamas terrorists with "material resources" and training to carry out the
bombing.

Other American victims of terrorist acts have won monetary damages against Iran
and Cuba, but have been unable to collect them because those nations' assets in
the United States have been frozen.

Although Syria has appeared on the State Department's list of state sponsors of
terrorism for decades, the State Department says it has not been directly
engaged in terrorism since 1986. Rather, it says, Syria gives indirect support,
by letting Hamas and other groups run bases and take refuge in Damascus or in
the Bekaa region in Lebanon, which is under Syrian control.

With that decision from the State Department, Syria is not subject to sanctions
as severe as those imposed on Iraq, Iran and other designated state terrorism
sponsors. And trade is permitted between the two countries. Therefore Syria has
assets in the United States that could be seized if a jury ruled against Syria,
the family's lawyers assert.

"We will prove that Syria has supported terrorist actions perpetrated by Hamas,"
said Nitsana Darshan-Leitner, an Israeli lawyer representing the plaintiffs,
Susan Weinstein, Ira's Weinstein's widow, and their children, Jennifer, 34,
Joseph, 31, and David, 17. "And we hope to dissuade Syria and others from
hosting and helping terrorist groups by showing them that the price paid for
doing so is far too high."

A spokesman for the Syrian Embassy in Damascus denied that Syria condones or
supports terrorism and deplored the killing of civilians throughout the world.
"We respect human rights and reject any allegation that we tolerate or sanction
terrorism anywhere," a diplomat said.

Lawyers for the Weinstein family are seeking $330 million and punitive damages
in compensation for the suffering the family endured when Mr. Weinstein was
mortally wounded on a bus that was blown up by a Hamas suicide bomber in
Jerusalem in February 1996.

"Ira Weinstein did not immediately die from the bombing," states the complaint,
provided to The New York Times by the family's lawyers.

With burns over much of his body, severe lung damage, shrapnel, kidney failure
and amputation of both legs, the complaint says, Mr. Weinstein suffered
"excruciating and conscious pain for seven weeks before dying." His daughter,
Jennifer, a nurse in the ward at the hospital where her father was treated,
"witnessed her father's injuries and agony for the entire seven-week period."

The complaint accuses Syria of providing substantial aid to Hamas at the time of
the bombing, including training, weapons and explosives storage, safe haven,
lodging, means of communication and equipment and financial services. The
lawyers said that Hamas's involvement in the suicide bombing was later confirmed
by Hassan Salamah, a Hamas member, in statements to an Israeli court that
convicted him of helping to plan the bombing.

Jeffrey A. Miller, co-administrator of the Weinstein estate and the family's New
York attorney in the lawsuit, said the family filed the suit in Nassau County
Supreme Court under a 1996 law that permits American victims of terrorism to sue
to recover monetary damages from states that sponsor terrorism or provide
"material support or resources" to terrorists.

He said the law does not require his plaintiffs to show that Syria carried out
or encouraged the specific bombing that killed Mr. Weinstein, but only that it
provided "material support" to the group whose members carried out the act.

Massacres in Kashmir May Be Effort to Sabotage Peace Initiative

BYLINE: By BARRY BEARAK

SECTION: Section A; Page 7; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 574 words

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Aug. 2


In a killing rampage remarkable even for the bloodied mountains and forests of
Kashmir, at least 93 people were slain late Tuesday and early today in six
separate massacres.

Most of the dead were innocents: pilgrims on their way to pray at a holy site,
laborers working at a brick kiln, villagers awakened from their beds and lined
up for killing.

To many in India the cause of all this killing seemed straightforward enough: a
peace initiative last week by one militant group has been deemed a contemptible
betrayal by others, requiring sabotage.

"It is clear that after the Hizbul Mujahedeen called for a cease-fire and talks,
other militant groups have been instructed by Pakistan to step up their attacks
on innocent and unarmed people," India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee,
told Parliament. He added, "I will tell these terrorists that we will not bow
down to their threats."

But Pakistan, as well as several of the militant groups critical of the peace
initiative, denied any responsibility for the multiple attacks.

Indeed, Pakistan's Foreign Ministry issued a statement asserting that India's
own ruthless conniving might be to blame. "On previous occasions," the ministry
said, "terrorist acts aimed at civilians have been carried out by renegade
elements at the behest of the Indian security forces, to malign the Kashmiri
freedom struggle internationally."

Each of the two countries now occupies part of Kashmir, though India's share is
far larger and includes the valley that is the heart of Kashmiri culture.

Since 1989, Pakistan-backed militants have been rebelling against Indian rule.
An estimated 25,000 to 40,000 people have died in the fighting.

Last week, the Hizbul Mujahedeen -- one of the main insurgents -- declared a
unilateral cease-fire for three months, a surprise announcement that brought an
offer of talks from India and condemnation from other Islamic militants in the
fray.

The Kashmir dispute is a deep morass, and while little common ground would seem
to exist between the Hizbul and India, plans for discussions appeared to be
going forward, so violent efforts to derail the process could hardly be
unexpected.

Many in India have presumed that the Hizbul Mujahedeen would not have declared a
cease-fire without at least the tacit approval of Pakistan's military
government, which has been under pressure from the United States.

Inflamed oratory aside, the attacks raise questions about whether Pakistan
indeed favors the new dialogue and how much capacity it has to control the
militants.

The attacks were particularly jarring and heinous, and the victims were
overwhelmingly Hindu. In the worst incident, gunmen opened fire on pilgrims on
their way to a religious shrine at Pahalgam, 55 miles south of Srinagar. The
death toll in that one incident has risen to 33, according to hospital
officials.

In a small brickmaking community near the town of Anantnag, attackers forced
people from their homes, lined up the men and shot them. Eighteen died there.

Curfews have since been imposed in parts of the state. The authorities say they
fear a violent Hindu backlash against Muslims.

For their part, the Hizbul Mujahedeen were loath to suggest that any militant
groups had taken part in the massacres. Instead, the group's chief, Sayed
Salahuddin, demanded that India's leaders come to the table without any
preconditions and be ready to discuss Kashmiri secession.

Karadzic Still Plays Hide-and-Seek With U.N. in Bosnia

BYLINE: By CARLOTTA GALL

SECTION: Section A; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1416 words

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Aug. 6


The high, forested mountains of southeastern Bosnia are a place to hide, and,
according to current local lore, it is there, in the steep gorges or trails and
high passes into neighboring Montenegro, that Radovan Karadzic has been hiding.

Dr. Karadzic, the former leader of the Bosnian Serbs twice indicted by the war
crimes tribunal in The Hague on charges of genocide and crimes against humanity,
took refuge, according to news media reports in Bosnia last month, in the
village of Celebici, right on the border with his native Montenegro.

A onetime psychiatrist who led a campaign of extreme nationalism and instigated
a lethal war of ethnic cleansing, he has been closely guarded since the war
ended.

Even men who were once his close associates say they have not seen him for two
years. His influence over the Bosnian Serb republic, which he founded, is said
to be waning, as officials close to him have been moved out of office, left the
country or been arrested.

Yet Dr. Karadzic, widely regarded as the man most culpable for the 1992-95 war
in Bosnia, is still at large.

His unrepentant presence glowers over every issue in this ruined society: the
return of displaced people to their homes, the rule of law, cooperation of local
officials and politicians with the international administration, and the failure
or unwillingness of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Bosnia, known as
SFOR, to arrest him.

"To me he is the central one," said Thomas Miller, the American ambassador in
Bosnia, who insists that arresting Dr. Karadzic is still a priority. "For my
government, if I had one single wish, it would be to get Karadzic. He's a war
criminal, responsible for terrible things, but to his people he symbolizes
resistance. If he goes, it collapses that wall of resistance."

Yet Dr. Karadzic has eluded the special squads who have steadily picked up
lesser suspects -- almost one a month in the last 10 months -- and he has
continued to move around the region, if with great caution and even more warily
since NATO troops seized his close associate and partner in war, Momcilo
Krajisnik, in April.

It is five years since Dr. Karadzic was indicted, and local journalists and
officials fear that despite all foreign promises, he may get away for good,
sneaking into Montenegro and then Serbia, where many other war crimes suspects
have found refuge.

Georgios Vlachogiannis, the international governor of Foca, the Serbian
nationalist stronghold closest to Celebici, said he did not believe that Dr.
Karadzic was still in the area. "There are rumors that he is moving through the
Montenegrin border," he said. "Some think he is moving into Serbia."

In Pale, the ski resort town outside Sarajevo that Dr. Karadzic made his capital
and wartime headquarters, his daughter has reportedly been looking for a buyer
for her television and radio station, Astra. That could indicate that the family
is preparing to move to Serbia, one local journalist said. Dr. Karadzic's son, a
businessman reputed to have ties to the widespread smuggling networks developed
during the war, has lived in Belgrade for some years.

Dr. Karadzic's wife, Ljiljana Karadzic, still heads the Red Cross in the Bosnian
Serb republic and in July attended the celebrations in Pale marking the 10th
anniversary of the founding of her husband's Serbian Democratic Party.

She appears to live apart from her husband for security reasons but remains a
standard bearer and praised the achievements of his party.

Support for Dr. Karadzic in Pale remains outwardly strong. "Everyone still
supports him," said a 24-year-old who gave only his first name, Mladan. "I think
no one would betray him, despite the big reward. If he were arrested, blood
would be spilled and there would be attacks on SFOR."

But others doubt that there would be unrest, pointing to the muted reaction
after the arrest of Mr. Krajisnik. "People are only interested in jobs," said
Mayor Dragoljub Pipovic of Foca, a Serb.

The governor, Mr. Vlachogiannis, says the thugs who made Foca notorious -- 12
men from Foca alone have been indicted on war crimes charges -- have gone and
the atmosphere in the town has changed. "My feeling is that after Krajisnik's
arrest they left," he said. "They are probably living in Serbia."

Asked why NATO peacekeepers would not arrest indicted war crimes suspects before
they crossed the border, a spokesman for the force, Col. Tom Beginnes, said that
it was not the force's task to pursue suspects and that they could be arrested
only when encountered in the course of peacekeeping activities.

Dr. Karadzic's top general, Ratko Mladic, has been living in Belgrade since the
end of the Bosnian war and has been sighted there several times in recent
months.

Yet even Serbia may not provide a safe refuge for some men -- as Dragan Nikolic,
a Serb wanted by the tribunal for crimes alleged to have been committed in a
camp for Muslims near Vlasenica in 1992, found out. Mr. Nikolic, the first man
indicted by the war crimes tribunal, was abducted from his home in the town of
Smederevo in central Serbia in April, driven to the border with Bosnia in the
trunk of a car and handed over to American troops. His abduction is said to have
been organized by Serbian bounty hunters tempted by the cash reward, who have
since been arrested in Serbia.

The State Department has posted a $5 million reward for information leading to
the arrest of the three most notorious men indicted by the tribunal, Dr.
Karadzic, General Mladic and President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, who was
charged for crimes committed by his troops in the Kosovo war last year.

If the reward has not brought any results so far, it has certainly raised the
stakes. Wolfgang Petritsch, who heads the international administration in
Bosnia, said the steady stream of arrests had increased the pressure. "The big
shots are still at large," he said, "but I can feel a heightened sense of
nervousness."

Dr. Karadzic has gone to extreme lengths to protect himself. He never shows his
face, but people know he is in Pale when they see members of his entourage
around, one journalist in the town said. That last happened two to three months
ago, the journalist added. Former associates say Dr. Karadzic went underground
two years ago after the murder of the young deputy police chief, Srdjan
Knezevic, in Pale in 1998.

Dr. Karadzic is widely believed to have been behind the killing, since the
influential deputy had defected to join Biljana Plavsic, then president of the
Bosnian Serb republic.

Ms. Plavsic, once an extreme nationalist, turned her back on Dr. Karadzic and
threw in her lot with the Western officials running Bosnia before losing the
presidency in late 1998. She reacted by withdrawing Dr. Karadzic's government
bodyguards, according to his former defense minister, Milan Ninkovic.

One of the few close associates of Dr. Karadzic still openly in circulation in
Bosnia, Mr. Ninkovic remains the most powerful politician in his hometown of
Doboj in the north of the country.

Yet the threat of a secret indictment clearly nagged at him. He complained that
peacekeepers' helicopters had started flying over his house on the outskirts of
Doboj.

"They often fly over the house and hover, and there is some indication that they
are photographing my house," he said. "I consider that there is no war crime in
my past and the only problem is that I am an obstacle to my political enemies."

He served as defense minister for the last year of the war in Bosnia, and so was
in office during the worst massacre of the war, at Srebrenica. He insists that
he had little authority and that Dr. Karadzic and General Mladic frequently
bypassed him when they issued orders to the army.

He blamed General Mladic, with whom he had frequent disagreements, for
Srebrenica. He was careful in his comments about Dr. Karadzic, saying the only
order he had seen was for the army to surround Srebrenica, not seize it.

Mr. Ninkovic, like Mrs. Karadzic, defends the actions of the Bosnian Serb
leadership during the war. An interview with him runs like a speech in his
defense, and one that takes little account of the recent arrests and indictments
of some of the most notorious Bosnian Croat war crimes suspects.

"My only mistake was that I wanted to defend my own people," Mr. Ninkovic said,
accusing the Muslim side of war crimes too. "Who killed the 30,000 Serb war
dead?" he asked. "Yet it is only Serbs who go to The Hague."

                August 12, 2000, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

Seeking Out a Just Way To Make Amends for Slavery;
The Idea of Reparations for Blacks Is Gaining in Urgency, But a Knot of
Questions Remain, Like: Which Blacks?

BYLINE: By DIANE CARDWELL

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 1; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 1494 words


In recent years the issue of reparations has exploded among nations wrestling
with the past. Scholars are beginning to see the German payout of $60 billion to
Jewish victims of the Holocaust, the United States decision to pay reparations
to Japanese-Americans who were interned during World War II and even Japan's
awkward efforts to settle with Korean "comfort women" as bedrocks of a new
political landscape.

Elazar Barkan, the chairman of the cultural studies department at Claremont
Graduate University in California, contends that since the end of the cold war,
the West in particular has entered a neo-Enlightenment period of political
morality in which restitution increasingly plays a leading role. Political
language has shifted, he writes in "The Guilt of Nations"(W.W. Norton), from
machtpolitik, the politics of power, to a shared belief among nations in the
rights of individuals and groups.

Consent and cooperation have become the buzzwords of global relations, Mr.
Barkan says, and agreement is now being achieved through negotiation rather than
force. "Certainly the eagerness of leaders -- Clinton, Blair, Chirac, the pope
-- to atone has been mocked," he said during a telephone interview. "But there
is a growing sense that you have to do the right thing."

In this new era, Mr. Barkan and others argue, the issue of American reparations
for slavery -- straitjacketed for decades in a kind of intellectual Bedlam -- is
beginning to look sane. "For so long it was just ludicrous for black folk to
even bring up the notion that they might be entitled to some just compensation,"
said Michael Eric Dyson, the Ida B. Wells Barnett professor of religious studies
at De Paul University in Chicago. "It was simply crazy." But after so many
successful reparations campaigns, including those for economic and cultural
restitution to various American Indian tribes, the African-American case has
gained momentum.

Every year since 1989, Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan,
has sponsored a bill to establish a commission to study reparations for slavery.
It remains stuck in committee, but away from Capitol Hill other developments are
having a significant impact on the national debate.

Black intellectuals like Randall Robinson, the president of TransAfrica, a
lobbying group, and the author of "The Debt: What America Owes to Blacks," and
the Harvard University professors Charles T. Ogletree and Henry Louis Gates Jr.
have publicly supported reparations. Individual cities and towns are confronting
their racist pasts: some, like Chicago, Detroit, Cleveland and Dallas, support
Federal hearings on reparations while others, like Tulsa, Okla., Rosewood, Fla.,
and Elaine, Ark., are either considering or are paying monetary damages for past
atrocities. As Mr. Dyson explains, "African-Americans themselves are beginning
to be politicized around this debate."

Mr. Barkan writes that slavery remains "the most glaring example of an
unaddressed historical injustice in the United States." He adds that this
"stands in direct contrast with the public culture that embraces the concept of
attempting to redress its imperfect past."

But opponents of reparations commonly argue that other examples of past
imperfection are redressable in ways that slavery is not. In the case of the
Japanese-Americans, the victims themselves were compensated for quantifiable,
provable suffering at the hands of an identifiable perpetrator, the United
States Government. With the descendants of slaves, this argument goes, the
situation is entirely different.

It is, first of all, said to be impossible to determine the actual present-day
effect of slavery -- to trace the impact of slavery on, for example, today's
overwhelming incarceration rate among black males, or to calculate all those
generations of lost or artificially depressed wages. Not to mention the quagmire
of determining who should be compensated. All blacks? Only those who demonstrate
direct linkage to a slave? Should those of mixed race be included? Or what about
Oprah?

Supporters of reparations find this line of argument irrelevant. "The way I look
at historical crimes or historical injustices is do the victims still suffer,
whether it is the victim or the victim's descendants," Mr. Barkan says. "Another
issue that's been raised is, 'Why should I pay for it, I didn't do it?' It is a
foolish argument. No one is responsible personally for any wrongdoing. But just
to stop the action doesn't mean to have paid for the past. The perpetrator is
very clear. It's the identity of the U.S. The U.S. as an entity is responsible."

Scott L. Malcomson, the author of the forthcoming "One Drop of Blood: The
American Misadventure of Race" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux) points out that whites
have been distancing themselves from moral culpability for slavery since as far
back as the Revolutionary period. Thomas Jefferson, for instance, argued that it
was the British who were to blame. Even so, many abolitionists at the time
supported their own form of reparations: the establishment of a colony in Africa
for freed slaves.

Although Mr. Barkan writes in "The Guilt of Nations" that national identity is a
result of history, "for better and for worse," and therefore we "should pay our
historical debts," Wendy Kaminer, a fellow at the Radcliffe Public Policy
Center, recently argued the opposite point. Writing in American Prospect
magazine, she said that the campaign for reparations "reflects some of the
premises of the aristocracy it attacks." She continued: "It allows the past to
define our entitlements in the present; it relies on a belief in the justice of
inheritance. . . . If equality is a birthright, you don't have to purchase it
with the sufferings of your ancestors, any more than you should be able to
purchase privileges with your ancestors' achievements."

Indeed, just how the past should be used is at the crux of the debate. Ian
Buruma, who has written extensively about the legacies of World War II, contends
that the quest for reparations tends to mire the petitioners in the very
victimization for which they seek payment, as well as encouraging a never-ending
flood of restitution-seekers. "If every group that feels a historical wrong
wants compensation, how far back do you go?" he asked in an interview. "It
becomes problematic."

As ethnic groups in the United States and elsewhere have assimilated, Mr. Buruma
went on, they have tended to replace their cultural identities with the residue
of past discrimination. This leads, in his view, to resentment, which undermines
the possibility of mutual understanding between groups.

"Instead of identifying as an American entitled to freedoms and rights and all
men created equal," he said of African-Americans seeking reparations, "you are
born into an aggrieved group deserving compensation. Then that's your whole
identity and you can never get out of it."

For some, the argument against reparations is simply that any kind of
compensation would be wholly inappropriate and inadequate recompense, not just
for slavery but also for the entire array of racial injustices that trailed in
slavery's wake. As the sociologist Glenn C. Loury wrote recently in The New York
Times: "Who can say what the out-of-wedlock birth rate for blacks would be,
absent chattel slavery? How does one calculate the cost of inner-city ghettos,
of poor education, of the stigma of perceived racial inferiority? The severity
of slavery's 'injury' is far more profound than any cash transfer will be able
to reverse."

But for proponents, the word reparations can cover a host of interventions, from
cash payments -- the current equivalent of, say, 40 acres and a mule -- to a
direct, official apology from the President. Some argue that affirmative action
policies already in place should be considered sufficient, though Mr. Barkan
responds that affirmative action aims at fixing present injustices rather than
compensating for past ones.

Mr. Robinson and Mr. Ogletree, among others, have suggested that reparations be
used to finance social and economic development programs for the benefit of all
black Americans. In another development, a lawyer named Deadria Farmer-Paellmann
is compiling evidence for lawsuits against a dozen companies that she says
demonstrably benefited from the slave trade. Among them are Providence Bank, a
precursor of the FleetBoston Financial Corporation, and the Aetna Insurance
Company of Hartford.

Ultimately, though, many proponents of reparations see the issue as a moral one
that cannot be dismissed because the practicalities seem byzantine at the
moment. "I think it's part of the social contract of justice in America," Mr.
Dyson said, "that if black people have done what they've done and have been
treated the way they've been treated, then they deserve what they deserve. And
we can argue about what that dessert should look like, but it ain't come yet."

WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Jeanne Moore

SECTION: Section A; Page 6; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 940 words



MIDDLE EAST

AFGHANISTAN: TALIBAN BACKTRACK ON BAKERIES -- One day after the ruling Taliban
shut down bakeries that employ widows and feed the poor, they reversed
themselves and said that all 25 could reopen and the 360 women return to work.
The Taliban, who rule roughly 90 percent of Afghanistan, espouse a harsh brand
of Islamic law and have imposed strict controls on women since capturing the
capital, Kabul, in 1996.  (AP)


IRAQ: READY FOR BUSINESS -- Baghdad's Saddam International Airport officially
reopened, 10 years after it was closed because of sanctions imposed on Iraq
following its 1990 invasion of Kuwait. But the only traffic the airport will
have for the foreseeable future is likely to be limited to the arrival of
private flights from abroad, which are not specifically banned by the embargo.

(Agence France-Presse)

EUROPE

LATVIA: DOWNTOWN BLASTS -- Two bombs exploded in a shopping center in downtown
Riga, wounding 21 people, the police said. No one claimed responsibility, but
Riga has had scores of bombings since Latvia regained independence in 1991, and
the police have attributed most to gang activity.  (AP)

BRITAIN: ROYAL PASSAGE -- Prince William, second in line to the British throne
after his father, Prince Charles, has passed his final-year exams and will be
attending St. Andrews, Scotland's oldest university. He plans to begin a
four-year degree course in art history next year, after a year off. He is
currently in Belize taking part in exercises with the Welsh Guards.  (AP)

THE AMERICAS

COLOMBIA: POLICEMEN SLAIN -- The bodies of three policemen who had been taken
prisoner by rebels 18 months ago were found with their throats slit after a
clash between the army and rebels of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia.
They were among more than 350 security force members the guerrilla group has
captured over the last two years to try to pressure the government to release
some 450 jailed rebels.  (Reuters)

MEXICO: BORDER CZAR -- President-elect Vicente Fox Quesada said that after he
takes office in December, he will appoint a "czar" to help resolve border issues
that have long strained relations between the United States and Mexico. A chief
duty, he said, would be to promote greater cooperation between local governments
on both sides of the border.  Ginger Thompson (NYT)

CANADA: BOLSTERING THE RIGHT -- The new right-wing party, the Canadian Alliance,
won another defection from its shrinking rival, the Progressive Conservative
Party, as Brian Pallister, a former Manitoba cabinet minister, left the ranks of
the old party, known as the Tories. Mr. Pallister, a former national Tory
leadership candidate, said he would run for Parliament from Manitoba in
elections expected next spring.

James Brooke (NYT)

ASIA

JAPAN: WOMEN AT THE WHEEL -- Two women have became the first female drivers of
the super-fast Shinkansen "bullet" trains. A spokesman for the JR West rail
system said Rumi Yamashita, 27, and Miyuki Fukuzawa, 29, benefited from a 1997
revision of Japan's equal opportunity law, which banned sexual discrimination in
recruiting, appointing and promoting workers.  (Agence France-Presse)

JAPAN: SUICIDE RISE -- The number of suicides hit a record 33,048 in the year
ending in March, with the nation's prolonged economic slump taking its toll, the
police said. Health problems accounted for half of all suicide cases while
economic hardship was blamed for another fifth, an 11.5 percent jump from the
previous year's survey. Ninety-two percent of the economy-related suicides
involved men, as companies abandon their tradition of employment for life.
(Agence France-Presse)

INDIA: GANDHI TOUR -- The Congress Party president, Sonia Gandhi, the
Italian-born inheritor of the Nehru-Gandhi dynasty, left, will make her first
trip abroad as leader of the opposition for a conference of presiding officers
of parliaments in New York that begins on Aug. 31. The delegation will also
include the Bharatiya Janata Party's Pramod Mahajan, the Samajwadi Party's
Mulayam Singh Yadav and the Nationalist Congress Party chief, Sharad Pawar.

Celia Dugger (NYT)

INDIA: ANTI-CHRISTIAN SUSPECT -- Police in the southern state of Karnataka said
they had arrested a junior air force officer, Syed Hasan Ur Zama, as a suspect
in the bombings of Christian churches this summer. They said Mr. Zama, a member
of a Muslim organization called Deendar Anjuman, admitted passing information
about the location of railway bridges and defense posts to Pakistan. Most
attacks on Christians have been blamed on Hindu groups.  Celia Dugger (NYT)

HONG KONG: HAVEN FOR ACTIVIST -- Hong Kong granted the right of permanent
residence to one of Beijing's most vocal critics, Frank Lu Siqing, who runs the
Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy. Mr. Lu entered Hong Kong
illegally in 1993 and started the center, which disseminates news about Chinese
dissidents, in 1996. Hong Kong residents normally can receive permanent "right
of abode" after seven years, but his illegal entry and the hostility of China,
which regained control over Hong Kong in 1997, had raised doubts about his
chances.  (AP)

AFRICA

IVORY COAST: ANTI-JUNTA PROTESTS -- Thousands of youths chanting anti-government
slogans marched through Abidjan, the commercial capital, in the first major
public protest since the military coup in December. They demanded that the junta
leader, Gen. Robert Guei, step down rather than run for president in Sept. 17
elections to restore civilian rule.

(Agence France-Presse)

                August 19, 2000, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Jeanne Moore

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 965 words



ASIA

INDONESIA: BOOST FOR MILITARY
The country's top legislative body passed a decree allowing the military to keep
its seats in the legislature until 2009, and banned retroactive prosecution of
rights cases. The new laws contradict President Abdurrahman Wahid's campaign to
remove the once-all-powerful military from politics and bring to justice members
of the security forces accused of committing abuses in strife-torn regions like
Aceh and East Timor.  (AP)


SRI LANKA: ELECTION CALLED
President Chandrika Kumaratunga dissolved Parliament six days before the end of
its six-year term and called national elections for Oct. 10. Her constitutional
plan for a quasi-federal system that would give greater autonomy to minority
Tamils is dead for now, but she has said she will revive the proposal -- an
effort to bring peace to a nation embroiled in a civil war with separatist Tamil
militants -- after the elections.  Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

PHILIPPINES: HOSTAGE RELEASE EXPECTED
Muslim separatist rebels were expected to free the rest of their hostages today
after releasing three Malaysians yesterday, said the chief government
negotiator, Roberto Aventajado. The 25 remaining captives include nine
Westerners abducted at a diving resort in Malaysia in April.  (AP)

PHILIPPINES: ENVIRONMENTAL SUIT
More than 100 people filed suit against the United States and the Philippines,
seeking $103 billion for deaths and illnesses they say were caused by hazardous
waste at former American military bases. American officials have offered to help
solve the Philippines' environmental problems, but insisted Washington has no
legal obligation to clean up toxic wastes at the former bases.  (AP)

INDIA: BARGAINING OVER ACTOR
Veerappan, the South Indian outlaw who kidnapped a movie star, had demanded that
five Tamil militants be released from jail, and the state of Tamil Nadu had
agreed. But four of the militants refused to be released on bail, insisting that
all charges against them be dropped before they are freed. Their refusal may
further delay the release of the actor, Rajkumar.  Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

AFGHANISTAN: CALL FOR RECOGNITION
The Taliban government called for international recognition as it celebrated the
country's 81st independence anniversary with a military parade featuring
thousands of soldiers. Now, only Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab
Emirates have diplomatic ties with the Islamic militia that has controlled most
of the country since 1996.  (Agence France-Presse)

EUROPE

KOSOVO: TWO EXPLOSIONS
A grenade attack slightly wounded nine Serbian children in a Kosovo village,
hours after an explosion in the province's capital, Pristina, wounded one woman
and damaged several political offices, NATO said. The children were wounded when
unidentified assailants threw two hand grenades onto a basketball court in
Crkven Vodica. The explosion in Pristina was apparently caused by a bomb.  (AP)

SWITZERLAND: VOTE ON FOREIGNERS CRITICIZED
The Swiss government spoke out against a proposal to limit the country's foreign
population, saying such a measure would damage Switzerland's economy and
credibility. Swiss citizens will vote on Sept. 24 on the proposal to cap the
proportion of foreigners at 18 percent of the population. As of last year,
foreigners made up 19.2 percent of the country's residents.  (AP)

THE AMERICAS

NICARAGUA: TAIWAN LEADER CULTIVATES TIES
The new president of Taiwan, Chen Shui-bian, concluded a visit to Nicaragua, one
of the Latin American nations that has diplomatic relations with Taiwan, with a
promise to promote investment in the Central American nation. He then flew to
Costa Rica.  (Agence France-Presse)

COLOMBIA: DRUG SUSPECT EXTRADITED
Alberto Orlandez Gamboa, accused of leading one of Colombia's most powerful drug
cartels, was sent to the United States to stand trial, days after drug dealers
threatened violence if authorities carried out the extradition. He will face
charges in United States District Court in Manhattan that he conspired to import
and distribute thousands of pounds of cocaine from Colombia to New York and
other American destinations. After a 10-year moratorium on extraditions, Mr.
Gamboa is the third Colombian sent to the United States to face drug charges in
the past nine months.  (AP)

AFRICA

ZIMBABWE: MORE FARM TAKEOVERS
The government said it would seize 229 more farms to resettle blacks, bringing
to 3,270 the number of white-owned farms involved in its controversial land
reform program. Last week the government began settling black families on 200
farms. The government plans to relocate peasants on about 100 farms in each of
Zimbabwe's eight provinces before the onset of the rainy season in about two
months' time.  (Reuters)

IVORY COAST: JUNTA LEADER TO RUN
The country's military ruler, Gen. Robert Guei, formally registered to contest a
Sept. 17 presidential election he called to return Ivory Coast to civilian rule.
General Guei came to power last December in Ivory Coast's first military coup,
and expectations of a Guei candidacy have already prompted street protests.
(Reuters)

MIDDLE EAST

IRAQ: U.N. BODY URGES END TO SANCTIONS
The United Nations Subcommission on the Promotion and Protection of Human Rights
called for the lifting of 10-year-old sanctions on Iraq, saying they had
"condemned an innocent people to hunger, disease, ignorance and even death." It
said the United Nations' oil-for-food program, which since 1996 has allowed Iraq
to sell oil to buy food and other essentials, was not meeting people's needs.
Washington opposes easing sanctions, insisting that President Saddam Hussein is
responsible for his people's suffering.  (Reuters)

                August 23, 2000, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

Effort to Recruit Minorities Falls Short in Trooper Class

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 689 words

DATELINE: TRENTON, Aug. 22


Despite a well-advertised effort to bring more blacks, women and Latinos into
the New Jersey State Police, only 15 of the 105 cadets scheduled to enter the
academy next month are black or Latino, and just one is a woman, according to
statistics released by the agency today.

Early this year, the agency settled a discrimination suit filed by the National
Association for the Advancement of Colored People by agreeing to scrap several
requirements that many black applicants considered discriminatory. The state
also pledged to make aggressive attempts to advertise and recruit in black and
Latino neighborhoods.

But in releasing the recruitment numbers today, the state police superintendent,
Carson J. Dunbar Jr., said he was disappointed that the agency's attempt to
diversify its ranks would leave the percentage of minority troopers virtually
unchanged, at 14 percent. About 3 percent of the 2,800 current troopers are
women, Mr. Dunbar said, so the new class actually represents a decrease in the
percentage of women.

Mr. Dunbar said the strong economy was partly to blame for the lackluster
results, because many female and minority applicants had found better-paying
jobs and decided not to finish the screening process.

He also acknowledged that the agency's reputation remained tarnished in many
black and Latino neighborhoods because of the Justice Department's highly
publicized investigation into discrimination by troopers and the state's
admission that some officers had engaged in racial profiling for years --
problems that preceded his appointment last year.

"I wish I could tell you there's a quick fix for this problem," said Mr. Dunbar,
who became a New Jersey trooper himself in 1973 and was the only minority
officer in his class. "The real answer is, it's going to be a long process."

He refused to specify what racial breakdown the force ultimately hopes to reach,
saying that he did not want to give the mistaken impression that the state
police were adopting a quota system. New Jersey's population is about one-third
minority, however, and in the settlement with the N.A.A.C.P. the state agreed to
try to broaden the demographics of the force.

Some elected officials said they were dismayed that the state had failed to
deliver on its promise to increase minority representation on the force.

"The state police have missed a golden opportunity to change its institutional
image," said Leroy J. Jones Jr., a Democratic assemblyman from Essex County.
"Clearly, they need to reassess their approach and re-examine who they are using
as consultants in recruiting more minorities into the ranks."

Some current troopers have also complained that the state lowered its physical
fitness requirements for new recruits, in an attempt to help female applicants.
During the last two years, the state eliminated its pull-up, broad jump and
vertical jump requirements, and applicants who fail the physical test may now
take it repeatedly until they pass.

Mr. Dunbar defended the less stringent requirements, saying they still allow the
state police to winnow out those applicants who are physically unsuited to
perform the job. The state police also worked with several consulting firms to
revise the application process and add screening that tests candidates'
temperament and decision-making abilities.

"It's not just about strength, it's about what kind of person you are," Mr.
Dunbar said.

The state police are scheduled to begin a new recruiting drive next year and
will work with the National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives and
the National Association of Women in Policing to try and expand the pool of
female and minority candidates. The state police may place more emphasis on
reaching out to women's sports teams, Mr. Dunbar said, and will continue to
recruit at schools and community events in minority neighborhoods.

But he said that his own experience in law enforcement recruiting, for both the
State Police and the F.B.I., had taught him not to expect quick results.

"It doesn't happen that rapidly," he said. "What I would like to see is steady
increases."

World Briefing

MIDDLE EAST

ISRAEL: SHAS CHIEF'S SENTENCE UPHELD -- The Supreme Court denied a request for a
new hearing on a three-year jail term for fraud, bribery and breach of trust
imposed on Aryeh Deri, former leader of the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party. It
ordered Mr. Deri to begin his sentence on Sept. 3. Mr. Deri, a charismatic
former interior minister of Moroccan descent who built Shas into a powerful
legislative bloc, was convicted of taking bribes at the Interior Ministry.
John F. Burns (NYT)


WEST BANK: BIN LADEN LINK DENIED -- The leader of the militant Islamic group
Hamas denied an assertion by Israel that a Hamas member who was among 23 Arabs
arrested on terrorism charges had been sent to Pakistan for terrorist training
with the group headed by Osama bin Laden, the Saudi-born Islamic militant.
"Hamas and I have no connection with bin Laden," Sheik Ahmed Yassin told The
Associated Press.   John F. Burns (NYT)

IRAN: DISSIDENT FREED -- A leading Iranian dissident jailed in June by the
hard-line judiciary for attending a conference in Germany about Iran has been
freed, a close associate said. Ezatollah Sahabi, a member of the Freedom
Movement, which opposes clerical rule, was released after paying $62,500 bail,
said Reza Alijani, an editor of the banned Iran-e-Farda magazine. Mr. Sahabi was
director of the magazine, one of 25 publications banned since April.   (AP)

EUROPE

GERMANY: 3 DENY INTENT TO KILL -- Three rightist youths said they did not intend
to kill Alberto Adriano, an African, when they assaulted him in June. Speaking
in court, where they have been charged with murder, they admitted attacking Mr.
Adriano and said they were drunk at the time. A murder conviction requires proof
of an intention to kill. The case has become the focus of intense interest as
Germany combats a wave of anti-immigrant violence.   Roger Cohen (NYT)

AUSTRIA: HAIDER HITS OUT -- Jorg Haider, the driving force behind Austria's
extreme right Freedom Party, said the Czech Republic and Slovenia should not be
allowed to join the European Union until they disavow decrees that led to the
expulsion of ethnic Germans after World War II. Mr. Haider, whose father was a
committed Nazi, has often said that German suffering in the war must also be
recognized.   Roger Cohen (NYT)

NORTHERN IRELAND: PROTESTANT FEUD CONTINUES -- A Protestant man was shot to
death at his home in north Belfast in what appeared to be another strike in a
feud between loyalist paramilitary groups. No group claimed immediate
responsibility. The shooting happened near where two Protestant militants were
shot dead on Monday.   (AP)

NETHERLANDS: LOCKERBIE CASE DELAYED -- The testimony of a key witness in the
Lockerbie bombing trial was delayed until Monday so the defense can ask the
Central Intelligence Agency for unedited versions of interviews with him. The
man, identified as a former Libyan spy named Abdul Majid Giaka who lives in the
United States under the witness protection program, is said to be the only
witness who can say that one of two defendants checked a bomb-laden suitcase
onto a plane in Malta in 1998.   Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

LATVIA: LANGUAGE LAW EASED -- Bowing to critics, Latvia issued slightly more
flexible rules for a law requiring use of the Latvian language in most
activities. The new rules no longer require lawyers and doctors to speak fluent
Latvian, and allow other languages to be spoken at international events.
Russian-speaking Latvians, more than a quarter of the population, largely oppose
the rules; some Europeans say the law does not meet anti-discrimination
standards for joining the European Union.   Michael Wines (NYT)

SLOVAKIA: GYPSY MOTHER SLAIN -- Just three weeks after a United Nations report
highlighted racism against Gypsies in Central and Eastern Europe, a Gypsy mother
of eight was bludgeoned to death by three men in the town of Zilina. Four
daughters of the woman, Anastazia Balazova, 49, were injured. Racial hatred and
extreme-right groups have been growing in Slovakia, and a similar situation
exists in the Czech Republic, Hungary, Romania and the Balkans.   Ladka Bauerova
(NYT)

THE AMERICAS

CANADA: CHURCH CHECKUP -- The United Church of Canada, which is being sued by
hundreds of former students of its Indian boarding schools, has decided to
submit all its ministers to mandatory police and sexual abuse registry checks
every three years. An attempt to lower the church's liability insurance rates,
the policy was adopted after lawsuits charged that sexual and physical abuse
took place at the church's schools in the 1950's and 60's.   James Brooke (NYT)

ARGENTINA: I.B.M. WARRANTS WITHDRAWN -- A judge has annulled international
arrest warrants issued in 1998 for two American executives with I.B.M. wanted
for questioning in a 1994 corruption case, court officials said. The officials
said the decision was intended to make it easier to interrogate the two, Steve
Lew and Peter Rowley, and to gather evidence for an investigation in which
investigators say some $30 million in bribes were paid in connection with a
government contract.   (Agence France-Presse)

AFRICA

CONGO: PEACE PACT SUSPENDED -- The government said it was suspending the
carrying out of a 1999 accord aimed at ending the conflict in Congo. Human
Rights Minister Leonard She Okitundu cited a substantial change in circumstances
since the signing of the pact by warring parties in 1999 in Zambia. He said
Congo wanted to hold direct talks with Rwanda, Uganda and Burundi, which all
back rebel groups that took up arms against President Laurent Kabila in August
1998.   (Reuters)

BURUNDI: BLAST KILLS 8 -- A grenade exploded in a market in central Bujumbura,
the capital, killing at least 4 people and injuring 50 others as tensions rose
ahead of a deadline for an accord to end a civil war between Hutu and minority
Tutsi that began in 1993. Tutsi militiamen are suspected of making the attack.
Neither side says it is ready to sign a pact mediated by Nelson Mandela, and
President Pierre Buyoya has asked him to postpone an Aug. 28 signing ceremony.
   (AP)

ASIA

INDIA: GANDHI TO SKIP NEW YORK -- The Congress Party president, Sonia Gandhi,
leader of the opposition in Parliament, has decided not to attend a meeting of
legislators in New York this month. Party officials say she has pressing party
business and also wants to be home when her daughter, Priyanka Vadra, gives
birth. Mrs. Vadra, who dazzled audiences when she campaigned for her mother last
year, is carrying a child that family loyalists hope will one day inherit the
Nehru-Gandhi dynasty.   Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

SECTION: Section A; Page 6; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 951 words



EUROPE

RUSSIA: TRANQUILIZER REPORTS DENIED
The mother of a sailor who died on the submarine Kursk angrily denied that
officials had tranquilized her to halt her denunciation of a Kremlin official at
a stormy meeting on the disaster. Videotape showed that Nadya Tylik collapsed in
mid-tirade after being injected during a confrontation with Deputy Prime
Minister Ilya Klebanov. But Ms. Tylik said her husband had asked a doctor for
the injection because he feared the confrontation would worsen a heart ailment.
Contrary suggestions in the Western press, she said, were "lots of lies."
Michael Wines (NYT)


TURKEY: 7 ACCUSED IN BOMBING PLAN
Seven people suspected of belonging to a guerrilla group were arrested and
accused of planning a bomb attack on the Incirlik air base in Turkey, from which
American and British planes carry out patrols over the no-flight zones in Iraq.
No details of the plot or the arrests were announced. The police also said a
member of the group, the Revolutionary Peoples' Liberation Army-Front, was
arrested in Istanbul in possession of explosives, hand grenades and a gun.
Douglas Frantz (NYT)

BRITAIN: JOINING INTERNATIONAL COURT
The government said it would publish legislation enabling Britain to join an
international criminal court that would try suspects on charges of war crimes,
genocide and crimes against humanity. So far 15 countries have passed such laws;
60 must do so before the court can come into existence. The United States
opposes the court, saying it would make American soldiers vulnerable to
politically motivated prosecutions abroad.  Sarah Lyall (NYT)

YUGOSLAVIA: MILOSEVIC WIFE IS CANDIDATE
Mirjana Markovic, the influential wife of President Slobodan Milosevic, will run
for election in the Sept. 24 voting for the federal Parliament. Ms. Markovic,
leader of the neo-Communist Yugoslav Left Party, heads a list of candidates from
Pozarevac, the couple's hometown in central Serbia. The English-language
newsletter VIP said it was the first time Ms. Markovic had run for Parliament
since her husband rose to power in the late 1980's.(Reuters)

THE AMERICAS

CANADA: PREMIER DERIDES POLLS
Prime Minister Jean Chretien, in power since 1993, has dismissed polling trends
that show his Liberal Party slumping and the opposition Canadian Alliance
rising. "We will win the next election because we have a huge majority over
everybody else," he said. Mr. Chretien, who has vowed to seek a third term in
elections that are to be held by next June, told reporters he was not bothered
by an Angus Reid poll that showed Liberal support falling to 43 percent of
respondents and Alliance support rising to 25 percent.  James Brooke (NYT)

PERU, JORDAN: ARMS RUNNING DENIED
Jordan angrily denied accusations by President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru that
top Jordanian commanders were involved in the trafficking of thousands of
Russian assault rifles through Peru to Colombian guerrillas. Foreign Minister
Abdelelah al-Jatib said Jordan and Peru were involved in legal arms sales, and
that corrupt Peruvian officials "are not capable of controlling the activities
of traffickers in their own country." Clifford Krauss (NYT)

Discrimination by the Scouts

SECTION: Section 4; Page 10; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 405 words


The Boy Scouts of America turned to the United States Supreme Court earlier this
year to protect its constitutional right, under the freedom of association, to
exclude gays from its membership. The Boy Scouts asserted that barring gays was
fundamental to its mission. But now, as local governments, corporations and
individuals across the country withdraw their support from the Boy Scouts in
response to this exclusionary policy, it is obviously time for the organization
to reconsider its stance.  The Girl Scouts of the U.S.A., it is worth noting,
does not discriminate against gays.

The swift reaction of public authorities to the Scouts' defense of its right to
discriminate has been heartening. Prodded by local anti-discrimination laws,
Chicago, San Francisco and many smaller communities have revoked the Boy Scouts'
access to public facilities such as schools and campgrounds. This is especially
appropriate where such access was granted on preferential terms. In San Diego,
for instance, the American Civil Liberties Union is right to challenge the city
for leasing 18 acres of parkland to the Scouts for one dollar a year.  Despite
the Boy Scouts' laudable role in the lives of millions of boys for almost a
century, taxpayers cannot be in a position of bankrolling its activities so long
as gays are excluded.

The negative responses to the Boy Scouts' position are not yet a widespread,
grass-roots movement, as evidenced by the Scouts' growing membership. But the
organization is losing some significant and high-profile financial backing.
Donors as varied as Chase Manhattan Bank and some United Way chapters have
exercised their own freedom of association by ceasing to support the Scouts.

Withholding support cannot be an easy decision. But the organization needs to
realize that a growing number of donors will question its claim to belong on the
center stage of American life if it continues asserting a discriminatory
philosophy. In today's world, children cannot learn about honor from an
organization that views homosexuality as a moral defect.

In some areas, parents and local council leaders are mobilizing to change the
national leadership's policy banning homosexuals. There is much to be admired
about the Boy Scouts tradition and much that is worth preserving. But the
extended Boy Scout family needs to save the organization from its present
self-destructive and discriminatory course.

Guerrilla Attacks Raise Worries in Central Asia

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ

SECTION: Section A; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1021 words

DATELINE: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, Sept. 2


Deadly clashes between guerrillas and the armies of two former Soviet republics
in Central Asia last month are deepening concerns that an effort is under way to
destabilize the region.

Guerrillas operating from bases in Tajikistan staged several incursions into a
remote mountainous region bordering Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan. Unconfirmed
government reports said dozens of rebels and at least 30 soldiers from the two
countries had been killed in the battles.

The Uzbek government says the attacks are organized by the Islamic Movement of
Uzbekistan, which it says infiltrated the Fergana Valley from Tajikistan and
Afghanistan.

The death toll remains low, and fighting has been sporadic. But the attacks have
been more frequent than in the past, and government officials and Western
diplomats said the rebels were better trained and equipped, with antiaircraft
weapons, night-vision equipment and sniper rifles.

The presidents of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan met on Aug.
20 and issued a statement vowing that "terrorist actions will be crushed using
the most decisive measures." President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan has
asked for broad new powers to curb religious extremists.

The Uzbek government said that the guerrillas included fighters from other
countries in addition to Tajikistan and Afghanistan and that they had modern
arms and communication equipment as well as good financing.

The evidence is strong that the insurgents are Islamic militants trained and
armed in Afghanistan, say Kazakh officials and Western diplomats. Some officials
said the rebels wanted to create havoc to keep borders open for the heroin flow,
which the authorities said was increasing sharply. Other officials speculated
that the intent was to spread Islamic fundamentalism.

Whatever the goals, the violence has clearly reached a new stage. Fighting this
summer rose significantly beyond the bombings in the Uzbek capital, Tashkent, in
February 1999 and the single incident last summer in which Islamic rebels held
several hostages in Kyrgyzstan.

Military officials in Kyrgyzstan said on Sept. 5 that the armed forces had
bombed suspected rebel hideouts after hundreds of insurgents had crossed into
that country from Tajikistan, according to news agencies. Officials said more
than 7,000 government troops had been mobilized to counter a force of about 700
rebels in the mountainous region.

Jerzy Wieclaw, head of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe's
office in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, said rebels had used antiaircraft guns and
possibly helicopters. He also said they were demonstrating new strength to an
impoverished population potentially ripe for change.

"These countries can cope with the threat now, but it seems to be a long-term
strategy to find military and political weak points," Mr. Wieclaw said.

Uncertainties remain about whether the fighting last month was the extent of the
rebels' abilities or a precursor to attacks intended to plunge the region into
greater instability.

"The question is whether this is what everybody has been fearing," Martha Brill
Olcott, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in
Washington, said in a telephone interview.

For years the leaders of many of the former Soviet republics have justified
harsh steps against political opponents by arguing that they are necessary to
keep terrorism at bay. The presidents are certain to emphasize the security
threat during previously scheduled meetings at the United Nations during the
gathering of worlld leaders there.

The first substantial battle was reported in early August. Government officials
in Uzbekistan said guerrillas from Tajikistan had clashed with troops, leaving
20 rebels and 12 soldiers dead. On Aug. 11 officials in Kyrgyzstan said 100
militants had entered the country and engaged in a pitched battle with
government troops. Unconfirmed reports said 20 soldiers and 50 rebels had been
killed.

Since then there have been sporadic clashes, including intelligence reports that
rebel snipers have used advanced rifles and night-vision equipment for attacks.

Kazakhstan joined its neighbors in sending military reinforcements to the
borders in the region, and Uzbekistan threatened to chase the rebels wherever
they went, an action that could create a new set of tensions if Uzbek troops
cross into Tajikistan.

Some diplomats worry that the threat will be used by the governments as a cover
for getting tougher on internal dissent in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and
Uzbekistan, where human rights groups already complain that political freedom is
suppressed.

Benita Ferrero-Waldner, chairwoman of the European security organization,
praised the cooperation among the Central Asian nations against terrorism but
cautioned them to avoid civilian casualties and repression. Democratic and
economic reforms, she said in a statement issued in Vienna, are the best means
of ensuring that terrorists do not find the support needed to expand the
fighting.

Even before the latest attacks, the presidents of all three countries
centralized authority and limited political expression in the name of fighting
terrorism and drug trafficking, though the degrees vary from country to country.

The attacks have caused geopolitical complications outside the region. The head
of Russia's security council attended the meeting of the region's presidents in
August and offered Russian troops, who are already battling rebels in Chechnya,
as reinforcements. The Chinese, concerned about separatists in Muslim-inhabited
areas of western China, have also pledged cooperation.

But the Central Asian leaders, struggling to establish independent identities
after decades of Soviet domination, seemed in no hurry to duck under a Russian
military umbrella or embrace Chinese security assistance.

In the long run, Mr. Wieclaw and other diplomats predicted, the outcome of the
war may be decided not by military power, but by how much backing the insurgents
find in the countryside, where unemployment and disenchantment with government
are running high.

Modern-Day Slavery

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 607 words


By a conservative estimate, there are 27 million people working under various
forms of slavery in the world today, and the number is growing. In contrast to
the slavery America knew, today's slaveholders mainly exploit people of their
own race. But as in the American past, they use violence and threats to force
people to labor for no pay. Slavery is illegal everywhere, but it thrives
because of the corruption of police and government authorities. Many people are
unaware that modern slavery exists.

People held in some form of bondage pick sugar cane in the Dominican Republic,
make the charcoal used in Brazil's steel industry and work as prostitutes in
Thailand. In Mauritania and Sudan blacks are forced into domestic and
agricultural slavery in Muslim households. Similar forms of oppression are not
unknown in developed nations. The Central Intelligence Agency estimates that
45,000 women and children are smuggled into the United States each year with
false promises of decent jobs. Instead, most find that their passports are
stolen and they are forced to work as prostitutes or maids, on farms or in
sweatshops.

But the majority of people who are treated like slaves, perhaps 20 million,
according to the United Nations, are South Asians in debt bondage. The system is
chillingly described in "Disposable People," a survey of contemporary forms of
slavery by Kevin Bales, who teaches at the University of Surrey in England.
Whole families, including children, are trapped into peonage to pay debts
incurred by medical expenses, a funeral or crop failure. Their debts are
inflated by outrageous prices for food and usurious interest rates. Families can
essentially be enslaved for generations.

Slavery and related kinds of servitude are a growing business because the number
of desperately poor people is increasing and globalization has disrupted rural
communities. In many nations, children, mainly girls, must drop out of school to
work. A girl in a northern Thai village can be sold into prostitution for $2,000
-- a huge sum there. A Thai survey found that many families knowingly sold
daughters into prostitution because they felt pressure to buy consumer goods
such as televisions. Girls stay until they contract AIDS, and are then sent back
to their villages to die in disgrace.

While slavery is illegal, it is hard to eradicate.  Even the United States lacks
adequate criminal penalties for those who traffic in human beings.  Moreover,
the victims -- the potential witnesses -- are usually deported. This may change,
however, as both houses of Congress recently passed a bill that would
criminalize trafficking, end the rapid deportation of victims and provide help
for them here and modest programs to prevent slavery abroad.

Slavery and forced labor are even more difficult to fight in nations where they
draw support from traditional structures of power and corruption, the
devaluation of women and, in India, the caste system. Educating the poor about
how to avoid falling victim helps, as do small loans and skill training. India
has an excellent program to pay off laborers' debts and give them training and
land.  But Dr. Bales argues that local officials and judges often sabotage it.

The first step in combating modern variations of slavery, however, is education.
The developed world needs to realize that slavery exists, and that its victims
may have helped produce the clothes, rugs and other goods we buy. It is
especially important for people in nations where it is widespread not to accept
it as a traditional practice but to see it as one of the most serious abuses of
human rights.
